comment: Weekly homework that is writing heavy. The class teaches a mindset, which you will take with you, and truly embracing this mindset makes the completion of the exams and homework significantly easier. The recitations, while optional, are very enjoyable. Very open during office hours where very enjoyable conversations can be had.

Rizzo is a cool guy. Fun lectures and is truly interested in making you love learning. Be curious and attend lectures or else this class will be a living nightmare. Some of the homeworks are kinda redundant but overall a great class to take.

Everyone says that Rizzo is a nutcase, and they're probably right, but his class was fun and although there was a lot of complaining, the workload wasn't that bad. TAs grade all your assignments and you can use ChatGPT on everything, even tests, but don't let that fool you into thinking its an easy A. Overall pretty good class would take again.

Took this class out of pure curiosity. It's definitely a hard class, and the way to a good understanding of the material is murky at best (hence the low rating, this class should be made more accessible), but it's fun if you appreciate learning that's more than rote memorization.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Worst unorganized lectures I have ever attended. A 5 year old with a lisp could teach economics better. The tests seem to consist of his diary entries and are graded harshly. First two were open note probably because he knows none of his teachings make any sense. Very subjective questions, none of the tests are multiple choice. So much homework.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment:
Only take this class if ALL of the following is true:

1. You're a good test taker. Tests are nightmarish: ten short essays with convoluted prompts. NO NOTES OR CHATGPT.

2. A philosophical approach works for you, and you can teach yourself math. 

3. An interesting class is more important to you than your final grade.

One of the best professors I have ever had. Would definitely take a class with him again if I had the opportunity to do so. His style of teaching a little different, but if you get used to it, there's no class more fun and interesting than Econ 108 with Rizzo
Good man good lecture

never ever take this professor, his lecture makes no sense, and never teach you what is economic, instead he just be yapping about why his wife left him and other nonsense. The test is useless,  three hour long, and ten short essays, what people do is just copy from chatgpt
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: He's big on yapping and you'll never know what he's trying to teach you. It's obvious he knows a lot about economics but he's bad at teaching the concepts without talking about his ex wife or kids (specifically his daughter). No one scores well on the tests and they are not curved. I have to take him again but would prefer not to.

Honestly one of the most fun classes you can take at this school. There are no exams, simply two projects during the semester, with at least one being a group project, and some weekly homework. It's a chill class where you can just come to listen about sports economics or you can choose to engage in the discussion. Would recommend it to anyone.

I received a higher grade in 207 but I enjoyed 108 more. Rizzo's 207 is not math-based and sometimes the exam rubrics can be controversial. He is less organized than other instructors. Besides the class, he is a great friend and we had serval in-depth conversations.

The approach of his ECON 108 is a little bit different and more towards humanity, which can create good insights. It is a lecture-oriented class so understanding his stories in class is important. It is easy for me to see the connections between his homework and lectures but I understand that others might not feel this way.
Rizzo's class can be challenging, but it's worth the effort. The lectures are engaging, and you'll learn a lot about economic principles. Unstuckstudy AI and the free textbook are great study aids.
There is a lot of homework, and the lessons are not related to the homework.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Test heavy

comment: I had no idea what he was talking about in his class, it felt like he was giving assignments that didn't have a single thing to do with the content of the class, that you had to write a lot every week in order to complete the assignments, and that you weren't going to get a good grade, even if you had the finances to do so
I love Prof. Rizzo! I chose to major in  Economics because of him. I'm a huge fan.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I enjoyed Rizzo a lot for 108. He goes downhill for 207. It does not feel like a real micro class at all. A lot of the things he chooses to cover in the course are based on what he likes to teach, NOT what is important for us to know. He stays away from the math which makes future classes difficult. Definitely not meant to teach a complex econ.

Rizzo is an extremely misunderstood professor by students. I know a lot of the other reviews say to not listen to the reviews like mine, but I think that his class was great. Somewhat difficult but great. You learn a lot in his class. Overall, it teaches you how to be a better student. The microeconomic topics are explained well and in a fun format

Rizzo is def one of the professors that you either love or hate. I personally enjoyed his lectures a lot, as they are more casual and conversational. He is also VERY knowledgable. However, his homework are extremely stressful, so be prepared to spend 5 hours each week for this weekly research writings. He also yaps too much on HW/exam questions.

Professor Rizzo is a amazing lecturer. He can make something as boring as CPI interesting. He truly cares for his students and only has the best intentions. He is a professor you will not regret taking. Just make sure to ask for help. This is what your TAs and office hours are for! It is an extremely rewarding class if you try. Thank you Rizzo!

Rizzo gets so much hate for his storytelling lecture style and his grading scale, but he is one of the best professor's at the University of Rochester. He is caring, knowledgeable, and always willing to help his students. Please get to know him! I took 108 and 207 with Rizzo and I have learned so much. Don't listen to others, take the class!
tough grader!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Very stressful.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Probably the most fun class I have taken so far. It is hard, but you really learn a lot and lectures are super entertaining. It is a lot of work but 100% worth taking the class over the other 108 option.

Love the guy. He's definitely better and more interesting when it comes to elective courses (sports econ, environmental) so take those with him for sure. I always learn something new and worthwhile during class.

Ignore all positive reviews, they are written by sycophants. Lots of homework(4-6 hours a week) and tests with unclear questions that are also a large percentage of your grade. I'm taking 207 with him and have noticed a large drop in quality recently(talks about taking his own life constantly!). Can't recommend him to anyone majoring in economics.

Guys. Do not look at the rate, it is not accurate. I just calculated the weighted average. The result is 789/216 which is approximately 3.65. NOT 5.0. Again, !!!!! HIS SCORE IS 3.65 NOT 5.0!!!! Do NOT take this class with him!!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Theory of econ rather than an intro econ course. More about the principle of econ, applying it to different scenarios and learning how to think like an economist. 2 hws a week and can be difficult if you don't understand how Rizzo works. If you like straightforward classes with textbook-based information and tests then this is not the class for you

He is a great professor, very engaging and never a dull moment. But, tests were confusing and graded weirdly imo. Homework heavy, around 5-7 hours of homework every week. But I really learned a lot from his class and would like to take another course with him. He is genuinely one of the only professors that I learned life long lessons from.

Could not tell the difference between his rambles vs actual course material, he lectures in a very strange way and is all over the place. Exam questions are hard to nail, reviewing the answers afterward was very frustrating bc you would never have guessed that's what he wanted out of it.

Lectures are entertaining, he mostly tells stories. But the stories are confusing and it is hard to extract the intended meaning from them. Lots of homework, usually unrelated to lecture material. His tests are totally bizarre. Grading feels unfair. Rizzo is a great guy, but I can't recommend his class.

It is not like AP econ. You will see supply & demand curves 2.5 weeks before the final. This class is a grade wrecker. He grades in a very specific manner and makes it extremely hard to get anything above an A-, yet complains that many students are dropping his classes due to the harsh grading scale. Take 108 with another professor.

This is a very bizarre class. He is concerned with teaching how to "think economically" but what you get is very vague and bizarre examples and anecdotes that try to make a point, but they are difficult to understand and don't work well. In the end, I didn't end up knowing much about priniciples of economics or "economical thinking".

Rizzo is a great lecturer and a really nice guy, but if you want to get an A I wouldn't take him. The ideas of the class are vague sometimes and TA grading can be extremely frustrating. There is also a lot of homework. Basically if you are fine with not getting an A and doing a lot of homework, econ 108 with Rizzo is very enjoyable.

biggest yapper i have ever met. obviously misses his ex wife based on the number of times he brought her up. just a dude who loves yappin and yappin. All the info you need is in the slides during his lectures but he forgets to go through them because he gets carried away talking about his ex wife.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: He does not teach economics, he teaches what I like to call "Rizzonomics" which is basically his views of the world. He's clearly hardcore libertarian. Exam questions make no sense, he just wants you to write down his views for the answers. 2 writing papers a week for HW! He talks a lot about his divorce. He's Unhinged. I'm taking 207 with Ashby
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: You either love him or hate him. Rizzo's such a unique character, his lectures are something you will never get to experience anywhere else. Be sure to attend his lectures, everything on the test will be from lecture or somewhat related to them (there are recordings but they're from fall 2022). No slides, just take good detailed notes. great prof.

Amazing professor and wonderful lectures! I learned so much from his class and would seriously recommend. Go to study groups and office hours. Attendance is not mandatory, but you will not do well if you do not go to lectures. Try and start weekly assignments early in the week as they are long and tedious. Tests are open note and internet.

Truly one of the best professors I have had. The lectures are engaging and completely changed how I see the world. Class is lots of work (I would often be writing 15-20 pages weekly), but if you put in the effort, I promise that you will leave a better student and person. Strongly believe that everyone should take at least one class with Rizzo.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Very tough class, but so rewarding if done right aka put in the work! The way he asks questions is VERY similar to a certain liberal arts interdisciplinary competition which is particularly popular among intl HS students (not going to specify, but iykyk). Its helpful to have prior econ knowledge. In exams, think like him. Go to study groups!!

Lectures hardly cover economics and are mainly him venting his opinions. Same thing with his exams. The only good thing about this course is that the homework is actually doable assignments and can save your grade from his terrible exams.

Rizzo's class has way too much homework for no reason. Also, he grades extremely precisely. If you get an 89.999999%, it doesn't get rounded up. It would be a B+. His exams aren't economic based it's basically just what he thinks. The tests are also graded on "vibes" -an actual quote from a TA.

Professor Rizzo is by far the most approachable professor on campus and has the most passion for economics I have ever seen by someone else. His exams are difficult, but possible to do well on as long as you go to lecture and make use of office hours/TAs. Overall, I'd be excited to take another course by him and hope more people do.

Everyone loves or hates him. I personally hate him. He does not teach, people will literally show up to class because its entertaining. I think he talks about him divorce more than he does economics. The tests also make no sense don't take this class.
Take Ashby's class if you care about your GPA, not GPB, GPC, or even GPD.
Take Ashby's Class if you care about your GPA
I wish I could understand half of what he spews.
GPA Destroyer

As a freshman, I found his class to be very intimidating and dropped out of it immediately. Professor Rizzo is very passionate about economics and is a funny and eccentric lecturer, but the downside is that his class is very disorganized, which is terrifying when there are so many readings and assignments. His ECON 108 could destroy your GPA.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Hilarious

comment: Go to class if you want to do well in Rizzo's class. You either love him or you hate him, but he grades very fair and most of the tests are open book and you are allowed to use the internet. Personally, I love rizzo and the style of the lectures but it's not for everyone.
Will give extra credit and drops lowest exam grade as well as adds 8 points to overall exam grades. Must go to lectures to understand material. Open note tests

Most entertaining yet informative professor I've ever had. Course consisted of weekly assignments that took 1-3 hours each (best to work as a group) and 4 exams that made 60% of your grade. You HAVE to show up to lectures otherwise the class won't be easy at all. He dropped an exam plus 8% grade boost so it's pretty easy to get an A.

His lectures got me interested in Econ. He puts all the concepts behind a story so it may be hard to decipher at first but once I did, I felt like I had a stronger understanding than if he just delivered dry lectures. Super funny, and watch out for the money he gives away on the first lecture...

It is a harder class as it's very non-traditional, but I think it's best to try and pick out the economics behind his stories. He talks super fast so it's kinda hard so just literally write down everything, then after class look it over.

The Econ concepts in this class are easy, but he like to teach them in a tough way. Tons of information in the lecture and the workload for homework is heavy, and he seldom give study guide for exams. The lecture is fun though.
Really fun class
Money wasted if you don't take his class

there is tons of hw, research assignments every week. if you want to pass go to lectures. alot of extra credit opportunities. he teaches through stories which can be nice but i don't learn that way. it is hard to tell if he is telling a story or if hes teaching econ. exam questions are weird too. ta grade everything. workshops are not mandatory
Be ready to listen in lectures and be entertained while understanding the principals of Econ 108.

Amazing lecturer, but tons of work. Lectures are extremely entertaining and easy to follow. They made me excited for economics. Weekly homework can take up 5-8 hours, writing intensive (1-2k words), and disconnected from class material imo. Can't really study for the exams, final was open book, mostly test on your thinking skills.

Professor Rizzo is a nice guy and his lectures are entertaining however I would strongly recommend against taking this class with him. There is a ton of HW each week and the grading is arbitrary. Also, nothing you learn in this class will help you with future econ classes. Take another professor for 108.

If you want direct, clear lectures, don't take Rizzo. Classes are more of an econ approach to philosophy. I learned a lot, but it's not your traditional econ class. Focus hard in lectures bc he covers like 20 topics in one class. A TON of hw and writing. You can't really study for the exams; questions are random and confusing and you j gotta pray.

Everyone complains about how difficult the class is because of his rambling. This is simply because they are unable to focus on his actual points. After a few classes, you will understand that his ranting and storytelling have a purpose and are metaphors for his most important points. Rizzo is definitely untraditional but is a great lecturer.

His lectures are funny, engaging and informative. You do have to be paying attention because he rambles/rants so make sure you don't space out. You can text him, call him, or email him with any questions. The exam questions are somewhat difficult because they are broad and sometimes confusing. Short research and ruminations due every Sunday.

Not for the faint of heart, but provides a different and interesting take that is a good introduction to economics without tons of math. Lots of writing and homework. 

Again - not for the faint of heart. If this is not one of your central classes you will not do well.

The correct way to learn economic is to learn the use of mathematics, graph and analysis to solve economic problems. Of course, critical thinking is important but will not simply improved by just learning some of your personal stories. If you are too free in college and want to waste your time writing, then go take it!
As I receive more comments/rates from students, I will keep updating the correct average score.

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Be very careful students! The rate my professor system provided a wrong score for Michael Rizzo

Based on Michael Rizzo's current rating from 174+1 rates, the frequencies are below:

90 chose a 5
22 chose a 4
23 chose a 3
9 chose a 2
31 chose a 1 (Including this one)

Therefore, the average is a 3.754 (out of 5)
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

For the student commented below who is trying to tell others to "try it out!". This is definitely a joke. Do you mind sharing your final grades to all other students? Did you got A? How long did you spend in this class? There are tons of things to do in college, why would you like to waste time in his econ class?

Why spend time writing all different papers? Why wasting your time talking to him to get your participation grades? Your future economic courses won't be like that! This guy solely teaches things based on his own opinions and let you waste your time to do all the work. It does not help your to learn economic and will drag down GPA significantly

He just rambles. It's either you're on the same page as him or you're screwed for the exams. He just rambles and sometimes you have no idea what he's even talking about. Outside of class, he's the best!

I missed professor Landsburg. Landsburg is so amazing. It is a pleasure and my fortunate not taking ECO 108 and 207 with Rizzo. I took it with Landsburg and got A in both 108 and 207. If I take it with Rizzo, I would have failed the two classes. Thanks God!

Make sure you read to syllabus cause there are extra credit opportunities that can be vital to getting an A. Going to lectures is important. Watching recorded lectures is difficult as you lose focus etc. Make sure you go to recitation as it can be helpful and you can get extra credit. A lot of homework every week
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Hilarious--Accessible outside class

comment: I loved Professor Rizzo! Although more often than frequently, he goes off on mini tangents about things that have no relation to economics. It can definitely be a little annoying since the class itself isn't very long. Also, it was very unclear exactly what to study for the exams which made things more difficult. Gives plenty of extra credit opps!

Professor Rizzo is an amazing guy, he really is. Get prepared to write for this class, like a lot. GO TO LECTURES! That is the best way to do well on exams, the zooms don't do the ambiance of the class justice. This class is more critical thinking based, don't listen to your friends just b/c they didnt like his teaching style. Try it out.

If you do the work you will do fine in any of his classes. Try to get the big concepts, not the small things. Really good professor with amazing lectures, and is always willing to help anyone who asks.
He is going way too fast with his lecture, and the amount of homework is demanding.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Lectures are awesome and he keeps you engaged with him the whole time. However the vast majority of what he says and goes off about in class won't be used on his exams. The central point of his lectures is all that matters. Exams are graded tough. If he gives you the option to flip the weights of your homework and exams, take advantage.

207 with Rizzo is a must. You could replace 2 exams by doing a group project with an entrepreneur where you talk abt econ in their business. You learn so much from the real world experience and it is such a valuable experience. Put in the work and you will do just fine. Most exams were take home - he wants you to do well and is very accessible.

While the class isn't taught like a beginners econ course, the insights Prof. Rizzo presented were far more helpful than a regurgitation of AP Econ. Exams can be hard and the material confusing at times, but once it clicks you gain a whole new view of the topic. Don't fall for low ratings from students hurt by a low grade and don't miss lecture.

I won't agree with the student commented below. Of course, economics is not math and we do need to learn core concepts from economists. Nevertheless, conclusion should be made based on evidence. Math helps you to make a conclusion in Econ. So I believe taking Econ class that focus on math is important. Specifically, take ECON with landsburg.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Best prof. His class is the best class I took in my life. BUT he has a very unique teaching style which might not fit everyone. If you want math based econ, this ISN'T the prof you want. If you want to think like a real economist and understand that economics is so much more than just math, TAKE HIM. Be open to his unconventional teaching style.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: This guy's teaching is unlike anything I've experienced before. He talks about economic concepts very broadly and most of the first half of the class is simply learning how to think about the world more analytically... not so simple for me. There's not that much work, but if you don't get it you don't get it. Good guy but not my cup of tea.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: before you read any other review-know that this professor is the difference between taking a course to regurgitate textbook material and evolving and changing the way you view the world. rizzo is an incredibly hard professor; all of his lectures revolve around stories and concepts-yet i promise he will force you to learn the absolute most from him.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Rizzo's lectures are entertaining and engaging, but don't teach you any economics until the last third of the course. There is homework every week that takes several hours, none of which is really relevant to the exams. And the exams are incredibly difficult and your grade will drop unless you write exactly what he wants to hear.
This is a terrible class I've ever had. I dropped it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: I got an A for ECO207, and fortunately, I did not take it with Rizzo. His ECON207 is extremely tough, with lots of writing and the tests are extremely hard. A lot of my friends are struggle on Rizzo's class. What he teaches are purely his opinion which is useless. My friends got B with Rizzo and I got A with Landsburg. Take 207 with someone else
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--So many papers

comment: It is essential you get basically perfect scores on all the homework assignments. He basically randomly picks 5 homework assignments to count as your entire homework grade (which can range to be 75% of your entire grade). Pray that he doesn't randomly select 5 of your lowest homework grades to count as your entire homework grade.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: One of the worst teachers I've ever had. You don't actually learn anything in the class, except the "economic way of thinking." If anything, this class should be a writing 105 class with a focus on economics. The homework he provides can be too much. The exams are impossible to get an A through legitimate means.

Worst class I've taken in my three years here. Lots of homework and reading all of which is irrelevant to the exams. Still not sure what this class was about, it certainly didn't teach me any economics or how to think as some would boldly presume. Take it with Landsburg as he actual gives you the econ fundamentals and knowledge for future studies.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: I got an A for ECO 108, and I took it with Landsburg. I believe that I will get an A for ECO207 (Await Final Grade), and I took it with Landsburg as well. I spent on avg 1 hour on homework and review each week in Landsburg's class, and my friend spend 4 hours for every assignment in Rizzo's class. I got A, and they got B. This is the difference!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--So many papers

comment: Overall a good professor. Lots of homework, but he was funny and made economics easy to learn and enjoyable. Would take this class again.

Professor Rizzo is definitely a GOOD econ teacher and lecturer. If you really wanna major in econ, take his class. There will be lots of reading and assignments (2 papers per week but if you really focus on it, you will learn a lot.) Try to understand his lectures, the EWOT is the most important thing you can learn in Rochester, and only with Rizzo
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Anyone that leaves a bad review on Rizzo is someone who is completely unwilling to have their opinion challenged. It is a shame someone would spend $70,000 of tuition only to attend classes of professors that only voice their opinion. Also anyone that doesn't like Rizzo isnt willing to put the work in and pay attention. If your lazy don't take this
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Lecture heavy

comment: Rizzo is one of the best professors I have ever had! Everyone complains about him because he ACTUALLY encourages people to argue and delve deeper into the politics in todays atmosphere. I think everyone should take a Rizzo class at least once in their life. He is a phenomenal teacher. He has taught me a whole new way of looking at life!

A joke of an econ class. Guy is so full of himself and unless you write what he wants on exams you're gonna do terribly. 1 research paper due every week, exams are fully written and are more like puzzles than questions. You will leave with zero economics learned and will struggle to keep up in future classes because of it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--So many papers

comment: This entire class is just him telling stories about his life. His exams are 3 hour essays that have you analyze poems. You learn almost no econ in this class so you will fail almost every econ class after this. Take it with landsberg so you're not behind for the rest of college
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--So many papers

comment: I have never hated a professor more in my entire life. This man can not teach, so don't bother. He talks about the course content maybe 10% and then just rants about whatever he wants for the rest. However, you'll still need to know that 10% for his ridiculously long assignments. Would not recommend this class or this professor to anyone.

His mid term exam is just like three hours. Analyzing poetry? What is this? A Literature class? A writing class? NO. It is a useless class. He just makes economics so hard and not really economics... I have no idea why those work in his class is useful. Definitely not a good instructor

Get ready to write your research papers everyday! I have no idea why his rating is so high. He is the worse professor in ECON 108, and everything learned in this class is not economics, it's rizzonomics. Take ECON108 in Spring and ECON 207 in fall with professor landsburg, it will make your life better and you will learn real Economics. NO RIZZO!!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--So many papers

comment: Rizzo is the best professor ever. If you come to U of rochester and do not attend Rizzo's lectures, then your tuition is wasted.

He is honestly one of the most interesting professors I have ever taken but the class was really difficult because he teaches in stories and you have to work to connect it to econ. Honestly, if you can work for it it's not bad. Cannot slack or miss classes though.
Terrible class. I dropped it.

Probably the easiest econ class offered at U of R; Rizzo admits it himself that the class is "a gut." Really interesting topics and very intuitive thinking course, very little memorizing or work required. Grading is just homeworks and a couple of projects that are tedious but not a lot of work. Recommend it for everyone!

You won't learn textbook econ in his classes, you'll learn how to think and to be critical about the things you read and hear about. although he tends to go off topic at times, every story a lesson and WILL show up on the exams. the key is to try to understand the point of the convoluted discussions. assignments & exams require 8hrs of sleep.

Key is paying attention in class to everything- esp the convoluted stories. He usually summarizes his concepts after he describes them, note those down, he expects exact same words on the exams. If you do that its most of the work. His lectures are unconventional, challenges you to think out of the box. Exams are challenging too. Little quant work.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor rizzo is the best econ teacher at the U of R. He actually talks about the issues that are important and doesnt just sound like a robot that is regurgitating a textbook. He makes you actually want to come to class because you know you will learn something new
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Funny guy, great lectures. I got more than 100% in both his classes due to extra credit ops. That being said, his classes are light on actual economic material, although he does a great job of introducing couple of critical concepts. Half of the classes is just his opinion, not based on any economics or statistical facts.
Rizzo is generally a good person. He gave lots of good examples in class, but the test and homework are tough. Also, TAs grade everything and there is no regrade.

Rizzo is a revolutionary icon at U of R. His teaching of economics is not traditional; it makes you think more than memorize. It's a really fun class but the tests are pretty tough. If you go to class and absorb his lectures, not only listen but understand, you'll do fine in the class. Minimum effort earns you a B, anything more will move you up

Would highly recommend. Rizzo is incredibly passionate & knowledgable about his subject. While at times we might be "off topic", he lets students ask about and explore what they are interested in, which made the class much more engaging and relevant to the students. If you're considering taking a class with him, absolutely do.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: Great man. I did not know an ounce of econ, I learned so much from him, although I couldn't tell you anything I learned. He loves to have conversations with students, so if you talk to him outside of class he will love you. His off topic lectures are always very interesting and funny. Highly reccomend. The homework is a lot, do it with your group.

Tough grading (TAs grade everything) with a lot of weekly homework. Class is lecture based (attendance is optional, but you won't pass if you do not attend lectures). He has an unique style with good points, but exams often do not reflect class material. All in all, he teaches critical thinking and problem solving rather than actual economics.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Prof Rizzo is easily the most unique professor I have ever had. He is definitely a tough grader but I enjoyed every minute of the three classes I took with him. He is very funny and makes class so enjoyable. He taught me how to view the world in a different way - a very unique thinker. His concepts can be confusing but overall very good professor.

Rizzo is awesome! I took AP Econ in high school, and I must say that Rizzo makes economics so much more applicable to real life than a heavy analysis of graphs. His energetic, hilarious personality turns otherwise "meh" material into engaging content and homework that encourage you to pose questions about real life you never thought about before.
Really funny, can be hard to understand, abstract teaching style. Lectures not technically required but if you don't go nothing will make sense
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Lecture heavy

comment: Rizzo is chaotic good. The lectures are not very organized but they are super engaging and really make you think about the world in a different way. The quizzes are very long and challenging, but I really feel like I learned so much from every quiz. He gives students a lot of responsibility, and I loved the independent (but guided) learning.

He's a great professor and his lectures are awesome, but he does NOT set you up well for the rest of the Econ Major or to understand the field from a mathematical prospective, which is the entire point of econ. My advice is to take ECO 108 and 207 with Landsburg and then take Sports and Environmental Econ with Rizzo for utility maximization.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Took introductory course (ECO 108) with him. Great class, very interesting lectures. Mostly focuses on teaching *how to think about economics* rather than economics itself. It is a rather "abstract" conceptual class. Homework is long but really helpful for exams. Very accesible and understanding. Will make you work hard, but worth it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: So I took landsburgs 207 and had to retake it (Im pretty sure Im not the only one). I have to say Rizzo changed my life. His lecture is excellent. I may not get really good grade from his class but he is surely THE economics professor I would follow. If I could go back to my freshman first semester, I would have picked ECO108 with him.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: 3 issues: 1. Ironically, as an economist, he's the most inefficient professor I've ever had. Will spend 30 min telling story to convey mildly relevant point. 2. On hw/tests, asks extremely vague questions barely related to econ, but wants an exact answer 3. No textbook, so it's hard to follow direction of the class and there's nothing to study for
He doesn't teach you economics, he teaches you how to think about economics. If you understand what he means, you'll never need econ help again another day in your life.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Rizzo gives very good lectures, but at the beginning it is quite difficult for international students to keep pace with

Prof. Rizzo inspired me to work hard to better understand economics at a fundamental level. He's always nice and will answer emails when you need him. The homework he gives can be very tedious but you learn a lot. His lectures are the best part of his classes and if you skip class to sleep in you will not do well on his tests. Take good notes.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Rizzo talks about a lot of stories and examples in the lecture, and it is quite difficult for students, especially those whose native language is not English, to catch up the main idea behind the examples.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: The absolute BEST class I've ever taken in my entire academic career. He will make you question everything that you've been made to believe. He's also one of the few professors who will uplift your self-image by making you realise how smart you really are. He is a superbly passionate teacher, which is what makes his class so incredible!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Hilarious

comment: ECO 108: Forget everything you ever thought you knew about economics. Rizzo's energetic, thought provoking lectures will change the way you see the world. Beware, his exams can be frustrating. 5 stars. ECO 207: Rizzo just couldn't replicate the charm of ECO 108. Spent more time on defending his opinions than on covering important concepts. 2 stars.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor Rizzo is a great professor. I think the most important thing everyone needs to be aware of is that he really tries to give students a unique experience with Economics. He is certainly the reason why I am majoring in Economics!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational

comment: This man changed my life. I look at everything differently, and I changed my major to economics solely because of this man. I recommend any and every person at the University of Rochester to take Eco 108 with Rizzo when given the chance. More difficult to get a good grade than a traditional textbook class, but you will learn far, far more.

Class isn't hard but don't go into it thinking you don't need to put in some extra effort. Talk to him and see where his mind is and you will understand things better. Honestly if you listen in class you pick up on a lot of concepts and even homework questions. Very approachable and great lecturer.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Rizzo is full of energy and seems to be very nice. But his style of teaching does not suit Asians. Will advice all Asians not to take him.

The only reason why I'm remotely interested in Econ. Not always the best at staying on topic, but one of the most genuinely interesting people I've ever met. Always there for you when you need him. A+
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Amazing lectures

comment: lectures are interesting and if you go you'll do well on the tests
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Amazing lectures

comment: Super interesting lecturer, if you go to class and are good at conceptual thinking this class is definitely worth it. If you are a math/equation based learner then this isn't the right professor for you!

Good lecturer, communicates complex ideas in ways that are easier for many students to understand than if they read them out of a textbook. However, he has a tendency to over-generalize, as well as an annoying proclivity towards stating his opinion as fact (minimum wage leading to unemployment, etc.) Responds to emails, but is not always helpful.

Rizzo is the reason I'm majoring in economics. It can be tough to grasp his way of thinking at first, but if you go to class, take good notes, and do minimal outside reading it will get easier. He greatly values participation. His lectures are fantastic and he really does love the material and care about his students.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Mr Rizzo was hands down THE best professor I have ever had. EVER. This man deserves a ghost pepper, not even a chili pepper can do him justice. You learn valuable lessons in this class that you will use all throughout life. I used hate public speaking and now love it. He teaches in a lecture style, but you will not be bored. It's Brandon Mr Rizzo!

Rizzo definitely makes a huge effort to try to educate the students on economic principles. Economics is just a really hard subject to understand. He responds to your emails pretty quickly and is very helpful when you ask him questions. It can be hard to go to his office hours because he's a very popular teacher so there is usually a long line.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Professor Rizzo is the best professor I have had in my college career. He cares deeply about teaching, and he is widely available outside of class. He is very passionate about a lot of things, and so his lectures tend to touch on a variety of topics, but they are always fascinating. Although it is not mandatory, you MUST attend class to pass.

Hardest exam ever! The final took 3 straight hours, almost 20 entire pages reading.  Yes I took the entire 3 hour exam to write and read then surprisingly noticed 1/2 people were still writing with me until the last minute. That 180 minute nightmare. Plus, he will Kill your GPA.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Prof. Rizzo's lecture is probably one of the best lecture in U of R, but the exams are MEGA difficult.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Hilarious. Why? You average 60% on your tests. What he says in class is not related at all to the test. He asked about whales on my test. You either pass with A or you fail. Lmao, GG no re sucker you picked the wrong elective!
- Amazing lecturer. Keeps you engaged. Very accessible outside of class.

Professor Rizzo is by far the best professor I have had at this school. His abundance of stories to tell you will really help you understand economics. This class will make you want to talk to all of your friends about economics. There is no textbook, it is solely lecture based. Pay attention in lecture, and you will be fine.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: You need to go to class. Get ready for anecdote after anecdote.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: one of the most talented, friendly, and interesting professors at this school.
Best Professor for Introduction to Economics
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Prof. Rizzo is the sole reason I chose to major in economics. His passion for the subject shines through every lecture and his unique way of teaching economics intuitively makes you start seeing life differently. Very kind and definitely the best lecturer in his department. If you slack off or don't show up to lecture you won't do well.
Very humble and passionate professor. Really makes you think critically and logically. One of the best professors I had the pleasure of learning from.

Professor Rizzo is such a fun lecturer! The homework isn't super easy but reaching out to the TAs definitely helps. He's always super helpful during office hours and in emails. Reading the papers on the reading list will make the class more interesting (and the tests somewhat easier). Don't cram for the exams; just make sure you apply the concepts.
Great professor, really interesting and you will learn a lot. But rest assured, this man will MURDER YOUR GPA.

Rizzo is a very good lecturer. He was always full of energy and makes economics interesting. Not a lot of work however tests are challenging. They all are questions that you need to apply what you learned in class. If you like to memorize answers and regurgitate them on a test this professor isn't for you.

Honestly, I never thought I would take the time out of my day to write a whole review for a professor but with Rizzo I have to. This man is an amazing professor and is so nice and helpful. His lectures are very interesting, and he completely changes the way you think about life. HOWEVER, the exams are a pain but if you study you'll pass. Trust me.
Lecture based

This dude loves his job and he loves economics which shows in his lectures. I think you'll learn a lot from him. One of the best  things is, at least in ECO207, he grades you on how well you can think like an economist. There isn't necessarily one correct answer (except maybe on some things). Overall, he's an awesome prof.
While the tests were difficult and weekly homework became a chore, what I loved most about this class was the engaging and relevant lectures made by a very intelligent professor.

Overall I enjoyed this class. Rizzo is an enthusiastic and fun professor and he provided a great introduction to Economics. This class really is not that difficult if you go to every class and take notes. The key to doing well on his exams is to restate the arguments Rizzo uses in class as most exam questions are related to a major theme from class
He's a great lecturer and a very helpful instructor.

He's a great professor who gives amazing lectures. No textbooks used. Attendance isn't mandatory, but it's highly recommended that you attend them as topics discussed in lectures appear in exams. Tests are not hard, but require a lot of critical thinking. Passing this class is easy, but you need to put in extra effort for an A.

Graded only on tests. Make sure you devote lots of time to problem sets and review the solutions carefully once they're posted (morning of exam). Lots of times, midterm questions come straight from these problem sets, word for word. Read all of the articles he "recommends". You'll learn a new way of looking at life from this class.

Is super engaging in class, but expectations are confusing. Has a penchant for making economic statements against the value of our university education and that no matter what we do we probably won't learn anything in his class. His tests cater to specific things he said in class, so make note of every crazy example he gives.

Professor Rizzo is the most motivational and inspirational professor that I've ever had. He is the sole reason why I switched my major to economics. His classes are incredibly captivating, and the content of his lectures are life changing. Would take any class that Professor Rizzo offers. They are the most valuable ones in college by far.

Rizzo is a very polarizing teacher.  He is also very busy, but if you reach out to him he will make sure he answers your questions. If you want to do well, read everything and ask him as many questions as possible. You really are learning about HIS principles of economics. But if you do all that this class is really not that hard. GOAT Lecturer!
a lecture-based class. no math involved. extremely difficult tests.

I could write a whole 10-page paper to express how much I love Rizzo's class. It seems he teaches four courses in UR currently; his way of teaching makes me decide to take all those four during my college life, though some are not necessary and I am not interested in. Definitely go to his classes, you will get more than knowledge itself! Well worth

ECO108 Fall'14 Rizzo is a really awesome and interesting professor. However, he doesnt baby you. He doesnt provide much notes and the tests are tough. Attending lecture is key as this is where you derive your study materials from. Stay up to date with the online readings and you will be rewarded! Make use of the forms of communication he provides!

Makes life very hard for students with no reference links, no powerpoints, no notes. If you're not fully engaged in his lecture, you won't get any good notes. Awful grading system. If you manage to think like him, you'll do well. If you disagree and don't understand his thinking, you'll struggle. Avoid him if you like working from textbooks.
Yay Rizzo! Cool dude. Interesting classes but I'm not sure how technically he is compared to what other professors might teach.

Yes, Rizzo is an extremely difficult teacher, but ultimately he loves those students that put in the effort and those students are rewarded.  If I could go back, I would have built a strong relationship with this professor in the beginning of the year because he is a brilliant and interesting dude.  He is my favorite professor by far.

I had him for 108 as well, and I really liked that class. However, he spent 238 ranting at us for many lectures. Sure, he shares a very interesting perspective, but spending 2 hours in class to get yelled at didn't help the experience.   Often, he got challenged by students, got mad about it and then took it out on us.

Professor Rizzo knows how to keep his students engaged. While he may get a tad idealogical, he does not indoctrinate his students. He teaches economics in a very unconventional way. He is more conceptual, but the way that he applies economics to literally everything continues to amaze me. The University is incredibly lucky to have him.
This man made me give up on Econ. I will not take economic class again.
My favorite professor ever. Super responsible and kind. He really wants everyone to learn something from everywhere. But it is true that the exams are extremely hard.
he's really interesting. make sure to attend EVERY class. the review questions/packet were very helpful in both 108 and 207

I had the man for 108 and 207. He is a true economist. He really gets you to think about the world. And his lectures do teach you about economics in a real sense. But his tests are entirely semantics and he isnt very helpful. grades are typically very low and there is no curve. his intentions are good. but you have to work really hard ON YOUR OWN.
you will learn a lot. very interesting. you will have to work hard though. well worth it

Class average on the ECO 238 final was a 20.5/30. That's a 68.5%. The final was 35% of the grade. The course was not curved. Class average was about a 2.3. That's an average, so half the class got below that. good luck
Literall the most funny and interesting man. GO TO CLASS. I guarantee A if you go to every class. Recitations are so helpful go to those too. I loved this class

I had Rizzo for environmental economics. Love him or hate him, this man is very enthusiastic. Half the class was spent learning economics that may be considered "unconventional". Rizzo managed to keep the class interesting and question a lot of world views. He's very intelligent, but sometimes it's difficult to tell what he's asking on the exams.
He's a great professor. He teaches you things beyond economics. This class is like philosophy. He teaches you the way to think. He's not easy at all but I've really learned a lot from this class.
Everyone should take this class with Professor Rizzo before graduating. I was going to transfer to Cornell, but as long as Rizzo stays, I'll stay.  I wish I took this course freshman year..
Amazing class.  Among the best profs in the department.  Rizzo is talented and brilliant.  The UofR is very lucky to have him.
International students especially should take Rizzo's classes. He represents what's special about US education.

Universities need more professors like Rizzo. He's the only one I've had so far who actually challenges me to think. Yes, formulas and fact memorization will be useful on standardized tests and for hard sciences, but without a mind behind it all you are is a robot. Rizzo wants you to use your head, not mindlessly memorize particular facts.
doesn't use a textbook. very low use of graphs or numbers. his way of teaching is VERY conceptual BUT it is amazing how he applies economics to real life.
The guy is a genius. He challenges every one of your deeply held beliefs - with reason and evidence, not ideology and rhetoric.
One of the most interesting professors I have ever had.  Lectures are both helpful and entertaining, but he is not afraid to be critical of every common notion and any counter-arguments to his ideas.

Rizzo is an excellent professor, but be warned that this isn't a traditional economics class! Instead of focusing on graphs and numbers, Rizzo explains the material through key concepts, which you must learn to apply to everyday life. It's difficult at first, but he makes himself very available, through both office hours and e-mail.
Great Professor- but you will have to learn the material to get a good grade. Lectures are not mandatory, but very entertaining! Try not to miss them!
Great lecturer, interesting material. Don't bother buying any extra books unless you want to read them yourself, they're not really necessary. Will be taking more classes with Rizzo for sure.
Great teacher. Just work hard and be interested!
He is pretty interesting. The class has nothing to do with models or numbers, it is all about social economics. Pretty cool though.

I was shocked when I noticed the stuff people were writing about Rizzo on rate my professor. The class isn't a cake walk, but its worlds easier than any advanced engineering class. If you do the work, you can get an A, nuff said. Everyone I've talked to loved the guy so I'm guessing most of the people that write these are the vocal minority....

Rizzo is an extrmeely hard teacher. He gives a lot of busy work which isnt even helpful to his students. He wants to make his exams hard to challenge the students, but often overdoes and over have the class recieves less than a B

I really don't see why people get frustrated bu this guy.  He takes more time out of his schedule to meet with students than the rest of the department combined.  Also you can get an A... just DO THE WORK, I see so many people say "OMG he slammed my GPA because I didn't turn in the HW and like study what a prick."  News flash: Do your work on time.
Just for the record, it is very possible to get an A in Rizzo's class... just go to class and do the readings. Rizzo is a great lecturer and his classes are definitely worth taking.

Professor Rizzo is infuriating.  He says that he wants his students to learn for the sake of learning, yet he kills us when it comes to assigning grades.  Not sure what you're trying to prove Rizzo but it really discourages me from ever taking a class with you again.  my gpa just can't afford it.
Good lecturer. However, assigns horribly made quizzes which are largely busy work and take much much more effort than their worth

The BEST lecturer at the university. Classes are very interesting and he often throws in useful anecdotes to aid your understanding. However, getting an A is difficult and all work should be done on time in addition to extra credit. Acing the exams is possible by thorough study of previous year's examinations and practice exams. Very,very fun class

Rizzo's probably the best professor I've ever had.  You can tell he's brilliant, but he's still very accessible. The class is interesting but you do have to work for your grade; the grading is tough, so I have to recommend the extra credit opportunities.  He's an engaging lecturer and I found the insights from his class invaluable.

Probably the best professor I have had at Rochester. I admit some of his lectures are disorganized, however, many of his other lectures are so intriguing and interesting. These more than make up for it. His personality is awesome and he is so enthusiastic about economics. I would highly recommend taking environmental with him-extremely interesting.

Rizzo is the man. If people understand that what he is teaching is not his opinion, but is economic fact, you can gain a lot from his classes. He is not crazy (maybe a little), but he gets very frustrated with how society misinterprets economics and states things as fact that are not. He loves his students, works insanely hard,do theXCyou'llbefine

Professor Rizzo is extremely passionate about economics and is constantly challenging your views on every topic you could think of. It's refreshing to have a professor who actually forces you to think instead of spoon feeding you information. Many think Rizzo gives his "opinion", but he always provides hard data and evidence to support his teaching

good thing's that the semester's almost over. Some students say he's an energetic or intelligent.I don't really think that he's.He makes a whole mess in class and acts like crazy person, then he asks students come to ask him questions.There are many students waiting for him "at his door."I guess he "enjoys" it.I also took eco211 with him.

He struggles greatly with structuring his classes in a coherent manner. Walking into class saying "I have no idea what we are going to talk about today. I'm sorry you have to deal with me" does not send a good message to students. Is not clear in asking what he expects. He is intelligent and energetic but this hurts him rather than helps him.

Rizzo's a fun guy.  You either like him or you don't.....He enjoys getting to know his students really well.  I record his lectures, and he knows my name, and is very helpful when I have questions.  I think he's a great guy, and an ok professor.

One of the most engaging and inflammatory professors around.  Hard tests and a hard grader, but if you try to understand the concepts from a rational/logical point of view, it makes everything easier.  Make sure to take good notes on what he says? you won't get a board to copy down his notes.  Always willing to help out students.

Rizzo's the kind of professor that you either love or hate. I think he's the best professor I've ever had and I really enjoy going to class each day. He's interesting and obviously passionate about economics but the tests are hard & I recommend that you sit in on a class first so that you know what to expect and whether you like his teaching style.

Best professor in the Econ Department, if not best professor on campus. WARNING: he is NOT an easy professor, you MUST do work for an A. He is not crazy, he promotes Austrian Economics. He is one of the only professors left who teaches the concepts of rationalism.
He's crazy. He talked what exactly what I said in my paper. But when I returned my paper, he crossed out everything...He says he hates books, as well as Landsburg:)or Landsburg's book;)

Definitely my favorite Prof. Cares a lot about his students and is absolutely hilarious in class. Also very thoughtful. Obviously a brilliant guy but very humble. You may not (probably won't) agree with his normative views, but he will definitely change the way you see the world. Be warned though, a many ppl find his classes challenging.

It's big unfortunate for the students that this guy is leading a research seminar. Talking, talking, and talking with no quality...like Soap opera. He's very rude, unbelievable! Everybody talks about how he's a crazy:)

His lectures are fun. He talks for a good 70 minutes at a fast pace. It is rather enjoyable, but he doesn't write anything on the board. This makes studying the material rather difficult since he doesn't really have a text book. You are better off not taking a class with him. I have lost faith in humanity because of him.

Rizzo is a great guy. His lectures are a tad bit ridiculous. But overall if you put enough effort into attending class, writing good essays, and doing the extra credit, you'll get an A. I started with a C and ended up with an A, mainly through visiting him at office hours and understanding how he teaches. Do the extra credit.

Everybody around me disliked Rizzo for not giving an A. It is very easy to get a B in this class. There's hardly any work to do except for a couple of essays you write once in a while. Just attend all his lectures and you get a B. But to get an A, you have to do all Extra Credits, which you must catch on quickly. Doing all of them is alot of work.
He's just horrible one. It is too bad for the university....The more this kind of professor, the more failure the USA

Rizzo... Probably my most interesting professor to date. First, VERY easy B but a difficult A. You can skip every class but go to the reviews and pull a B. The ONLY way to get an A is to become a pet. 10% or so of your grade is "extra credit" (HIS DISCRETION). I did tons of EC and got no grade bump. Didnt like him, learned nothing, escaped with a B
enjoy his class

Best professor I have had so far. Made me fall in love with Econ. He has a great sense of humor and will almost always keep the class entertained. Gives lots of optional and interesting material to read or watch outside of class.
He is extremely enthusiastic but it is difficult to follow his lectures sometimes.

I used to love economics until I took this class. Thankfully, all the important things that you should be learning in this class and will eventually need to know will be covered between Hong/Hawkins' macro classes and Wojdat's finance classes. This is like a very subjective history/philosophy class. This is not economics. If you enjoy econ, avoid.

Very enthusiastic and inflammatory.  At the same time very hard with his grading, and seems to get some pleasure out of that.  Helpful outside of the classroom.  His papers are extremely difficult and graded toughly.  Don't recommend this for your writing course.

I don't understand why students are so positive about him... They way he acts in class is just craziness...Too much drama...I heard he didn't want to have TAs...he wants to be a popular instructor..or what?
hands down one of the best economics professor on campus. though he may be hard but at least you learn to think and that's what matters the most.

Worst teacher/prof I have ever had at any level. I was shocked he even had pre prepared lecture notes. Class had no structure. Professor was only interested in promoting his libertarian views and spreading anti government propaganda. Do not waste your time and money on this class.Unless you think just like him, you will struggle.Extremely unhelpful

I have had him for both Intro and Mirco. I have switched to an Econ major because of his classes. If you attend class, take notes, read the text, and attend office hours when you have questions, you will do great. However, if you don't put any work into it, you won't do well. Its that simple. He is very personable and cares a lot about his students

One of the worst professors I've encountered at the UR. All tests are short answer and if you don't get his exact wording, you get the whole question wrong. Gets VERY whiny in class and blames students for not doing well. TA's also give their friends high grades and you can't talk to Rizzo about it. If you want your GPA to go Rizzo is the best!!!

I don't know why people rated this guy so high. Sorry, but he was horrible. Uninteresting. Average of grades like a D- on tests and he doesn't curve. Big whiner also. Thinks the students are to blame for everything, when really its his sporadic teaching method that makes absolutely no sense. I would not recommend this Professor at all.

Rizzo is probably one of the best professors I've had at UR. A former Investment banker,he makes the class really interesting. No grading curve,and to do well you must take very good notes. I Highly recommend the class.

Great, enthusiastic lecturer. Very passionate about economics. However, I think he kind of messed up when teaching ECO108 (understandable since he's new), and I felt we either glossed over or just didn't learn basic (but important) economic principles. I feel that this screwed me over during the spring since I took micro with a different professor

Professor Rizzo is a very hard worker and gives enthusiastic and entertaining lectures.  He really knows his stuff and does a great job explaining the material.  I genuinely look for forward to attending every single class.  All around, best teacher I've had at Rochester, hands down, by far.
Coolest/sexiest/nerdiest teacher alive.

Great professor. He's full of energy, and always seems really excited to teach you the next thing in his agenda. He gives plenty of examples, and he's always ready for e-mailed questions or at office hours if you need the extra help. What I especially liked was the review sessions he held before each test; you have to give the man props for spendin

Rizzo is a great professor. He really tries to engage his students in the class, his energy level is amazing, and you can tell that he is passionate about econ. Make sure you go to class (which is fun) and you should be able to pull off a good grade.

Rizzo is a fabulous professor who obviously adores teaching economics. His passion and enthusiasm for the subject makes studying even at a 100 level really interesting. The greatest thing is that he manages to lecture to 150 students and sound like he's teaching a 15 student class.
Rizzo is absolutely great. He uses the best examples, is very personable and extremely energetic...especially for the 9 am class!
He is very passionate about the material he teaches and it makes the class very enjoyable. I always look forward to class.
Mike Rizzo is basically the balls. He is extremely nice, engaging, helpful, and knowledgeable about the subject matter.
Professor Rizzo is a great teacher and has made my university experience really enjoyable. He has opened my eyes to the importance of economics and how it relates to all aspects of life.
No Comments
Enthusiastic teacher, fun class. Would recommend.

Dr H's lectures were very unorganized and hard to follow. He drags on and only teaches in examples. However, his office hours (if you can fit it in your schedule he usually only has 1-2 hours per week in the middle of the day) and workshops are helpful. The grading was pretty lenient, but the second half of the class was much harder.
He had really good lectures and was always available if you needed help outside of class. I've always struggled with chem but this class was very good and prepared me for the exams.
Recommended for everyone who want to take chem131, his office hour is also very helpful.

Although this is the intro to chemistry, it was still an entertaining class. All lectures were recorded, and you didn't have to pay for the textbook since it was online, but you did need to pay for the software for homework. Grading was a points system that I really enjoyed and it was a surprisingly good course to learn the basics of chemistry.
As someone who took ap chem I still struggled a little with this course. Do the practice tests because what he teaches in lecture is only the basis.
slow lectures. however great for someone who has never seen chem before. tests were fair. easy A if you do the work.

Dr. H's lectures can sometimes be confusing and tedious, but there are resources outside of lecture that help a lot. His office hours were great and really helped my understanding. Test difficulty is somewhere between the Aktiv homework (easy) and workshop problems (hard) so I would recommend keeping up on those if you're struggling.

Dr. H's lectures are super hard to follow and for me, useless. If you're really struggling in the class I would attend office hours and pay attention during workshops. He does want you to succeed and will help when prompted, but going to lectures alone probably won't help you—they're all over the place. I had to teach myself a lot of basic content.
he is a nice professor. the content is easy just focus on workshops. class is a bit disorganized and confusing. wayyyy better than other chem professors
The best professor I ever had.

He is a great guy. Super nice and charming. However, lectures are confusing and hard to follow. He basically does math problems on the board for an hour and 20 minutes and half-heartedly explains why he does what he does. He gives lots of points and really wants you to pass, but the style of teaching just wont work for everyone

As someone who came from only taking one chemistry honors course during the pandemic, I would say Hafensteiner didn't help me the most as I transitioned into college-level chemistry, as he wasn't clear on concepts and was scattered. I guess the point system was a redeeming factor in his class. Does talk about his kids a lot.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Dr. H is funny and engaging but his lectures are a bit scattered, so going to workshops really mattered. Either way TAs grade very nicely (lots of partial credit) and Dr. H and TAs are available through office hours often. Did not regularly attend lectures and still didn't even need to take the final to get an A (but you have to take the final)

Professor H is a friendly guy, but his teaching style can be hit or miss. While lectures may lack organization, workshops and past exams are key for succeeding. Leveraging resources like Unstuck ai alongside the textbook can make this course manageable.

Dr. H is a good professor for 131, but for 204, he's not very good. Orgo is complicated and having a prof with good organization is essential. His lectures are poorly organized and jump around. Compared to Prof. Dinnocenzo, his class is confusing and requires a LOT more memorization. Learn how to do mechanisms solo because he doesn't explain them.

Yea Dr. H doesn't seem like a great prof during the course however, compared to Matson and Knowles (CHEM132) he is amazing. The class is very easy to get an A in with the amount of extra credit and simple concepts. Dr. H goes on annoying tangents about his daughters and does not use slides so you have to take your own notes. Ok prof.

Dr. H is super friendly and willing to answer questions, which often makes lectures feel like office hours. If you have a background in AP chem, you're set. He explains concepts decently well but they could be better. However, Dr. H is very willing to help you out during office hours.

Honestly if you took AP Chem within the past 2 years you will be fine. Class is on the point system, which if you play your cards right, you might only need a 20% on the final to end with an A. If you're confused in lecture, I would recommend reading the textbook, doing past exams and definitely going to workshop.

Dr. H seems to be a genuinely kind and passionate person who wants his students to succeed. However, his teaching style is not for everyone. What he covers in lectures is very different from the types of problems that you are given on tests. I'd say the most helpful things were workshops and past exams. Study and connect concepts outside of class.

This class is the reason I changed majors. It was hard for a gen chem, especially because I have no chemistry background. It had workshops that were helpful to an extent, labs that I enjoyed, and homework (Aktiv) that you had to pay to use. Lectures didn't apply too much to tests, workshops were better for studying. Funny guy tho!

Dr. H, at heart, is a good person. Lectures are funny and he is accessible outside of class. However, I struggled in his class. His lectures can be hard to follow, so put in the time outside of class to understand the material. I walked out with an A which was mainly a result of doing really well on the final and teaching myself material.

Dont get me wrong. Dr. H is a wonderful person. However, I do feel that his lectures could use a bit more organization since a lot of the time, I found it hard to follow. I recommend to study at least every time you open the textbook. Other than that, this class is very doable and can even be cheesed if you're satisfied with a B.

Dr. H understands the material he's teaching, but he is hampered mostly by poor lecture organization, so if you're the type of person that needs well-organized lesson plans, you're out of luck. DO THE AKTIVCHEM. Remember that aktivchem problems aren't ordered by difficulty - sometimes the easy ones that actually teach you the material are last.

this class was fairly manageable/easy for someone with no prior chemistry experience. if you have a decent understanding of algebra and math, this class should be easy. Reviewing past papers is recommended when studying for exams. the homework helps with understanding the basis.

Prof. H is good at teaching and makes class interesting. However, this course is all math-related and I did not expect that at first. Attending lecture and doing the practice exams are extremely helpful for passing the class. If you're not good at math, it may take some extra work but you should be fine if you put in the work.

Go to lecture, do your homework, go to workshop, and you will do well on the exams. This has been the easiest STEM class I have taken in college. He literally gives you a checklist for what you need to do to do well. The lectures are 100% recorded so you don't even have to get up for class. Ridiculously easy, but still fun nonetheless.

This course is easy, just do the practice exams. He gives extra credit and you can easily get full score on the lecture part. The experiment is tiresome, but it doesn't count a lot. The testing is easy and TA gives as much score as he/she can. Overall, not hard to get an A even without participation.

Dr. H is a good professor and his exams are fair if you understand the material covered in lecture and workshop. I wish he included slides or had more organized lectures, because sometimes material was inconsistently covered between sections.

Great professor. His lectures are good; they are recorded, so you can re-watch them, which I highly recommend. His HW on Aktiv Chem cannot be compared to his exams. His exams will brutalize you :( Please do the practice exams, and study a little everyday. I ended with a B. Coming from a person who got a C in Orgo I, you can do it too :)
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. H is overall a great guy who cares a lot about his students- however, his lectures often were behind and he seemed to treat the lecture time like an office hours period.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. H is great at teaching and his lectures are easy to follow and he doesn't skip over information assuming you already know it, but his exams are extremely hard much more so than what is in the homeworks or the workshops. He is very approachable with questions and accessible outside of class. Memorization is super necessary so start from day one.

Dr. H is an amazing person, just not a great teacher. Often in class he would get distracted and very rarely would we ever get through the material that was planned. In a 75 minute lecture, he would take about 40 minutes to answer students questions that are meant for office hours. He doesn't give a lot of examples, just basic broad ideas. Go to OH

Good person, not a good teacher. His lectures were often unorganized and did not provide many examples of material that was actually on the exam. For those with no chemistry background, this class can be very tough. To succeed, I recommend securing all the "easy" points (hw, wrkshp, etc), extra credit, and review wrkshps and past exams for practice
He isn't a good teacher, but on the bright side, gives a LOT of extra credit. Lectures are not at all useful. Use the textbook, YouTube, workshops, and practice exams.

The structure of the class (number of tests, homework assignments, lab etc) made this class manageable. However, Dr. H's lectures did not help me much. Dr. H is almost too nice, he spends a significant amount of time answering every question that is asked during lectures, which results in content not being covered and difficult exams.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Test heavy

comment: Professor Hafensteiner is a very kind and caring person, but he just doesn't know how to teach. He doesn't know how to pace himself and is too nice to answer every single question to the point where half of the class is just answering questions. Good person though

Go to office hours. Dr. H is a great guy with an amazing understanding of chemistry but he SUCKS at translating that knowledge to a large classroom. The only times when I felt I was truly learning was in office hours. Lectures can be funny, but don't give you that much. Also, he'll teach us a simple concept, then make it more complicated on exams!

Dr. H seems like a great guy and enjoys teaching this class, but his lectures for the most part are drawn out and rushed for time towards the end of class. He spends lots of time answering unnecessary questions during lectures. I would say his grading criteria is very clear and he gives lots of opportunities for a good grade.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Just focus on the practice tests from past years, and use organic chem tutor on youtube. Not good lecturer and confuses you more. Stopped going to lecture and started doing better in the class.

Pros: Dr. Hafensteiner has a wonderful personality & offers many extra credit opportunities for homework.    
Cons: He cannot teach. I stopped going to his lectures after the first exam because they are not as useful as I expected. I wish he had a few slides summarizing the main takeaways or steps for approaching different stoichiometric questions.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I feel bad giving Dr. Hafensteiner a lukewarm rating, he is a very kind and funny man who clearly loves his job. However, his lectures were all either unnecessarily easy or ridiculously hard to follow. I did not learn very much at all from him, and I felt it was mostly on me to learn the course material outside of class.

Very nice man & good dad to kids he always talks about. Lectures started off strong & easy to understand but were disorganized later & it was easy to get lost. Answers too many questions even the dumbest that have nothing to do with what we learn. Tests much harder than the practice. Really challenge yourself, do the labs & extra credit for an A.

Professor H is charismatic and a really kind guy, a good family man, but not the best professor. His lectures seem scrambled and unorganized. His tests are quite difficult. Wish we did more test prep in class. This class is challenging if you've only taken gen chem in high school. Be prepared to put in lots of effort if you want an A/study ingroup

Dr. H is like your Uncle, who growing up you thought was super funny and inspiring and whatever. But then you grow up and realize what a bald face lier they are. Letcures are 90% useless information and the only way to do good in this class are to come in with an already good background understanding of chem, or teach it all to yourself.
