it would be nice if you could avoid him, but he is the gateway to the biological sciences at UR - and he knows it.  it is extremely difficult to learn from him.  anything you DO learn will likely be a result of your own personal investigation elsewhere.  regardless of what you understand about the concepts, unless you learn to see how he sees and talk like he talks, you will not have opportunity to demonstrate what you know on an exam.  success in biology does not equal success in his class and vice versa.

If you actually go to lecture, this class is just about the easiest class possible.  Exams straight from lecture.  And Olek is histerical always so condecending when people ask stupid questions, makes it amusing.
One of the worse experiences...
can't really learn from the experiments it in no way involves the students and keeps them from understanding the concept to the full extent

He doesn't know what he's doing nor does he know how to convey his ideas to others.  He is very rude/ offensive. He doesn't clearly expalin questions.  His exams are oddly questioned.  One must develope a new method of studying just to pass his class.
mmm...just don't get what he's trying to do

Looks like President Garfield, he's "always" right becuase he's got a doctorate.  He has no clue how to answer questions sometimes so he diverts by asking redundant questions.  Sometimes he says.. he doesn't know.
Very Rude and down right negative towards your aspirations and goals...

People are too quick at judging his different style of teaching.  Oh no!  He focuses on concepts instead of brutal details that can be picked up from textbooks!  Olek tries the conceptual approach of "telling it as a story" -- if it's not your style, the TA's can help you grasp things with a different style of explanation.
The lab manual made me sick. He must be from another planet.
knowledgeable and a good guy, hard exams...need to know what he wants to hear or you won't get credit
Stay away from any lab he leads.  The clarity with which his labs are written really makes me question his literacy skills.
His classes are boring and he's mean and intimidating.

Very difficult. I studied like mad and still barely passed. He makes up his own terms and is fairly unorganized in his lectures. His tests ask the strangest questions, so that you can know all the material, but still fail.

Trys to inspire students to think of Bio in a way the dosen't foster learning.  He seems to makes half the material up and it seems inconsistent with the science community.  You could know a lot about Bio and still fail his course because answers have to be what he wants instead of what's true.
"Everyone on board?" - his key line in lecture... but I never was.  I studied like crazy for this class and it never seemed to help.  Hopefully you have a good bio background from high school.
Big Tony rocks!
No Comments

I'm amazed at how he decides to make up his own terms to describe the science that is biology. Furthermore, he barely mentions the least important facts that don't really matter to a major process like say glycolysis, and then wants us to know it for the test. Hardly worth my time.

Olek can and tries to be intimidating.  His teaching style takes a little while to get used to, but the way he puts everything in context is effective.  You just have to figure out how to answer his test questions properly.  The recitations are really helpful.  Stay on top of lecture material.
No Comments
His teaching isn't very effective, he's soporific to listen to, and when you ask questions in class he doesn't usually give a straight answer.  Pray for a good TA and study really hard.
No Comments
curses on this man! he is a terrible teacher

Both Intro Bio profs suck. How are we ever supposed to excel in the Biological Sciences with professors who don't know what they're doing. Olek's class was useless along with his clarity. Helpful he was not until after being pestered.

I really liked his class. He oversimplifies a bit (which can complicate things later on) but overall, I found the class enjoyable. It helps if you have a good TA though just to fix the occasional slip ups he has
His notes are disorganized and he contradicts himself daily. This man should have never been allowed to teach.
HATED HIM; HATED THE COURSE. KILLED MY GPA

Who allowed this man to teach? I realize that this is a weeder course, but give me a break! You cannot be 100 percent correct in his class, and if you are, he takes off point on your exam because he's convinced you memorized and did not learn!

Hard material, gotta stay on top of things. Not helpful if you are not doing well in the class. He likes to prove how great he is and if you need help, he is very intimidating and it distracts you from learning. Didn't like him.

He has a bit of a false modesty thing, but that's his schtick.  He's a smart guy, and teaches complicated processes in a manageable way.  And for the reccord, it was one of his grad students who nearly killed himself with a lion fish, not himself.
He is not very smart....Do you know the lionfish?
I like the way he teaches. Makes concepts very clear but grades and tests harshly.

the material is really elementary. professor olek on the other hand is just very intimidating. he's not the type of person who would give encouraging words, rather he's the type who would and can really discourage you.

Not the worlds greatest course but a good basic course.  You need to constantly study to stay current with stuff but this course is DEFINITELY doable.  If you want to get into med school this course is a must.
lectures stupid
Be very careful of wording on tests... he's not overly helpful to talk to after you fail. Trick to staying awake: participate/ask questions.
*I* thought he was funny, in any case...
He didn't know what he was talking about half the time... and the other half the time we didn't know what he was talking about!
No Comments
Although funny at times, he often is not aware of the kind of information he's giving out.
if someone has a trick to staying awake in oleks bio classes let me know.  it is the only class i fell asleep to consistently

He told the entire lecture on the first day that hydrogen had two protons.  He obviously has no knowledge about the subject and his slides are prepared completely by his TAs.  He's also one of the rudest, most inconsiderate people you will ever meet.
No Comments
No Comments
gives you a good understanding of introductory biology.
No Comments
knows how you should teach but hes not so good at it himself. great personality
Uses lots of powerpoint presentations so if you miss a class its ok
overwhelming arrogance
don't bother buying the book
Never slept through so many lectures in my life!
Professor does a great job of communicating and explaining material, also a really nice individual. Sometimes grading criteria can be a bit confusing so just do your best on everything.

Inter-personally, he is nice, but the class can be slightly disorganized. If you do not read the textbook and try to understand both the equations and the concepts, you will have a hard time. If you go to his office hours and try to care, he'll walk you through the whole problem, answer and all. Lots of questions on the assigned homeworks. So-so.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Sefkow is a great professor. He takes the time to help his students when they ask, is compassionate, and understands busy schedules. His quizzes can be difficult. The professor wants students to get the most out of his class and will explain confusing concepts in a one-on-one setting.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Fantastic professor, he makes learning fun.

Prof Sefkow is nice and cares about his students. However, lectures aren't engaging and he only uses the blackboard. He doesn't record or post lectures. His handwriting can can be illegible, due to spelling mistakes and small writing. Homework can be difficult and may require a TA to teach you. Can be a harsh grader. Beware of hard reading quizzes

Professor Sefkow is a nice guy, but he mostly just lectures out of the textbook. I almost never felt like I got anything out of the class that I wouldn't get from the book. He is very available for students, and during office hours would explain concepts in a way I wish he did in class. He also started grading harder partway through the semester.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: He is a very nice professor, but his lectures strictly follow the textbook and do not explain the material enough for full understanding. Be sure to attend recitations, as the TAs will go over homework problems and help prepare you for the exam.

Good professor! I would choose him again. He is very approachable and easy to talk to. If you miss a quiz, you can always go to his office hours to make it up, and he will patiently answer all your questions. He's also an easy grader, but you should be prepared to spend time reading the textbook to succeed in the course. Highly recommend!

He seems like a nice guy and explains things well. Doesn't record lectures or post notes unfortunately. The way he runs the class seems like he's very new to teaching. Follows the textbook to the letter, his lectures are textbook recitation sessions. Sometimes provides materials to help study for exams but sometimes not? TA's carry the course.

Very kind and made himself available outside of class time. However, he followed the textbook very closely and there was an imbalance between long mathematical derivations and useful practice problems/practical applications of the material. Grading was stringent, but not unreasonable.
Clearly restated content straight from the textbook, in his own speaking style. Very nice.
Clearly restates content straight from the textbook in his own speaking style. Is very clear in his words.

Solid professor. He speaks clearly, gives a lot of examples, covers the material, and is open to student feedback. He mostly read directly from the textbook. His ability to go "off script" was rather limited. He gave the students opportunities to improve their grade, but his rubrics were frustrating. I had neither a bad nor exemplar experience.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Sefkow is overall a pretty nice person, but not a great professor. He doesn't post lecture material so going to class is a must. There is a lot of information he does not go over so you will definitely need the textbook. He gives reading quizzes are tedious because you practically need to memorize the chapter word for word to do good.

He is a tough grader and asked the TAs specifically to grade harder. There are reading quizzes that often are on things he never taught. Doesn't post notes, only writes small and messy on the board. He's a very nice guy, he just isn't the best professor.
Reading can be super important since the lectures rely on the textbook. Fair on exams and homework. Recitations help tremendously for the homework.
Reading is important as the textbook goes along with the lectures. There were short in class quizzes every couple of weeks. Recitations were a great help for the homeworks.
Teaches very closely to the textbook - getting your hands on a copy is a must. Lots of diagrams and examples, drawn well on the board in lecture.
The lectures are good and they cover most of the book. Recitations are helpful with the homework. Quizzes are tough so be prepared to study for them.

He basically recites the textbook, but the examples he uses are very thorough and got better over time. Willing to accommodate students, and not too hard of a grader. He is decent at explaining if you ask for clarification. Homework is very useful for understanding. His course was easy for a fluids class. Didn't cover enough material imo though.

He is very accomodating with students' needs and really seems to want students to succeed. Lectures aren't recorded and he doesn't post his notes though so attend class to get the notes which follow the textbook pretty chronologically. Not many examples during class at the beginning of the semester which made the material more difficult.

Class is based on the textbook, so good to have access to it. Recitations are very helpful for doing the weekly homework. Exam questions are fair. He is willing to listen to the classes concerns and input on assignments, but sometimes is a little disorganized.

Professor Sekfow is difficult yet fair. While his assignments and exams are extremely challenging, his grading criteria favors those who are willing to put in the work. Be prepared to work very hard in his class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Prof. Sefkow is an approachable professor that does listen to the needs of the students. The lectures were good, however sometimes they felt a bit repetitive of the textbook. Homework grading was tough later into the semester.

Professor Sefkow's lectures are thorough, and he follows along with the textbook very well, so if you need to miss or skip lectures, you can catch up on your own. Homeworks are graded a bit harshly, exams have conceptual questions. He is very reasonable, I contacted him about potentially missing an exam the day before, he was very accommodating.
Great person who cares about his students. Course could have moved more swiftly to better cover the harder content.
Uses relevant examples from the textbook to assist with the material, answers everyones questions, and does a good job making sure all the material is covered. Make sure to have the text book.

Sefkow is a solid professor. His lectures are pretty solid, but it is tough that he doesn't post lecture notes or anything so try to make it to class. Homework, recitation, etc is pretty manageable and it is nice that recitation is tied in with the homework.
Definitely make sure you have access to the textbook for this class. His lectures line up almost perfectly with the textbook, so it is a great resource for supplementing what you learn in class.
Was having a really rough year and professor Sefkow helped make it a lot easier. Really good guy and professor

Professor Sefkow is an incredible and caring educator. With his detailed, flexible teaching style and engaging discussions, I enjoyed learning the course material on a deep level. He always made himself available outside of class hours and would adjust due dates and exam restrictions based on open communication of class feedback. Amazing lectures!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Sefkow emphasizes a lot how important it is to understand each topic and uses great examples as often as he can so that the material covered can be understood more intuitively. Always open to any questions regarding the class and also discusses implications of the material into other topics.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: I took Plasma 2 as a first year graduate student. He was amazing and made me feel more confident about my knowledge coming from Plasma 1. His lectures are neatly written and contain full sentence explanations so write down exactly what he writes. I loved the spurious discussions as a class when someone asked a tricky question, rather than avoid it.

Prof. Sefkow is great at taking complex topics and breaking them down into more digestible pieces. He really cares about his students and keeps the syllabus very flexible depending on their interests. His class felt more like a discussion. His lectures can be dense, but he's very open to answering questions and focuses on understanding.
Always changed rubric for grading. Even change the exam date arbitrarily.
Unreasonable final and project grading.
Always changing syllabus until one week before the final week.

Very good professor, very understanding and offers good support so don't hesitate to reach out! Go to lecture and recitation, actually read the textbook (especially helpful when making cheat sheets), and you're all set for the class
He changes the schedule whenever he wanted. Try to please everyone without actually pleasing anyone.

He's a good professor and very obviously cares for his students. He also makes the optional recitations very useful to go to by covering half of the questions on the upcoming homework during that recitation. However, he is very unorganized. The exam dates would constantly change and would not match with what the syllabus had originally said.
Professor Sefkow was very engaging and provided excellent guidance throughout the class.  No complaints at all.

I loved the way Prof. Sefkow ran lectures. He always slips in these funny jokes while lecturing and I mean, when you're listening to fluid mechanics explanation, any joke will make you laugh (nothing against fluids :)
The instructor is accessible, helpful, knowledgeable of the subject, and always able to relate it to real-world applications.
Overall a really good professor. Just wished he gave us more time for us to study for midterms but other than that, content was actually digestible and he was a decent lecturer.

Prof. Sefkow does a great job making his lectures interesting and informative. He makes complicated concepts digestible for his students and makes himself available for help and questions. He clearly cares about his students.
I thought he was really chill and understanding. Taught the material well

Professor Sefkow is a great guy and really means well, but tries to please everybody. He changed our grading scheme multiple times to try to please people in our class, but it really ended up making no one happy.
Professor has a lot of availability to ensure students understand the concepts. Cares about student's question, concerns, opinions, and feedback.

Professor Sefkow is very nice and cares about students. He is willing to accept feedback and change accordingly. He also provided opportunities to improve grades. This was his first semester teaching the course, so at times it was a little disorganized. I believe in future semesters this will not be a problem.

The class is a tougher course for sure but if you're willing to show you care about the course then Sefkow is more than happy to accommodate and be reasonable. Honestly for an engineering professor he is super fair and really nice, just start the homework early and attend class for the pop quizzes (which he sometimes lets you make up if you missed)
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: The concepts are introduced in class, and writing out textbook examples in homework helps with understanding. The professor is very approachable and understanding. Exam times are sufficient and good for slow workers. However, the course (hw, quiz, exam, project) is not quite following the schedule, kinda hard for people who like to plan ahead.

Professor Sefkow is a very knowledgeable and dedicated person about fluid dynamics. He has a great passion about the subject and clearly wants to share his knowledge with his students. As a first-year teacher in such a comprehensive and intense subject we faced some inconsistencies with the course schedule that he handled very smoothly.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Caring

comment: Professor Sefkow is very smart and dedicated to his profession. He did a solid job teaching ME225 this semester.

Professor Sefkow is very knowledgeable about the topic of Fluid dynamics, It was his first year teaching the course so there were some bumps along the way. He handled these issues to the best of his ability and it ended up being a good class. He was sure to answer any questions in class and go into detail about them so students can understand.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor is very receptive to students, and sets clear expectations for the course! Extra help is made available to complete assignments, and exams are pretty fair if the assignments and recitations are understood.
Professor Sefkow is a great professor. His lectures are clear about the materials and the homework was helpful. He cares about students a lot and he listens to the various opinions.

Professor Sefkow was always receptive to feedback and willing to take accountability. He also was willing to be flexible for students. His teaching style emphasized big-picture ideas rather than getting caught up in little details.

Professor Sefkow is great, but the class itself is challenging. He truly cares for his students and looks for ways to help them improve. The main issue was the class structure and organization overall. His tests are hard since he combines problems from homework/recitation into exam questions to challenge problem-solving skills, so be ready to study

Professor Sefkow cares a lot about this class, but he is too disorganized. The homework keys he used often had errors, he was never clear about the grading system of the class, he set unreasonable assignment deadlines, and he made multiple changes to the syllabus until the end of the semester.

Prof. Stefkow shows great knowledge and enthusiasm for the course he teaches. He has been a bit disorganized with the course schedule, nonetheless he has cared for his students well being and has provided students with as much as information as possible to succeed in his class. There is space for improvement when regarding course structure.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Sefkow is extremely intelligent and coherent during his lectures. He knows how to structure lectures and recitations so that students wish to participate, and it is clear that he wants all of his students to be successful. He is always open to helping a student outside of class, and he makes sure that we all get the assistance we need.
Professor Sefkow was a good teacher, and always was very approachable. It would've been nice to have clear course expectations defined from the start but that's my main gripe.

Cares a ton about students! Has a strong understanding of course content and lectures well. But, his flexibility to 'help' the class grew over the semester into a mess of undefined projects, unclear due dates, and anxiety. He has the personal/academic skills to teach well, but did not display any logical planning in design of course operations.

Professor Sefkow genuinely cares about this course and the student who are taking it. As it is his first year taking this course it is understood that some changes are to be made to the syllabus as the semester goes on. However, I feel he was too accommodating to students in that people took advantage of his flexibility.

Professor Sefkow was teaching the class for his first time so it was a learning experience for him, with a few mistakes here and there, but he was accountable and made up for them. He was open to feedback and constructive criticism which is great. He always tried to understand the student's situation and be academically accommodating when necessary

Professor Sefkow shows respect for students. He is always open to feedback and you can tell that he tries to help students out when he can by offering extra opportunities to improve your grade. However, the course was quite disorganized: he showed up late to class regularly and did not follow the syllabus.

Professor Sefkow is a great professor, his lectures and assignments are explicit and valuable material for the exams he gives. There were a few mix-ups in terms of scheduling in this course but overall he is very caring and considerate of students and their other commitments.

Prof Sefkow is very down-to-earth and funny, it's clear he cares for his students, always asking what he can do to improve. However, he did have a semi-disorganized style that was especially uncomfortable to those who rely on testing accommodations, ie. not knowing when a midterm/quiz is scheduled until days/hours before.
Overall, the professor is doing a good job giving lectures to students. His exam is challenging for students. He cares about students' opinions and always think of improving the teaching methodology

Overall, the professor is doing a good job giving lectures to students. His exam is quite challenging for students. He cares about students' opinions and always think of improving the teaching methodology

He cared a lot about his students and tried to fit the course to their schedules. However, this did lead to a little confusion as the syllabus kept changing. Overall very nice professor who is very interested in the topic he was teaching.
The lecture is taught pretty clear, and the homework is helpful for understanding the main points from the book.

Professor Sefkow is a great professor overall. The lectures tend to move fairly quickly because of the 50 minute class time; however professor Sefkow makes sure to inform students of his availability outside of class. He is very eager to help in office hours and willing to make accommodations to work with students with grading, assignments, etc.

Professor Sefkow is a very friendly and enthusiastic person. He clearly loves teaching and cares a lot about how the students experience the course. His homework are designed to encourage participation during recitation and read the textbook, making the course less stressful while emphasizing the crucial topics.

He cares a lot about the students and the class but was very disorganized and changed the grading scheme too frequently. It was his first year teaching this course so I'm sure that he will have a much better idea of how to organize the class next time.

Professor Sefkow is caring and accommodating as a professor. As a student athlete I had travel come up for a game when one of our tests was scheduled and he made sure to accommodate me taking the exam at a different time. He also is also hosts office hours often to talk about any concerns you may have with the course. Easy to talk to and helpful!

The professor did respect the students as he tried to remember everyone's names. The content of this course is harder than the exam and quiz, but some of the conceptual question and concept are not explain well. You do need to read the textbook inorder to do the homworks and quizzes, but the workshop is useful as half of the hw is covered.

Professor Sefkow is very caring and passionate professor. He always tries to reflect on students' opinions and thoughts, and he tries to give students a variety of chance to improve grades in different ways. Exams might be a bit hard, but if you focus on his lecture and his recitation class, you'll do great in the class.

Professor Sefkow is very friendly and caring for his students. Despite his relative lack of experience in preparing for lectures or the method of organizing rubrics throughout the semester, which involves multiple changes and is pretty confusing, his intention is genuine and respectful.

Overall, the professor is doing a good job giving lectures to students. His exam is quite challenging for students. He cares about students' opinions and always think of improving the teaching methodology.

This professor has a great awareness of students' needs in class and ensures that every student is appropriately addressed according to their needs. He is excellent at teaching and structures his course with recitations which proved helpful. He also provides additional valuable advice to students not doing great in class.

Professor Sefkow knows the material of the course very well and provided reasonable material to go along with it. However, he is very disorganized; often late to class, completely changed the syllabus in the last two weeks of class. Was his first time teaching it so it might be easier for him to plan for things in the future.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Sefkow is an extremely caring and accommodating person. He regularly asked students how they were feeling about the course and welcomed feedback. Lectures were a bit hit-and-miss. Sometimes, he would present the content well and clearly, but other times lecture felt disorganized and confusing. The course generally felt a bit disorganized.
Very reasonable with assignments and exams, just don't try to use the bills as a excuse for a homework extension.

Super nice person, however, lacked in being a great professor. The professionalism has been all over the place this semester with the syllabus changing and often showed up late for class. Syllabus changes were slightly understandable since this was his first semester teaching this course, but threw off students for the expectation of the course.

His tests, weren't very reflective of the homework problems/review given to us. Throughout the semester he's also changed the grading scheme multiple times which seems nice, but with doing this has also made an optional project required with only 2 weeks left in the semester. Prof Sefkow had great intentions, but the way he did it wasn't the best.

Professor Sefkow genuinely cares for the success of his student. He always make sure to ask if students have questions during lecture and is readily available with office hours. The class can sometimes be a bit disorganized since he may occasionally cancel lectures. The recitations are also lackluster since you are just given solutions to problems.

The class is not too bad overall as long as you do the work. Most material is directly from the textbook. I wish he added more practice problems to go over in class. You can tell he cares about his students and gave multiple opportunities to help grades out throughout the semester, even though a few of his test questions were unfair/unclear.

I was pretty nervous about taking fluid dynamics at first, but Dr. Sefkow was able to explain concepts very well and was very accommodating. It's very clear he cares about students actually learning the content and wants everyone to do well. He is very positive and enthusiastic about the subject. He is definitely my favorite engineering professor.

The Professor is approachable both in and out of the classroom, and he will pause for any question a student raises in class and respond to students' problems during his office hour. The content is difficult due to the nature of fluid dynamics, particularly the derivation of equations and concepts, but HW & test problems rely less on hard calculus.

Professor Sefkow is always willing to listen to feedback and truly does carefully consider each student's input when given. He teaches the material effectively and is clear on what material is important during his lectures which is then reflected in the assignments and exams. He is always willing to clarify anything during office hours or by email.

very approachable and helpful professor. exams were really conceptual and hard for me. I did ask for help and he responds well over email and gave some advice. Lots of opportunities for improving grade.

Professor Sefkow takes time go deeper into questions presented in class and reflects an ethusiam over thoughtful questions that I haven't encouned often as a student. He makes an effort to memorize all the names of students in his class which made me feel more seen. It is clear that he enjoys teaching the subject.

Professor Sefkow is incredibly catering towards students. He is constantly offering extra office hours and other resources to help his students. The TA lead recitations are somewhat useless as it heavily relies on the quality of the TA leading. The course grading scheme has changed multiple times throughout the course which has been a bit annoying.

Professor Sefkow is very open to student feedback and answering questions during class. He was easy to talk to and would take student's concerns into consideration when making decisions about the course. The only problem I saw was that things seemed a bit disorganized sometimes.

He is a very respectful professor that cares about his students and their outside commitments. However, he shows up late to almost every class or right at the time lecture starts. He loves to hear feedback from students which is unlike most professors but he had a lack of structure in the course. Overall, I would have him again.

I thought that professor Sefkow did a good job teaching Fluids. He was very respectful and listened to the students. The only complaint I have about this course was that it lacked structure so one could not plan accordingly. Overall I enjoyed this course and learned a lot.

There were a few organization issues on his end making it hard to plan ahead but he was very accommodating and gave us opportunities to gain credit back on assignments and worked to fix any issues. As a lecturer he did an effective job teaching us the information and would check to make sure we got the concepts and you can tell he cares.

Professor Sefkow does a good job of explaining all of the material necessary for the course. The homework and tests come from material covered in lecture, and the assignments do help build understanding for the material. My only gripe is that he is not very organized and his schedule is just wrong, so it is hard to plan ahead for his class at all.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Beware of pop quizzes--Accessible outside class

comment: I had a really good time in this class. He was clear about the subject and found that I enjoyed taking the course far more than I was expecting. It's nice to see a professor that actually cares about the subject matter they're teaching.
Wasn't very clear on course or grading guidelines, but was very accomodating and provided a generous amount of ways to make up for bad performance.

Great professor, very personable and easy to talk to. Very accommodating and understands that students have a lot on their plate. Lots of homework, lots of reading quizzes. Reading quizzes really tested knowledge of the material. Homework tended to be more difficult than the exams.

Very approachable, and was open to feedback regarding the course and teaching. Difficult course in terms of content, but recitations were helpful on the homework and further understanding of the course. Attending lecture and reading helps a lot on some otherwise difficult concepts.

Wasn't clear about course structure and exam dates, but was very flexible and accomodating. Lectures were very focused on derviations of equations rather than their applications. Overall, super nice guy but could have been more organized and structured.
Willing to take feedback and adjust course accordingly

Do not take his class if you want to learn plasma physics. His heavy homework focused on stupid math and could not help students understand course materials. It seemed to me that he was giving a lecture about math rather than plasma physics.

Chris was such a nice and caring professor, with the course material being super interesting too! I wish we had more in person lectures with Chris though, as most of the course was a mix of online modules and in-class discussions with TAs. The grading criteria, and how the attendance would factor into the grade wasn't made very clear either.

Unclear of grading criteria for students and may change it without informing students beforehand. Unreachable outside of a class that is almost entirely asynchronous and pretty much only taught by TAs. Nice and funny guy, but almost impossible to get an A for bogus reasons.

The professor only had two lectures and the rest were asynchronous videos. Grading criteria was not clear on how participation impacts your grade. The out of class discussions can feel forced, most of the time no one has anything to add. Nearly impossible to get a hold of the professor or the grad TAs over email.

I wish I were able to give a more detailed review but I saw the professor twice the whole semester. The class is basically taught be TAs and some videos. The professor only teaches two classes in person. The TA sessions are required and sometimes they feel very forced and the TA just wants everyone to speak even if there is nothing to be said.

Great professor, material is really basic and broad, he made psyc a little bit more interesting. Go to lecture and take notes, rewatch all lectures that will be tested on the exam. Overall just memorize to get A.

By far one of my favorite professors, and I loved that this was one of my very first college courses. Neimeic makes lectures hilarious, interesting, and light to learn, and tests weren't hard either. Mini workshops helped, and his reenacting of Freud's psychosexual theory still is one of my favorite memories. Love to take more of his courses!

Niemiec is a great professor. He explains the content clearly and is super funny! His style is also very passionate and doesn't bore you.  Not hard to get a good grade. 4 easy-medium difficulty tests and a ton of extra credit; like so much extra credit your grade can be raised by a full letter. Please take this course if you can.
Chris has great lectures and the tests are very straightforward if you study. Just know you will have to take mini courses run by the TAs- these don't take a lot of time.

Prof Niemiec keeps lectures light and interesting, stays on topic, and uses personal anecdotes to help students connect with lecture material. Class is easy and manageable if you take good notes and review them regularly.

Christopher is a great professor. Always go to the lectures they are very engaging. The exams are straight forward and easy to do well on if you study. Take lots of notes and go over the slides before exams. There is also an opportunity for extra credit with the mini courses provided.
Chris is so entertaining and his lectures are actually entertaining. Loved this class, made mre realize I want to minor in psych.
Records all lectures so you don't have to attend class if you don't want to., thus practicing what he preaches about self-determination theory and the importance of autonomy in intrinsic motivation.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Chris was a great professor and really funny! It was nice being in a class of all freshmen with a chill professor. The tests aren't hard as long as you effectively study. I got a textbook but it's not necessary (he records all lectures and the test material is only from the lectures, not the textbook)
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Great person and professor. Gives clear and organized lectures that prepare you well for the exams. His class was entertaining and a great introduction to psychology. Made me even more interested in the field. The mini courses were a bit stressful since it was outside of class, but it's not tough. You'll do great just by reviewing lecture slides

Chris is a great guy and his lectures are always entertaining. His tests are multiple choice and are only based on what he says in class, so I wouldn't bother reading the textbook. The mini courses were easier but just annoying to attend outside of class. The whole grade is based on four exams, and there is no final. Great introductory class.

For PSY181, Niemiec is essentially an abstentee, only sometimes popping up into the TA discussions (we all watch the same 5yr old lectures - don't like the lecturing tbh). Don't like the class set up. Exams aren't horrible, but all mc/T/F means a few wrong is a big hit to the grade. This course is a HISTORY of psych course. Title is misleading.

The class is alittle harder than expected. The tests are based half of T/F questions and its annoying. They are also only 25 questions so it is hard to do well. You meet with a TA once a week and discuss the lecture you watched instead of meeting with Niemic. The set up is odd and the class is a little boring, mainly memorization. Hes nice tho

Prof. Niemiec is very passionate and knowledgeable in what he teaches. Lectures are very engaging and informative. The materials in this class are useful and easy to understand, but expect at least 2 research papers to read and 1 essay to write per week. Overall, definitely a class that's worth to take.
He was a pretty awesome lecturer. He grades based off of tests (not cumulative) and mini courses led by TAs. The mini courses are super interesting. Easy class but also informational!

Take him, easy/funny - you dont have to show up to class to get A, he records all lectures. 4 multiple choice tests worth 50 points each. 2 mini courses offered by TAs (attendance and a small asaignments to do- you choose the course) worth 25 points each. 2 discussion/debate session worth 2 points each (for showing up) - can get extra credit

Chris is essentially everything you want for a professor, especially for an introductory class. He is well spoken, funny, and he makes the material as interesting and engaging as possible. The classes were lecture heavy but I think that's more a result of the psych 101 material itself.

I know that PSYC101 typically an easy course, but I guess the hard part about this one was the lack of grades being put in. Most exams happened to be when I had exams for engineering or papers for writing due, so it was hard to find time to study for an elective. I did pretty well with minimal studying and there is extra credit and mini courses.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: For intro psych, the tests are multiple-choice which is a real blessing. His lectures are straight forward and he tells personal stories which helps keep students engaged. He's funny and laid back. I would recommend this to everyone, especially pre-meds.
Compassionate. Supportive. Compelling lecturer. Lots of theoretical knowledge. The readings and classes are 110% worth your time and effort. Manageable workload.
Amazing guy! Clearly passionate, and so will you be after you take his classes!

grading was super late and i had written half of the essays before one was graded. weekly in person recitations and zoom workshops. intensely boring lectures. i felt like i was just regurgitating information for a grade.

Chris is awesome, especially considering the online format because of COVID. Grade is based on a few 50 question multiple choice tests w/ explanation, open note. Tests are easy, if you watch the lectures. Also, you have attend some mini-courses taught by the TA. Overall a positive low-stress class to take with some interesting material.

Almost all of the grading is based on the exams which can contain very obscurely-formatted questions a lot of the time. All of the lectures are pre-recorded so you can watch them when you like but you must watch them if you want to pass the exams. You're gonna be talked at for 2.5 hours every week and you need to scribble down notes. Very boring.

taking notes for his recorded lectures were hard for me because he covers a lot, so attending in-person was a must for me. Plus, I liked going to his lectures because it's always a good time. Exams are straight memorization from the lectures because it's multiple choice. Great and easygoing guy. If you're going to take PSY 101, take him!

Chris is a really inspiring lecturer that'll change your life for the better. Learning about motivation is really important and interesting, even to a non-psychology student. The class is really easy if you do all the papers and attend the lectures (they're recorded too!). I would take Niemiec again in a heartbeat
Literally just show up for a good time, super great personality, and entertaining lectures.
He is a good professor who would record his own lecture and post after the class. The exams are always covered in the lectures. So be prepared for reviewing the videos before the exam.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Chris is a great professor and a cool person. He is very interactive with the students on class, and he always keeps the lecture exciting. The material is easy and all tests were multiple choice. Mini courses outside of lecture were also interesting and were easy points towards your grade.

The structure of this class was very different than any other psych class I had taken. It was nice to be able to watch the modules on your own time and I found my discussion group helpful. Chris is a great guy and his videos were very straight forward, but I think for this course in particular, you interact with the TAs way more.

Psych is a lot of common sense and especially in this intro class, so if you've got your head on straight you'll definitely pass and probably do well without too much effort. Don't bother getting the textbook, only his lectures matter. He is entertaining, posts lectures online, but going to class is worthwhile bc he's funny.
He may be fun but the lecture halls are too big for him to actually care about you and your struggles in his class

Had a really bad experience with the first essays in recitation, where everyone got a fifty percent or below because the grads and undergrads were saying different things about the grading criteria. Niemiec's response to this was saying that our grades don't matter as much compared to the material we learn in class.
Would definitely take this class again, Chris was an incredible Professor and the course was interesting.

He is really fun and makes the lectures entertaining, I didn't do amazingly in the class because I struggle with multiple choice and there was soooo much content but he is a really good professor and really good at explaining.
Very multiple choice test heavy, which can be a good thing. Lectures are amazing.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: If you study (which you should), you'll be just fine. He is a charismatic professor who cares about his students and makes lectures interesting, I would definitely take again!

Fun and interesting lectures, but not an easy A class. You'll do well if you're good at specific multiple choice questions. Class seems too big for him to care about his students. Not sure if he's too useful for specific/personal questions...
This man is the greatest teacher i have ever had. I love him so much. he makes the class fun, he's organized and he is just an amazing prof all over

He records his lecture so attendance is not mandatory. Overall, I thought the class was very easy. Exams are multiple choice. Make sure you study all your notes and memorize them. Even though I thought the class was easy, I did not do extremely well on all the exams so make sure to do the extra credit which will bump up your grade say from B+ to A-

Make sure you do the extra credit. I think a lot of people go in expecting an easy A. Well let me just tell you that the average exam grade was usually a low to mid B. Trust me, there are plenty of people getting below an A- in that class. Make sure you actually take notes and everything. It's not too difficult, but I wouldn't say an easy A

This was a very easy class. Tests were simple, mostly you just have to memorize vocabulary. However, his recorded lectures were impersonal, and they were incredibly boring. The discussion response papers were not graded efficiently. By the time I submitted the 6th, I had only received feedback on two. I will be avoiding Chris' classes in the future

He's my favorite prof that I've ever had. He wants you to want to learn, and doesn't force anything (he talks frequently about his hatred of exams). He talks a lot about his family and how the material applies to life, which is great. He makes you feel like a person, not just a student. All his lectures are put online as well.  10/10!

Professor Niemic was such a cool guy and showed a lot of passion in what he taught. The class topics were really interesting and there was not a lot of work. As long as you understood the main points of his lectures and show up to the mini-courses,  you should get an A.
Chris is the GOAT. As long as you take notes on everything he says in class and study off of that the night before the exam, you will get at least a B+.

This class was one my favorites throughout all of college. Niemiec makes his classes so that if you come to the required discussion sessions/recitations, do the required work, and study for his exams, you will get an A. His tests and assignments are super fair and the materials are interesting. He is also very relaxed and seems to love his job.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: Well the class was divided into an online module version and an out of class discussion session. The modules are watched at our own pace, but it's a ton of material and it took me three hours worth of time to note everything. The out of class discussion was useless, as it didn't really add to anything. The exams were very fair.

Very straightforward class. The exam questions come from all of his online lectures and are factual in nature. A lot of different personality theories in this course but most of them were covered briefly in his psy 101 class too.

Really great lecture, does a good job of making things interesting. The only grades are the 4 tests, but they are  all 50 multiple choice and fairly easy.  He does assign the textbook, but you really don't need it and you don't need to read it.
Easy class to pass. Just have to memorize and you're fine. The SONA extra credit is also helpful.
Easiest class ever.

Chris Niemiec is the man take his class it's very straight forward and not hard at all. He really cares about his students and the class is an interesting, easy class to make life easier first semester freshmen year. All his students love him.

The class is a joke, and I kind of hate it. Psych itself is really interesting though, but the class isn't about learning psych, it's about figuring out what's on the exam. The lectures are recorded, it's a walk in the park.

Tests are super easy, and you do not need to show up for classes to get an A. However, he recited the lecture and it's boring and rigid. The classes are good for non-psych majors with mere interests, but for people who wish a deeper career in the area, it's not as helpful.

If you want any easy A, take this class. You get out of it what you put in, but he presents it as a game to figure out what's on the exam, not about learning the concepts. It was interesting however, and it was a good first exposure to psychology.

He's a good professor overall, but lectures were SO FREAKING BORING. Sometimes he would say something hilarious and we would wake up, but overall he just read the slides. "turn now to another consideration" is burned into my brain. But the class was a typical intro course. Nothing too hard.

Chris' freshman psych class was one of my favorites. He gives you every opportunity to succeed (putting noteslecture recordings online, test review sessions, and make-up tests), but his lectures are also fun and engaging. Even though I could skip class I never wanted to because it was always fun.
Chris is a great lecturer. The points are clear and straightforward. The videos are posted on blackboard so you can choose to learn at dorm. I register his PSY262 for next semester.

Chris is a great, and in my opinion the best, professor in the psych department!  He leads all of his classes from an SDT perspective so you have a lot of choice regarding the class and he is extremely open to feedback.  You will not only love Chris, but also the class material!  He is also a very approachable professor
Niemiec is very passionate, though his lectures may drag and lack in organization sometimes. He is however a great lecturer and tests are easy if you pay attention during lecture.

Tons of philosophical theory in this class, which can be pretty dry.  Memorize absolutely everything for the exams and be ready to spit it back up verbatim in the short answer section.  MC is pretty easy.  Its sad because Niemiecs an awesome prof and the material in this class is just terrible so he'll probably get an undeserved bad rep.
He was a terrible teacher who never used the textbook. His test was just based on memorizing his lectures.

He does not use the text books. Tests are based on what he says in class. He records his lectures and has them (and his powerpoints) available online. However, for the tests, he wants you to memorize EVERYTHING he's ever said and use his words. Paraphrasing the concepts in your own words won't get you any points.
Awesome guy and enjoyable class.

Chris is awesome (prefers to be called chris as opposed to Professor Niemiec). Very funny and keeps class very interesting. If you study for the test and now how the stuff relates you will get an A. No final exam which was huge

Prof. Niemiec is a great professor and clearly loves what he does. His lectures a crystal clear and he records them in case you missed anything. He also is very reasonable with tests and grading. It seems that it would be very hard to fail even if you were trying to. All in all, Prof. Niemiec comes highly recommended.

Niemiec is an awesome lecturer.  Speaks very clearly, really well-prepared, knows his stuff.  Definitely recommend downloading the powerpoints before class and taking notes on your laptop.  Exams are multiple choice and non-cumulative - easy if you study.  There are two short papers that are pretty painless. If you like psych this is a great class

Good lecturer, seems to have powerpoints memorized. Posts recordings online of class in case you miss something, which is quite helpful.  Always willing to answer questions for clarity.  Definitely knows his stuff

People rating Prof. Niemiec's courses as easy or boring have not taken any of his upper level classes where he truly shines. Good speaker, if a tad bit sarcastic at times, and a great professor to boot. Very knowledgeable in material and helpful at the same time. Lectures are online, but go to class - saves you a lot of trouble in the long run.

Niemiec is a strong lecturer - very articulate, clear and open to questions. The textbook is not necessary (all pertinent info is covered in class) and the exams are EXTREMELY easy, as long as you attend lecture and put in a little extra studying time.

Very boring class and very boring lectures! But overall, I would take this class because it is an easy A as long as you go to class and memorize every slide. The final is not comprehensive. Four exams about 5-6 lectures each. You just have to memorize all the lectures and the class should be easy for you! Great class for freshman!
Awful class, great professor. He's funny and entertaining. Definitely a great speaker. His exams have no surprises or trick questions. He even posts lectures online. Great guy.
He is mad cool. Really easy class. Pretty interesting. No need to buy text book.

lectures are extremely interesting, tests are easy multiple choices, no need to get the textbook at all. He records all his lectures and they are available on iTunes, so you can study at home without going to classes. very nice guy, my favorite prof in the psy department! strongly recommand
Easy test, boring lecture but very clear and to the point
Take this class. Tests are easy and based entirely off of lectures, which he records and puts on itunes.

Everything about this class is very clear.  He gives you the powerpoints beforehand and if you study those, your notes from class, and the bolded terms from the text you'll get an A no problem.  Coming to class will really help but you could get most of the info from the text if you wanted.  Overall a great course!

He was clear and talked slowly enough, so note-taking was a breeze. He even posted the slides beforehand and videos of lectures after class. The tests were incredibly easy (50 multiple choice) but I found that there were always at least a few vague questions. However I was bothered by Niemiec's speaking. Something about his syntax was irritating!

Niemiec was a great professor. You could definitely tell that he had prepared his lectures well. In addition, he video taped all of his lectures, so if you missed class, you could watch the lecture you missed. Tests were very easy; just 50 multiple choice questions. If you reviewed his lectures, you would do fine.
Although his speech becomes difficult to understand at some points, he is a very nice guy and a very knowledgeable teacher. Definitely better than most.
Really clear and helpful, tries to benefit student as much as he can.
So he uses really bad syntax and talks too much, but other than that, great guy. You don't have to do the readings and the tests are easy
this class is fine, but extremely boring. you learn the same thing every lecture, just with slight variation. its all memorization and the true/false is really obnoxious.
He gives hard tests for a psych class. All the info you need for this class is on the powerpoints, and he records and posts his lectures on blackboard. He's a fair teacher

Uggghhhh. Prepare to be bored out of your ind for 1hour and 15min a day if you take PSY181. He repeats himself over and over, talks in a monotone voice, and paces back and forth. He clearly knows the material, but he presents even the most interesting of theories in a way that makes you wish you were anywhere but that lecture hall.
Chris is a great professor. He kept class interesting and as long as you paid attention in lecture you did fine. Was very clear and easy to understand in lecture.
I found this class quite challenging. Was not really clear to me what was important and not. Eventhough I did not do well in the class, the class was enjoyable and interesting.
Awesome professor! Take this class!

Very approachable guy. He really makes an effort to get to know his students by name. Very flexible when it comes to tests. Stresses the importance of learning over just receiving a good grade. He's a great guy, and if your interested in psych, i  recommend this class!
He's such a nice guy and the class is really simple. Just read the textbook and go over the lectures. He's very clear and obviously loves what he's doing.

He is one of the best psych professors I've had, you can tell he is very knowledgable and passionate..he has done a lot of interesting research and always has good examples and stories..very nice and understanding too
Clear, organized, and very approachable.

Chris is a very clear teacher.  The videos of the class are extremely helpful in studying at home.  The exams are fair.  Lots of essays but if you do your studying, you will do well.  I have taken 2 of his classes and will be in a third next semester.
omg one of the worst psych "professors" (he's a grad student) in the department. rambles, talks in circles, totally unclear. class was absolutely painful.
Very nice. Video tapes all lecture and put online for you to view. Don't even have to go to class!

Loved this class and Dr Davis is hands down my favorite professor here. The best advice to do well in this class is just REALLY familiarize yourself with the paper structure because it's always going to be the same.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The material is interesting but in order to get an A, be prepared to spend every day looking at notes. You'll have to study your butt off if you don't memorize things quickly. Expect to study ~14 hours a week (at least) to memorize everything well. This class made me emotionally numb and I burnt out quickly. Don't take it if you don't need it
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: the nicest professor ever. his exams are really difficult though. you need to understand his questions and try to predict them. lecture heavy. highly recommend going and/or watching the old recordings he provides

Having him for a year in 110/201, I say he is very passionate about the material, caring and accessible, and an all-around respected professor. My suggestion for studying would be drawing on a whiteboard, writing down notes of recitation concepts, understanding his testing style, active studying, and getting OH with either TAs/Davis. All the best.

Dr. Davis has so much passion for what he teaches, and his lecture style really did help me grasp super hard concepts. Extremely effective professor. I looked forward to his lecture every M/W/F. Probably the most difficult exams I've taken in my life (you do have to get used to his question style) but otherwise a great time.
His fits and tests could use some work but he's chilling fr. Very content-dense lectures.
K dawg is the man. Best professor at UR hands down no questions asked.
really difficult tests given by one of my favorite professors on campus. don't take it if you don't have to, unless you want to. in that case, enjoy it!
Kevin is the best teacher I've ever taken in U of R. He's fun and really excited about his teaching. However, be ready to fail his class since he's the worst grader.

Its hard to enjoy a class with such hard exams and content but Kevin Davis really did a great job. I really enjoyed his class and the content but you really cannot get through this with a good grade unless you study. He is also extremely understanding and accommodating! I highly recommend his classes but do beware that it might hit your gpa.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: He did a great job, his lectures were clear and posted in case you need to rewatch them, and he was very clear about what you would be tested on. Generally a great teacher. However, the class is incredibly difficult because of the sheer amount of material within it. It sets up a great basis for the rest of the major but it is so damn hard.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Loved the material of the class and the professor. Didn't love the tests. Probably spent 15-20 hours a week studying, and even with the curve averaged out an 88. Study a LOT for the exams and review the material the day you get it. There is tons of content loaded into his lectures, but it's generally easy to understand if you go to lecture and rec.

Dr. Davis is a great professor. His lectures are well-organized, entertaining, and super informative. That being said, this was the hardest class I have taken at U of R. If you haven't taken BCS 110 before hand, prepare to learn a lot of material and feel way behind. That being said, he is super accessible out of class and cares about students.
Professor Davis is truly one of the most caring professors on campus. He actually wants you to succeed. There was also a lot of generous curves given on the exams.

Dr. Davis gives high-quality lectures and the slides are of the most organized among all courses in the university. He is caring and accessible after class and gives extra office hours before exams. His exams are truly tricky, but if you organize your notes and try to think a step forward and predict what will be on the exam, you will be fine.
He is one of the best professors I met at UR. He is caring and he explains concepts clearly. The course is interesting but really time-consuming. There is too much content to remember and understand.
Lectures are fun & enjoyable, however there are only 4 tests & an optional final so beware... Pls go to lectures he talk about what he'll test on in lectures only, and you need to study a lot. A LOT.
Super hard to get an A. As someone who cram a lot, I feel my brain is about to  explode every time before the exam. The course is informative and interesting, except that it may destroy your gpa!

I love Professor Davis, he was so amazingly helpful in office hours and he has a really big curve. I took BCS 110 as a transfer student who was not familiar at all with how harsh the U of R education system was going to be, and he made it a really welcoming experience for me personally .I think his lectures are fair and you need to study though!

Very engaging and interesting professor who has great lectures, just a very difficult and lecture/test-heavy class with lots and lots of studying outside of lectures. Despite all, he grades pretty fairly and passing is very feasible. It's just getting an A that is extremely difficult.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: BCSC 110 is my second course with Dr. Davis, and I have grown to like him and his classes a lot more because I am prepared for the workload (which is a lot). Go to class and record the lectures yourself (the older recordings are less relevant). Pay attention and write down every word, reorganize the content later, and ask him questions to survive.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Davis has the most organized, detailed, and understandable lecture slides of all my professors. You could ask him anything you want during his office hours. You can't give him a low rating just because you didn't put in enough effort. The content is challenging, but not impossible, given the generous curves that he gives on every exam.

Prof Davis is such an amazing prof and person. You can tell he is super engaged in his material. BSC 110 is just an extremely hard course, but he makes it his best to make it engaging. He is very animated.The curve in the class is insane, the tests are like no other. The entire class is pure memorization. Be prepared to study and study for the exam
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Amazing professor who actually knows a lot about his area of study and is genuinely focused on teaching. However content are hard and exams are harder. Curves helps but each lecture and exam results just leaves me so strained and hopeless. If you are a very sciency person who wants to learn lots about bioscience go ahead

Super great lecturer but tests were no joke. The curve works in your favor so most people don't do worse than a B- but you definitely have to put a lot of effort in to do well and understand the concepts.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Nice as a person and lecturer but he made this class so much harder than it has to be and will not recommend if 110 is not mandatory in your major

Dr. Davis is a hilarious and engaging lecturer, however I found his lectures very confusing. His tests are notoriously nuanced, specific, and difficult. He will re-do lectures for you in office hours which is great. If you want to do well in this class, expect to study A LOT. I also hope you like memorizing tables and diagrams...

Dr. Davis is a hilarious and engaging speaker. I felt more alert in his class than in any others I took this semester, and he definitely put his heart and soul into lecturing. That said, the recitations are mediocre at best and the tests are unnecessarily arcane. Dr. Davis and BCS 110 demand a lot for you, don't underestimate the low course number.

His lectures are quite engaging, but there is so much content to learn that the exams are really difficult. The wording of his exams can really trip you up so asking clarification questions on the exam is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. I recommend going to office hours too. You need to think like Davis thinks, and not just know the content...
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Great lectures. Tests are super nuanced and difficult, great curves though. Tests are on his lectures, you don't need to get a textbook. You need to study hard if you want to do well.

Professor Davis is a really funny and great lecturer but really does not care about his students' success. His exams are hard and he usually writes them the night before so you do not know what he could be adding to them. To do well in this class you really need a good TA.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: He's a really engaging and thoughtful professor. He puts everything in a way you will understand and he's accessible outside lecture if you need help. As long as you study really really hard, you'll be okay. If you put the effort into the class, you'll get a good grade since his curves are really good.

He is an interesting lecturer and this class got me interested in cognitive science, but he makes his test unnecessarily hard. He curves every exam average to an 83 so if you study hard you'll be fine, but there is absolutely a way to teach the same material without such difficult exams, and that is the only thing your grade is based on.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: DR.Davis is my favourate prof of university. He is so nice and helpful, give clear and good lectures. And he is Always delighted to help us on Office hours. I also took BCS110 and would like to take more of his lectures. His tests are hard.

If you're someone who crams, you will fail. I can personally tell you that you should be scared if you always cram lol. I do mean this is the best way possible. I did take the class online and so he made it more difficult so others wouldn't cheat, but even then, please go to lectures. The exams were multiple choice (online) and he made it so hard.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Loved the class! By far my favorite class and I took it online. Professor Davis is a great lecturer and explains complex topics in way that is interesting and makes the class fun! :)
Dr.Davis is super nice and experienced. Give good lectures and explains everything very clearly. But his course isn't easy, get ready!

My absolute favorite professor this semester. Funny, clearly cares and wants you to succeed, and his lectures are well organized and clear. Extremely difficult topics so you’ll need to study a lot but exams are generously curved. Go to his office hours too; he’s super nice and always willing to help!

In order to do well, you will have to memorize every single detail of what he says and puts in the lectures. No getting around it because most test questions include multiple concepts stacked on each other. But, his info is organized nicely on the slides and if you study A LOT, you can do well .
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Davis is definitely one of my favorite professors. He is very organized during lectures, and often uses understandable analogies when teaching a complicated concept. If you go to lectures, work hard, and make sure you understand everything, the exams shouldn't be that hard.

Dr Davis is amazing, the best professor I've ever had. The tests for 110 are very hard but he curves them to make the average an 83% which is really nice. The lectures are engaging and he makes them interesting. It is clear he really knows what he is talking about. Office hours are a little scary but helpful
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: What a guy. This class has pretty difficult content that's mostly memorization, but he makes a dry subject genuinely enjoyable. The grade is based on 3 midterm exams and an optional final that can replace your lowest midterm, and he curves 40-50s to an 80.
Dr. Davis, So many things to say. What a silly goose. Live Love Tables.

Professor Davis was a great professor, he always explained the material very clearly and he was happy to meet outside of class to answer questions. The exams were open note, with a moderate amount of studying it wasn't hard to get an A with the curve, but they would be a lot harder if not open note (I think they aren't during non-covid).
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Every test class average was somewhere around 50% -- Davis crams so much into his lectures that it's honestly impossible to really remember all the information, much less know it how he wants you to know it. Studying will probably leave you at an alright spot after the curve.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr. Davis is an amazing professor and truly loves studying the brain. He has so much energy when he lectures and in office hours, is always laughing. The exams are extremely tough and I'm sure without open notes, I would not have done so well. However, I would 10/10 take another class with him.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor Davis is incredible! I took his BCS 110 class, took his NSC 201 class while TA-ing for his BCS 110 class. I love this professor's passion, and if you show you are interested and go to his office hours, he'll be happy to talk about the material. The tests are the hardest tests I have ever taken, but the curve is generous! Highly recommend!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: In BCSC 110, each unit is packed with information. It's pretty hard to remember it all. Because of COVID, this year it was open note and idk how I'd pass if it wasn't. The average grades are still pretty poor even with notes, but the curve will definitely save you. I got a 43 on a test and the curve brought me to an 85.

Kevin Davis was an engaging professor and made lectures fun, but the brain diagrams on his exams are insane and he has to curve test averages to a B-. One of the toughest courses I've taken at U of R.

Davies is an entertaining professor, but this is definitely a tough course. You really have to memorize everything and anything that is taught in class. Also it's impossible to get an A on tests but the curves will save you a ton. Wish the tests were more reflective of how much you study but oh well.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Dr. Davis is an incredible professor. The material is difficult to grasp at first and he doesn't record lectures so you really need to pay attention in class. Study every slide and memorize as much as you can and you'll be fine. If you aren't a big memorization person, this class isn't for you.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Kevin Davis is a really funny, interesting, and knowledgeable lecturer and professor, however his exams are incredibly difficult. Went to him to see how else I could be studying and he told me I was doing everything I could, yet my scores were never where I wanted them to be. Interesting course, but be prepared to study like a mad man

Davis is an amazing professor however his tests are extremely difficult. the avg for each exam is around 50% but theres a heavy curve which will save you! MUST go to class , lectures are all his tests are.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Great prof! Hard grader but worth it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Davis is a cool guy. Would love to take another of his classes.
Loved his teaching style - he is able to explain complex concepts well and uses relevant examples. Funny guy too. REALLY hard tests but he is often available for extra help.

I usually get 9 hours of sleep each night, but I still SOMEHOW fell asleep every single day in his class. BCS110 is a nightmare. His class is not worth it. He makes exams way harder than they need to be and it almost feels like he enjoys seeing all of his students get stressed when midterms come around.

He is THE best professor. His lecture is so fun so interesting. Don't think it's hard as the curve is too high. I got a couple full marks. (even though my raw marks are not 100) You will definitely fall in love with him after you take his lecture. I promise.
Great class, great professor
His lectures were clear and necessary to understand the material. He is energetic and passionate about the topics which motivated everyone to pay attention and actually enjoy the course.

Davis is a great professor, but only for students with a particular style of learning. If you can absorb and memorize information just by hearing it presented in lectures, you'll be fine. You will be responsible for a lot of information on his exams, which are unnecessarily challenging. Get ready to spend a lot of time in the library.

Kevin Davis is one of my favorite professors at U of R. His lectures are very well organized with a fun delivery. His tests are very hard however, they require a lot of memorization and even then the questions can be vague as to what he wants for an answer.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Tests are tough

comment: A model of consistency. Always has quality lectures with quality energy. I am a math major who doesn't really care at all about this topic, but he made it interesting enough to make me want to learn/get an A (as opposed to declaring pass/fail).
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Davis is passionate about neuroscience. His lectures are well organized and the way he teaches is exciting. The content is difficult, but as long as you study and pay attention, the class is fine and is very interesting.
rating_tags: TEST HEAVY--Tests are tough--Would take again

comment: At the beginning this year, I took his class as a requirement for Psychology major but then I switched to become a Math major. technically, I can just declare P/F in his class but I didn't because I love his teaching style and his passion for the material! His tests are challenging they are curved nicely!
One of my favorite professors! Great lecturer! Tests are hard but he tells you what you need to know if you go to lecture. No textbook needed.
I think it's hard to teach a class of more than 50 people, so given that, Proff Davis does a good job. Otherwise, I'm not a fan of the class.
Wonderful wonderful lecturer. The way he talks makes me feel intrigued with the material!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: He is the best professor as you can learn stuff and really get help

I loved taking his class. Obviously there are some topics that can be pretty boring, but he is a great professor. I would totally recommend. He is a fair grader and his exams are also fair. It is not mandatory to attend his class, but it would only benefit you more.
I enjoy his lectures so much! His style of teaching is engaging and inspiring. The recitations are helpful in connecting what he said in class. Never Regret taking his class!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof Davis is a great lecturer and really passionate about what he's teaching. Things on class is important for students to get a good grade in tests, so I would say definitely attending the class. Because of little backgrounds on Bio and Chem, I faced a hard time in taking all the information. The tests is specific and require lots of memorizing.

You can tell that he cares about what he teaches.  Every lecture is very involved and you will learn a lot in this course.  The tests are straightforward and he answers questions very well.  Overall, this is a great class and made me even more interested in pursuing my major.

He really knows his stuff and his lectures are pretty interesting if you care about the material. Tests are hard and 100% of the grade, so be ready to study, but he curves the average to an 83 so don't be too scared. Textbook optional, but can help reinforce lectures. Overall I thought he was a really great professor. Challenging, but rewarding.
