His lectures are excellent. He takes the book notes and makes them much clearer and more easily understood. Take his old exams as practice because they will be very similar to the exam given. Workshop is also very important to go to and very helpful in learning the material. He's funny and the class is very good, although the final was brutal.

Dr. Goodman needs to retire and give someone else with more patience and passion the opportunity to teach. I was really looking forward to phys org, but this man made it out to be a complicated mess. He is a great guy, but not a very good professor. SKIP!

He's hard, but if you have a good workshop leader and pay attention in class it is passable. Grades are only based on a few tests, and they're incredibly hard, but if you try to answer every question the curve will save you, and you can drop a test. He can be funny, and though some students find him uncaring I just think he has high standards

To be honest, he likes his quest students more. He also does not like pre-meds as most chem professors do not, becuase of the general idea of not wanting to learn, but just needing the most points for med school. Organic Chemistry is tough and you either get it or have to really really work for it. He is very helpful, approachable, and practical.

Goodman teaches a very tough subject, but does an incredible job of explaining concepts in understandable ways. Sometimes he goes a little heavy on mechanisms, but his workshops and examples offer a lot of clarity. The best thing about Goodman is that he is EXTREMELY approachable and will help you understand to the best of his ability.
The lectures are not clear . The contents of exams are all from workshops instead of lectures.

Going in, I thought Prof. Goodman was going to be tough and intimidating. Never before have I been so relieved to find this was not the case. He is incredibly down to earth and, more than once, got the entire class to laugh at his jokes. He is very student-oriented, so as long as you try your best and show you care, you'll be fine. Great professor.

Orgo's a pretty rough class to begin with and he doesn't make it any better.  Has no problem yelling at and belittling students in office hrs. Lectures are somewhat helpful but often unclear.  Book is virtually useless except for some practice problems.  Get your hand on as many old exams as possible and go to all the workshops.

So, Goodman inspires strong opinions. You can tell from the other comments. Here's my take: his primary goal is to teach you to think and reason like a scientist. To that end, he did his job (at least for me) and I learned a ton. Homework and workshop really are key to an A. Don't be petty, and he's friendly enough. Hard class but nicely curved.

His class is hard, no doubt about that. He wants you to learn to think like a scientist so that may frustrate some people. He can be borderline mean if you rub him the wrong way, but can also be really nice and helpful if you show an interest. Book problems and workshops are KEY to success. Handwriting kinda sloppy, but all info needed is there.

Goodman's awesome! Witty, sarcastic, funny, and expert in his subject. Runs a difficult class, but if you work hard you should be able to get at least a B-. Friendly in office hours if you approach him correctly.

Great but challenging professor. Lectures are interesting in that he presents observations and real experimental data and then shows us how it all fits with the current topic. If you desire to learn (fake it if you have to!), he's helpful in office hours. If you just want more points on your test, prepare to be belittled. He can tell.
Good prof. A little intimidating, but helpful if he sees you're willing to learn. Exams are very similar to practice tests and workshop problems. He loves to make you think.

Like someone else said, he's all business and not warm and fuzzy like some other professors. But he really made me appreciate and enjoy organic chem, even though I disliked chemistry previously. He's got a witty, dry sense of humor, and his lectures make you think-they aren't just reams of information to memorize. Exams are very fair.

His class is conceptual and he loves to make you think, but his exams are very fair and reflect the practice tests and workshops. He covers all the material in lecture, and is very helpful in office hours. He's very approachable when students make a sincere effort to learn, but can be nasty if they act like they obviously dislike the subject.

One of the worst professors I have ever had.  I cannot understand why he is permitted to teach orgo to non-majors when he clearly resents it so much. His lectures are transcribing notes, handwaving theory and tend not to help with the exams.  Exam material is taught in workshop, which means you are entirely at the mercy of your TA.
Does not care about his graduate students, does not help in trying to understand graduate material. Rushes through lecture notes fast. Does not understand the material.

Goodman is alright teacher, sit up front and you will do fine. do all the practice exam so you get accustom to his type of question. His exams are challenging but worthwhile and fun. Don't expect to get clear answer from him, Read the text and go to workshop.

I got an A-. Lectures present impt info, but lectures are confusing because he includes lots of extra, not needed info. Exams are hard, but questions are VERY SIMILAR to practice exams AND workshops. Class is crazy curved so aim to get above average. Always understand and memorize practice exams cuz you never know what will be on the test.

Goodman is what you can expect of an Organic Chemistry professor. He doesn't joke around or give free points- he wants you to earn your grade. His tests are fair and you will learn everything that is on the test (even if its a small section of the notes). Just go to workshops, follow the notes, and memorize what he tells you too

He's got a sense of humor, so lecture is interesting. He presents the material by giving observations first and letting the class work out how it fits together. It's extremely useful. He's a nice enough guy, and answers questions clearly. But his handwriting is pretty bad. If you aren't listening when he writes something, abandon all hope.
ok professor. Tests are kind of tough. Not too bad though

He's a great teacher- to the point and very fair. If you study class notes, attend workshops and listen carefully to what he says you will do well. To me, his explanations were a lot better than the book's so I didn't really find the book helpful at all for the course.

This guy is all business, and because of this, he can come off as cold and abrasive. However, if you put the effort in, attend class and workshops, and study on your own, you should do fine. The tests are very fair and you get to drop one. Has bad handwriting and makes the final more difficult than the rest, but curves to a B. Recommended.

Least helpful person I have ever met.  He clearly is only interested in his research and only teches in order to be allowed to do this research.  Way harder than a professor needs to be in order to teach and orgo class.

Organic Chemistry is a hard class. You have to put work in it for sure. I felt that his lectures corresponded with the textbook except for the exceptions HE mentions. His tests are "fair" meaning if you go to class and workshop you will be fine. Also make sure your TA is smart. Goodluck to everyone about to take orgo...get that A!
He's friendly and has a good sense of humor, but not the best at actually teaching. It was tough to follow what was going on and he frequently disagreed with material from the book.

Goodman is a funny genius. People who complain about his class are those who fail to use all their resources to fully understand the material. Go to class because he has his own opinions about chemistry. He is what a professor should be: presents ideas and formulates material such that you must put it together into a logical percept. Just keep up.
He is just too smart. You learn a lot in class but most of the time I have no clue what is happening in class. Although reading the book before lectures can help sometimes

He is literally the Antichrist. Horrible handwriting, absolutely no explainations, and when I went to him for help he told me I was just stupid. Has made similar comments to friends, telling them they are wasting his time and they are idiots. Evil evil man with no teaching abilities and unwillingness to actually teach. Avoid at all costs.

The only problem with Dr Goodman is that he's too smart. His lectures are like a bad essay - no connections until the very end, but then everything falls together with some explanation. And some reading. On your own. Of the textbook.

I attended class for the sarcasm and amusing comments but should have stayed home in terms of learning. Class was lists of data and diagrams, all written messily with nearly no explanation. Tests were funny--because there was no way we could solve the problems.

Good Professor. First one to actually get me to appreciate a class. His exams were rather enjoyable. It wasn't stressful taking any of them. I would recommend that any student interested in organic chemistry should take this course with Doc Goodman!! Two thumbs up!!

One of the most likable professor I have ever had. He might seem like a sarcastic jerk in class but go to talk to him even once in office hours and you will see what an awesome professor he is. He is brilliant. He cares about the well being of the students and will not let you down. He is HILARIOUS! I had a LOT of fun taking his exams.GREAT prof.
This guy does not deserve to be a professor. He's dead weight and should be removed from the department.
Very intelligent and willing to help. Slightly disorganized but brought donuts to tests. Tests were not that bad.
Very thorough and clear in his teaching and notes.  Helpful in class or in office hours if you have questions.  Good sense of humor too, pretty sarcastic.
This guy will make you appreciate Dinnocenzo even more.
No one in the class does well, everyone just does lesser degrees of bad. We shouldn't have to say "Sweet! I got a 54 on my last test!"

At first you might think that he is not a very good teacher.  However, if you stay in the class you will start to understand the way he teaches and the material will seem easier to you.  He's actually nice to his students- just ask him questions and he'll answer them quite clearly.  A good prof.

I had him when he first started teaching second semester Orgo and he had no idea how to present the information. I'm assuming he's gotten better since then, but to his credit, he is very open to student opinions if the class as a whole doesn't like something.

I don't understand why so many people don't like him. Yes, in the beginning, when he goes through stuff that he expects you to know, he goes very quickly and is hard to understand. But once he gets to new stuff he is VERY thorough and very clear. He's even amusing. I think he's an excellent professor.

Everyone gives this guy a bad rep because he goes very fast, but he is very passionate about the subject and care a great deal about the students.  He is thorough with the material and while he does go fast sometimes, he makes sure everyone understands it before he moves on.
he is the wost teacher i have ever had.
He throws a bunch of crap at you without explaining it. I'd rather have a teacher who explains what the stuff we are reading is all about, and when it's helpful, rather than relying on luck.

He's not a bad professor, despite everyone's opinion. Once you get accustomed to his dry humor, sarcasm, and bluntness, he's actually pretty funny. He may come off indifferent at first, but he actually wants you to learn the material.

He actually isn't that bad of a professor, in my opinion.  He's pretty straightforward in what he wants.  Basically, go to lecture, go to workshop, make some notecards, and you'll be fine on the exam.  I have a B and I haven't even touched the book.  People may think he's rude, but in his review sessions he's very personable.
Pretty good

I have never been more disgusted with a teaching style. He actually had the nerve to use another professor's lecture notes (from a previous year) to teach the class. Aka he copied onto the board, at a superhuman pace, a ton of material that he himself couldn't explain or justify. Whatever institution gave him his PhD should be ashamed.
Among the worst at Rochester
One of the worst if not THE WORST professors I have ever had. He is a horrible teacher and is extremely disorganized. Expect to learn nothing (as far as chemistry is concerned).
No comments for this guy yet? WOW

He is kind and really thinks the best for the students and don't want you to fail. However, his lectures really isn't helpful to learning unless you already knows a lot about statistics before coming to class. Study the handouts and you are going to be fine in 221.

216 with Zaino isn't too bad, but his lectures are not helpful. The weekly homeworks are difficult and he gives pop quizzes for attendance points. Tests are not easy either. He makes it possible to get a good grade though and is willing to help outside of class. Would suggest taking him for 216, and using R is not required at all which is nice.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Accessible outside class

comment: This is the worst professor I've ever met... He never gave the actual lecture. He read all the equations on the slides and the class ended... He actually typed math symbols like square root as sqrt() in his powerpoint and read it out loud. His lectures felt drowsy, and he tested hard on midterms. Almost gave up my statistics major because of him...

Nick is a great guy who makes things very simple for his students. Show up, pay attention, and take the pop quizes for participation. Homework is rather long and his exams aren't a breeze, but he is very clear about the criteria and is very accessible by email (and you get a cheat sheet). One of the real ones!!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: This professor changes my perspectives about statistics. His in-depth explanation really makes you understand the concepts and not just how to do the problems. I deeply enjoyed his class. He is soooo accessible outside class and very passionate.
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This prof is amazing! His style of teaching can be hard to follow at first. Also, this class is hard and he has to teach a chapter per class so dont expect to know everything after his lecture. However, he is so clear during office hour after class and explains the concept very clear

This professor just reads out the the book, easy A. But did not learn anything, he spoke more about music than he did math. The math class I took after him I was lost due to lack of prep by Zaino. ...
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Lecture slides are clear (I refer back several times after this class ended). Homework is heavy but I understand more by doing homework and going to office hour. After taking his class, I asked to be his TA and I did. He cares about teaching and helping students to learn. Going to his office hour is always makes my life easier:) Minitab help 5��

I had health complications during the semester that caused me to miss a lot of class, and talked with him to explain this. He told me that hed work with me to help me through the course. Admittedly, it mayve been useful to talk to him more to drill it in his head, because either he just forgot or didnt care at the end of the semester.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Lecture heavy but always willing to slow down and help outside of class. Workload is tolerable and the class is not bad as long as you pay attention to the material. Always available for long office hours and will even sit down with you for the entire problem set. Zaino seems to actually care about his students if you take the time to talk to him.

It was difficult to follow him in class. His mood is so calm and boring to be honest. It was easy to get distracted. Had to rely a lot on the textbook. He gives pop quizzes and is more likely to give them back to back if he notices people are starting to miss class. Still, he is fair and willing to help and give his time if you ask.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: It's really easy to get an A in his class and the exams are not difficult.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: The class makes a big jump from the intro stats, but I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT if you are pursuing a job  in analytics/stats. Every single interview I had this past year  relied on topics covered in the course.  Zaino is a decent lecturer. Very kind in person. I relied heavily on the TA for help on homework. Open book tests.

Zaino is a nice person but a bad instructor. His lectures are unorganized and boring. He is often confused about the slides himself. The homework is harder than what is taught in class. There are pop-quizzes, which makes attendance mandatory. Studying from the textbook is a MUST, since he doesn't really teach in class.  I dont recommend taking it!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: If you take the time to talk with him outside of class, he is more than willing to assist you with questions and concerns. He recognizes when a student is trying to do well, and for that, he will go out of his way for you. You get what you put into your course. If you're effortful, it'll show in the grade.

Expect homework which nearly kills you with no help from the professor. He welcomes you in office hours only to tell you to work on your own and the course was designed to make life miserable for students. He should have warned that it is super tough, instead he encouraged everyone to take it, probably to save his ranking. Poor teaching.

The homework questions were long and tedious it took one a whole week to get them done and he would give the longest problems just to make life hard for students. He would explain the concepts but not help you do the homework which was impossible to do unless you're a genius at Stats. A waste of time, do not take this course, esp with this prof.

Professor Zaino should have specified that this course is one of the hardest courses ever and unless you are pursuing a degree in Statistics it's best not to take it. He encouraged me to take it and then wouldn't help me with homework problems because he magically expected me to work on my own. One of the worst teachers, expect little to no help.

Zaino was probably the driest lecturer I've had thus far. He jumped all over the places and we learned topics in isolation, so it was difficult to see how things related. Weekly quizzes, tedious homework and his exams are okay. Recitations aren't that helpful, but go to office hours if you can. Avoid taking this class unless really you have to.

The class was rather dry and very typical of an Introduction to Stats course. The Project however is probably the single hardest thing about STT211. PLAN AHEAD you need to sort and gather your own data most of the time to actually get a decent grade on this. Homework is long, tedious hard graded and frankly his policy is ridiculous.

Avoid taking any class with him! I mean it. He left very mean comment on my project, and I got the lowest grade in the whole college span from nowhere because the contents are actually quite easy for me. Poor lecturer who assigns tedious and useless HW, taking his class wastes your time because you never know what those theories mean.

Lectures are pretty scatterbrained and dry. Homework is very tedious and labor intensive. Material is very easy and all exams are open note, open book. Getting a good grade is easy if you do the work and go to class. Open note and he drops your lowest assignmentsquizzes. He's very niceknowledgeable in person, and very helpful during office hours.

Open note & book exams. HW got a little tricky and were sometimes long, but recitation I was told was helpful for the tougher problems. Great course on expanding knowledge of statistic inference and some advanced techniques. Pop quizzes every once in awhile, but they were pretty easy.

He's a nice guy, but his lectures seem unfocused and disorganized. He is an inconsistent and boring lecturer, but if you hand in your homework and show up to take his pop quizzes you can make it through. He drops the lowest 2 homework grades but won't accept late homework. Attendance isn't mandatory, but it will help your grade.

Professor Zaino does really care about his students. All you gotta do is show up to classes, do the homework. and if you still dont understand, HIS OFFICE HOURS ARE VERY USEFUL! He is very kind and respectful. Homeworks sometimes do get annoying, but it is definitely useful on behalf of getting a good grade.

I think you can always find a better alternative to Zaino's session. He assigns to many homeworks and demands so many trival requirements that make this intro class a labor consuming trap. If u check the cdcs, u will see that his sessions are always half-filled and those alternatives are always over-filled. Smart students vote by feet. Good luck.
He really wants us to learn and is a nice guy.  Stat can be boring quite often, but he at least tries to make it interesting.  Overall a caring professor.

A very nice guy and he makes students his priority. However the class itself tends to be a little boring--DEFINITELY go though because only then will you be sure you know the material. He knows what he's talking about even if it doesn't always seem like it.
Tests are to the point, open book tests makes it not too hard if you generally know what you are doing. Tedious homework, boring class, but not hard.
Lectures poorly strctured, aweful instruction techniques, dull  - absolutely fails to engage students in the course.

The class was overall not too bad. I had taken AP Statistics in high school which made this class much easier since I already had learned the material. Even without this, though, the class wasn't too bad. The two tests are open book, which makes them fairly easy if you have a clue of what to do and if you attend class. A bit boring, but still good.

I'm sorry, but refusing to accept homeworks in the case of emergencies is a little anal. Sure, he drops two, but telling us not to have more than two emergencies? I had five or six. "Caring" is not at all the word I would use in  my dealings with him. Avoid the class at all costs if you can help it.

horrid class, horrid book.  open book tests had failing averages.  nice guy, but sucks at explaining things, despite his apparent knowledge.  he is also quite dry.  try to avoid him if you want to be interested in statistics

DO NOT TAKE STAT WITH HIM.  I loved statistics in high school and was planning to major in it, but he RUINED STATISTICS FOR ME and now I'm going to be an econ major.  He doesn't teach you how to do anything; he assumes you know it already.  He also assigns really tedious homework where you type in data sets for 15 minutes.
Easy class and gives you a base understanding of statistics. He's very nice and lenient but lectures are boring.

Eventhough the class maybe dry...he is a very nice and knowledgable man. Hes always available after class to explain things to his students and is very caring toward his students and his class. Zaino is one of the better prof at Rochester...def recomend him for any stat class.

He is a nice guy but his lectures can be boring.  You really only need to read the book and show up once a week to turn in the weekly homeworks.  The tests are not too hard and he scales them generously.  He was very friendly when I went to his office hours to discuss my final project.
I'm not a good technical reader, so statistics is difficult anyway.  He's a nice guy, but the class puts me to sleep.  Literally.  And I sit in the front row.
Terrible lecturer
Prof Zaino is the nicest guy ever.  He is really enthusiastic and tries to the the class involved.  His tests are predictable and it's really easy to do well in his class.  I really enjoyed him.

soooo easy. Just do the homework and you can not go to class too much. He kind of assumes you can learn the concepts from the book, so class consists of him saying "lets supposin..." then doing a sample problem. Nice guy as everyone has said.

I am just so confused all the time.  He gets up there and talks, but nothing he talks about is on the homework or test.  He just isnt a great teacher.  He gives out candy sometimes though in class.  Go to recitations and you may do okay.
Just plain not a good teacher.  teaches much of the stat at UR, yet only has an MA.
Zaino is not the best teacher..  but he is nice.  Watch out for your final grade, it may come out of nowhere.
Couldn't do the homework he assigned.  Must learn from the book and fellow students.

really nice guy, see him at the mel all the time.  teaching just ain't his thang. he always gives 2 exams, one is really hard and one is really easy, both open book, but im pretty sure he gives a generous curve.
No Comments
Hes a nice guy and I thought the class was really easy overall.
nice guy, class gets boring after a while

He's still teaching stat?  It's probably because no one really attends his classes, so when evaluations roll around his rating is not as poor as it should be.  He is a nice guy, but "nice guy" does not equate to "effective teacher.&quot
He is a nice guy, but I don't think teaching is his thing...if you have a basic grasp of recitations you will do well in his class
Terrible Teacher.  He is also very lazy.  He tries to be nice, but teaching is not his skill
No Comments
He can be nice at times and lenient, but the way he teaches his class is not geared for u to learn anything... I learned more at recitations and from others than from him.

if you can understand through the slur, it's not too hard, although the tests and especially grading on the final project can be hard, coming out of nowhere compared to the joke of a class it is normally
wow what a complete and utter joke that class was

You leave this course feeling like you truly learned. Though this is probably the hardest course in PSCI, I recommend it to every student taking the major. Gamm is super approachable, I enjoy his lectures, and his office hours will direct your essays. Only reason he isn't a 5 is his grading system means you're best doing the minimum amount of work.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Respected

comment: Lectures are a waste of time, and classes are boring and unnecessary. I would never take them, if not for credit. He is a good person, but not a good professor.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: He is one of the best, and most knowledgeable political science professors at this university. He is overall an amazing person that wants the sucess of all of his students. The only reason that his rating is so low is because his class is genuinely a bit challenging and almost impossible if you are not willing to do the work. 1000% worth taking
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: I love this man. Great lecturer, funny, has great personality. I learned so much about US history and why our country is the way it is. Very helpful in office hours. 4 just because TA's didn't grade papers consistently which was unfair. Weekly essays, lots of work but doable and you become a better writer and reader. Review for midterm and final.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes--So many papers

comment: Prof Gamm is one of the only professors at UofR who truly cares about the well-being of his students. 202W was tough - a lot of reading and it takes awhile to get the hang of what he and the TA's are specifically looking for in papers, but if you go to office hours (WHICH I REALLY RECOMMEND!! IT HELPS A LOT WITH THE PAPER) you'll be okay!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Caring

comment: This class was one of my favorites I've taken at UofR! Professor Gamm was a great teacher and I really enjoyed the class with him. There's a lot of reading and writing and the class can be extremely difficult, but I found it really enjoyable anyway. If you aren't ready to do all the reading I would recommend against this class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Gamm is a fantastic lecturer and a passionate teacher. I never disliked a reading, and the material was relevant. The class consists of around an essay a week plus 100-150 pages of weekly readings. The essays are graded by TA's, so it can be difficult to score well, but the TA's are helpful. It's hard, but a must for any PSCI student.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: This is the worst class for the political science major and the hardest class I have ever taken. I did it online so that wasn't the best option (but covid so what can you do) but it was just SO MUCH. I got overwhelmed and just honestly had a rough time, don't recommend this class. Too much reading and too many papers imo
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: A lot of reading and a lot of writing for this course. The grading criteria for the papers, which there's 1 every week, is pretty arbitrary and difficult; it takes a long time to learn how to write about what Gamm is looking for. It's a fascinating class and he's a good lecturer but the TAs are extremely tough, so take the class at your own risk
rating_tags: Respected--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Extremely tough grader, TAs grading even tougher. Lot of readings and homework. Just don't overestimate yourself. Trust me.
Prof. Gamm is the best political science lecturer I have ever had. Very passionate and bright. Get ready to read and write alot. Exam is difficult, but doable. Great professor!
Too many textbooks and too much reading. Grading is arbitrary and often makes 0 sense at all. Feedback was never useful. That being said the professor is extremely passionate about the subject.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I took 202 and 241W with Gamm and he's truly a professor who deeply values his students' points of view. Though he assigns a lot of reading and is a tough grader, you will become a better writer for it. Utilize his office hours and don't be afraid to speak up.

Professor Gamm is a phenomenal professor. Not only is he brilliant, but he is a passionate professor who  genuinely cares about his students. I would recommend his class to anyone who wants to be challenged, and to anyone who sincerely loves to learn.
His instructions are clear, he's pretty helpful. There's though tons of readings for the class and it is literally VERY hard.

Very good professor, very engaging and passionate and approachable.  The people who complain about him are usually the type who think they deserve an A just for showing up and doing their homework or who whine about having to read --gasp--100 pages a week!  At one of the top Universities in the country?  NOOOO!

Professor Gamm is an extremely good professor because he is extremely passionate about his teachings. However, this class is just awful because of the expected amount of reading. He expects the students to read about 100 pages per week. The TA's are also very tough at grading which makes receiving good grades on papers and tests extremely difficult

Class should be called "History of people who write papers about Political Science."  Lectures are very good, but he expects you to respond to paper questions in a very specific manner. Winds up being more about the reading itself than what the reading is actually about, and this drives me up the wall.

Professor Gamm is fantastic. Have had him for both 202 and 241, Urban Change. I've found him to be extremely interested in his students' thoughts and easy to engage with. 241 has a significant workload but I think it's fair because of how in-depth the course is. His lectures are always insightful, and it's clear he cares deeply about the subjects.

Lectures are ok. EXCESSIVE reading and writing. TAs were extremely tough graders. You'll likely feel you didn't get the grade you deserve on papers. Would never take this class if not required for major - uninteresting and overbearing. Wish Gamm would take a step back and re-examine the course.

His lectures are not great. They are average - starting out pretty good in the beginning of the semester and declining into oblivion and seemingly irrelevant information. TAs are harsh and probably not uniform in grading. WAYYY too much reading - excessive writing. Would never take the class if it weren't required for the major. Ever.

He is an amazing lecturer but if you try to discuss with him outside of class you feel like you are being tested rather than assisted. It is frustrating working so hard and not receiving the grade you think you deserve because of the arbitrary value he puts on certain things over others.

Aloof and above the students, good lecturer but good luck talking to him outside of class.  seems to care about students until he actually has to do something, then his condescending attitude is evident.

Gamm is a good lecturer. BUT he is not very approachable or understanding. He doesn't really care about his students. It is very hard to shake him from his devotion to academia (good and bad) and robot students.
great lecturer, tas are not very helpful and are harsh graders but he is always helpful in office hours, a lot of work but a worthwhile class to take

Really good lecturer though sometimes covers seemingly irrelevant material.  Very very long (but fair and relatively easy) final.  Extremely large amounts of reading (sometimes it's a little excessive and unnecessary).  Grading between sections (by the TAs) wasn't always consistent, and Gamm is very reluctant to override the TAs.

Though not liked by all, Professor Gamm is a very strong teacher and a good person. He's a tough but very fair grader; if you're willing work hard and are interested in the material, you should do well. He runs a very structured course, good for organized people (or people trying to get more organized).
Gamm is a remarkable lecturer.  Truly inspiring.

fantastic lecturer. i think you would have to try to fall asleep. he is always very excited to be there. only downside is his grading. It is pretty easy to get a B but near impossible to get an A. I think he gave only 3 in a class of more than a 100. def recommend taking one of his classes

Amazing lecturer, I have rarely looked at the clock during Gamm's classes. Very friendly and interested in getting to know his students. He expects a lot of work, but grades fairly. Exams are harder than most, but if you write the papers and participate in recitations you'll be fine. Definitely take his classes.
Gamm is terrible!  I am in law school now, and he is bar none one of the WORST teachers I've ever had, ever!

He's one of my favorite political science professors at Rochester.  He is the best lecturer I've had and is always willing to help.  He is a hard, but fair, grader.  Sure, he can be awkward (listen for his voice to crack when he gets excited), but compared to other professors he's normal.
Yeah he can be awkward, but when it comes down to it, is an extremely knowledgeable professor and good lecturer. He also cares a great deal about his students.

I think he's a great lecturer and I actually enjoyed the early American history (shocker given I don't like most US history).  Very engaging, can be arrogant at times, but always enthusiastic.  Main complaint I have is on how he grades exams.  His expectations for a 50 minute exam are too high and n
Arrogant but engaging. Pompous, picks on students a lot, but not a bad guy once you figure out how he works. REALLY knowledgable.
Good lecturer, but not as good outside of the classroom and in his interactions with students on a non-academic basis.

Incapable or unwilling to hide his political bias. Plays favorites, grades sometimes arbitrary. He does try to be polite and helpful, but it doesn't always work. Needs to be clearer, fairer, more tolerant of other points of view.
No Comments
Not typical of the high quality in the PSC department.
Ok Prof
Gamm meddles in other people's lives too much.  Tries to be everywhere, everything etc etc.  Relax!  And please, lose that stupid bow tie and your man crushes.
Generally a good professor, tries hard with student.  But plain and simple just too weird and ackward.
One of the best at UR hands down
crazy dude, pompous jerk, weird relationship/favoritism/crush on male UR athletes!

Gamm, for whatever reason, is omnipresent.  You can't get away from him!  He's everywhere!  I saw him at the airport once and was like, wtf mate?  Only I didn't actually say that, cause that would have been dumb.
Awsome lecturer and tries his best to be unbiased. Hard grader though
very very tough grader...
Great prof, better person.  Helpful and informative.  Does make you work though.
makes topics that always seemed terrible, interesting.  very dramatic lecturer, practically brought me to tears with the "disappearing quorum" lecture.
Gamm is one of the best professors in the poli sci department.  Smart, interesting, approachable, and he loves this topic.  He just needs to lose the Boston accent.
No Comments
He's an excellent lecturer but hard to talk to since he is always right. Very pompous person.
A really good guy and encourages you to eat lunch w him
No Comments
No Comments
He is a good prof, but

His lectures are well organized and build off each other. For me the information took a lot of time to digest. I rewrote my lecture notes, rewatched the lectures, and explained concepts to friends. Workshops were one of the best places to harness the information, but it requires engagement and not being afraid to try and get problems wrong.

his lectures are not very helpful. you understand the material from the workshops. I highly recommend going to all of them. his grading scheme is ambiguous.  his exams are hard you will have to learn the content elsewhere. go to the review sessions they are really helpful.

The lectures were not particularly helpful for tests, mostly learned the material on my own through other resources. Tests were very difficult but manageable if you studied a lot and workshops also helped a lot.

Overall, a decent professor. Lectures are strange in that you have to seek outside resources to really understand the material. Workshops are crucial. The same goes for practice exams. I found that grading is based on how closely it resembles the key, so make sure you memorize the wording used for the keys on past practice exams.

Dinnocenzo is an decent professor, and he clearly cares about his students. However, his lectures are really difficult to follow. In lecture, he assumes you have knowledge from the textbook, so if you don't read before the lecture it will likely not make sense. Review past exams and rote memorize and you will be fine, but it is not an easy class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dinno is a warm person who wants you to succeed and I suggest going to office hours where he's far more helpful. That being said, his lectures leave a lot of blanks so you have to do a lot of reading from other sources. He says the textbook but if you use orgo tutor vids and the masterochem site to make notes, you'll be fine. Do the practice tests!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Dr. Dinnocenzo is kind and knowledgeable, but is delusional and unorganized in the lectures. The lecture notes are not helpful tools to study for exams. Go to workshops and do all practice exams in advance, you will be fine. Also try to remember the reaction itself first before trying to understand the mechanism.

Dr.D's class notes are not very helpful for exam prep.Class is tough. Grades only based on 3 exams and final. There's a lot to learn and not enough time to learn it- make sure to keep to a strict study schedule. I think for OChem it's important to memorize first then TRY to understand material and then do practice.Exams get harder with every year.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Dr. Dino is great, but the class is challenging for everyone. You have to change your study style. He doesn't explain everything, more like key points. You must read the textbook to do well. Go to workshop, and take advantage of help sessions by TAs. You must heavily study past exams, use flashcards, and watch youtube. You will thank me later

Dr. D is a very kind and knowledgable professor. He obviously cares about his student's success and always makes himself available for questions. That being said, this course is very challenging and it is frustrating that your grade is only determined based on exams, which are graded harshly.He struggles with simplifying concepts that are difficult
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: This guy - although by nature very caring - is not merciful at all. You have to submit your test for regrade IMMEDIATELY after receiving them back, so forget about it if you are unwell and cannot make it to class. Even if you qualify for partial credit, you won't receive it because he is a tough grader as well.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He's a decent professor and really nice guy, but I can't stand the way he lectures. The notes he writes down are basically useless to study from and he skips over the most basic concepts expecting you to know them. Tests are also pretty hard but the curve is nice. Great guy, but not a great professor.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Womp womp. The man cannot teach.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He does not care about students at all. I missed exam 2 in his class, as one of the exams can be dropped so I wasn't worried about that. When it went on to exam 3, I had to request make-up due to medical reasons and he did not allow it, and it was just because  "he cannot give make-up to all students because it is too much work"
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dinnocenzo's lectures are great but they will not make sense if one just rote memorizes. They are taught in a way that requires thinking about how to organize notes in a logical way, but that helped me understand the material even more than with just memorization. Grading is extremely exam heavy, but all orgo courses are. Office Hours are great.

Professor Dinnocenzo is very knowledgable but an awful teacher. His lectures are disorganized and hard to follow. He skips over certain topics and explanations. He is very stingy with partial credit. getting regrades is necessary because of how many mistakes are made when exams are graded but requesting them is a complete mess.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Dinnocenzo is clearly knowledgable but is an awful teacher. His lectures are disorganized and hard to follow. He assumes a lot of prior knowledge and therefore skips explanation of fundamental topics and reading the textbook is necessary to be successful. His exams are formatted exactly like the practice exams which is how I got through.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Honestly don't get all the positive ratings on here. He is a terrible professor who has terrible lecture recordings and you can't see the board at all in the recordings. He's also a harsh grader on exams and the entire class is graded solely based on exams. Do not recommend at all.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dinnocenzo is a good professor. He knows what he's talking about, but is delusional when it comes to how he teaches. He considers this course a "liberal arts course", but if you have a different way of thinking about something you are marked wrong. He is the most unaccommodating professor I have met for numerous reasons I can't fit in this text box
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He only grades on exams and nothing else, so you're screwed if you have test anxiety. He also only accepts 1 type of answer to a problem on the exams, so if your mechanism or explanation is right but isn't what is on the answer key, you get 0 points. The only times I did well on exams was when I memorized answers provided on practice exams.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Prof Dinnocenzo is an expert in orgo but not good at teaching it. His lectures are very unorganized and hard to follow. I spent most of the class teaching myself and learning through workshop. I cannot wait for this class to be over.

Genuinely the most uncaring professor I have ever had the displeasure of being taught by. His lectures have no direction, and since he barely holds office hours, most of lecture is spent by students asking questions that are for irrelevant material/prior exams. Met with him about an exam and he agreed I was correct but refused to give points back.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Refuses to hold office hours before regrades (regrade period is during 50 min class), meaning if you write a plausible mechanism that doesn't match the test key, you will get the entire problem wrong. Never responds to emails OR requests to meet if you cant make office hours (which are during an orgo lab time btw). Knows Orgo but a BAD professor.

This class is so traumatizing and prof dinnocenzo does not make it any easier. Lectures are so unclear and all over the place. The only grades are the tests, but you can drop your lowest midterm. The only reason I am passing is because the tests are very similar to the practice tests. Grading scheme and regrade policy is awful.

This is 100% a tough class, but if you put in the time outside of class you will be just fine. Lectures are a bit dense because there is a lot of information to get through. My best advice is to stay caught up with the class so you are not trying to learn a month's worth of information the night before the exam. Also, workshops are supper helpful.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I loved Dr. Dinnocenzo! His tests always have similar style questions so you sort of know what to expect on the tests. His lectures are relatively clear and he is really good about telling you exactly what you need to know for the tests. Be careful though because this class is only test based so they really matter, but you can drop the lowest one.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Organic chemistry is dreaded by most students but Professor Dinnocenzo makes the subject accessible. He provides affirmation, grades fairly, and dispels myths students may have about o-chem. Reading the textbook is necessary and lectures can be a bit dry, but put in the effort and you'll find that you'll have learned a lot in the end.

Prof. Dinnocenzo developed the first-year orgo course and teaches it with great precision and efficiency. He genuinely cares about his students, and provides many great resources outside of class. Workshops are excellent preparation for the tests, but you will need to put in work. One of the most rewarding courses I've taken.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Dr. Dinnocenzo was a fantastic professor. Organic chemistry was certainly a difficult class, but if you worked hard it paid off. He would offer study advice during his lectures that was ultimately very useful and would oftentimes stay long after class ended to answer student questions. It was clear to see that he wanted students to succeed.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Organic chemistry is hard, but it's a lot easier with Professor Dinnocenzo. Straightforward class and had A's for nearly every prelim expect the final (a 7-10 pm exam). He gives out practice exams that are very similar to the exam you would get without surprise. Very kind, teaches very well and was a pleasure to have. 100%better than 2nd year orgo
He's really nice and very accessible outside of class. Email him for office hours, which are super helpful. The textbook problems aren't that helpful, but I recommend reading it.

Class is very one-directional, traditional lecture style, primarily based on examples and very hard to follow in my opinion. Grade is entirely made up of tests. Prof is very caring and does not believe in stupid students, only those who haven't found their right study method yet, which is nice.

Professor Dinnocenzo really cares about his students. He's extremely useful when you ask him questions during office hours so I highly recommend doing so (he doesn't make you feel stupid at all)! He always talks about test taking/studying strategies but teaches at a fairly fast pace so it's important to read the textbook for extra clarification.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Professor Dinnocenzo's CHM171 is really hard----even for those who got 5 in AP CHM. Some students drop the class and go to 131. The reason is the pace in class is very fast and he supposed you to have finished textbook readings which are impossible to be finished before class. But he is very patient when answering your Qs. Wrk leaders & TA awesome

Lectures are somewhat boring, but the class is great overall. He is very kind if you talk to him in the right way and clearly wants his students to succeed. The TAs will help alot, and he always has great TAs.

As a lab lecture professor, he was decent. Lectures were uninteresting but not unbearable, and group work made lab understandable. He clearly wants students to succeed, although he is less forgiving than you might hope. Overall, he did a decent job

I started freshman orgo thinking I was going to fail (no really). I ended up with an A and became a TA for organic chemistry. I worked hard, but Professor Dinnocenzo definitely helped me ALOT. He was always available for questions and he never made me feel stupid. He is hands down, the best professor I have had at UR.

Orgo is impossible, but dinnocenzo is really good at explaining it.  expect a ton of work reading the textbook and doing extra problems.  class pace is really fast, but he tries to answer questions before moving on.

Organic Chemistry is hard, but Dinno loves it so much, and really wants his students to love it to. He really wants students to exceed. Exams were tricky because explanations got you all the credit for the question, and but if you do all the workshops, practice exams, reading, and homework, it'll pay off. Funny guy. Good class (for orgo).
Dinno is a great professor. He really cares about his students. Tends to weed out the weaklings in the beginning, but seems to lighten up a bit as the semester goes on. Just be sure not to give up.

I didn't do very well at the beginning of the semester, but managed to rock an A on the final. I think the class actually gets easier and easier because it comes full circle and all the concepts start to make sense and become applicable. Great professor.

hate chem, detest his exams, but can't say prof isn't good.  nice, a little uptight and intense but loves orgo and teaching thats for sure.  Wonder what he does in his spare time --- Props b/c u can tell he always prepares for each lecture thoroughly.

He's a good professor and dedicated to helping students (you won't find many professors who are willing to hold 3 hr review sessions on weekends). But his exams are difficult and he's a very strict grader. He's one those guys whose life outside of school/chemistry is hard to picture.
Lecture had a poor focus/direction.  Workshops were awful.  Book reading had nothing to do with exams.  Exams were impossible.

This guy must be from the gods...by far the best professor Ive ever has in my history at Rochester. His concern with students understanding of the material is incredible. He stays way after his office hours for his students and comes in on the weekends to reteach material that we didnt quite get. Outstanding listener, outstanding professor!!!

Calls students who ask for help "irresponsible," and spends more time talking about how he won't fill our heads than he spends teaching the concepts. A sign of a good teacher is not getting upset when people do poorly, but rather having a class where people are able to excel, which very few people do.

Amazing teacher; the best I've had in this school yet.  Incredibly passionate about Organic Chemistry and genuinely wants students to do well.  He gets upset when class averages are a little low because he feels he didn't get through to people; the sign of a great teacher.
Always available for help.
Good teacher, thorough.  Very informative
AWESOME: smart, nice, understanding. Student's are almost as important as chemistry is to him:). Cool research, lab full of fancy glassware and tools! Lets me play with the laser.

his handwriting is amazingly neat!  also, if you get bored in class, watch him use the chalk.  he only uses new pieces, so there's a massive pile of barely used chalk at the end of the board!  haha  he wants everyone to do well.  very nice and encouraging.
great teacher, nice handwriting...
He is very smart and a good lecturer.  However he talks down to his students and mocks them openly in class for proposing incorrect answers.
No Comments
Very Good Handwriting
No Comments
No Comments

Amazing professor, can't recommend him enough. Explains calculus in a clear, simple way, and if you pay attention in class you won't fall behind. Lectures are engaging and funny, but not to the point of being distracting or off-topic. The class moves fast, and it's easy to lose momentum, but if you stay focused and do the work you'll be fine.

Great lecturer and provides well-motivated and clear but simple explanations of all the major topics. He's very enthusiastic which is great, the lectures are high-energy. Sometimes a little intimidating to contribute in class but great guy. Effectively references the textbook as a good supplement but not required to read.

Dr. Herman is a phenomenal lecturer; he's very engaging and passionate about the subject, and he goes about teaching in a very clear and concise manner. The course content wasn't the easiest (as somebody who isn't the best at math), but he breaks it down in a way that makes it a lot more manageable. Highly recommend!!

This dude is hilarious. He'll talk to himself making jokes, tell random stories from his life, advertise Pepsi, and on top of that he's a remarkable professor. Answers questions, explains things clearly & legibly. The class is tricky, but I wouldn't want anyone else teaching it to me. If you ever get the chance, take this guys class.
BEST MATH PROFESSOR!!

He is a really great guy and always more than happy to help with anything. The class isn't easy by any means, and the exams in particular were hard. Homeworks are not too bad if you ask for help when needed. He just wants you to put in the effort which is great to see. Also he makes funny jokes.

Diverting and amicable, as Mark always has been, Math 208's quizzical materials were broken down into palatable piecewise information that was fairly tested on. Had the assignments been easy, the class would not be a banger. Challenging as they are designed to be, they siphon out students' thoughts.
he is nice

I'm typically not the rate my professor guy that will write comment or rate the professor, but I signed up the account for him! His class is truly interesting and engaging. I really understand a lot of concepts that I didn't get before with his help, he's just amazing!

He was hilarious and knew how to teach so well. It was a morning class and the attendance wasn't mandatory, but I didn't miss a single lecture even though I did most of the material in high school. If you take cal 161, take it with Prof. Herman.
He is funny and nice! Explains concepts very clearly!

Prof Herman does an extremely well job in teaching math. One of the most brilliant math professors. He does however teach extremely fast and sometimes can be very direct and rude at times. He definitely cares for math and genuinely tries to teach students, but i found his teaching style to be sometimes difficult to grasp. Be ready to take notes.
He's very fast but he also teaches well. If you pay attention and do webworks you should be fine.

Hands down one of the best professors I have ever had. Professor Herman is incredibly helpful and genuinely wants his students to succeed. I have developed a greater interest for mathematics because of his excellent teaching. Great class!

Prof Herman is a great lecturer and gives many examples for each topic. He also explains why concepts in calculus exist instead of just giving you the formulas, which really helps with understanding. That being said, the pace is fast and it's almost impossible to cram for the tests, so it's important to stay on top of your homework and studying!

The best math teacher I've ever had, never got the chance to lean from him or talk personally, but his lectures were awesome. He connected so many dots for me that had been floating around from previous calc classes. There have been multiple times I've thought "Why didn't my teachers in HS just day that?". I wish I could take him for 162 :(
Great professor
word hard, then you will get an A

Professor H is a great math teacher and really funny. Showing up to lecture is very important. My advice is to really focus on the homework because that is what prepares you for the test and the practice quizzes.

Great professor, walks you from the eaiest ever examples to the hardest ones. detailed lectures and alway on point when it comes to what really matter for exams. I would recommend attending the lecture he gives pretty great examples in them.
Amazing 161 professor. He gives a lot of examples to help understant.

When talking about the Dijkstra algorithm, I am confused. Taking so many years of algorithm competitions, I am surprised he is teaching algorithms this way. I can feel if I am new to these things I might get confused. He gives me a feeling he wants examples to explain algorithms, but those examples may not be suitable and confuse you more.

I think this class is fine. I went to his office hour and he helped me a lot. Sometimes I just cannot follow this class or missed a class, and I can go over his notes. He basically includes everything in his notes.

This guy is the bomb. I have no idea what these other dudes are talking about. Maybe they are not attending class. He clearly pours his heart into teaching this class. Take it if you get the chance. He's smart and hilarious and super helpful if you go to office hours.

I have no idea why we are going to class. His lecture is sooo confusing, and I just couldn't follow. Notes are extremely confusing with lots of useless phrase though I have to review it to know how to do homework. Takes lot of time. Why am I taking this class??? If you want and easy class, take it, and get ready to study everything by yourself.
Notes are not clear. Lectures are not understandable. Homework is hard. We are struggling.

Amazing professor, would definitely take him again. Cares about his students and is very understanding. Funny and gives clear explanations, lectures are recorded with notes. Difficult tests, but they are the same regardless of the professor. HW load is reasonable. I'll never love calculus, but Professor Herman made me hate it a little less.
Very nice teacher and class. The pace is fast, and the exam is hard, so you should always review the notes and webwork assignments.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: The course-load is not very heavy. There is homework due at the end of the week, which is very manageable, and the tests are hard, but not if you understand the material. Overall, as long as you can grasp the lessons, it is a great class and Herman is a great Professor who always answers your questions and emails and cares about his students.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Class moves pretty quickly but he's very helpful outside of class. One of the best math professors at UR.
Lectures were not recorded. He's very open to questions and good at explaining but will not stop moving forward (pretty quickly might I add). Overall one of the better math professors I've ever had.
He's such a fun, quirky guy! His lectures are extremely fast-paced and hard to follow but the perk of that is you get many helpful examples.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Such an odd and funny guy which makes class interesting. He gives good examples during class that will mimic those on Webwork so it's important to attend class.
He has a true passion for math. His interest in the subject during the lecture draws me into it a lot. Always answers your questions with enthusiasm.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: THE WORST!!!!!!!! I DON'T EVEN UNDERSTAND WHY THE HECK IS HE TEACHING 150!!! I AM AN A STUDENT AND I HAD TO STUDY EVERYTHING ON MY OWN!!! WHY THE HECK ARE WE PAYING $5000 FOR THIS COURSE ALONE???
He just does not know how to teach probability or math in general. Lectures are boring. Reading textbook is better
Great professor, a little fast but honestly he is amazing. Take him.

He creates exams that doesn't make sense. Even the past 10 years exam posted do not match up. worst of all he is the head of the department. Doesn't know how to teach and assumes everyone knows what he is talking about. I will NEVER recommend this Professor to anyone
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: soooo boring and assumes you'll know things that you don't when lecturing
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Great intro to discrete math. Very funny guy and explained things well. Always took the time to answer student questions clearly. You will need the textbook but you can find the pdf, and the questions from the book always translated very clearly to what he lectured in class.
Prof. Herman is very skilled in his expertise. His lecture are fun and organized. He is also very respectful to all the students. Overall, he is a great professor. Fully recommend to anyone.

I really love Prof. Herman. He is one of the few professors who listen carefully to the students. You can ask him question almost anytime and he would explain clearly and patiently. I would fully recommend him to any students. Go for it!

Herman is a great guy and answers questions well. That said, he just writes notes way too quickly on the board. I spent all class trying to keep up and get the notes down without being able to process anything.

Don't miss out! He has perf amount of humor in lectures. Office hours are worth going as he explains things well. He doesn't talk into the board! He responds quickly and is impressively patient despite how busy/knowledgeable he is. You can feel his effort to help students learn. He has  great comedic timing- I 'd definitely have him as prof again.

You'll be fine as long as you pay attention and take notes. He tends to move a little fast, but his office hours are helpful and he replies to emails pretty fast. Woe unto you if he's the one setting the exam, though. Otherwise, he's a pretty decent professor. Don't take too long to seek help for problematic areas, it's hard to play catch up

Herman is a really great guy and a wonderful professor. He gets really excited about the material, which keeps class entertaining. He explains everything clearly and gives examples of every concept. Highly recommended

Unnecessarily long and repetitive hw assignments, though they're pretty doable. Good intro to math logic without killing you on it. Lectures are better than the book for notes and understanding the material. Practice exams super helpful. Not a walk in the park, but if you put time into the course you'll ace it. C or below if you don't.

Herman is one of the better teachers in the math department. He is extremely knowledgeable and explains things clearly, but he moves very quickly through lectures. Always go to the lectures, you basically have to in order to do decently in the class.

Herman is a decent professor. I probably wouldn't have him as my first choice for a class, but he's a good back-up plan. He does write and talk fast, but you get used to it after a few lectures. The class itself is hard, especially when it gets to infinite series. Herman does help to explain the harder concepts, but it's not enough on its own.

MTH 162 is an awful class, and Herman didn't make it any better. Moves ridiculous fast in lecture, and his handwriting is terrible.  Can be condescending and rude if you ask a question he considers simple. Webwork is really hard, and doesn't help you prep for exams.  The book problems are a lot better. Midterms were tough. Final was BRUTAL

Out of all the MTH162 professors, Herman is the best. That, however, is not saying much. He speeds through lectures and uses exact examples from the textbook. I found it much more useful to just read the textbook and watch lectures online. The tests in 162 are pretty fair, aside from the final, which was ridiculous.

Herman is a great professor! He does tend to go fast, but this is because he is giving you more in depth coverage/examples than the other professors. Also, he is open for questions.  He goes deep into theory, but once you understand that you can understand anything that could possibly be on the exam. For the harder subjects do look a the book.
Excellent professor. I really enjoy be in his class though he speaks super fast and provide students lots of notes. He is willing to help students after class in his office hours or by appointments.

Excellent professor.  He is super helpful outside of class and makes himself very available to his students.  His lectures were almost comically speedy at first (but still clear), but he slowed down by October.  Must have been the weather... Also a good guy to know (Director of Undergraduate Studies)

He's young and has a sense of humor. He can be eccentric but he always seems happy to help out students who are making an effort. He writes & talks at supersonic speeds which makes note-taking a challenge but his lectures were good enough that I barely had to crack open the book all semester. I would definitely take him again if I had a chance.

Lectures are always very engaging and he throws in a nice bit of humor. He speaks really, really quickly in class, but you get used to it after a while. Really patient/helpful in office hours. He like to use the entire grading spectrum, so you might get a low test number, but he adjusts the curve accordingly.

Very helpful professor who is always willing to spend extra time with his students. His lectures move at the speed of sound and will burn through a dozen pages of notes in one day. His curves are helpful and generous but not obscenely large. He is gorgeous and I want to run my fingers through his receding hairline.
Very good teacher. Although he goes over stuff bit fast in class, he is very helpful afterclass. He explains the problems to you until you get bored. His test can be long and a bit hard

Large lectures, the class was held in Hubbell. Weekly lab was very easy and rarely took more than 30 minutes. Content can be a little tricky at first, but all the later units are VERY similar, with slightly different procedures, and so the class for sure gets easier as it goes on - do no give up hope. She did lots of examples, and explained well.

this was the one class this semester I was not excited to go to and really struggled to remain focused. I felt like she overcomplicated incredibly simple concepts and had a very slow paced class when you would normally expect math/stats to be fast paced. Content itself and exams are easy and u could honestly self study this whole class

Dr. G is very helpful and patient, especially during office hours. There may be a lot of homework and the class may seem slow at times, but doing the homework is extremely beneficial as it gives you an understanding of concepts you may not understand just from lecture. I highly recommend taking this class as it is easy but it just takes effort.

Dr. G is very helpful and patient especially when you come in with questions to her office hours. Though the class may be a bit slow and there are many homework assignments, I believe these homework assignments truly did help my understanding so I would recommend spending your time on them as they also contribute to your grade.

Though the class may be a bit slow sometimes, Dr. G is an incredibly kind and helpful professor who is very patient when you come into office hours with questions. She gives a lot of homework but the homework truly helps with your overall understanding of the class.

The class was so boring (as someone who really likes Stat & Applied Math). There are so many opportunities to use statistics to actually research something you're passionate about & gain a deeper understanding for whatever that material is. The labs don't do that at all. She's a good lecturer, with good slides, but needs to change the curriculum.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Homework assignments are overly simplistic and require detailed work on basic problems, which feels like unnecessary busywork. The lack of challenge makes it hard to stay engaged or develop new skills. It makes everything worse when attendance is also required. If you want a class that pushes you, I'd suggest reconsidering this one.

Dr. G has a lot of patience when working with students. I was always the only one in her office hours and she would always be more than happy to clarify confusion. This course is R studio heavy so be prepared to memorize codes for exams.

Dr.G is an amazing professor. Her lectures were super easy to understand, although a bit slow. The homeworks were really helpful in understanding the material and if you do the practice questions first, you'll do well on the homework. She's also super organized and the extra credit from the practice homework problems help your grade a lot.

219 is one of the easier stats classes I have taken- would recommend. Some of the material can get complicated, but Dr. G acknowledges that and doesn't expect you to perfectly grasp all the theory. She teaches it in an accessible way. Heavy on the group work, most hw is done with your group but isn't bad. only 1 midterm exam and final project

Tough and hard professor. She won't let student do anything easy. The most mean professor I have ever seen in UOR. Though lectures are not bad, lots of rubrics and standards make it hard for students.

her lectures are incredibly clear and everything's super easy to understand. honestly i didn't go to a single class and i just watched the recorded lectures and got an A. the projects can be tough at times but you get to work with people so it's not as bad. homework was easy and based entirely on the lectures. dr g was also really nice.. love her

276 isn't an easy class if you have no coding background (if you do it will be easier). Tests are HARD, def study, and homeworks are really time consuming so start early. However, Dr G still makes it possible to get a good grade if you put in effort, so show up to class and ask for help if you need it. Overall, difficult but learned a lot.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: She is so nice!! She uses a lot of her own time to help students and sets extra office hours! She gives lecture recordings so you could study at your own pace! She explains concepts very clearly.

Dr. Grzesik values the learning the process in her classes. You get out what you put into her course. She offers plenty of office hours and is very responsive to her email chains. Those who don't spend the extra effort to learn the material that they struggle with are just lazy... 5/5 Stars
Dr.G is so kind and amiable! if you have any question and email her, she would definitely reply very fast!!love her!!!

Professor Grzesik is really nice and you could actually learn a lot from her. However, she grades homework and exams extremely strictly. It is really nice of her to give out extra credit but unfortunately not really help to boost your total grade. Be prepared or you might freak out every single Sunday night.

While Prof. Grzesik is nice, she focuses too much on the conceptual calculus part of statistics, which is not in the homework or the exams. She covers so many equations that by the point she says something that's actually relevant, I'm not paying attention. I got much more useful information from lab, but I don't recommend taking a class with her.
Very strict in grading and do not accept any mistake caused by third party factors.hard to understand during the class

She was really nice and I really liked her as a person, but I just don't think I learned too much in her class. I'd recommend one of the other professors. She often brought up concepts in lecture that we didn't need to know, which just confused me and distracted me from what I did need to know. The only topics I did well on was what I learned in HS

Wow this class was tough. Really interesting class to take and you learn a lot from her. She grades ridiculously strict on homeworks, but gives good feedback. Start them early in the week. A lot of all nighters pulled on Sundays... Midterm and Final are closed book coding exams. Very hard, but she was understanding when it came to grading.

Good teacher. If you're interested in statistical analysis take her, she knows what she's talking about. However if you're just in it for the credit, take a different prof, it's easier. She gives you everything you need to succeed on her tests, but you have to work. Graded the group project tough. Is a stickler about being on time and office hours
I would rather try the course offered by some other instructor instead. She is an elementary school grammar teacher.
Very clear explanations of very useful information to know. 100% worth taking if you have an interest in statistical analysis
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Online Savvy

comment: I lost interest for stat after her 276. She is nice, but her grading is cruel. She always takes off points for tidy mistakes. Heavy workload, however, exams are way harder than hw (basically close book coding exam). If you care about your grade, consider it before taking it.

Dr. G is generally nice and straightforward with her grading. Sometimes the course can be frustrating in that it is super focused on formulas rather than critical thinking and understanding. I recommend doing at least some of the practice problems (especially before the homework and exams). Workshop was also quite helpful, but it depends on your TA
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: I took Statistical Coding in R with Dr. G (I couldn't select this option in the rating for some reason), and she is extremely knowledgeable and helpful. It's not an easy class, but it's the kind of class that will actually help you get a job after college. I highly recommend. Also, she's a wonderful person.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Grzesik is an okay professor overall. She's straightforward with the grading and what is expected of you, but boring. Homework every week gets harder as the class goes on, but even if it's time consuming it's not too bad. Prepares you well for tests, but some are harder than others. There is one basically semester-long group project.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: The professor is great if you don't have any disabilities, medical issues, sickness, or anything relating to being late or needing to change when complete the course.

Dr. G is an amazing professor and will go the distance to help you maximize your learning. I was intimidated at first because of all of the negative reviews, but they seem to all be from when this course was taught online or lazy students. Sometimes the HW is a bit long but exams are very fair if you did the HW and the practice questions.
If you do the homework and discussion, then it's easy to get an A for this class.

Very time consuming. Students are expected to watch pre-recorded lectures, attend workshop, write discussion posts, and complete homework WEEKLY. Aside from the heavy workload, Dr. G is very accessible. She answers emails very quickly and clarifies problems during her non-mandatory Zoom meetings.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: I think that something Professor G forgets is that this is an introductory course, which means that a large number of the people taking it have to as a major requirement. So they aren't going to have a lot of background knowledge that she assumes we all do. It's tough, especially if you aren't very talented when it comes to math.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: It is a LOT of work. Especially for an introductory course. I spend about 10 hours a week on this course, which is twice what I spend on any other. You have to watch lectures, watch videos for notes, attend workshops and then do homework (which can take hours) and then do your discussion. Which is outside of revision needed for the multiple exams.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Dr. G is a really good teacher and she puts effort into her lectures. The recent poor reviews are probably lazy first years who wanted an easy A. The biggest con is that it's too much work. She is a bit nitpicky with tests. Homework is a bit annoying, but this is a math class after all. Yellowdig participation was a complete waste of time though.

You're just going to spend every week listening to hours of videos that she filmed years ago. 50% of the test material was never taught in class so you better have done outside-of-class research on top of the weekly videos, lectures, workshop, homework and discussion requirements. And you're going to lose dozens of marks for nit-picky remarks.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: A really difficult class. It's called Applied Statistics but there isn't a single opportunity to practice application within class-time. If you want to take notes on the (re-used) videos, attend class, practice tests, attend the workshop AND do the assignments you'll need AT LEAST 7 or 8 hours a week. And the tests are covered in un-taught material

I've only had her online, but I've had no problem with her recorded lectures and the discussions so far.
