comment: She is nice but a rather harsh grader when it comes to the big essays. I think if I went to her office hours more than once, she would be more lenient. She said I was a good writer but took points off for who knows what, which is why I dislike humanities courses since they're not straightforward like the sciences. Participate in class and read!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Class is very boring, she is very unclear when lecturing, all over the place with her thoughts, really hard to take notes on it.  Demeaning marks on papers. Not fair.

She's very kind and encouraging and loves when students contribute in class. Lectures can get boring....but she's a lenient grader and gives a decent amount of completion time for her take home exams. First FMS class I took, really enjoyed the material

Professor WIllis is extremely knowledgable about her craft, and she is very engaging in class.  She's very interested in ideas brought up by students, especially if its something she hasn't considered before.  She is funny and quite charming.  THe class itself is very interesting, as long as you watch the films.  Exams are take home papers.

I really enjoyed this class much more than I thought I would. The work load is slight. The exams are all in take-home essay form and you can chose which questions to answer. She grades a little on the easy side, and you can see she is passionate about what she teaches. Take very good notes though, because a lot of material is covered.

She's a great teacher. Definitely take a class with her if you can. She's a fair grader (if not slightly lenient). Classes are more discussion based. If you take notes and stay attentive in class you'll do fine.

She is quirky and funny -- makes class interesting. Speak up! She rewards those who talk and does not put people down. Encouraging. Above all, go to class. It makes writing the papers (exams) so much better. She is looking for thoughtfulness on them, not any "right" answer per se.

She always acted better/smarter than any one else.  The class was extremely boring and far-reaching.  Basically I put alot of effort into my papers, handed them all in on time and received demeaning comments, while another student (who she clearly liked) handed in all of his papers after finals were over and received an A in the class. How unfair!

This class I took was severely uninteresting and unexciting. The professor was understimulating and frequently asked questions that had obvious answers. For one paper she told me the  advertisements I chose to write about were uninteresting and failed to see how I could write a paper about them. I thought they were extremely  interesting. avoid her

ridiculously closed minded to other peoples views and very condescending. Told me my interpretation of a painting was wrong, how can that be? its opinion based...anyway class is boring. I'm not alone in my opinions either, many others in this class feel the same way

Clearly she's brilliant and know what she's talking about.  you MUST follow the reading syllabus and NOT fall behind.  Her film class can be a tad bit dry as a result of the philosophy of film in some texts. Hang in there and use your journals to structure your essays.  You can even form your own essay topics! Whatever you do, dont fall behind!

Brilliant and flooded with irreverent humor! Your papers will get a one (sometimes 2) page critique with a fat grade at the bottom.  She's a fair grader and loves...and i mean LOVES people who talk consistently.  If you shy away, office hours are key.
No Comments

Obviously and facinatingly brilliant. lectures are very interesting although occasionally difficult to follow and one sometimes gets the impression that she doesn't recognize the fact that not everyone else is a brilliant as she is. overall a great professor and one of my favorites.

A pleasure to listen to during lectures and a fair grader. Very knowledgable and great at encouraging class discussions. Do not be afraid to speak up in her classes, she expects and rewards it. Wears great shoes!
Fascinating courses--brilliant teacher.
Superb Film teacher. She cares about the students, and makes class particularly interesting.
No Comments

He wants you to engage but if you say something, he'll tell you it doesn't matter... He creates a negative environment for students to express themselves and learn. His class is boring and mostly consists of him talking. I struggle to keep my eyes open just 10 minutes in. He's kinda pretentious. One more class left, please pray for me.

Every class is so painful. He just likes to listen to himself talk. If you are good at dealing with pretentious professors, you'll be fine: class isn't hard, but listening to him talk makes me want to hit my head against a wall. If you don't like the writing techniques he does, he becomes very passive aggressive. Proceed with caution.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I definitely feel like I learned a lot from his class, but it wasn't always enjoyable. The tests as fine as long as you take notes and handle time management decently. The grading criteria for the essays is pretty vague.

Don't call Longenbach pretentious.  He's just way smarter and better read than all his students, & his colleagues, and he doesn't want to waste time or energy being patient with foolish questions people could answer themselves if they were smarter or better read.  If he's ever demeaning, it's to shrink your ego so you can think more clearly.

I have never written a review here before, but this time I just had to. I took Renaissance Love Poetry with Longenbach for my cluster, and it was such a good decision. He is very engaging in class, and the material is awesome if you're at all interested in poetry. He may seem a bit intimidating at first, but he's just really smart.

Because of his literary genius, Longenbach can be intimidating at first, but I think that if you have even the slightest opportunity to take a class with him, you need to do it. He not only teaches you about the art of poetry and writing in general, he gives great advice about life. The  class experience really changed me for the better.

I was kind of worried at first, only because I had heard some negative things about Longenbach but I soon realized I had nothing to worry about. He's a very passionate teacher that really cares about the work and the students doing well. He's really good at explaining the text, and the tests and essays were fine as long as you went to class.
The best teacher I've ever had, no qualifiers needed.
Longebach is awful, and I did very well in his courses. People who teach 'frivolous' material often try to compensate in irritating ways.

I prefer being taught by someone who's pretentious but knows what he's talking about than by someone who's humble and dumb. That said, I think Longenbach only seems pretentious when you first meet him. He's KNOWLEDGEABLE -- and if that makes him a bit intimidating, just deal. His class will change your life.

Meh. Super pretentious dude. Very critical. Almost impossible to write poetry under his fascination with traditional elements. Intimidating, plays favorites. Can't see out of academia. Pretty cute though.

I took his modern poetry class, and it changed my life. As others said, he seems pretentious at first, but in fact, he's just really smart and not afraid to show it. Best English professor I've ever had.
Best professor ever.

This man is amazing... one's first impression would be to classify him as pretentious. This is however, not the case. He knows the subject matter thoroughly and I can safely say I would not have been able to appreciate Ulysses thoroughly without his guidance.
Super intelligent, very clear, pretty stuck up, but overall, a great teacher. His Modern Lit class is a good amount of work but intro Poetry is easy. You will learn a lot from this guy, either way.
I'm not enjoying his class at all

Wonderful! One of the most engaging professors I've ever had! He had me on the edge of my seat nearly every class, and he still found time to be a goofball every once in a while. If you are considering taking one of his classes - do it!!
Great professor, taking his class was a lot of fun and I learned a lot.

I did not find him pretentious, as other commentors did.  I can see how that could be a first impression, but if you give him more than one class you find he is to helpful, funny, and engaging to be pretentious.  Great professor.
total ham, but in a funny and engaging sort of way. i really enjoy his class.
I took his Yeats and Joyce class in the mid 90's. It was the best class I ever took. Learned a lot and had a blast.
once you get past his incredible pretensiousness, he's a great teacher.
He's ok if you get past the pretentiousness
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

Not sure what the previous reviewers were smoking, but Prof. Clarke is far from a Trumpie or "politically incorrect". His lectures include a bunch of interesting material that changed how I view a lot of political topics. His slides are uploaded online and the exams are a breeze if you make yourself familiar enough with the lecture material.
He is the Donald Trump of PolSci Dept. at UofR; he spends most of his time making politically incorrect jokes.
He thinks he knows everything. He simply doesn't.
Very bad professor.
The most egoistic person on campus. He has a superiority complex. He tries to prove that he is smart by behaving rude. I believe he has lots of personality problems that cannot be treated.

Professor Clarke has a unique way of teaching. His slideshows are non-traditional and to get a good score you have to play keen attention to the lectures. Approaching him outside class helped supplement a lot of the content. The class is graded by 3 tests and a final paper each worth 25% with each test being 6 short answers.

KC has a great sense of humor and gives cool lectures on otherwise depressing topics. there's three in class short answer tests and an essay, but they're very fair. I went to class, took good notes, studied a day or so before the test and I was just fine. he gives a list of topics to study for each exam and its super helpful

Great professor, but the class in itself was boring for me. Had this been in person, I probably would have been more engaged. The most important thing is the lectures; you can get a good grade without reading any of the material as long as you attend lectures and write notes. Pretty cool guy.

i was undecided about my major at beginning, but professor clarke def makes the class more interesting than i expected. go to every lecture and take note, you will be fine and feel more confident for exams and final research paper.

He is a lively professor, always spicing the class with some funny thoughts when teaching. He provides an outline for the exams and explains what is going to be cover. This class has 3 exams and a final research paper. take it if you can, the topics are worth it.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: There are a lot of readings for this class, but if you attend all of the lectures, the readings aren't as important. The lectures are incredibly important for the exams, so don't miss them, esp because he doesn't post them online. He is a great and caring prof, he encourages all kinds of questions, and he makes lectures fun. Would highly recommend!

Helpful, clear lecturer, answers all your questions, and a good sense of humor. He remembers all of his students names, nice but can hurt you if you don't come to class. I loved the grading structure and thought the workload was definitely manageable. While attendance is not mandatory, his lectures are gold for the exams & he doesn't post slides...
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: This professor is the only professor I've ever actually felt the need to review for the sake of future students that may wind up in PSC 200. He is unfortunately very bad at making statistics understandable and he also intentionally tries to get his students to perform poorly, which is not included in the qualities of a good professor.
His lecture are posted online. That and the book basically teaches the class. He is pretty irrelevant.

This is a mandatory class for PSC majors, but I still had a high interest in taking the class. The class did not at all live up to my expectations. The textbook was basically horrible, though we had to use if for all the HW assignments. The TAs were okay, but not the best, and Clarke was okay but not at all the best prof i have had.

Pretty funny and interesting lectures.  Most of his jokes are pretty liberal-minded (and can be anti-conservative), but they usually aren't offensive.  Hidden secret: go to office hours!  It's EXTREMELY helpful and the only way to ace the problem sets.  The TAs were crappy at grading and explaining things, but you could always appeal to Clarke.

I hate statistics, I'm only in this class for the major, but he makes the class great. Im a conservative, but his jokes are still funny. His office hours are so useful! You cant not get an A on problem sets if you go. He's really funny and laid back. He's always willing to help if you don't understand. I definitely want to take more of his classes!
No Comments
Very friendly, very fair professor.  Good lecturer.  Accommodating provided you're not ****ting him.
dennis quaid look-alike! very hot indeed.
I'm swooooooning! If only he would look at me!
teaching was ok, but class was not very fresh and exciting
Very approachable and clear in examples and explanations... funny, an awesome uncompromising liberal :) VERY organized.
Oh my god. So hot!
He is Soooooo Hot!
No Comments

Karen is the best! I loved all the hydrology topics she taught us. The only thing I regret was not turning in my writing assignments on time since I could have gotten an A in the class. As long you go to lecture, you will score high in her class.
Really great professor. Well organized lectures and I learned a lot

Professor Berger is an outstanding professor that makes Envi Sci easy to learn. Although material is easy the workload is still there. Recitations are annoying but there is no homework. The tests are lecture heavy and she covers a lot so studying is needed if you want an A, but if you put in minimal effort a B would be really easy to get.

Professor Berger is absolutely incredible. Her class was interesting and there was a good balance between lecturing and group discussions. Her exams are very straightforward and based on lecture material. Show up to class + study well and you'll get an A!

Pretty accessible class for variety of reasons: easy to communicate with professor, grading criteria made clear, and good as an intro class to environmental science. Occasional surprise participation points in an otherwise attendance optional lecture class--heavily concentrated at end of term. Professor Berger is a cool person and class reflects it
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Karen explains the material clearly and is open to answering any questions: she is an accommodating and accessible professor who wants you to succeed in her class. However, I felt like I did not get much out of her EESC 221: Quantitative Environmental Problem Solving class. I wish I had taken a different skills course for my envi sci major

If you put genuine effort into this class you will get an A or A+, the only reason I didn't is because I didn't take advantage of the extra credit opportunities. The exams range from really easy to fairly hard, so make sure you study all the material. Professor Berger is extremely nice and helpful in office hours.

Don't take this course. It overly focuses on water sustainability instead of hydrology. The labs are pretty much useless. They basically just let you feel guilty about every drop of water you use. The grading is unreasonably harsh.

Good professor, but one criticism I have is that the exams were mainly memorization-based. As long as you go to her lectures, do the extra credit readings, and answer the 'test your understanding' questions at the end of each presentation, you will get an A in the course.

The whole course was like a memory contest rather than a thinking development and learning. This can also be seen in the high percentage of exams, quizzes and recitations in the grading rubric.
If you are going to take this course, check your memory first.

Her approach to the course was very painful. You had to conform to her thinking and perspective on issues, and if your thinking didn't align with hers, she would see even controversial questions as the wrong answer.  You don't really need to learn about the environment to get a high score just by crudely memorizing it.

Professor Berger had extremely informative lectures that covered a wide range of material. As a NON-STEM student, I found the class interesting and challenging. Most of the grading comes from quizzes, exams, and recitations. There is additional reading that is optional and could be used to improve grades. All around great person great class

Professor Berger was extremely accommodating and accessible throughout the course. Lectures and the corresponding workshops were well organized. Communication was great- never was unsure about what I was supposed to be doing.
Pretty bad.

Even though I'm not at all involved in STEM I really enjoyed the class. Professor Berger was kind, thoughtful, and communicative. She was thorough in her descriptions for all projects and gave extensive feedback, even for smaller assignments. The class generally had a low workload with labs being short and informal.

Professor Berger has easily been my favorite STEM professor (as a social science major) so far. She is caring, thoughtful, and informative. I took hydrology expecting to be pretty bored but I actually loved the class. Highly recommend taking a class with her if you're at all interested in environmental science!

Professor Berger is nice and gives good lectures. She doesn't have tons of homework except for the writing section student (need to complete a 12-15 pages paper). Tests are fair, and you can ask her lots of questions before the tests during office hours. Some extra credit. The only problem is the A line is 94%, so be careful. Labs are easy.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: This class was one of my favorites that I took this semester. Lectures were all super interesting and you can tell how much she cares about the material. The tests were open note but not super hard. We had assigned readings out of 3 books which were all super interesting. I really enjoyed this course and look forward to taking more of her courses.

I loved EESC 103 and Karen Berger. She is so smart but still takes the time to know all the names of students in her class. Recitations are nice because you get credit for just going. The class is so interesting and makes you feel woke. I would 100% recommend! As long as you study the slides you will do great.

Professor Berger is well respected by many on this campus, but I personally found her style of teaching to be very bland. If you copy down all the information she provides in class and study it well, you will get an A. But if you are looking for anything beyond a VERY basic level of information on EES, you will be bored out of your mind.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Great professor and person, really cares about the class and students. If you put in the work, you should be fine.

Professor Berger is amazing. I've taken both EES103 and EES213W with her. EES103 was a walk in the park. EES213W is harder because its an upper level course. You have to do the readings and there is a big project or paper depending on which section your in. Over all she's an amazing lecturer and you can tell she obviously cares about her students.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Her expectations and instructions are pretty clear. he has PhD in civil engineering so expect her classes to be math-heavy. For EES majors- she is the EES academic advisor. The dep is NOT proactive or student-friendly. She, as well as the entire dep, is not at all helpful for post-grad life unless  you're getting a BS and a strong researcher.

Professor Berger is one of the best professors I've had here. She's extremely nice and genuinely cares about the material she's teaching. The material can be dry (despite being about water) and very difficult, but she does a good job of helping us through it. One of the fairest professors I've ever had.
Karen is the greatest teacher I have had so far at the University. She is extremely interested in the material that she teaches. She is smart and really knows what she is talking about.

Passionate, knowledgeable, kind person. Lectures are typically dry and full of information. Hard grader. Some math (3/12 homeworks), a lot of writing assignments that are graded on quality of writing. Tests and homeworks are demanding. Attendance is mandatory. If you always come to class and accept that it's mostly busy work, you should do fine.

Professor Berger is not an easy professor, I had to put real time into her class. That said, her Hydrology class was easier than my engineering classes. I also found the course to be quite interesting, and Prof Berger is quite friendly, genuinely interested in the material, and happy to hear her students out. But beware, it its no walk in the park.
I think the biggest catchwords for this professor are -nascent dementia- I would also say arsch hole,  but that already describes 65% of professors.
I think the biggest catchwords for this professor are -nascent dementia- I would also say arsch hole,  but that already describes 65% or professors.

Harper is a disgrace to teaching and professorship, and I wonder why he is still even at this University. His tests are arbitrary, and while the book selection will let you know everything he wants you to learn in class, he treats his subject matter like the wonderful world of Harper's opinions. I would not take another class of his if you paid me.

Harper is a really nice guy, really funny, but the worst teacher I have EVER had. I didn't learn a single thing, and I'm not exaggerating. You never know what will be on tests, and everyone does terribly. We had 3 tests- on one of them, the class average was a 55, if that gives you an idea. Class is boring beyond belief and the workload is too much

No textbooks are used which makes it extremely hard to follow along with the professor.  Learned nothing from the class. First week of HLS 116 taught me everything I learned from Harper.  DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS

The first test had questions about the syllabus on it.  The tests tend to be hard and you can never really be sure what grade you're going to get. He is always willing to meet with you but, having done that myself, I did not find it very helpful.  No textbook, and the books used can be really boring and hard to get through.
He's a good guy, personable with the students. Tests are difficult. Grading style makes a good grade definitely possible.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! He makes it sound as if the class would be an easy A but then he piles on the work and comes up with the most difficult questions on the exams. To top that all off, he doesn't teach you anything in the class and there is no textbook to learn from either so pretty much you're really screwed on the test no matter what.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Don't do it. There's a lot off bulls hit about how he gives As at the end of the semester: NOT TRUE. It WILL kill your GPA. HE is a sweet old man but you will waste your time, learn nothing, and get a horrible grade. Frankly, the man is a terrible professor and should be fired immediately.

Such a nice guy. Awkward at times but means well. Isn't very clear about...well, anything. Hard to know how he grades, but from what it seems like, he doesn't hesitate to give A's at the end of the semester. Classes can be boring, although he does come out with some ludicrous comments during class that are good for a laugh. Overall, good professor.

He's a sweet man, very absent-minded professor type.  I didn't really learn a lot but he loves to teach.  He wants students to do well, doesn't care too much about grading, and was the only prof I've had that has given out his home phone number and encouraged students to call for help.
Very easy class, just do the work required and make it to class as much as you can.  Extremely nice guy.
so much for an easy A.  i only got a B+, and all my friends in the class didn't even do that well...
Nice little old man. Sometimes he's a little confusing, but he seems to know what he's talking about.
Nicest man ever!!!!
Wonderful little guy,****e professor. Intro Soc doesn't cover any basic sociological theories.
Can be a little unclear sometimes, but on the whole a good prof.  He grades papers with a very keen eye for grammar and all that stuff.
Seems to care about students learning, but the class was a little confusing/arbitrary.
Cute little man, very fun. Could make class a little less boring though, but he seems to genuinely care about his students.
Very nice. Good class discussions. Flexible about deadlines.
So adorable and knowledgable.  Knows his stuff.
funniest old man i've ever met. initiates good discussion in class. knows his stuff.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
Cute old guy who teaches you lots, and the work isnt' bad

If you have the opportunity and find interest in Tai Chi please take this class. Bob is a sweet older man who just wants to teach the basic forms and principles of Tai Chi. A great easy class to take in between hard classes. Graded on 1 reflection a week and 1 final presentation. The form tests are so easy as well. HIGHLY RECOMMEND <3 love bob
Love Bob. He is such a sweet man and cares so much about the subject and his students. You will feel guilty if you don't go to class, and why wouldn't you, its so fun!
A lot of reading. A lot of paper to write. A lot of work for 4 credits. A lot of reading. You even have 2 presentations
Very caring professor, very passionate about what he teaches. All papers are graded very kindly, hard to not get an A.

Bob is a great teacher. I don't know what the other students here are talking about; the class was incredibly easy. All you have to do is write a 1 page journal after each class, which takes about ten minutes. He's a very easy grader and I got above a 96 on every skills test (movements) and presentation we did (you're required to do two).
4 credit class or more. Bob is a tough grader if you dont put effort in your PRESENTATION and WEEKly journal you wont pass. He is very tough.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: Bob is never helpful, he is a tough grader. This is a writing class.. There is PRESENTATIONS in a dance class....

A lot of work. Not a dance class. Not an easy class. Bob is a tough grader. He reads journal like a WRT105 professor. You will get an E if your writing is not good. The class title should be changed to a writing class. Also presentations and he is tough on you during them
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Took both 208 and 209. So many journals and he is a rough grader this class should be a WRT105 class plus 2 Presentation in this class. And prof is not helpful. He will also fail u easily. Messed up my gpa was looking to have fun and enjoy the class but instead got to write 30 journals and a 10 pages paper at the end of course.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Bob is a good guy. He cares and the class is not very hard if you keep up.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: a 4+ credit class took that for fun but it messed up my GPA
Take care to select this class, unless you wanna select a writing class!!!!! More than 30 journals one semester! And this just a 2 credits class!
Avoid this class, too much work for a 2 credits class. This class more like a writing class instead of a dance class. But professor is nice.

DAN 208, DAN 209, and DAN 211 have all been fun, interesting, and relaxing courses, and Professor Loughridge is an excellent teacher! He's quiet but really nice. There are written assignments but they really won't take up much of your time and are fairly easy.

Too much work for a 2-credit class. Daily Journal entries and final portfolio, 4 performanceworkshop response papers, lots of reading. Make sure to stay on top of journals, will bite you in the end otherwise. Not as relaxing a class as it may seem. The class-time itself was usually fun and interesting, however requires a lot of outside effort.
this is a 4+ credit course definitely

Wow, thought I would take a relaxing dance-ish class because all my other classes are super hard and have a ton of work..... too bad this class is more work than many of my other classes.... Professor Loughridge has way too much time on his hands and thinks his class is the best class ever! nice guy, just waaaaay too much work. stay away!
sometimes i wonder if this class is a writing class. A lot to read and write and he is a tough grader.
Course is a lot of work tough and if he does not like you,you wont get good grade. Tough grader.

Bob is a great professor he i helpful any time and he knows his tai chi very well,put a lot of effort and he will notice it,but the thing is that the course seems to be a 4 credit course it has a lot of work. The journal entries and so on and the final journal portfolio ,i think this course has a lot of work

It is definitely an easy course.  Attend class regularly and keep on top of your journal entries. You really won't use much of the "required" text/videos he asks you to get, so save your money. Bob is a great prof and grades on effort.

He was extremely nice and interesting, very understanding and genuine and seemed like he really cared about tai chi and teaching it to students of different abilities. I was really bad at it, but he was very understanding and graded based on effort not talent which was really great! He has a ton of knowledge and is really interesting..great guy

Tai Chi. Bob really knows his stuff! Very laid back. grades on EFFORT! so even if you are a uncoordinated and can't do all the movement testings, as long as you come to class and try he will give you an A! Has a goof understanding of Tai Chi and Chinese culture for not being a native Chinese

great prof., wonderful class.very clear and precise about what he wants.class is very laidback and relaxed, great atmosphere for learning taichi.very helpful, gives detailed feedback on all assignments.in general, a very welcomed change from all the rigorous stressful classes. i looked forward to each class; planning on taking his other classes :)
I agree that he is somewhat "overly mystical" but overall he is helpful and fair.

A little overly mystical; *extremely* friendly and approachable.  Knows his form well but is not the best teacher -- if you don't understand, his solution will be to demonstrate it again.  If you need something clarified, don't ask him to show the movement, ask him a very specific question about it.

I've never had a professor phone it in this hard. Johnson is crazy disorganized, unfocused, uninteresting, and clearly not trying. I can't believe he has so many positive ratings. Nice guy though. Very easy class. But, you won't learn anything.

Amazing professor with really insightful lectures. Likes to go on tangents but he's funny. The readings are fairly dense but definitely manageable and engaging. Very lenient grader and super flexible with extensions too; he definitely cares about his students. Also really helpful if you go to his office hours if needed.

Took during covid. Lectures are him talking about the reading the whole time (great if you don't get the readings or if it was really dense) I skipped like the whole class the entire semester (it was rough okay) and I still passed with just skimming the reading. He was amazing though. So kind and understanding please talk with him if you need help.
Professor Johnson's class was really good which I learned a lot from. There is not much reading, approximately 50 pages per week. Recommend this class!

James Johnson was a fantastic professor, he was interesting to listen to and he was understanding of difficulties caused by life. His class was super reading heaving and was mainly discussion based which made it fun and easy to stay entertained/involved. The paper at the end was challenging, but also fun because of how much freedom you have with it
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures--Lecture heavy

comment: We love Professor Johnson for his humor. He can always keep students awake--even when I'm taking his class in the middle of the night! He loves reading, and he makes sure his students love reading as well. So get ready to read a lot, otherwise you won't understand what he's talking about. A good grade will ensue if you do all the readings.

Very relaxed class. All discussion based with a lot of reading but not a lot of assignments. Very understanding of students and flexible around certain things. He just wants his students to learn and grow and doesn't care about grades, which is scary but it works out in the end. Course is really unique and changes your perspective, highly recommend

Terrific guy! Down to earth, is there for the students, humble, and makes the dull subject matter (e.g. 17th century political philosophy) understandable and, somehow, interesting.  My favorite professor this semester and would definitely take another class with him again.  You really only need to hustle for the three big papers he assigns.
He is a good professor who really cares about the students.

Johnson is a character. He likes to be agreed with so don't argue, he has favorites, he expects a lot of "smart" comments but if you try, pay attention and care about the subject you will be fine.  I really actually like him, he's  kinda disorganized but i'm being negative, he is actually really good, so overall i think you should take his class.

Prof Johnson is extremely good at getting you to understand political philosophy, and teaches the "lectures" in a seminar style that allows people to really get to the heart of an issue. He can be redundant but that helps drill crucial points in. I will try to take another of his classes ASP.

Prof. Johnson is amazing! Really smart and eager to help students out. I've never found him to be arrogant, for being as brilliant as he is, he is really down to earth. His classes can be easy, but he always assigns great readings and offers great insight on them.

Very funny and relaxed, Johnson will keep you somewhat interested in going to class, although his seminar does have a lot of reading and discussion so definitely be prepared for that. He is VERY lenient about time pressures, so gives extensions liberally as long as you're not an atrocious student.
He is very smart, interesting and cute.

Johnson is one of those professors who you'll want to wake up at 9:00 in the morning and listen to. His overwhelmingly benevolent and hilarious nature is what makes his class so honestly enjoyable; don't get a Poli Sci degree at Rochester without taking one of his courses.

Sort of annoying. Take notes on everything he says and then regurgitate it to him in your paper. Although you can input some of your own opinion, it is important to show through your essays that you know what he said.

Gives great lectures.. If you take good notes it is easy to do well on the writing assignments even if you have not done all the readings completely.  He is very helpful and understanding if you go to his office with questions/concerns.  Lectures can get long but he is pretty funny and is a good teacher.

Very interesting and well informed professor. I don't see how that other person could have said that he would mark you down for different views. He does have his views but he likes opposing views too because it sparks discussion (and its a discussion based class). A lot of reading but still a good class.
Really enjoyed his class, he's pretty funny and very nice.
Really arrogant, thinks what he says is the word of God.  Also, not very warm when it comes to interactions.  Hes kind of all business.  Sort of intimidating.  But I did learn stuff.

Great Class. Really got me thinking.  I disagree with the earlier comment about his liberal views.  He's really quite fair, and is pleasently quirky and fun loving in his biker jacket.  If you get the chance, take one of his classes.  Ask him about Brent Henry or Noah Leibowitz.
No Comments
He's a hottie. I love his beard and his sense of humor. You may never figure out the point of his class but you will enjoy the experience.
Good professor, quite funny, does a good job with difficult material.

He is a very funny and interesting prof and very down to earth.  No lectures, just class discussions.  These discussions were often disorganized and could lead off topic but he would always try to bring the discussion around at the end.  A lot of reading but only 2 papers (make up your whole grade).

Javier is def a good person, but not a good professor. The class is disorganized and you should expect so many unexpected changes. This was the first semester he introduced exams (2 in total) into this course. This is a bad idea since it was a rush for him to make exams, too. Lastly, grades weren't on file before the deadline from registrar.

Bautista is far from a good lecturer and going to class is rarely worth it. The exams and assignments, however, were super fair! The semester-long group project is kind of a hit and miss tho, and really depends on who your group members are. Really easy overall, but I think I learnt most of the material from the textbook to be honest.

Even though he isn't the best lecturer, Professor Bautista is the nicest, most caring professor I have had. He truly cares about his students. If you have solid AP Stat and Math 201 knowledge, this class is an easy A, with a ton of available extra credit from HW.
Easy A, but you don't learn things. The only useful thing is SAS coding. You can learn from YouTube yourself within a week. Tons of extra credits.
Even though his lecture is hard + Difficult + Not Easy to Read, but he is a very nice professor who is willing to help you when you needed.

-2 Midterms and a Final(65% total), A project(25%), and homework(10%). 
-Each exam easier than the last. You get a cheat sheet. 
Got a 60, then a 75, then a 90 and got a B in the class. 
-I'm BAD at math and got a B. Got a D+ in MATH 201 if that helps. If you got a B- or above in the 160 series, you can very easily get an A
-javier is a good human
The most boring lecturer I have ever seen, the software we learn in class can be super useful, unfortunately he is just terrible at teaching, therefore this class is a waste of time and effort.
Why is everyone give out 5/5 when he is a bad lecturer, we didn't learn anything in his class, please ignore the fake comments from whoever it is, I just want to help you all to aviod the pain.

He is not that great of a lecturer but is extremely helpful and kind. He is always willing to meet with students outside of class to discuss projects or help with homework. He is truly a kind and caring guy
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Kindest professor I've had, very caring and gets to know all of his students. Class is 40% project, 35% Homework, and 25% in class assignments. Project grading is really easy as long as you follow the guidelines. You will do poorly on the homeworks if you are sloppy. In class assignments are free 100s. Easy A if you give effort.
Really nice. Lectures you don't learn much, but if you study on your own you can do very well. 25% of the grade is a group project!!! So good!!!
Fake professor and don't know what he is talking about, any rating over 1, do not trust it.
Terrible professor, acting like a university professor, but doesn't even understand the material he is teaching, learnt nothing, super boring, waste of time.

comment: oh Javier, what can I say. Most caring professor I've ever had. Yet very unclear in his lectures. Left most of us more confused than when we came in. The mark of a good prof is when they have clear lectures, expectations, and exams. He had none of those. That being said he is the most accessible professor I've ever had. Wanna be friends with him.

My favorite prof in the CS dept. Great lectures, really cares about the material, and is great to explore ideas more in depth with in office hours. Also took CSC279 with him this semester and loved it. He didn't follow a textbook for either class, so he explored lots of interesting ideas/topics. Highly recommend taking a course with him if you can.

Great professor, and easily accessible outside of class for questions. The material is tough, but also really interesting and applicable outside of class. The homework is difficult, but the TAs are helpful so go to office hours.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Horror stories you may have heard about this class are from years ago, it's much easier now. It's still hard, but Stefankovic is an interesting professor. It's easy to get full points or close to it on the homework, just listen to the TAs at workshops. Prepare for a really hard final exam.

Actually this is the evaluation of CSC 484 - Advanced Algorithms in Fall 2022. He use no textbooks nor slides but writes a lot on the blackboard. 5 homework assignments (some with coding), no exams. Generally you should spend much time after class to learn how to code about the notions learned in the class. But the final grading is not tough now.

He is really a good professor. He explains the materials well and give you solid knowledge in very important topic (Algorithms). He is 1000 times better than Zhupa. He is a tough grader and exams are usually hard but he is exams are getting more reasonable over years. If you want to LEARN take Stefankovic not Zhupa.

I'd recommend taking 282 with Stefankovic because I think you end up learning more from his lectures than from Zhupa (at least based on what people say). And apparently, he also became a little more reasonable with his exams this semester (Fall 2021).
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: The material is really hard. Stefankovic does his best to explain in a way that makes sense. Your grade is decided by 3 exams. Final is 40% and cummulative so pay attention all year. Best advice: do a lot of practice exams well in advance of the tests. Exams are more difficult than in-class material. This class takes a lot of effort.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Rumor says CSC282 exams might have median scores of 0, but this is not the case. Homework and exams are difficult but still workable if you pay attention in the classes and practice a lot after class.

comment: One of the best professors in the department. Extremely clear lectures, useful office hours, and he's just a really nice person. Just know that this is strictly a math course. If you go into it with only MTH 150 as a background, you're going to be at a disadvantage. It's best if you take as many math courses as you can before CSC 282.

Stefankovic is incredibly intelligent, and delivers phenomenal lectures. Is very open and respondent to questions during lecture. Knows the material extremely well. One of the most difficult graders you will ever have. One small mistake on a written response will get you a 0. If he graded easier he would be the best professor I have ever taken.

comment: An interesting course but the grading criteria is tough for a good grade.

Don't get me wrong, this was a very interesting class. Lectures were boring, but I really enjoyed reading the textbook and teaching myself the material. However, the testing and grading criteria for the class could be better. I understood the material really well, probably better than most of my classmates, and I still got a B-.

This guy REALLY knows his stuff, but that stuff is very difficult and abstract. He really does care about his students, if you know what's going on in his class. But it's hard to see that. If you can't keep up, don't count on a lot of help from him.

He is a really great professor. I'm just taking film for a cluster, but I genuinely enjoyed the class. Attendance is mandatory, but lectures are not that boring, so I don't really mind. Tests are graded easily and homework is pretty easy too (watch a movie every week on your own time and answer 1-2 questions about it)

Professor Middleton is the reason I ended up majoring in film - he really values student input and contributions, and he speaks to the class as if they're intellectually equal to him which stimulated amazing discussions. He values every student and is super nice. He knows so much about differing aspects of film and is open to new ideas/theories
One movie a week, taking screenshots, and write a journal. Tough grader. Mandatory attendance.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Professor Middleton is probably one of the greatest professors I will ever have. The material and the way he presents it in lecture makes it really engaging to participate and be in the class. The class has lots of discussions but you will rarely have that awkward silence. Also the films we watched in the class were amazing and thought provoking.
I love his class.
Extremely chill. Doesn't overwhelm you with assignments. Gives interesting lectures. All you have to do is submit short, weekly film responses and write 4 simple papers throughout the semester.

He is definitely a nice person. He's always ready to discuss with you about your paper or any questions about the course. Also, he is the director of the major of film and media studies. So if you want to declare that major, you can ask for his help. He would also offer extension when you may get overwhelmed.

Great dude. Very knowledgable. Loves his job - it shows. Super easy class with lots of examples in lecture. Get ready to watch a movie and write a 2-page film analysis every week. Only 2 exams (mid-term/final). Does review session before exam & gives effective study guide. No digital note-taking!!! Answers emails in timely manner. Supportive. 17/10
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: Passionate about the course and willing to help his students succeed. Lectures can be a bit heavy in content but also consist of discussions, and participation is encouraged.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I have had the great pleasure to take several classes taught by Professor Middleton and he is by far the best professor I have encountered. He is passionate about what he is teaching and cares a great deal about his students and their ability to succeed in class. He is always available for help outside of class and goes above and beyond to help.

Jason is by far the most inspiring professor I've ever had. He is beyond knowledge, engaging and friendly. He truly loves what he does and it shows. He always has time for his students, whether it's for help on essays or just talking about film. He spent countless hours helping me on my own films and even took a weekend to act in one! Amazing.

I had Professor Middleton for intro and for documentary, and I'm about to have him for horror.  His classes are extremely interesting, and he's very engaging with students, listening to their opinions with an open mind, and working with them to extract ideas.  He's extremely knowledgable of his field, and he's very relaxed and kind.
One of the best professors I've had so far.  Very easy class, but really interesting.

Middleton is awesome!! By far my favorite class of the semester! He's a great lecturer and really nice and understanding with students. Put an honest effort into the journal questions and study the review sheets he gives you for the midterm and final, and you've got an A. Really interesting class, too.
You're hard pressed to find a film Middleton hasn't seen.  His knowledge of his craft is remarkable.  Best professor I've had so far on campus.  It's sad he's leaving this semester.

I took "Intro to the Art of Film" with professor Middleton and absolutely loved it!  The way he teaches in class and uses the in(and out of)-class screenings to exemplify his lectures really catches the interest of the students in the class.  I hope to take another class with him in the spring semester.
If you want to know about film, he's the guy, enough said.
Do your reading, pay attention in class, DO NOT FACEBOOK WHILE IN CLASS you will miss important information.

J Middleton is the man. Best professor I've had at the school yet. He's funny, interesting, clear, and shows us the best movies. I actually enjoyed going to class and the screenings. As long as you went to class and wrote the journals you were guarenteed an A in the class. Midterm and final were as easy as they come. TAKE THE CLASS!

Extremely knowledgeable  & enthusiastic. Classes are well-structured and his lectures are very clear. Brings everything together nicely and makes good use of clips/sources. Readings are manageable, relevant, & interesting. As long as you can smartly analyze a film papers aren't bad; don't BS him though.
Always asks if clarification is needed, which is wonderful.  Keeps things interesting!
Very personable and friendly in small class setting.  Really knows his stuff and is very helpful with final cut pro, camera use, etc.  Friendly and fun, too.  Definitely take 162 if he's teaching it.
Lectures are focused and clear, with excellent supporting materials. Knowledgeable, funny, and attentive to every student's opinion. Relies heavily on participation. Runs a smooth and fun classroom.
No Comments
No Comments
has got to easily be one of the worst professors here at u of r.

Tough class... definitley one of the hardest business classes i have ever taken here as a finance major. Be prepared to study and really understand the content and material. Difficult exams, little to no leeway on grading. No curve either in the course, maybe a few points on the exams.

This class was actually not too bad. Professor isn't great, so you learn through the practice questions. Exams are hard, but it's possible to do well if you master the practice questions and the excel tools he lets you use on exams. Try to get partial credit on questions you don't know. He uses a generous points scale to determine your final grade.

The professor seemed more interested in trying to "stump" students rather than trying to teach. He made questions very unwelcome in class and would make students feel stupid for asking any questions. Very harsh grader and does not curve exams.

I have no idea how to study for these exams or do well in the class, its like the theory of inventory management? It is a bit outdated for an undergraduate business course and i find it very difficult. I am not sure if i will pass the class

Great professor, to be honest At the beginning, I also considered him a tough grader, but finally, I realized he was so great. The class takes an attendance check, but if you show up and pay attention to the class, you will be fine. For the assignments, you just need to get 50% correctness. Exam is similar to the practice exam with curve.
awful class

Can be rude and is very stubborn. The tests are complicated and there's very little time given to actually complete them. There's math involved in these exams and you're either right or wrong and there's no in between.

His tests are pretty tough, but if you do the practice exams and re-do the homework you should be able to score above average. Curves the class, gives extra credit for turning assignments in on time, and offers generous participation points. If you put in at least the bare minimum, you'll be fine, though lectures are uninspiring.
Lectures are hard to understand, exam questions are really hard. No clue about how to study for his class.
Lectures are pretentious and hard to understand. Not very clear. Exams are really hard.

Awful. Zero empathies, unorganized and unhelpful lectures, and case studies that are not interactive at all. Very unclear grading criteria on the final presentation. I don't know how he is still teaching a required undergrad class.
Show off professor, classes are not helpful at all, but the course in general was not very difficult. Don't go to lectures and study on your own.
I dropped this class 1 week in, he does not seem like he cares about students. absolute zero excuse for missed exams/homework's/assignments, yes, even if you have COVID! So beware.

His tests are extremely unfair and he does not prepare you for them at all. He is a nice guy but needs to reconsider his approach to teaching students. The way your grade is actually calculated is extremely unclear. I am not sure other professors teach this course so good luck when you take him.
The high score isn't hard to get.

I don't know why there are so many bad ratings for Prof Groenevelt. He's an understanding professor who allows some make up work. His lectures are rather concise. At the start I was going to drop the course because I thought it was irrelevant to my career path; however, the topics he covers are not only useful but also interesting.
Tries to show off, you don't learn anything in class, tests are very hard, no clear grading criteria, horrible teacher. Such a waste of time.

He is not a good teacher. He likes to show off and doesnt teach anything substantial for the exams. He shows up late to office hours all the time. He is mean too. His exams are impossible and he does not prepare you for them. He throws new things at you he didnt teach.
In addition to other bad things, he is mean and doesnt show up to office hours on time.

Syllabus not clear regarding to the grading criterion of final presentation. Test is open laptop, and the most difficult part doesn't have to do with lectures. If you are late for one case discussion class, your final grade get reduced by half of a full grade. Wondering why this is a required course for business major.
He is very knowledgeable and clever. He can do tons of calculations in his head. Great lecture and contends. Statistics involved.
Lecture had nothing to do with homework which had nothing to do with exams.  Lab instructor really taught the class
Easier than GBA 411 but difficult nonetheless. This class focuses on OLS and regressions.

Considered the most challenging professor, he doesn't give the best method to introduct modeling, but its not an easy subject. He is a very smart professor, but very challenging. Expect to fail, class averages were around 30-40%. Thank God for the Simon curve.
Fair professor. Explains things clearly and logically, uploads slides for study at own pace with no mandatory attendance. Grade is on 3 midterms that are extremely predictable and easy.

Dr. Firooz is EXTREMELY test heavy (84% over 3 exams, 16% over 4 homeworks). 

His lectures follow the slides very closely (and are pretty slow), and exams are almost identical to the practice exams(!). 

I didn't go to class after September and still got an A-. He is very willing to answer questions, but has a zero late work policy to be aware of.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The professor isn't very flexible
exams takes 84 percent in total GPA, which is extremely hard. And there is no extra credit.
Tests are hard but curves are nice.

3 tests and 4 homeworks, thats it. The tests are very unpredictable and not what the practice questions were, there is a lot of comparative stats that are mostly done in class/hw/practice questions and when you get to the test, then ofc there is a question that is so weirdly worded you cant even figure out what is changing. The tests are tricky.

Very nice professor. He is always available to take questions during lecture. He will give you examples if you ask him to. The exams are pretty difficult. They don't always follow the practice questions so there are curveballs. Four homeworks that were fair. It is a very lecture heavy class and he does not record lectures.
Format of the class is pretty tough and exams are worth about 84% of the grade with homework being 16% which made it hard.

Don't do it. he is extremely nice but I'd rather pass away than take his exams. nothing like the practice questions, the homework is ok but no extra credit at all. I wish I had taken the class with someone else. I slept in class multiple times, I had to run out of class once because I had a panic attack of how terrible of a lecturer he is.
This is a lecture I don't really want to take again
The course was not helpful
Not a high quality lecture. At least professor is a nice guy.

He's average as he just basically reads off the slides from textbook and explain, but he's nice and and always answers questions. So So
Best Econ Professor I've ever had! He made everything so clear and his lectures were interesting!!!

16% of grade is hw and 84% is tests.  Exams are extremely hard and so many people fear having to retake the class. They really are the worst. He gives 4 HW problems and releases a practice test of 4 questions so u rlly only have 8 types of questions to review. Given the choice to lick his butthole or take an exam, id rather lick his butthole
Best Econ teacher I've ever met!

He is really good at teaching. lectures helpful and clear; he is nice and always responds to questions. Exams are hard but they test your understanding to the materials. I never studied for the class just attended lectures and took notes and it went well. fun fact: he always refers to the unknown third person as "she" idk why but it's funny.
Professor Firooz is a really great professor: he's a nice person and really cares about the students. Besides, the lecture is clear and the exam is not hard if you understand the course materials.
He makes the exam relatively simple compared to the complex content. His logic is consistent and good.
It's not easy and complicated. Due to the nature of macroeconomics, logical contradictions are likely to follow. Just keep asking questions.

Professor Hamid is just so great. He gives instruction very clear, and tests are fairly easy as long as you go through the practice exam. His class is really organized and inspiring. TA will grade everything including tests and homework, and partial credits can be earned.

Hamid is really funny and is a very clear instructor. I took the honors version which was an added lecture every week which went more in-depth into the math of macro, basically what is in the first year PhD. Tests are almost all of your grade, but the practice questions are pretty similar to the tests. Fairly easy and exams are graded generously
Great professor!
He just tries to complete the semester with minimum potential effort on his behalf.
From his interactions with the students I realized that Prof. Anand doesn't understand much about research.

Professor Anand appears indifferent to the fair distribution of work among group members in the capstone project. Whenever complaints arise, he tends to overlook them. Additionally, during his office hours, he is often unavailable.

This guy has been given a semi-important position at a university because of his experience at a Tier 2 company. UofRochester should hire better professors with a better research background. Having gray hair and an old belt shouldn't qualify you for a professorship at UofR.

His lectures are satisfactory, but he did not provide grading rubrics. Despite sending many emails throughout the semester, I received no responses. When I questioned the grading of my final project and attempted to schedule a meeting, my emails were ignored. He changed the group project to an individual one midway through the semester.
Completely inaccessible outside class, never responds to email. Many points were deducted from the final project without any feedback at all.
Not the best course I have every taken, and not the worst course I have ever taken. Slightly less than mediocre - you can take it, because there aren't too many options in the department anyway.
Fair course for data science, statistics, and other STEM major students and for those who want to go data data-related industries. Lots of extra credits for undergrads.

I have been a student in his capstone course, and he simply doesn't know most of the tools a modern data scientist needs to know. He just comments on how 'nice' the visuals look and cannot say anything substantive about the content or the technical aspects.
Less than average.
OK.
Falling asleep is guaranteed.

I did learn a lot from his lectures, but I have to say that his exams are just terrible. Me and my friends spent hours studying the materials, understanding every formula on the lecture notes, but none of them showed up on the exam sheet. My double sided hand written cheat sheet looks like a joke to me.

Another professor with NO charisma at all. His usual way of teaching:

Anand: Does anyone know about project management ?
Student: I know. 
Anand: Oh, great. Where did you use it?
Student: I used it at my job.
Anand: Oh, great. That is where you usually use it.
Whenever Prof. Anand is done with a lecture, he starts talking about useless stuff to fill up class time. He provides excellent lectures on how to bore students to death.
By far the worst professor on campus. I should have taken a class on 'how to properly smoke a cigar' instead.
Prof. Anand is a somewhat good professor.

Very good class. Very fit professor. He can fight with two bears using his bare hands. He can lift two cars at once if he wants to. And he can whisper beautiful songs into the ears of lions to control them.
Fairly good course for Data Science majors

Easy class, harsh exam.

Professor Tucker is really a caring teacher. I switched into his math 141 lecture after dropping from 161. He was always nice and open to meeting and helping with homework. All around, a nice guy and worth taking!

comment: He is definitely one of my favorite math professors at u of r. The content is really hard, but he managed to taught the materials in a way that students may better understand. Haven't gone to his office hour yet, but will definitely do when I have time

Tucker is a great guy, but I struggled to click with him as a professor. I did not take ap calc (I only took precalc) which made the class difficult. His handwriting can be hard to read, so ask if you cannot for clarification. I did find the other professors for 141 easier to understand, but again Tucker is a good person and not an awful professor.
Professor Tucker is a very nice guy and a decent lecturer. My only problem with him was his hand writing is a little hard to read.

Pretty awful calc class. I took calc in high school and if I didn't have that knowledge I'd be pretty up a creek. Do the homework - it's free points, and it teaches you the material better than the lecture. Or watch Khan Academy.

Always a pleasant experience to take his course. Took his MATH201 and 280. Though some minor mistakes are frequent in lecture, he has been one of the most reponsible and caring professor in the department. OFFICE HOUR helps a lot, 100% recommend

Really, really good professor. Presents foreign concepts very readily in a digestible form and the exams (bar the final, which was fair) weren't that hard, just understand the concepts and study the class examples/homework and recitations and you're good.
Truly gained a lot and made me prepared for MTH203. I almost got full score in final!

He makes MTH217 very interesting. The material is pretty dry, but can be confusing and he clears up the common issues. Exams are on the material and if your do good HW, you will do well on exams. Highly recommend.

comment: He gives clear and understandable proofs. Also, he is very nice and willing to answer any question about math. Nice grading and curve.
Awesome professor. He gives very clear, structured, and intuitive explanations of abstract concepts.
No matter how hard 171Q is, Prof. Tucker saved my day multiple times.
His voice is the sweetest of lullabies. It is impossible to stay awake in his class if it starts before noon.
His exams and homework problems are never easy but the curve is generous (but fair too). He is definitely one of the better professors in Math Department.

He was a very nice, adorable kind of professor. He was not intimidating at all, which I liked and took away pressure. He made simple mistakes a lot, but explained things well when asked a question. Material may be confusing if you didn't take AP Calc, but it was easy because I did and I'm not even that great at math. I got an A and enjoyed 141.

Difficult material, relatively easy grading. Pretty good lectures, but it's advisable to prepare before class, because he does tend to get a little confusing when jumping between different theorems. TAs are very helpful.

Makes a few minor mistakes while writing the proofs and ideas on the board. Doesnt rarely affects his teaching. Good guy. If youre taking 171q for the first time and youre not from china, good luck understanding all of it. Its really hard to pick up but once you have it its godly.

I could barely read his hand-writing, so it made going to class kind of pointless.  He seemed to get very confused while doing examples, which made me even more confused than he was.  Nice guy though, and very fair.  I didn't go to class a whole month and still managed to get a good grade.
He is great.  big fan
Nice guy and he makes the grading nice and easy for ya.

really nice guy. very good teacher, connects with the students alot. takes some time out of the class to talk about more fun things than math which helps because this class can get very boring after all the proofs
Quite a character.  Cares about his students.

Classes can get rather dry, with theorems and the proofs presented one after another, but what do you expect from algebra? Read ahead of class class. I find it hard to follow his proofs when I see them the first time. Going to office hours helps too. He frowns on students who skip his classes =).

The professor is quite nice and approachable. It's the last semester he teaches here. 
The weekly assignments and workshops are very helpful as well.

comment: I don't really like computer science but overall Sarkis was funny, kind, and clear, and his assignments were doable, although I often needed assistance from a TA or tutor. My grade is low because I didn't do well on the tests, but the labs, quizzes, and projects were all super manageable.
easy A, but if you really wanna learn something, lol you won't
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: An autograder determines a large portion of your grade, and he is impossible to reach outside of class. His lectures don't really apply to many of the assignments and he is not good at explaining how to do things despite his clear knowledge in the area.

I had coded before but really enjoyed the class and the assignments. They made me think but I never couldn't figure out the answer. Get started on the project early that definitely makes it easier. He always answered my emails or Slack messages in a timely manner. Go to the last few lectures, he does EC quizzes during the last few lectures.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: His CSC 161 course is my best class I have taken. Coming from a non coding background, it helped me a lot in future CS courses and inspire me to minor CS. He's also super fair with hiring TA with an interview process. 10/10

Actually a 3.5. He is a good professor and provides a good intro to programming for students who have not previously done it. As someone who hates coding, I found his class bearable although, the assignments were quite challenging for me. He is personally not that available but has a ton of TAs to help out with assignments.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: If you just want your GPA and credits, go to his courses, his class is easy to get a high grade. But if you want to learn something, sorry, no way.

Though get a good grade, but I do not feel I really learned much from him. He really does not care about his students, not reachable. I once sent an email to him asking for how to solve the programming problems. He said he was too busy to help me???What????

NO a good professor. He do not care about student. Unreachable after classes, especially during the online version. He does not respond to your questions and there is no way for you schedule an office hour with him. He really sucks!!!

tough grader  autograder is hit or miss lots of homework  weekly workshops, lab assignments, quizzes, and The Project The workshops were good and helpful until mine kept getting cancelled. Professor lectured super quickly, was difficult to communicate with (ex. not giving space for questions in class), made coding not fun :-(

This class is fabulous. I have no CS background, and this is a very smooth introduction to CS. I also like the project we did. Professor Sarkis is very nice, and he tries to provide extra time to students due to the pandemic. Dont turn in things late, because he gives you plenty of time (If you get a 0, it is your problem.)
Grades Harsh and dont try to argue with him

Sarkis is very knowledgable about CS but isn't t the best teacher. He lectures quickly and sometimes assumes we have prior knowledge of coding. I had no prior knowledge in python or CS so this class was difficult but manageable.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: He was terrible about the switch to online classes during the spring 2020 coronavirus outbreak. He ran the class as normal, but assigned more work, and made it harder to access help. He doesn't respect his students and his lack of compassion especially showed during this time. Hard grader and does not accept late work, even during a pandemic.
Highly disorganized and doesn't treat his students with the slightest bit of respect. I'm blown away by how easy this class was. I can tell that he never really thinks ahead. Such a disappointment.

If you are a business student who would like to take data science or computer science double major, I definitely recommend CIS 191for you rather than this course. It is a simple A but I think the only thing covered is really basic python skills and no useful project or modules are introduced. If you want to inject water into your GPA, then take it

Very approachable and cooperative. Spends plenty of time explaining concepts and tries to make sure that everyone is following along. Lectures can get a bit dull, but he tries to liven them up occasionally.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: His lectures are really clear for a beginner. Also, he gives a lot of extra credits in the lab assignments and the project. Even when you are unsure about your exam score, you can finish extra credits in the weekly homework to approach A.

Professor Sarkis knows a lot about Python and tries to break the material into feasible content. Lectures are mostly straight-forward. The weekly lab assignments and project can take a while if you don't know what you are doing. Overall, I thought this class was a bit tough for an intro course.

Okay lecturer, didn't make things very exciting. There were a lot of homework assignments which were very difficult for people not used to coding. Towards the end there is a final project on top of the homework which can be a lot if you don't start early.

The lecture is great and he's pretty nice, however!!! The exams are difficult (much more difficult than questions from workshops and homework). There are weekly quizzes, HW, and workshop. Also, there're projects across the semester.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: He is a very good teacher and knows a lot about computer science. He is very accessible out of class and is a good teacher. However, if you know nothing about computer science he goes by very fast. You have to take a quiz, attend a workshop and submit a lab each week. Homework and projects are hard for people who don't know how to program.
Really fun class and great professor!

I love Professor Givens, so knowledgeable about the subject and matters at hand. He cares about his students and really strives to make class as thought provoking as possible. Lots of reading for this class, and he does grade harsh, but it has driven me to become a better writer overall, he WANTS you to understand the content.

Taken numerous courses with John, and he's an amazing professor. One of the smartest and kindest individuals I've met. He makes you work for it in his lit classes, but you will be a better writer and reader because of it. At times it can be lecture heavy, and I wish it was more of a seminar style, but office hours are where you can really learn.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Really energetic and engaging. My interest in Russian is now higher. Offers a lot of extra credit so if you go to classes, you will be fine.

He is awesome- very entertaining and funny in class, sure to make you want to learn Russian. He's nice and very supportive if you have a problem. Tests are mild- if you study, you'll probably do well. They're fair at any rate. He's very knowledgeable and engaging. Great professor.
Best professor I have had at U of R!

AMAZING. Funny, great teacher, goes the extra mile, really enjoys the material and makes you enjoy it too. A lot of work but you will learn a TON and learn it well. Take his classes, they will be the highlight of your college career.

I love him. His Russian courses are good, but try one of his others and you'll be forever enchanted! He is an extremely hard grader with essays, but he really cares what you learn from the novels and discussions. He wants you to be involved with the text and for it to change you in someway. He's just awesome.

Prof Givens is the reason I'm still involved with Russian. I took 101/102 with him, and though he takes a little getting used to, he's an extremely good professor who knows his material. The tests could be better, as could the fact that Laura TAs the class, but the class overall is awesome. He will go out of his way to help anyone really interested

I still love this man! Entertaining lectures that double back a little so you get reenforced as you go along. Very hard paper grader, however, he reads everything with a very attentive eye! Extremely hard grader, but amazing and helpful and I just love him!

I love this man. I've taken two of his courses, plan on taking two more, and I just finished up a summer doing research with him as my faculty mentor. He's extremely helpful and very entertaining in class. He's also very accessible and eager to help out anyone who shows an interest in Russian.
Really great guy, MUCH better than his wife. Funny, helpful and informative. I felt like I learned a lot, even though I didn't do so well. The only trouble with his courses is Laura as the TA.
I love this man. He is what convinced me to major in Russian. Great guy, very kind and helpful.

Took 101 and 102 with him, fair grader, easy tests.  As long as you can learn some vocab, you'll do fine.  He's a funny guy, and makes the early morning lectures worth it most of the time.  A bit crazy with his sayings and poems.
Lectures vary, but are generally entertaining. Very accepting and funny. Very fair grader. Exams were a tad lengthy.
wonderful!
No Comments
Very entertaining and funny, take as many of his classes as you can, tests can be a little tough at times, very approachable and understanding
I'm absolutely smitten with him.  He's incredible.
AWESOME
he was great! his classes are really interesting and hes nice, smart, and funny.
He's very funny, and easy to understand, even when's he's speaking in russian!! in his literature classes he is obviously very passionate about the material!!

Givens is amazing. He used to scare the crap out of my when I first started taking Russian, but now I think he's hilarious and over the top and incredibly knowledgable about all things Russian. Two thumbs up.
Very helpful, clear, and entertaining.
No Comments
She's always really excited about what she's teaching.
She is a good teacher and knows her stuff well. Be sure to study the concepts as well as the calculations. The exam covers a wide rage of materials so that students can at least what they know.

Loved Dalecki! Great lecturer, very clear and easy to understand. Exams are straightforward, homework is tedious but highly relevant. Overall really passionate about the subject and she thoroughly conveys that to her students. Solidified my career interest in BME. Could not have asked for a better professor for an introductory course.

Professor Dalecki is THE BEST!  Her BME 101 class was an awesome overview of of biomedical engineering.  She teaches the class perfectly, very clear and easy to understand.  I learned so much and I'm so excited about BME because of that class!  Homework can be hard sometimes and it's graded but her tests are really fair.

This class got me so pumped about majoring in BME. Dalecki has so much passion and does a great job showing all of the skills required for the field. Homework is not only math, there are writing assignments as well. Class is not only lecture, sometimes there are really interesting videos and guest lecturers.
Great Teacher.  She knows her stuff and knows how to convey it well to students.  i am a BME major and her ultrasound course was the best BME class i have ever taken.
Seems intimidating, but is very approachable.

I love Dalecki. Does a great job giving a solid overview of all of the concs of BME. Wonderful lecturer, must go to class to pick up info because she picks some from textbooks and then gives you some other stuff to know. Definitely do your homework well. Graded. Similar to tests. She's the reason I dropped my pre-med interest :)
Loved this professor!! I have to say that she definitely cares about what she teaches and the students. The course can be quite challenging but she and the TAs are always willing to help.
I loved this class and the professor. She made the subject extremely interesting. It is clear why she teaches an intro class because she does such a good job of making the subject interesting

I took this course as an elective (took it as PHY252 technicallhy...) and it was by far the best course I've taken at UR and the best prof I've had!  Prof. Dalecki is awesome and really wants all of her students to learn to think like scientists.  Her course can be tough but she's always willing to help and it's certainly manageable!
Great BME Professor.

she explains things in too much detail for topics or procedures she has notes for. Sometimes her lectures are unnecessary, liek when accompanied by slides, research guidelines, or recitation assignments.

Definitely a helpful teacher, she gets to know all her students and is willing to help.
