Fun atmosphere. Nice guy and very knowledgeable. Pay attention to the key points he mentions in class! Hard course, but curve at the end is nice.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Amazing lectures

comment: The man is passionate about his responsibility to teach and his flame gave me energy often as well. He is somewhat unconventional And for the better. I always left the class room with some sort of new, useful, knowledge. I don't understand the poor rating and I wish he taught more of my courses. It's not an easy subject but he makes it fun. ����

He really cares about whether his students understands the material. While the material can be hard to grasp Chen was very patient with explaining concepts. His notes condensed everything but going to class is still essential. Great prof overall
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Chen is a literal bro and is professor goals ermahgerd

Chen cares a lot about his students. Last semester, he went out of his way to make himself resourceful to his students and he curved very nicely in the end despite difficult exams. He was basically my long lost chinese father!

I do not understand why Chen gets a bad rap. Despite his quirks, he's very funny and has a big heart. And I learned a lot. He's the most memorable teacher I've had to date at UR. this dude is unpredictable! a very nice guy but needs to change his teaching methods cuz it is the same complaints year after year.

Good/Decent professor.  Tough exams!

He's tricky tricky tricky.  (not in the sweet Run DMC way)

Dr. Bi's lectures can sometimes be a little hard to engage with, but the guest lecturers are worth it. His exams are very detail-oriented so make sure to really study the slides and know all the details.

He's a very nice person but his classes are not that interesting. The guest lecturars made it worth it. Those lectures were mostly amazing. Most grade comes from the tests and they're pretty hard as you have to memorize a lot of things. The slides and practise exams are actually very helpful.

He tests on lots of details, but answers emails very quickly and office hours are extremely helpful. You can do well in this class by taking advantage of all the resources at your disposal, especially your TAs and professor.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Bi is honestly one of the best bio professors. His tests are entirely based on lectures and while they do somewhat force you to make connections between topics and think critically, they are very fair. He is easily accessible outside of class and more than happy to answer questions. His lectures are interesting and he's obviously passionate.

This class was kind of a joke. Equipment was always malfunctioning or the TA wasn't paying enough attention to the class while they poured chloroform directly into trash cans. As long as you review the power point slides he makes before your quiz you'll be fine. He usually curves and did curve our class grade at the end.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Don't take 268.  Take independent research instead.  If lab reports aren't worded exactly how he would (he'll make corrections for feedback), he takes points off.  He even takes points off for the TITLE of reports.

Although the content can be difficult to student who don't have a really solid biology background, his grading is generally fair and it's very clear what needs to be studied for the exams. General workload is relatively low. Lectures are interesting.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I don't understand why this professor is getting this much hate. He's passionate about what he is teaching and (if you like bio) it makes the lectures very interesting. You do have to make an effort to follow along in the lectures sometimes but he answers all student questions and is very accessible via email. Also exam grading is very lenient.

Dr. Bi expects you to be able to pull random slides from memory and explain random concepts in detail. His lectures were very scatterbrained and very dry. You can do well in the class by spending hours reviewing the lecture slides on your own. Be prepared to study and make sure you understand every single slide in detail.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Overwhelming amount of content and details. Expect a low GPA. You need to absorb every detail of his slides and workshops to do decent. If you're pre-med, drop this class, if you're passionate about bio, might be worth it. Hard class, but do-able with a lot of effort. Pay attention to workshops, and literally absorb each slide.

He can be very hard to follow and does not explain well. He mainly reads off the powerpoint slides and does not really teach the curriculum with further explaining on the slides. Does not tell you what you need to know/what is important and gives a lot of overwhelming information.

Most reviews are somewhat correct: this class is challenging, and Dr. Bi can be difficult to understand sometimes. BUT, this class is fair. The tests will definitely make you think outside the box (which is where most students struggle), but they are clear and reasonably graded. You will need to apply yourself in this class, but it is doable.

Compared to 113, Dr. Bi's class was great. I barely applied myself, but if I did I could've done well. His slides are confusing, but filled with info. Guest lectures are amazing, and the material exposes you to all of the microbio topics that are offered in later electives. Overall, I would take it if you're interested.

okay. Dr. Bi is a nice guy, but this class has absolutely no reason to be labeled "advanced" biology. it is NOT advanced, it is disorganized. one lecture you'll learn about telomeres for an hour plus, and then the central dogma, then replication, then operons i have never had something impact my opinion on science so much. but there goes my grade

Dr. Bi's lectures are extremely rushed and not worth showing up for. It is a better use of time to skip class and go at your own pace. The guest lectures are far more concise and enriching. Dr. Bi doesn't give you the time of day and is extremely distant and impersonal. He understands the content really well but struggles to communicate it with us.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: He does not test on the material on the majority of the slides but expects us to have memorized and be able to fully recite random slides from memory. The tests are uncurved so you do not know your grade until the end of the course and the labs are a joke. Never in my life have seen a man be so confident with his teaching skills yet be so bad.

Man. This guy. The course description described the guest lectures, which for the most part, are engaging and well thought-out. Dr. Bis actual lectures are extremely rushed, and he seems more interested in reading off of the slides than actually teaching his students anything. If you study, you still might fail! Theres way too much material.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Made the course ten times harder than it needs. Very harsh and rude grader and does not communicate clear guidelines regarding reports. His lectures are very dry and does not give students a place to voice their answers without immediately interrupting them and making fun of their concerns. Overall, this professor lacks any teaching capability.

Lectures were mainly on research topics- interesting but challenging for an intro course. There was a lot of fluff information on the history of different discoveries and less time was spent actually teaching the material and explaining important concepts. Half of the lectures were taught by other professors who were more concise and educational.

1st time teaching and i rarely understood what was going on. he loves research and it showed in his lectures but it took away from content that mattered most. he'd talk about a discovery's background for 50 mins then explain concept in 20. half the semester's lectures were given by other professors he invited (they were more straightforward)

i can tell he must be so respected in mathematics, but he is such a poor lecturer. his class is dull, the explanation of ideas is too theoretical without clear examples so it is so hard to follow and understand. even tho he always uploads his notes, its HARD to understand his idear or his handwriting. i feel bad for him but I feel worse for myself

Actually, he is patient but not helpful at all. The practise matrials do not have key answer and the practise exams are far away from the real exam. He can convey the material he want to discuss, but he cannot let students to understand them.

He has lots of thoughts that can't convey to his students. He is patient and responsible. He uploaded his notes quickly every time after class, and the notes is clear and well-organized. However, his classes are sleepy and not attractive at all.
Not good, do not go to his course and just study yourself.
POOR GUY! Just talk example in class, not very helpful.
Very poor lectures, terrible exam and grading curve.
Practice exam not helpful. Everything post was late!

Professor Greenleaf clearly cares deeply about the content that he is teaching. Given this, his ability to explain what he is doing on the board is very challenging to follow as he primarily focuses on theoretical values and fails to use practical examples to make the content understandable to anyone not interested in proof based mathematics.

Prof. Greenleaf is a brilliant man, yet his lectures make sense to everyone no matter how much you are struggling. His lecture style is fluid and easy to learn from. Very attentive and wants to make sure you understand the material

Dr. Greenleaf is a very thorough lecturer, explanations can be a little long-winded, but he moves at a good pace. He is always respectful to his students and is very helpful during office hours.  He is also willing to accommodate for any conflicts or issues you have. Be aware, tests are very hard.
GREAT PROFESSOR.Very clear during lecture and very helpful. BUT becareful about his exams, sometimes really hard.

Gifted Lecturer.....however you will suffer gradewise as his system is skewed and he gives random pop quizzes on material from lectures over a month ago...So unless you are studying your entire months worth of notes before every class that 15% quiz grade is a killer.
Very good lecturer...Unfortunatley his grading system is absolutely awful, so be prepared to suffer grade-wise.

He's a very thorough and good professor. His lectures are very clear and caters his lectures to making sure even the slowest person understands the material. He should be teaching more classes - at least more than Harper does. (I'm not saying that Harper doesn't have entertainment value though!)

This guy is absolutely top notch. His grading is reasonable and he doesn't pull fast ones on tests, but at the same time you'll only do well if you know the material. He has, by far, the best lecturing style I've ever seen. His lessons are fluid and superbly planned. Overall, a gifted teacher.
No Comments
He seems like a nice guy but be prepared to suffer.  His grading system is ridiculous and his homeworks take forever, I wouldnt recommend taking any class with him.
Greenleaf is very theoretical, but you just have to adjust to the way he teaches.  Personally, I think he is the greatest!!!
Boring and too theoretical to teach anything other than 170 series math.

Greenleaf makes it apparent to his students that he is passionate about mathematics- but he neglects to teach them!  If you're registered for 171Q series classes, be prepared to learn out of the book.
He was the best professor anyone could have asked for.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Dietsche is an amazing professor. I miss his class so much!!!

Dietsche is my most memorable UR prof - you will never forget this guy! His stories are great & I loved his life lessons - he showed a Kevin Trudeau "Natural Cures They Don't Want You To Know About" infomercial & then revealed all the misleading BS! He wants to produce thinkers & successful medical students. Great prof!

He is the best ever! He tells many stories about the time he served in the navy, and those are so much fun to listen in class. Tests are very straight forward, but doesn't mean they are easy. Nobody could teach physiology better than him!
Best teacher ever. This is a class about taking notes and memorizing. you would be surprised how many people havent developed these skills by the time they enter college

Not a bad teacher, tough class especially over the summer.  Tends to not be the most organized guy but could be worse.  His stories were great.  Tests are short but are hard.  Teacher recommended summer class is not (to much info to fast).

Very unorganized.  Though he is a very charismatic man, he fails at being a good lecturer.  He doesn't even bother to let us have access to the slides he puts up and his tests are quite difficult compared to what he teaches.

Excellent lecturer.  Very fast paced.  Straight from the book and lectures.  Glad to see he's still teaching.  I had him in 91/92 and I kept my binder from that class because I was so amazed (and still am) at how much I learned.
Awesomeness incarnate. Tough class, but he keeps the material interesting with his personality and stories. Very friendly and personable.

This man is one of the most caring professors I've had.  Makes a point to meet every student during lab (and remember names) and give them on the spot advice for life.  Lectures are fast paced, but the tests are very basic and easy to pull an A.

The class was rough with the amount of material that you were expected to memorize.  All tests were multiple choice and non-cumulative but really specific.  He was a very good teacher though and extremely funny.  The little annecdotal stories he told during lectures definitely helped with remembering material for the exams.
No Comments

****ing awesome- bitter divorcee, proud ****, ex-farmer, vietnam navy veteran, outright crazy and one hella charming man.  Teaches each lecture with a moral for life, and gives you a lot of other valuable life lessons along the way, mostly through didactic horse breeding stories. Take the class
this man, while hillarious, has no sense of organization. I'm also pretty sure he does no preparation for this class... i mean honestly is an overhead with some key terms to much to ask for?
He's quite literally very very crazy, but entertaining. And the class is relatively easy too
Fantastic lectures, I didn't skip a single one.  The guy is hysterical.  Painful amounts of memorization, but all tests are non-cumulative.

I really enjoyed this class and professor.  There is alot of memorizing in this class, although it's an easy course concept-wise.  A few students do comment that he doesn't have much organization within his lectures, but I didn't find this the case.
I love this man.  I am a man myself.  Boy that is wierd.  Anyway, an amazing teacher who can make even physiology a fun and interesting class.
Very direct - brute memorization class ... great naval stories

Dr. Stauffer gives very good and detailed feedback on all the papers you submit, which helps a lot. Attendance is part of the grade, but as long as you attend, it is relatively easy. There were readings and summaries due before almost every class, which could be long sometimes, but otherwise, the class was relatively easy and helpful.
He was a great prof. He gave helpful feedback, and the lectures gave a good perspective on what is expected of job application materials. Highly recommend taking this class with him.

Definitely one of my favorite professors. Very kind and respectful. Attendance is important, so if you show up, you're all set. Always willing to meet or discuss during the week if you need help on anything. Overall, I'd highly recommend his class if you want to have fun in-class discussions and want a great professor.

He's really nice, I liked him a lot. The only thing is the 8-10 page paper at the end of the semester is 40% of your grade. He's a pretty light grader though. He also cares a lot about attendance, so make sure to go to every class. He doesn't ask much, there are just short readings for each class.

Stauffer is an incredible instructor! Always accessible outside of class, they offer valuable guidance and are highly knowledgeable in their field and writing. Their passion for the subject makes learning engaging and enjoyable. I would take their class again!"
Perfectly good teacher for the WRTG105 class. Teaches you what you need to know, and doesn't make it painful. Has students email assignments instead of using blackboard, which I found annoying.
While not the hardest teacher, he definitely makes sure you learn in his class. Definitely take his class for the WRTG105 credit if you get a chance.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Took his "The Meaning of Life" course and the readings & discussions were very insightful and makes you think. Super nice guy and always is able to add on to your comments in a discussion. Very clear grading, as long as you follow the criteria you'll get a good grade. Great prof for 105!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: he was very nice, and quiet. but, i feel like the class is hard to do well in if you are not the best writer. I feel like it is hard to get the grade you want. I think he has clear expectations on what to do for your papers. I tried REALLY hard on my final paper and went to so many resources for help and still didn't get the grade i wanted.

This class was definitely not an ez A. However I do believe that this class is a great seminar style class with weekly discussion and interesting readings instead of a dry writing class like other classes. I think Dr Stauffer did a great job by making the topics interesting and always available to help his students with their writings.

I always enjoyed Stauffers' class. Interesting (and long) readings that led to great discussions, always asked us interesting questions and created a good atmosphere in the classroom. Amazing at giving feedback on essays, and a very fair grader. Answered emails very quickly and I felt that he cared about all his students. Great teacher for 105!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Even though I typically don't like writing, I really enjoyed Dr. Stauffer's class. The one I took was about life in the digital age so the content actually was pretty interesting and the essays weren't bad at all. Show up, participate, and put a decent amount of effort into the essays and you'll do well.

Definitely take him!! I took his life in a digital age this semester, which is always very intriguing. He really like to bring up critical thinking question and statistics to drive the class discussion further. For his essay, make sure your organization and logics flow well then you should be fine.

He is THE BEST writing teacher. I took his human nature class. We basically had to show up to class, participate in the discussions and do the papers by the deadline. Easy to satisy requirements for A and the teacher is very kind, accesible and gives very good feedback. Take him!

I LOVE his class. The grading is extremely clear and as long as you follow the instructions, you will get good grades. We had lots of terrific discussions in class. I put effort and I also like the content of this class. The final paper (8-10 pages) is the college policy, but he helps me a lot through developing ideas on this final papers. THE BEST
I love his class. We had lots of interesting discussions in class, and the professor gives plenty of good feedbacks on your writing. I hope that he can be my upper level writing professor!!!!
Very friendly and accessible out of class. Interesting topic. Participation is highly recommended. Will recommend his course to peers.
The best professor ever!
Great professor, I had him for WRT 105 Posthumanism. I saw that he's teaching one of my other writing course, so I'm definitely taking it with him again!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: A really good professor talking about American's society and politics.
Great professor!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Making of Trump's America is pretty much your typical WRT 105 class. It is not just a Trump roast-fest, more of an examination of the state of modern america. It won't blow your mind, but Stauffer is fair, and the assigned readings are quite easy. He does not put grades online quickly, (or at all so far), but I can't imagine getting less than an A-
Easy class if you show up to lectures and meet deadlines. As long as you produce something half decent within the deadline, you will be getting high grades.

She was an awesome professor! We had discussions for papers we read about social movements but she made the class very comfortable where everyone's opinion matter. She always checked in on each one of us to not fall behind and gave good feedback on my paper. She wants you to succeed and is very understanding if your stressed or overwhelmed.
Too much work

If you can take Professor O'Donnell for your 105, you definitely should. All the assignments are relatively easy if you do them, and she is really helpful when providing feedback on your drafts. This class does not have more writing than necessary, and the topic of modern social movements is actually interesting. Definitely recommend
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: I thought Professor O'Donnell did a great job teaching the Writing 105 course. She offered great feedback on each submitted assignment and helped guide the students through each required paper. She helped keep students engaged and encouraged group discussion on various social movements.

Rachel is so funny I literally want to get a drink w her outside of class.  A great teacher and genuinely cares about her students. Her writing 105 class is easy and engaging, I'd love to take more classes with her!!

Prof O'Donnell was a great professor who really cared about her students and understood that we were all stressed. She gave good feedback on brought drafts and final drafts and her office hours were amazing if you wanted more feedback. 10/10 would take again.

I had Prof. O'Donnell for WRTG105 contemporary social movements and would definitely recommend her. She is approachable, understanding, and flexible. Gives good feedback and isn't a super tough grader. The course in general is a basic 105, so it's nothing too crazy and isn't that difficult.
Prof. O'Donnell is a great WRTG 105 professor! She cares about her students and is very understanding and if you participate and don't skip class you will easily walk out with an A

Professor O'Donnell is a very caring and compassionate person and her class is very enjoyable. The work is very fair and entertaining and her flexibility helps keep the stress at a minimum. The classes are set up to maximize the material and engage with classmates. A great class.

Professor O'Donnell is amazing. Participation is a big part of your grade, and she really appreciates students speaking in class. There is quite a bit of reading and you have to do them to be ready for the discussions. For papers, go to the Writing Fellows to get feedback. This was probably my favorite class my first semester.

She is extremely nice and understanding which makes the class so much less stressful. I had her for her WRTG105 class on social movements and I loved it. She also gives back great feedback and facilitates group discussions and feedback well also. It really makes the class go by fast.

Super kind and understanding professor. She makes lessons accessible and shows that she cares a lot about the students. Even in a social distanced classroom, we had lots of small group discussions, so come ready to talk. Directions/grading criteria can feel a bit too vague sometimes, but she's always available to talk if you need clarity.

Great professor, teaches writing in a very accessible & managable way. Gives amazing feedback, is extremely understanding and works with students to help reach their full potential. Take her class if you are interested in gsws or social science. She's very supportive and easy to talk to. Readings are interesting, very managable.

She's a great professor, very caring and kind and easy to talk to. She works hard to get everyone engaged in the work and gives great feedback on papers. I love how she structured that class and made a writing class interesting to the best of her abilities. We have similar academic interests, so I'm planning to take another one of her classes.

Reachable, kind, patient. She gave helpful supports and suggestions during office hour. I took contemporary social movement with her. If you work hard in this class you will get an A and feel more confident about writing.

She's one of the best professors I've had during my time at Rochester! There are some students who believe that they can get away by doing the bare minimum, but as long as you put in your effort, the class will not seem as intensive. As like any other class, if you want an A, be proactive, and you'll see your results.

I was recommended Professor ODonnell by multiple other students prior to taking one of her classes. She encourages creative thought and discussion, while also enhancing students learning on each topic presented. Shes extremely supportive and easy to talk to. Shes enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and one of my favorite professors Ive had.

She seems like a nice person but I feel like she takes this class way too seriously. It's basic required writing 105, not advanced 400 level English major specific writing. Also, she is not a very warm person, she acts like she is very funny and friendly but her comments on our papers and work make her seem harsh and cold.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--So many papers

comment: I met at least five other students who took her classes and everyone shared the same feeling about professor O'Donnell: thought-provoking, funny, caring, clear. I took her Modern Social Movements class, the assignments were challenging, but her guidance was excellent. The readings and discussions: absolutely engaging. Very supportive professor.

About 10 students in my class, he reported 3 of us for academic dishonesty. How he report my essay as plagiarism was basically he told me it's ok to just cite the primary source in the secondary source, so I don't need to cite the secondary source. I followed his advice and he reported me, my TA went to hearing with me to prove he was lying.

All these 1s are right on the money. Prof. Cashner should not be a professor. His lectures are so hard to follow, and his roundtable discussions are unrelated to the material of the course. He does not explain how anything is graded, and he just makes no sense overall. He would benefit with clear grading guidelines and more organized lectures.
The worst professor in this university.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE! WORST PROFESSOR EVER! Not fair in grading assignments, approximately 30 pages of reading before every class.
Worst professor in my college life. Unorganized lecturing.
Besides 7 journals and 1 evaluation paper, you have to write a 1500 words essay during the final week for a live event. That's ridiculous for an elementary class.
Approximate 10000 words essay needed for this class. Even more writing than writing course. He is ridiculous.
WORST professor. A lot of writing assignments but tough graded. Not an elementary class but is MUSC500W
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: For weekly journal, he made us write 3 pages analysis essays. He clearly stated in the syllabus that journal is to keep listening and reading experience. He is a really bad teacher, don't take his class, folks.

Jesus! Help me!!! I don't understand why the intro class is such difficult!! I'm trying to finish the journal for this week and I'm kind of frustrated. My overall grade for journals is only 80%. I think it is like MUSC400W. Please DO NOT take this class if you want a higher GPA.

Such a bad professor. So many essay for musc100? He said don't think my class is easy because it is called music100 in the first class. And he asks us to read a scholarly reading or book every time before class, which takes 6-7 hours to actually accomplish.

Showing off his travelling, research and piano skill more than talking about lecture. Terrible teacher! Every time we are discussing in the class as a group, he starts showing off his piano skill that we can't hear each other, so have to listen to his piano. Always digress from the topic to his travelling experience. And he doesn't give good grade
WORST teacher. He is so insecure and makes MUSC100 so hard just to not let people think his class is easy. Deducting points for no reason. Really disgusting.

Professor Cashner is an example of a good scholar but not a very effective teacher. His lectures are often drawn-out and disorganized. This makes watching his videos a chore, and you may be left with little after you're done with them. He is also not very good at explaining problems to students, which has led me to make many detrimental mistakes.
MUSC100 more like MUSC400

A mixture of irresponsibility, insecurity, and apathetic. Passive-aggressively telling students not to be late while routinely be late to his music history class for ten minute. Giving no reason why he deducts a ton of points from your paper. Saying "students who like to take notes will struggle in my way of lecture" with a smug smile.

As English was not my first language, taking Cashner's class was very difficult. He does not write down what he says, and he does not give you review sheets. He never even makes an effort to make sure what he says could be understood by students. He also was a very rude person and not approchable at all. Would never take a class with him again.

Andrew Cashner never organized his lectures. He rambles on and on about things very unrelated to class for two hours each lecture, and then EXPECT you to know everything he said. That's right! He does not use powerpoint, does not write down what he says on blackboard, does NOT provide exam review sheet, and just expect you memoriz anything he said.

The WORST professor ever! He does not care about his students at all. His lectures are boring and unorganized, and he has no idea about how to form an effective class discussion. The worst thing is that this is a required course and you can't even choose another professor to study with.

In my five years at University of Rochester (4 years + take five program), I have studied with fourty-two different professors/instructors. And Cashner is BY FAR the worst professor I have ever had. He is highly insecure, irresponsible, and blame the students whenever he can.

Go to class, go to office hours, Rudi's really nice and doesn't judge you for your level of understanding even if he seems intimidating. He cares about your learning and will answer just about any question.

Four exams, and a 5% recitation grade. Fasan very clearly cares about communicating clearly with students and is approachable outside of class, but his one downside is that he doesn't clearly denote how/where to apply concepts learned in class. To this end, do the workshop problems/practice tests over and over again to prepare. Worked for me.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: It was so bad... I want to give you a zero, but that's not possible so I give you a one.

It can be very difficult to follow Fasan during lecture and take away what's important. His exams were very difficult (as expected) with only a 10 point curve, and you may fail even with copious amounts of studying. Orgo 1 is a different beast, and you can tell that Fasan is very smart, but he just doesn't *get* his students.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: You can tell Rudi is passionate about what he teaches but doesnt quite understand why his students struggle. Lectures are technically not mandatory but if you want to pass you should go and do all practice problems. Dont rely on a curve because there barely is one.

The professor is great during office hours and cares about his students. One issue though is that the exams are not the most reliable with getting curves that are needed to get a passing average for the class.

Did really bad in beginning of semester, but slowly making progress. I still end up with a decent grade at the end. He gives big curve for exam 2 and 3. I think as long as you are willing to try for his class class, hes willing to curve the grade.

His lectures are so bad that it's funny. You have to learn everything (and I mean everything) from Youtube. Grading breakdown: 95% exams, 5% workshop participation. Not a great grading scheme considering the averages were typically in the mid 40s.

Worst professor at the school. His lectures are terrible and you're better off not even going. Avoid him at all costs. If you have to take him, just use Youtube. The content isn't that bad, he just makes it hard because of how bad his lectures are.

Stopped attending his lectures and did better on the exam. Sometimes his notation is blatantly wrong but no one can correct it so you have to just repeat the wrong notation. Curve is not enough, never clear what he wants to emphasize in lecture. Lots and lots of youtube.

Teaches solely through examples, gives very little to no explanation as to what the examples pertain to. Gives absolutely no definitions. Your grade is basically entirely made up of test grades. No lecture slides/notes were posted. Made an already notoriously challenging course more difficult.

Dr. Fasan's accent sometimes makes understanding him difficult. He also tends to mumble. Grade consists entirely of exams: 4 preliminary exams and a final. The exams were all very challenging, but the curve was always reasonable. Lecture attendance and textbook readings/problems are not mandatory but strongly encouraged if you want to do well.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: He explains things well, usually, and he has hard but fair tests. Sometimes his accent makes it a little hard to understand a word or two, but he is fairly clear is his explanations. Lectures are a bit boring, maybe- I start to yawn a lot by the end of class. I think he's probably one of the best organic chemistry teachers out there.
He is just the best. He does have very hard but fair tests and the average is almost always very low but he is a very fair teacher and curves it if the average is too low. I love Fasan.

He's an excellent teacher, and his accent is epic. The material is presented in lecture in a clear and understandable manner, and he's always there to answer questions. His tests are very hard - the average was around the 50s in my class, but he curves it.
Great professor. Pretty clear. Tests are fair.
Professor Fasan is very helpful and available outside class for any assistance in better understanding the concepts. His tests are very interesting and challenging. His sense of humor is awesome!
I love Rudi. The course was hard, by no fault of Rudi's, organic chem has a rep for being hard.

Rudi is the best! He was such an awesome teacher and he really knew his stuff. I loved going to his office hours, because he was very good at explaining concepts. Also, his accent is the best thing ever. :)
Rudi is awesome and wears elf shoes. His accent takes sometime to get used to, but overall he was really good.
Yes, he is young, kind of funny, easy to understand, he uses multiple colors of chalk, BUT I wouldn't go as far as far as calling him THE BEST teacher that I've ever had.  Maybe that's just me.
Smart Approachable Easy tests Easier homework sets

I guess he's one of the better professors in the lower math courses (but that isn't saying much).  Most of what he explains is done really well, but he did just graze over some things that were more important than he made them seem.  The two midterms were exceptionally easy.  The final was a bit harder but fair.
Great professor, but teaches right out of the book.  He's easy going and makes himself available to students.  A kind man.

HOT!! He has an adorable accent! Also a great professor! Takes the time to explain everything in detail everytime and doesn't assume that you should know things. Is very helpful in office hours and wants students to succeed. Tests are fair and mirror class notes.

To his credit, he is a good teacher and explains things very clearly and points out intricacies that other professors overlook or assume you understand. Additionally, tests are very fair and mirror the practice tests. As a teacher he is excellent, HOWEVER, he is a jerk and an ass at times.
Excellent teacher.  Makes everything perfectly clear.  Has tons of office hours and will help you however he can.
Awesome teacher, very nice and willing to work with the students.

Heap is a math god.  My roommate and I call it "going to the Heap concert", and we get front row tickets, everytime.  I hated math, but thanks to Heap, I can now tolerate it.  To all the ladies out there, be prepared to fall in love.

"Heap is a god!" Heap one of the most clear speaking and devoted teachers I have met at this school. Be prepared to work your butt off on homework sets, but if you have any problems he will take you through step by step (and he makes himself readily available for help). It's really unfortunate that he has to leave so soon!
boring class...great teacher
No Comments
No Comments
Great professor who is eager to help students.
very cool guy.  office hours are more than helpful.  great to joke around with.  what a math-lete!
Awesome prof. willing to help. really nice
best math professor ive ever had, he gives clear and useful notes, and hes always willing ot help you figure out the webwor
Great professor who will help you whenever needed.....be happy if you get him.
He's the nicest guy and really enthusiastic and helpful.  His lectures are a little boring, but he knows his stuff.  Go to office hours!

He opens his office hours for students 3 days/wk, 2 hrs/day. Plus he comes to most of the workshops which is nice cuz the ta's aren't superb. He comes from Texas and use to be a minister. It's his first year teaching, so maybe his enthusiasm will decrease, but he wants people in the class to succeed

Very unclear lecture. Almost no examples. Handwritings are extremely unclear. Just avoid him otherwise you will be regret hahaha. Avoid avoid avoid. Worst prof I've ever met. Yu can hardly learn anything from him.
Lectures are extremely unclear. Learned all material from outside sources.

Lectures weren't always clear or useful, but he was good with extra help, and the material tested was pretty much the same exact questions as webwork.  The tough webwork assignments were definitely worth it in the end and served as excellent test preparation.  Medium level difficulty.
Reading the book was way more helpful than going to his class

He was more about theory instead of showing examples, so when the online homework came around, it was difficult to finish without going to office hours, which still didn't help me fully understand problems. I did a lot of the problems in the textbook, but that still didn't help, and was a waste of time, becaue the exam problems were different.

He is awful!! I can't follow anything he says and neither can anyone around me. The class is easy so you feel like you don't have to put in a lot of effort, but then the test comes around and you realize that you never really learned the material. Also he won't give you any solutions to workshops or practice tests.

Gage is great.  He focused a lot more on theoretical concepts than applications but if you really paid attention to what he was saying the applications come naturally.  Hard to follow in lecture sometimes.  If you are lost there is a good chance everyone else is as well.  Stop him and ask him to explain something again, it will be good for everyone

Gage is the god of math... He somehow can at least appear to know everything known to man because of a few mathematical properties... I'm suprized that his head isn't 20 feet in diameter... Awesome guy although a little flighty.  I suggest getting help through email.  He's always very quick to respond and almost alwasy can lead you to an answer.

Good lecturer but his WebWork assignments didn't follow the lectures or the tests. If you take good notes you will do well on the WebWork, and if you read the book backwards and forwards you will do well on the tests. He's decent. I give him an A-.
Not really clear, but the content is easy enough for you to teach youself. Ask for help from TAs and not him. Needs to spend more time with examples then deriving random formulas and using variables
No Comments

Incredibly easy class with gage, the tests were mirror images of the practice tests.  Webwork was a b*tch and lectures were boring and didn't follow webwork.  He derives to much in class then showing how to apply the material.  However an easy class nonetheless

Avoid taking this class if Gage is teaching it.  He spends all his time talking theory and not enough time actually teaching the things you need to be learning.  Workshops are horrible and tests follow the same pattern.

Wasn't all to bad.  Too smart for his own good, does a lot of theoretical stuff without actually applying it to anything.  Leaving you with no clue how to do webwork.  Tests were very fair and curved fair.
he starts deriving an equation but never gets to the point where he tells you what the equation is, or shows you how to apply it!  goes off on tangents and never gets to the point....
i may be a moron who can barely take a derivative but that is due to my undiagnosed ADHD definitely not this guys fault he was a really good teacher
I thought he was a great professor.  He was very knowledgable and if you can keep up, you you will do well in the course.  I thought it was very esay to get an A.
An Uber-Geek who was not very approachable

Arguably the worst Calculus teacher on campus.  Knows the subject too well to teach it, i.e. he expects you to know most of the material right off the bat.  Also not very approachable.  You're best off taking another Calculus teacher if you can.

Terrible professor, would talk endlessly about mathematical topics secondary to teaching Calculus--this was supposed to be an application, not a theory course.  Would talk a lot about everything except getting to the meat of how to do problems.
meh

I put my comment here since there's no option of GBA478. We understand the course is disorganized and lack of work instructions because it's new, but I hope the professor understands our difficulties instead of comments "really poor works" massively and messes up with our grades (At least 3 groups I know gets 2/10, seriously?). Avoid at all cost!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: I never taken so bad class before, I can not believe what horrible class it is. Not only uselss, but also heavy tasks... Waste my time, bad! bad! bad!

I found the delivery of the course material unengaging and monotonous, making it challenging to absorb the content effectively. The professor required intense attention during lectures, which was difficult. Moreover, the grading system was inconsistent and lacked clear standards, leaving us unsure about how our work was evaluated.

Never take a class with this teacher. His class isn't difficult but utterly useless. He reads directly from the book with no engagement or excitement for his students. Despite the boring class, he insists that students focus on what he's teaching. This is the first time I've felt like my tuition was wasted.

I'm so confused about what this course is up to. No one has any idea about his lectures too, even for the MBAs. And he always blames students for not listening to him, though he only has four lectures in a semester. Would never see him again.

I will never take any class with him again. He made us do 1 task in 7 different ways. Just useless. The class content was so unstructured that we could not understand where all this material led to. I have heard the same from his previous students.
Stand up guy and straightforward with class and tests.. not much else to say.

One of the hardest classes I have taken at the school. However, Dan is an exceptional professor, and CIS 211 is an extremely useful class. I definitely would recommend Dan to anyone who can take him and his classes.
He is very caring, cool and knowledgeable. He knows and delivers what is helpful and important for his students. I highly recommend this course for everyone.

Ok if you just want an easy course for an easy A, Prof doesn't know a lot but I guess sufficient for a business course in this University. Horrendous TA and grading that made the course a lot more frustrating that it needs to be.

Dan Keating is the best professor I've had as of yet. Not only is he clear in communicating class content, but also gives a lot of tips to help with our professional lives, and clearly wants nothing but the best for his students inside and outside of the classroom. CIS 211 is a very useful course with him, and should be a straightforward A.
Class is extremely easy, if you can count to ten you will get an A. Unclear grading with unclear answer keys, but perhaps that is just the nature of the course.
Goes over the topics clearly, attending lectures is always better than watching it online as you retain more info.
What an excellent class. It was tough and there was plenty of work but it was so rewarding! I would love to take a class again with Professor Keating!
Curved too much for the first midterm, final too easy. So if you lose a point in homework or participation your rank will go down a lot.
Great class, great professor
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Great professor, he doesn't want you to screw up. He tries his best to curve and give you extra credits if you make up the missing work or do extra homework
Professor Keating is the best Professor I have ever met in the U of R. He is very vice and approachable and explains the material very clearly. I would like to take his class again.

prof quillen was always super reachable and incredibly kind. when i was struggling my freshman year she let me submit all of my missing lab reports a week before grades were due- and graded them herself. the sweetest lady ever. be aware though the lab reports are awful plz j take 121 instead

Alice Quillen is like a sweet little old grandmother who bakes you cookies every time you see her. The workload and homework are challenging, but if you work with people and take advantage of your TAs, tutors, and upperclassmen, it will be 20 times easier. Just be prepared to put a lot of time into it, and you'll be okay.

This class heavily relies on homework and they are a bit difficult but Quillen is very reachable. She is such a wonderful and kind human being, and she loves seeing students in her office. I really enjoyed this class with her, she is such a fun spirit and is really helpful during her office hours!

Professor Quillen is the nicest human being I've ever seen. She is intelligent and knows how to teach students. She is very accessible outside class and likes to talk to students. Very inspirational and encourage me to pursue physics and astronomy.
She has really good notes and lectures are fun to attend because of how passionate she is about what she's teaching. Homeworks can be challenging but she is accessible outside of class.

Quillen is the best. She no longer does tests, but you'll still learn a lot in her class. The way she weaves in modern physics in her lectures is incredibly helpful without being overwhelming to first years. Even without tests, 141 is a ton of work, but it's worth it in the long run.

Adds a lot of junior year level content which made her lectures confusing (I'd taken IB physics), so don't worry about understanding everything. TAs were great at teaching, go to recitations! Collaborate on the problem sets (took me many hours) and do the labs well (multiple days worth of work). She is caring and will help you a lot in office hrs

Pros: Very good lecture notes, very easy to reach, and cared about students and tried to make the class fair. Cons: all-over-the-place lecturer; I took honors physics 1, which required having taken high school physics - had it not been similar material to high school, I wouldnt have learned. Lecture notes taught me better than lecture.

I am not a physics major. But after I took this class, it seems like I'm a physics major. I spent an entire day to do the assignment each week, and take another 2-3 days to do lab report. The lectures and assignments are really hard for me, even though I've taken AP Physics in high school. They are not at same level! Fortunately, no tests or exams!
She is very kind. Lab reports can be a bit intense.

Alice has perks and cons. Although she had great knowledge in physics and she is extremely strong mathematically, she usually overestimated our ability to understand what she says. Sometimes I lost track of her. TA was more helpful than her. Her lectures are not enough to understand. However, she is caring and understanding and NOT tough grader.

She should not teach freshmen.  Although high school calculus is recommended for AST 111, the calculus in her presentations involves multivariable calculus.  Additionally, her lectures are hard to follow, due in part to her poor ability to teach AST 111.

She hates teaching freshmen and it shows. She teaches things that juniors who took the class never learned in AST 111 and either learned them in higher level Astro classes or not at all. Her lectures are ridiculously confusing and include multi-variable calculus, even though only a high school understanding of calculus is recommended. Fall 2016
She is great.

Real chill and smart. She knows her stuff well. It helps to be genuinely interested in physics and astronomy otherwise you'll find yourself getting a little bored because she's extremely passionate about that stuff.

Such a nice person and really enthusiastic and smart. It's sometimes hard to follow what she's saying if she gets carried away by her excitement and wanders from topic to topic, but she's always willing to back up and explain things if you don't understand.
Awesomest teacher ever.  Plain and simple.
Brilliant. Hillarious. Great boss.
Great teacher... but as it turns out, I still have no idea what she was talking about half of the time.  Astronomy is hard.

Professor Otis is very nice and has good and interesting lectures. He also gives feedback on the quizzes and final paper before you turn in your work to help you get an A. Highly recommend his class to any students looking to gain a basic understanding of philosophy and ethics.

Man Machine and Morality is a great writing class, not too much work and Otis gives genuinely good feedback and can provide more if you ask. The structure of the class is writing focused so you don't learn too much the second half of the semester outside your own research but it serves as a basic philosophy intro. Otis makes things clear and easy!

he is a little bit lazy and sometimes slacks off
but i promise there's no easier way than taking his class to get A and 4 credit, just submit every assignment then you got it

Professor Otis is a nice guy who will give you great feedback when you need it. If you follow the directions and put in reasonable effort you're almost guaranteed an A. If you're struggling to choose a Writing 105 class and you want an A, Otis is the best pick. He'll almost always give you an extension if you ask.

Clear grader on writing, and very good at providing feedback outside of class, and a fun professor to talk to. He makes it easy to succeed if you put in the work (which isn't much compared to the other writing profs.)
BEST Writing Professor!!

Man, Machine, and Morality is probably one of the easier WRTG 105 courses. Very little reading outside of class, and the only big assignments are the short essay and final research essay that all the other 105 courses have. He also gives good feedback on drafts, so it's very easy to get an A in his class.

Man, Machine, Mortality was the easiest class ever. As long as you come to most classes and try the slightest bit you will get an A. If you are looking to genuinely learn then this not the class for you, however, if like many you are just trying to fulfill WRTG105, this is the best class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: 100000% recommend taking his writhing class. It is not hard and it really helps you develop as a better writer. He is understanding and really cares about the topic. He drops 2 of your lowest informal assessment grades and grades a lot of things based off effort. I learned a lot about the ethics of AI in this class and would love to take another.

super chill professor, is willing to give extensions if you just ask and tell the truth, topics revolve around ai and morality, you're graded on some in class informal assignments (3-6 pts), a short essay (100 pts), and the 8 to 10 page research paper (you will not pass if you dont turn it in). miss 1 informal assignment, it wont hurt your grade
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: Super nice guy, and very willing to give extensions. The essay criteria was super clear and the assignments were easy enough to do. My only gripe with him was just that he didn't give a lot of assignments so if you got a few points off a formal assignment it kind of did a bit of damage.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Otis is great. He has clear guidelines on his papers and understands that most people going through his class aren't English Majors. He is very accommodating and gives great feedback on papers. He also lectures well and gives good advice on how to approach argumentative essays.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Man, Machine, and Morality turned out to be way more interesting than I thought. James is very engaging and knowledgeable on the topics discussed in class. He is also very empathetic with students and understands our busy schedules. He is incredibly kind and truly wants you to succeed. Take his advice carefully and you will be more than fine.
Such a great professor. Easy A if you attend every class and complete the project on time.
Would like to take this professor's class again

he is a great professor. i am a stem person but i found his class very interesting. flexible teaching style, go with the flow guy. no final, just 3 short essays. does miss class sometimes but usually gives enough notice. you're able to submit your own topics to talk about. no hw, some in-class assignments.

Somewhat reading heavy at the start of the semester, but once we got into the writing portion not so much. Less writing assignments compared to what other WRTG 105 classes had, and he is a pretty fair grader, and can be lenient with deadlines if you ask.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: Easy to follow lectures and lenient grader. Majority of assignments are graded by completion, including part of the grade for the final research paper. Half the classes at the end of the year are just doing your work in class, which should be optional to attend, but he randomly check for attendance. Easy A if you do the work.
He is very sympathetic with students. We had good discussion in the class. Grading is not hard at all!

I took "Man, Machine, and Morality" and it was a super fun class. His lectures are short and sweet and encourage class participation, and he gives plenty of time to work in class so there's not too much work to do outside. If you want to write about something a little different from the prompt he's, laid back about it as long as you do it well.

Really good professor. Makes it clear exactly what he wants in the papers and is very easily accessible outside of class. He understands that writing isn't everyone's strong suit so he gives plenty of time in class to complete assignments. Often makes attending class optional.
Good
He's super nice and approachable. His notes are good, the class is tough tho. His exams and the final are fair and not super long.

One of the most intelligent professors in the department, Anthamatten deconstructs relatively simple topics into several pieces, providing theory, application and history behind various energy sources. While he goes in-depth on lectures, his tests (while somewhat tricky) were structured on only the relevant principles. Makes you think, but easy A.

Solid professor. A little robotic at times, but other than being an alien space android he was pretty good at communicating ideas in a clear and understandable manner. Course material was also extremely easy.

The class material was not too hard but I felt that some of his lectures were kind of hard to follow along. The true and false questions on his exams are very tricky. However, he curves very reasonably.

Material is not that hard. Professor explains it nicely and simplifies very difficult topics. He is always open to questions, very approachable and very helpful. Pay attention in class if you want to ace the exam, you really don't need to read the book, just write down all small details in lecture, they come in the exam. TA's were worthless though.
Very interesting class and a very reasonable curve

His exams were curved reasonably. If you focus at the SMALL details he mentions during his presentations, read the textbook before class and try to work the HW on your own, you'll do fine. If I were to go back in time and improve my performance in that class, I would've studied the small details in the book to ace the multiple choice questions.

Luckily he curved the exams nicely. TAs in this class were zero help, and his lectures were often confusing and rushed. Homework was hard. The multiple choice on his exams was ridiculous, it was not the main important information and was often from something he may have discussed for half a second in class.

Well the first thing you gotta know about Mitchell is he is one of the greatest guys you will ever meet. He was by the greatest professor I have ever had. Even though the class was extremely hard Mitchell never gave up on us. He always curved the exams very reasonably, if you showed showed up to every class and didnt sleep he always had your back.

One of the worst teachers I have ever had. Took a true passion for the course and destroyed it. Doesn't connect his thoughts. Homework is nearly impossible doesn't have anything to do with class and the TA's are useless. Exams are extremely hard. Fear the dreaded "back of the envelope" calculation
he was not very helpful during class or outside of class. he frequently used "back of the envelope" calculations. and made you come up with your own "back of the envelope calculations" on  tests
Class started out really difficult, but got better. Homework is MUCH harder than exams. Very reasonable guy, wants students to understand material-doesn't assign useless work.

Probably one of the worst professors I have ever had. He is not helpful and the lectures do not help you with the homework. If you are lost the TA's can't/won't help you. Basically yoyo, You're On Your Own. I advise that no one take this class even if it is required...

He is a very good teacher but expects you to put the work in. The material is difficult and the class is by no mean "easy". The exams are rough, but if you make an effort to stay on top of the material you will do well. He is extremely approachable which is a huge plus. He is always opening to questions and is really good at getting back to emails.

This course is very hard, but the Professor is helpful at office hours and tries to make things clear as possible.  Homework is difficult, exams are impossible, but you will learn a lot once you get through it.

Tries hard to get the challenging material through, but he is a bit too smart for the class to keep up. Writes VERY small, makes note-taking difficult if you sit in the back. Nice and approachable but can sound condescending when pointing out what he thinks are obvious points.

His class is *not* easy, but I think that is less a question of the professor than of the subject.  Anthamatten covers a lot of material and does a pretty good job explaining it in class.  See him if you have trouble. If you are cut out for engineering, you will learn a great deal in his class.
His class was very challenging, but I feel I have a much better grasp on the subject.  Overall, I think he did a great job making such a fundamental class exciting.
He might try hard, but he is still the worst prof I've seen.  One word sums it up: Terrible. Not much else to add.

Professor Cline's class is confusing. He has a lot of complex calculus that is past mth 162. I'm not a mathy or physics person at all but I was able to pull off a B. The class is curved at the end, so always try to get above average on the exams. Make sure to do the practice exams, and homework problems; he pulls frequently from them for exams.

He seems like a nice enough and smart guy. However, he should stick to teaching upper level physics classes. The level of detail he goes into is too much for an introductory class, and his powerpoints reflect that. Not to mention that they're composed mostly of walls of text taken straight from the textbook, and therefore not terribly helpful.

He seems like a nice enough and pretty smart guy. However, he should stick to teaching upper level physics classes. The level of detail he goes into is too much for an introductory class, and his powerpoints are very dense. Not to mention that they're composed of figures (OK) or walls of text (not OK) taken straight from the textbook.

Awful. Sure, most of PHY114 are pre-meds, but that doesn't excuse the fact that this entire course is presented in a way that is unapproachable. Maybe pre-meds are complaining because this class is among the worst of the required introductory level courses offered at the University. The physics department must be in dire straits.

Prof. Cline does teach upper level physics. The physics dept. is low on teachers, he did not choose to teach you brats. Just because you're Pre-Meds doesn't mean every other class you take should be easy. None of you are taking upper level phys courses, so you can't compare intro level with what majors take. Get a tutor if you can't handle it.

I feel that Dr. Cline gets kind of a bad rap because his lectures were confusing and the course was difficult. He was definitely tough to adjust to but in the end he's a good guy who just got stuck teaching a bunch of pre-meds. He is smart (too smart) so I think he would be excellent for upper-level physics courses, just not intro-level ones.

I didn't understand anything that was going on in this class. Prof. Cline claimed that difficult concepts and derivations were 'intuitive' but UR Physics Majors couldn't do the PHY 114 Homework. My TA didn't know what was going on either.

Does not heed the needs of his students. Spends every lecture doing 3-dimensional calculus proofs in what the physics dept. calls an entry level physics class. Most students are overwhelmed. As a very good student in general, this class was frustrating and not helpful for MCATs or otherwise.

Never before have I seen a professor so against answering questions during class. Does not adapt well to anything that falls outside of his "comfort zone" in teaching (i.e. does not like to post practice exam solutions until right before the exam, does not like to give examples in lecture or elaborate on topics, etc.)

I sometimes wonder if he understands the material at times, especially when he is answering questions.  His tests aren't too difficult if you read the textbook.  Lecture notes lack details.  It's just maths!

I learned very little from Cline.  He goes through material very quickly and isn't very clear about it.  Do the homework and learn by practice - it's the only way.  His tests are fair (though incredibly hard).
Should be teaching graduate classes not undergraduate pre-med physics. Most people fell asleep or didn't come. Preparation consisted of studying yourself because he never applied concepts in lecture.

Although lecture was a bit dry, he is very vested in his students.  He weekly sent out tabulated excel sheets with our grades and the class averages for comparison.  Tests were fair. Slightly tricky, but if you studied the workshops, and hw, you could master most questions.  Good professor.  Would have him again!

He wants to give everyone A's but he makes the class so hard that no one actually does.  He's really a nice guy, and supposedly prepares students for upper-level physics classes, but I wouldn't say so.  Supposedly harder physics classes have defnintely been easier.

Very helpful, likable, easy to get along with.  Lectures sometimes a bit complicated, but nothing a bit of studying can't work out.   [In response to earlier comment:] Doesn't expect students to be "brilliant" -- just to be willing to think and

Nice guy.  Really does want all of his students to pass, but won't set his standards any lower than postgraduate level.  Very poor at explaining ideas in a lecture, fair at explaining them one-on-one, he just expects too much background for an intro class
Do not take his class, you will fail most definately. Has the highest expectations from students, Educated at Oxford himself. Genius mind, but can't teach mediocre U of R pre med students.

Very friendly interesting and helpful.  Unfortunately he's brilliant and expects everyone else to be as well.  Not a good teacher for an intro level physics class.  Even as a physics master, YOU WILL BE LOST!(but an excellent choice for advanced courses)

He is a horrible professor.  He isn't clear in his teaching and he pushes too much material too quickly.  Plus his grading system isn't great and he is incompetent when you ask him questions about the homework (he will lead you on a wild goose chase).

Chen is one of the nicest professors, with nerdy jokes that keep things fun. His class can be a bit disorganized, but if you put in the effort, he's generous with grades. Outside of class, he's even better—always supportive, helpful, and genuinely cares about his students. An amazing person overall!

Relies off undergraduate TAs for exam questions. Past exams are completely different, so it's impossible to know what to study. Instructions for projects were often not communicated well and clearly not proofread. If you have to get through this class for the BS, take it a different semester.

As someone who tries to distinguish the professors and the subject. This professor somehow was able to make me hate this class to it's core. From how disorganized and confusing their assignments are, I can not be more lost.

As someone very interested in CS, it seems like he's tried his absolute damnest to make me lose whatever interest I had - no one has ever come closer, so hats off to him for that. THIS is NOT how you "teach" a class (teaching huh, what's that?). THIS is NOT how you structure a class. THIS is how you push people away from CS.

Our exams and labs were the worst, he let undergraduate TA's who had studied under a different professor with different course materials design and create questions for our midterms. Instructions for the labs were also unclear, he didn't even know what was happening and sent us to the grad-TA.

Worse experience I've ever had with a professor, respects to the guy because I do think he's genuine and nice, but within the course he's one of the worse lecturers I've ever seen in the CS department. He resorts to past professors slides and even as a last ditch effort uses the actual PDF of the textbook and scrolls through it during lectures.

I did not listen to the review that said "Trust me, you will regret taking this course." I did regret taking this course. A huge part of the course is graded on a complete group project. You're assigned a random group, and you better pray to get group members who show up to class and do their parts. And instructions on assignments are super unclear
Trust me, you will regret taking this course.

One of the most helpful and respectful professors out there. He has a unique philosophy and does things unconventionally, but with passion and meaning. Talk to him outside of class, it'll only do you good. He genuinely wants students to succeed, not just academically and will do his best to provide support and advice.

I liked him as a lecturer and actually prefer him for 254 over Scott. He's one of the nicest CS professors I've encountered and super accommodating of things like job interviews if you let him know in advance. Attendance is necessary because of the random quizzes. He's friendly and his personality shines through in his lectures.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Bad course design and lectures.
Probably the most unhelpful and unorganized guy in the CS department. 254 should be one of the most important courses but I feel like I learned nothing from his lectures.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Please do whatever you can to avoid his classes. Horrible teaching skills.
He tries to make jokes at the start of class. They're not always funny but always nerdy. It sounds bad but it's really not.
Decent lecturer and the class is not easy, but he is the nicest guy in the department
Do yourself a favor and get to know Chen outside of class. He's not the most organized guy, but he's passionate and will go out of his way to help you.
While very willing to help out students, he can't seem to actually do it.  This compounded with one of the most boring subjects in computer science equals one crappy experience.

Chen is a great guy if you get to know him outside of class (and in class as well). He puts a reasonable amount of effort toward his students, but his greatest downfall is his accent, which can make him difficult to understand and his (at times) weak grasp of English. Projects are as expected and he definitely expects you to work.
Chen is the man! At first what he says is a bit unclear, but you get used to it quickly. I learned alot in his courses, and he knows his stuff. he will be happy to help you!

Worst professor I have ever had.  Worked for hours and hours on projects only to receive terrible grades.  When asked for help, he provides no answers.  Difficult to understand in class, and no matter what the material is it ends up being recreating his r

After having Professor Lambropoulos for both ME 226 and ME 223 there is no doubt that he is an incredible professor. His lectures are very fast paced but he articulates the content clearly and always clarifies when something is not understood. Wonderful professor and very nice guy.
So caring and makes hard topics easy to understand. Never looks at his notes but writes a million miles per second. He is like your favorite uncle.
Best professor I have had thus far at UR.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Prof Lambropoulos is incredible. He knows how to make lectures interesting and manageable, is always looking for feedback, and really cares for his students' career paths. He is very accommodating and a great professor, hands down.

Professor Lambropoulos is a great professor. He is very reasonable and understanding of students. He continuously asks for us to reflect on his performance. He really knows the material and is great at answering questions. I would definitely take a class with him again!

He is a nice guy and a good professor. The class material is pretty difficult though. I would recommend going to all the classes and all the recitations if you want to get the best grade you can in the class. Also definitely find a friend to do homework with because it will make your life so much easier.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Lambro is the best professor in the ME department. He is super caring and available for the students, and very knowledgeable about the subject. His exams are 1.5 hr but you get 3 hr, and they are extremely relevant and based off of what's been covered in class. He tests knowledge of material, not problem solving abilities. Best professor I've had.
I would say he is the best professor I have ever had. Amazing lectures. He always says I will give you 3 hrs to do a 1.5 hrs test. Just loved him.
Best Professor ever!!! He makes hard concepts easy. But his name is not spell correctly here - whats up with that???
The epitome of teaching and caring by a professor.

Dr. Lambro is so caring. Honestly, if you go to class and you pay attention, there is no reason you shouldn't get an A. He provides every resource one would need throughout the semester. I didn't even have to take the final.
The BEST professor in the Mechanical Engineering department. Explains the hardest concepts so easily.
Best professor  I've had here.

Its no wonder he's the head of the Mech E department. Amazing guy, very helpful, and a great teacher. His tests are fair, and his lectures are super clear, and he never turns a student away.  Beware though, don't disappoint him if he takes a special interest in you!
One of the best professors I've had, really fun and interesting

Honestly, one of the nicest/smartest guys I have ever met. Extremely helpful and always excellent at answering questions. His grading system is easy if you go to class and do your work. Definitely recommend!
Great teacher! all his classes were interesting and I looked forward to going. Projects and homeworks were useful. ALso a nice guy, very helpful and understanding

Great professor who really cares about his students.  Very clear lectures that definitely helped in understanding the material.  Not a hard class, but you have to put in the work.  Homework sets and exams were very time consuming.
Great professor and great guy

Stella is such a nice lady but her class is very homework heavy and unless you do extra work you will automatically receive a B grade. The class isn't very difficult and she is very understanding but expect a lot of tedious work.

Professor Stella is wonderful! Both inside and outside the classroom, she is a student advocate who takes mental and physical health very seriously. She's very accessible outside of the classroom because she would stay until 10pm to provide support. Just a person who has a great spirit! I definitely recommend her classes.

Ms.Stella is an AMAZING professor. She is very caring and understanding which is a trait you hardly find in most professors. She has experience in different writing styles and techniques and has helped me to find a citing style that would benefit me for my major. She's just the sweetest professor ever. I recommend her class a ton.

Professor Wang genuinely cares about your growth as a writer or a student. She is always available for meetings outside of class. The course has a heavy workload but everything is graded based on completion. If you do everything you need to do it's an easy A. You will get as much as you put into the class.
Easy to get good grades but don't expect to become a great writer after taking this class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Please do yourself a favor and never take a class with this women. She never gives feedback, she wont teach you about writing and she will constantly remind you to breathe. I have no clue what i am doing in her class. She just randomly comes up and tell me that she doesnt like my paper and thatI should resubmit it 3 weeks after submission.

Stella is about the nicest, most caring person you can imagine. She has a "labor based grading contract", which means your grade depends on how much work you do (basically just participation, if you do the work, you get an A). Expect homework almost daily. She doesn't really give feedback, so don't expect to improve too much as a writer.

Stella is such a caring and understanding person and shows that love to each of her students. Her grading is pretty much just participation and just getting your work in on time. Her only downside is almost daily homework (though it's not too intense most of the time, just tedious) and she doesn't really give feedback on your writing.

The grading criteria is clear. You submit the tasks you get A. As long as you do everything, the grade is under control. However, you will not get any benefit of the class, she gives no useful feedback no writing materials. You never expect to be a better writer after taking the course. In short, wanna easy A without learning, take this class!

Professor Wang is super supportive under this special circumstance. She replies emails very fast, she always come prepared to class, and she is genuinely concerned about students' health condition. Put effort into this class and a good grade will definitely ensue. She is just so so kind! Wish I could take her other classes
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: She is a very caring and accommodating professor, unfortunately I never felt like she actually made us better writers. She often gives criticisms in order to make you conform to her perspective instead of finding ways to help you argue your point more effectively. Overall having her as a teacher was not a great experience.

Stella is very caring and gives very thorough feedback. Nothing is graded until the very end of the year, so it is a low stress class. Not a lot of homework and she is very flexible with due dates (if you have a test on the same day, just reach out to her and she will change the due date). Always accessible outside of class! Very sweet teacher.
You think you can go to her class and get an easy A? Go find another professor to get an A

She is a wonderful person. Very engaged with her work. Truly and positively motivating. If you have an ambition you can create a wonderful project thanks to her amazing supervising, feedback and inspirations. She's truly openminded and let students explore their ideas.
She is one of the nicest professors at UR. Always so passionate in class discussions and is very accomodating to students. I would definitely recommend her for WRT 105!

I don't mean to take this class in the beginning, but I really love it and learn a lot from Stella! She is very nice and gives helpful feedback during office hour. She talks a lot in class and expects class discussion. And she will try her best to help everyone to enjoy writing. I love her WRT 105E!!!
