In BIO 110, Olek is not as bad as most students make him out to be. Its usually freshmen who have the biggest problem with him because they are not handed the information like in highschool. To comprehend Olek's lectures some work outside of class is required, if you put in the work, the class is easy.
SKIP STRAIGHT TO 112!!! DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WORST TEACHER EVER.
not a good teacher at all. so disorganized and gives the most random and ambiguous lectures ever. if u can try to get away without taking this class
So disorganized.  He claims that we need data to back everything up, but much of the data he provides in lecture is mathematically impossible.  Half of the class is a slippery slope argument.

He was the worst professor I have ever had. He was extremely unclear in lecture and was extremely disorganized. You could never tell what lecture was actually about. Worst class EVER! I'm so glad that I don't have to take Bio 110 again.
Whatever you do . . do not take this class. I still do not believe that bio 110 is not a biology class, but to understand the mind of the professor.
Olek just kinda sucks at teaching... PERIOD! If you have a choice in the matter, just go straight to bio 112.  bio 110 is really not worth your time

Don't need to attend class to pass the tests. Literally spoon feeds you the exams on his website. Very disorganized. If you're confused about a concept, don't ask him; ask your TA, Olek will just confuse you more. Upside, he plays music before each class.

Olek seemed to be bit disorganized in his teaching. The material taught wasn't difficult, and if you study off of past exams you will do FINE in the course. He seems to be lazy when it comes to changing exams from year to year.
Made each lecture extremely interesting and made me excited to go in each morning. After taking the class I feel like I know a lot about the subject and I wish that there were more teachers like him.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: One of the best professors I've ever had. His lectures were electric and gripping. Our class had 60+ students, but he was still personable and accessible outside of class. Would strongly recommend to any student.

Not my favorite. He made the midterm the tuesday coming back from spring break and has unclear grading criteria for the midterm. Everyone told me that this was an easy A class but so far it is not looking like it. I personally didn't like his lecture style and he jumps around a lot making it hard to follow along. I would not recommend.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The class is self-graded, which alleviates a lot of the pressure of a college course. With that said, the readings and lectures are pretty interesting and worth completing! The final project is manageable and on whatever topic interests you. He wasn't always the easiest to contact outside of class but overall fine. Readings could be a bit long.

One of the best professors at the school. The class itself is self graded but he still makes it interesting enough that you want to come to every lecture. Readings can be pretty long but it really is a treat to listen to him talk about these topics. Very little work besides a final project and readings. Overall an amazing prof

Easy class while not being too boring either.
He is a fun professor that keeps lectures going.
If you don't mind a bit of reading a week, you'll probably enjoy his classes as a lot of the grading just has to do with discussions about what you read.

Attendance is not graded, but there's no way to catch up if you miss a lecture. papers are short and fun to write, but the final is very lecture heavy. Homework assignments are insightful and a good read. All in all, Fleischmann slays!

Professor Fleischman was a good professor overall, lectures were generally interesting and informative. The only real complaints that I have are that lectures weren't recorded, and that we could sometimes lose class time due to Powerpoints that weren't fully completed (lots of jumping around slides, or missing slides). Gave good feedback on papers.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read

comment: I had Professor Fleischman for postwar Europe. He is a good lecturer, but a bit disorganized and unclear about grading criteria. He doesn't really use slides with his lectures, so make sure to take in-class notes, as they will be valuable. He's definitely pretty laid back and tests and all graded assignments are pretty writing-heavy.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: He's amazing! The class material is really interesting and he's so enthusiastic about what he's teaching. Lots of reading, but the readings are interesting and definitely worth your time. He is very accessible and clearly cares about his students and their success. Highly recommended!!!!

Simply the best, outstanding, and knowledgable about the subject to the peak. I really enjoy this class and also learning from a very young person. Trust me, it is worth taking this class, even if not this one, another class being taught by Professor Fleisch should do you fine.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Fleischman is a great lecturer. He is very knowledgeable about the subject matter and you can tell that he is passionate about it. He is approachable, kind, and made the heavy subjects we talked about feel relevant and important. I really recommend taking a class with him - even if you don't necessarily like history!

Had Prof. Fleischmann during the "all online" semester-- but he was a fantastic guy through and through. The lectures were early morning but super interesting if not outright entertaining, there's no way I could've fallen asleep. Any time anyone had even the most esoteric questions, he'd almost always have an answer, too!

I had Fleischman my first semester at UR and he has by far been my favorite professor. Lectures are engaging and class discussion is encouraged, although not required. He always managed to give the class a laugh and rarely went off track, and even his tangents were fairly interesting. Highly recommended to anyone wanting to take a history course.
Favorite class I have taken out of all 3 years, best lecturer I have had in 3 years.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Amazing lectures

comment: Probably my favorite class this semester. A great professor and very interesting subject matter.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Fleischman is incredibly passionate about his course and is quite hilarious as he seems to constantly be having a crisis with technology. Lectures are very fun but be aware, he will sometimes randomly call on people from the roster for answers to questions when its a little too quiet. Overall, 11/10 professor.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: The class material itself was a lot of fun to cover. The professor is charismatic and clear about what he wants from you. His lectures are well structured and they're to the point, but he also slips in a lot of real life advice and jokes in there to lighten things up. The class isn't hard and the papers were manageable. Overall, a great experience.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Amazing lectures

comment: I was heartbroken when Wyman left UofR. He is one of those professors you feel absolutely charmed by because he is nice, polite, and smart! Absolute gentleman. He is also young so he understands students well. He was also the calmest math professor who is not boring!
One of THE BEST professors I've had in my college experience. A class with him is a must! Very kind and understanding, good sense of humor, and down to earth!

Attending his office hours is always useful, you get to connect with him and get more useful information that he may have not said in class. His lectures are good cause he can make calc not so unbearable.

Wyman is one of the best professors I have come across! He's passionate, caring, and makes lectures pretty enjoyable. Despite dealing with relatively heavy content, he keeps the class pretty light with his top-tier humor. He's super understanding too, and is amazing at explaining things. I would highly recommend attending his office hours!

Wyman is a very good professor. His lectures are clear and he gets right to the point. He even makes jokes and tells funny stories. He is kind and very understanding. I would definitely take this class again. Do your hw, go to class and recitations, ask questions and you will do succeed.

Wyman is a very good professor. The material is rough, but he takes the time to really explain it. He is kind and very understanding. I would definitely take this class again. Do your hw, go to class and recitations, ask questions and you will do succeed.

Professor Wyman was just an all-around good professor. It didn't feel like he ever went too quickly in explaining concepts but still managed to keep up with the curriculum of the course. He is very easy to approach and is always happy to talk through problems that you might be struggling with after class or during office hours.

*i have already taken ap calc ab and bc in high school* he is very young but knows how to teach math better than other professors. he has dry humor but it is pretty funny. explains topics throughly and answers questions. he doesn't upload his notes because he does it all by hand on the chalkboard. don't write in pen, he tends to erase
This guy is great. Tough, but cool. I like his style of teaching.

Prof Wyman teaches material really well with a very enjoyable sense of dry humor, but takes questions and explains in a way that always makes sense. He's caring, he lets you schedule your own office hours, and even once talked with me for a while outside of lecture when I was on the fence about going to Math141. 10/10 class, 200% recommend.

Prof Wyman was an outstanding teacher. His lectures were well organized, clearly articulated, and legibly transcribed. He often let his personality shine through the lectures, which made them that much more enjoyable and engaging. He's always happy to politely and carefully answer questions whether it be a brand new topic or rehashing something.
Super nice guy with a really dry but funny sense of humor. Super knowledgable about the subject. Would definitely recommend.

I am a senior student majoring in Applied Math. So trust me, among all professors who taught me, Wyman is definitely the best. He explains concepts clearly, and he always answer students' questions fast as well as helpful during class time. 

No hard homework or exam in this class. Again, I must say, EXCELLENT professor.

Professor Wyman is a very excellent professor! He took notes clearly, had nice handwriting, and was really superb at explaining concepts thoroughly. Though math may not be one of my favorite subjects, he kept class interesting.

Prof. Wyman is really good at lecturing Complex Analysis and always be prepared. However, he is too quick to follow in class so I'd suggest watch his lecture recordings instead and go to his office hours. He is smart, so it's sometimes hard to follow...

Watched his lectures instead of going to the other professor's lectures because he is an amazing professor. Makes calculus easy to understand even if you're not much of a math person. Really caring and is good at communicating abstract ideas.
Genuinely a really great professor, actually helped me understand calculus and was just really nice! If you can take 141 with him!

Prof. Wyman is a great 141 professor. Does a great job teaching within the constraints of the math department and the course. Go to office hours if you are struggling, as class moves FAST. You learn the basics in lecture, WW is a lot harder, and exams are somewhere in the middle. Prof. Wyman jokes around and is very fun.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: It was a little bit more work than I expected for a two credit class, but Amy was super chill and caring. I think she is done teaching now but I really enjoyed class with her. She was very down to Earth. She did sort of grade the final project harder than I was expecting. Also her class I a little disorganized.

Don't pick her if you can't handle her energy. I don't know how to describe it but she kinda has like sassy girlboss humor. She's the director of the Speaking Fellows, so she gives pretty good advice when it comes to dialogue and self-image. Yeah, the class is a lot of work, but you can't really blame the professor for that. Blame the department.

Seems nice, but is a unreasonable amount of work for a 2 credit class. Harsher grading than necessary. Was sick halfway through the semester and had some late assignments and it hurt my GPA for no reason. If you are busy and don't have the time to do the excessive amount of work, def take it with someone else as there are many prof who teach it

There's a good amount of work in this class, but its like any other college class, difficult and long! Amy is easily one of the best professors i have ever had, she is funny, kind, and someone who can be there for you!! Amy ily

Amy is one of the best professors I have ever had. She is so kind and very thoughtful to all her students. The work in class is sometimes hard and can feel overwhelming, but she is really supportive and has many great pointers and tips for doing your best!

I did not prepare for a bunch of work that was needed to be done for a 2-credit course. Amy's lectures are full of fun, and she is a good professor herself. However, she is not a good grader, and the criteria is kinda misleading.
Love her she's the best. Took her for the Taylor Swift writing class. Super engaging and funny. Super understanding, just communicate with her. Really fair grader, not hard to do well in her class.

Amy is a great professor at UofR! If you have the opportunity to take a class with her do it! She is so funny and really cares about her students. There are lots of readings for the class, but they are fun and work well with discussions. OYS!

Amy is a great professor! Class was pretty easy and she gives thorough feedback. You could get away without doing the readings. Some of the assignments were corny, ngl. Peer review and discussion are huge so be prepared for that! Amy is super lenient on deadlines and she cares about her students a lot.
I LOVE AMY. She's so kind, so helpful, and so funny.

If you have the opportunity to take a class taught by Amy, jump at it! She is so engaging, funny, and well-spoken, and the class materials might be lengthy, but the discussions make up for it. Amy really cares about her students, and making her courses as perfect as they can be. Feedback is a major theme in this course; peer review is huge!

Amy's Wrt 273 class was great. She always balanced relevant advice instruction with funny stories about her kids. Some of the assignments felt a bit cheesy, but choosing a real reader was a great part of the course, and she was always around to help with resumes and cover letters.

Amy is the best professor! She gave lots of good feedback and taught you lots of good writing strategies. The reading may indeed be overwhelming, but it is all worth after since it is so helpful. It is not an easy A, but it is definitely the class you can learn lots of things that can apply to your future writing. Take her class!

Amy is an amazing professor. She truly cares about her students and wants them to succeed. Her class is fun, and she'll spend quite a bit of time telling stories at the beginning of class, but she always makes it through the material. Overall this class has been an excellent learning experience, and I'd always go for her class if given a choice.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Amy is kind and respectful of all her students. She provides thorough feedback on rough drafts and helps out often. Though, if you are looking for an easy 105 pass this isn't it. You will learn a lot, but its nearly impossible to get an A. (Must get a 95 in the course for an A, and the highest you can get on a formal paper is a 97, then 92)

Amy is super caring and understanding. Her lectures always made sense and felt relevant, and she always went the extra mile to make everyone feel included. Her feedback was always constructive and she genuinely wants her students to succeed!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Super caring and funny professor, really gets to know her students. I took an intro writing class with her and it helped me so much as a writer, whereas most of my friends got nothing out of their 105. Definitely recommend.

Professor Arbogast (Amy) is amazing!! Take her class!!! She gives really great feedback on every single assignment that you submit (quickly, too). I wouldn't say it's an easy A, but it definitely isn't impossible. I actually learned a lot in her class. She's also hilarious and so sweet which makes class enjoyable! TAKE HER CLASS!
Grading is tough but fair. Her class requires great amount of works for a high grade, but it is definitely useful for future writings assignments.

She requires students to work hard, but my writing has improved drastically thanks to this class.  The assignments were interesting and class discussions were great!  The professor was very clear and a fair grader.
She keeps everyones interest

TERRIBLE professor. Plays favorites with people who kiss up to her; if you don't suck up, she acts pretty cold to you. I thought my paperswere decent, but she made some pretty ridiculous criticisms and refused to sit down and talk to me about them. She doesn't make class interesting, either; very boring lecturer.
like most cas classes (so I hear) this one was dull dull dull.
a dull and confusing class.
CAS IS A HORRID CLASS AND WE REALLY SHOULDN'T HAVE TO TAKE IT BUT JENNIFER MADE IT INTERESTING AND I LEARNED MORE THAN I THOUGHT I WOULD EVEN AFTER GETTTING AN A IN AP ENGLISH.
boring, but then again most CAS classes are. Or at least that's what I hear from everyone else

FABULOUS!!!  Best prof I've had at UR.  Period.  Great class!!  LOVED CAVENDISH!!!  I don't know what people are talking about when they say she's unavailable she was ALWAYS available to me and I've never had a prof be clearer or more attentive to helping students.  I can't wait to take an English class with her!

I hate this class.  I'm totally frustrated by her lack of understanding, unrealistic expectations, and ridiculous standards.  I like to be challenged but I also like my teachers to teach me how to acomplish what they want me to accomplish.  She's also really unavailbe.
boring.  hated every moment of it.

ugh.  dull dull dull.  i didn't expect this course to be ultra-engaging but I at least expected something I could relate to and get interested in.  I say if this is the only section of CAS you can get into, withdraw and take it some other semester!!
I really didn't like this class.  confusing guidelines and deadlines. I actually liked studying shakespear in highschool so I expected to like this class
Prof was hard marker.  Fair though--respected the class's views.  Loved the witch topic!!

This course helped me a lot.  I highly recommend it--I wished I'd taken it when I first got to UR.  It is pretty easy stuff. The prof was highly approachable--she even took the time to discuss issues that werent really apart of the class, but which affected my study skills--she rocks!
Ugh.  This class drove me crazy.  It was an easy A but I learned absolutely NOTHING
it went well .. a summer class
her guidelines were confusing and she seemed to design the course so that she had to do as little work as possible.  I know other sections of this course can be dull too but ours was THE WORST!!

Professor Reis's PSYC 263 class is the reason I'm a psychology major. His lectures are really interesting-- both in content and the way he frames them. He uses real-life scenarios in order to convey his information and regularly engages with students. All in all, 10/10!!

Professor Reis is my favorite professor/lecturer at this school thus far. His tests are hard and you definitely have to go to class, read textbook, etc but its worth it if your'e interested in the topic. He also offers additional optional assignments which is very fair -- if you work hard you'll get a good grade! Definitely recommend to everyone!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: My experience with this professor was not the best. The lectures were very interesting but the tests were VERY hard and unfair. He wouldn't accept feedback and the TAs told me he made it intentionally hard to prove that psych wasn't easy. He doesn't curve and isn't phased by failing class averages on tests (which happened frequently).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Reis is one of the best professors I've ever had. His lectures are interesting and engaging, and he incorporates relevant articles into the course. His tests are very hard, and if you don't read the textbook, you will be unlikely to do well. The extra credit he offers is a lifesaver, well worth the effort, and not too hard either.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: If you pay attention in class, do all the readings, and study a lot for the tests, you'll do fine. Oh! And do any extra credit you can. Overall though, interesting class, cool professor, would recommend to anyone.

The tests are not tailored for the lectures in a meaningful fashion. Reis is a good lecturer in the sense that he can get your attention and make you think or laugh sometimes, but he fails to present the significance of the material related to the topic  epically.

Generally, very clear, but he's got a very weird dymanic with students and is not terribly approachable. Also, on certain topics, his personal feelings win out over empirical evidence, and that is lame.

Prof. Reis is one of the best lecturers I've had at the UofR. PSY 263 was an amazingly interesting course and I would recommend it to anyone. Doing the readings, attending class and STUDYING are extremely vital in order to do well in the course!! However, because the course is so interesting, actually doing the work is not so much of a chore.
He is such a funny guy, always makes us laugh in class. can see he emphasizes on writing, essays are required even you take 263 without w. the materials covered are interesting. haaaaaaard tests.

Interesting, engaging, funny and brilliant. The tests can be tricky but they're exactly like the practice tests he puts up (even the same questions sometimes). If you pay attention in class and do the reading, it's not too bad. Probably my favorite class I've taken so far.
not that great. his tests don't really relate to the teaching and they can be unfair. all common sense. i didn't learn much. he is a nice guy thouh but i think the class wasn't worth it
hard exams hard exams hard exams... get ready to study
Reis is a GREAT lecturer and 263 was my favorite psych class at UR because of him!
I loved the course, hated the exams.  The reading is a chore.  Best lecturer I've had yet.

Harry is the best professor at the univ. His tests are pretty difficult and you do need to attend every class and read everything if you want to do well, but he teaches in such a down-to-earth way, trying to relate each topic to his students. He's incredibly nice and wants the students to do well and learn.  Very passionate and respected. Love him!
He seems like a funny and interesting guy.  He's also well published and his studies are often cited in the text.  I like him!
This guy is really really bad.  He just needs to smile and be open.  It would be painful for Harry Reis to smile.
I wouldn't take a class with this person
Worst professor I have ever met
I think she tries but some people are just not meant for the teaching profession
Just the worst professor I have ever had.
Unusual teaching style and doesn't care about her students at all
rating_tags: So many papers--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Awful teaching style, very condescending person. Cares more about have a quirky outlook on numerical analysis than actually teaching numerical analysis. Terrible examples that made no sense in the context of the lectures.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: This professor is disorganized, unprepared, and doesn't care at all about her students. She has also given us wrong information in class, and when I brought it up to her she doubled down. Please do not take any classes with her.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Obviously an intelligent and caring professor, with lots of knowledge. Her lectures are honestly pretty interesting with a balance of intuition and proofs. However, there is just too much work and too little planning. There are usually multiple items due per week and I felt most of my work are rushed because of it. Not the best but could be worse

Slightly unusual teaching style, but I learned a lot in her class. Also very accessible outside of class for questions. Make sure you attend lecture and pay attention, but for a math class that's a pretty reasonable guarantee to do fairy well!

Literally do not take a class with her, she makes SO many mistakes and thinks she is teaching some “innovative” applied math class but her approach is completely uninteresting. I don't understand why the department even lets her teach an upper division course, she is utterly clueless
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Worst experience as an applied math major. Lots of unnecessary homework that she think is necessary but not beneficial at all. Lectures are unorganized and does not follows textbook. She assumes students know too much and her lecture lacks explanation on lots of things.

I've taken a lot of advanced math at UR, and honestly, 280 doesn't compare in difficulty to courses like 265 or 240. Proof-based classes are way tougher than computation-focused ones. Also, she's the most caring professor I've known—can't understand why some students vote against her dedication.

The worst experience in college. The professor seems to change the course a lot by adding unnecessary hw, which she thinks are beneficial to applied math students, but it makes me feel unfair to be treated like this and now I lose interest in applied math at all. I wish I had taken this course previously with other professors.

Crazy workload with unnecessary projects and too many knowledge prerequisites that were not covered in previous courses. I feel like I haven't learned anything valuable yet. The projects have nothing to do with math, and there are logs that don't seem to serve any purpose. The professor also makes a lot of mistakes while teaching as well.

Disorganized course with no lecture notes and confusing deviations from textbook methods. The professor has unrealistic expectations of students' prior knowledge and responds to confusion with additional readings. Heavy workload, with extensive homework, project drafts, and midterm crammed into a short period.

By far the worst class I've taken in college. Professor Adams lacks the ability to teach. Classes are extremely unorganized, constant mistakes, inconsistent notation, and an overwhelming workload. She doesn't follow the textbook and makes things up, so students rely on the lectures, but the lectures don't make any sense, thus we're screwed.

The professor is highly unorganized. Lots of mistakes on the board and lots of typos in the homework. The hints and explanations in homework often make me even more confused. Lots of long emails every week, keep updating the requirement for hws and logistics. A very confusing experience.

Professor was very unorganized. I feel like she was never prepared for class and I felt that it was a huge disadvantage for me as I felt very lost. She was good at communicating in email but if I had to take this class again I would choose another professor.

Dima is a great professor, although he is a tough grader. He fingerspells too fast during exams, even for ASL 101. I wouldn't  have pushed myself this hard in this introductory class without him, yet I think this is still a bit too harsh given this intro-level course. Overall a very enjoyable experience despite the grade.

He's great! I love him.  He's really helped me understand more about Deaf Culture, and there's so much learned from him despite the lack of speaking, which I was a little hesitant about at first but now realize was a silly worry.  He's very caring and will help you with something over and over again until you get it right.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Very friendly, approachable, helpful and humorous, I've taken two of his classes and he's always a pleasure. Does have a tendency to pair strong and experienced signers with less skilled ones, which can be awkward for both. Don't listen to the MCC students-he's a good teacher, he just doesn't tolerate rude behavior  like speaking or texting.

If you're looking for a good way to fasttrack your ASL education, then Dima is the way to go! He is a hard grader, but that is because he really wants you to learn.  However, if you put in some effort outside of class an A shouldn't be too difficult to obtain.  Just realize that you MUST put in that effort. Otherwise, he is super funny and nice!

Dima is an excellent teacher.  be forewarned, however, he expects you to take the subject matter seriously.  That should be obvious, but in my experience, it apparently isn't.  Dima is a great teacher for people who genuinely want to learn ASL.  Those looking for an easy credit should look elsewhere. For serious students, there is none

DO NOT take his class if you're looking for the easy way out.  Also, show up on day one knowing ASL alphabet and numbers, at the very least, otherwise you WILL be confused.  I like a challenging class, but the challenge should not be based on inability to understand what the professor wants you to do.  Other than that, great teacher all around.

I love Dima! He is definitely my favorite teacher in the whole school. Because of him, I was inspired to change my major to ASL. Like said previously, he does seem cold but once you get to know him he is so much fun. And even though he is the toughest grader, it totally pays off!

I took 101, 102, 105 with Dima. He is the best professor I've had at this school. At first he may seem a bit cold, but he is the friendliest person ever. He is known to be harder the hardest grader, but it is so worth it. In 101 I was able to communicate comfortably with people in 105. I wish he taught more classes so I could always have him!
He was funny but the same thing happened to me as the previous commenter, I got a B in 102 even though I worked hard and seemed to get good grades throughout the semester. I still like him though.

I enjoyed having Dima as a teacher until I received a B in his 105 class last semester.  I put much more effort into his class than what was expected.  His grading policy is unfairly vague and subjective, and it has made me dislike him.
Love Him!
He's hilarious.
Love Dima! He helped inspire such an interest in ASL and he is so helpful!

I cannot express how upset I am that he's no longer teaching 105.  I was seriously going to plan my whole schedule around his class.  I took his evening class in Fall '05, with only 10 other kids (small classes are the best esp for ASL).  Best class ever.
Amazing teacher.
dima is awesome!!

he was an awesome, fun, and helpful teacher. i took 101 and 102 with him and he was always incredibly helpful and had great activities to practice your vocab and the projects and tests weren't hard at all. a great guy.
No Comments
Very friendly and extremely nice. You just need to show up and speak every once in a while and basically you're guaranteed an A.
Super chill
He's such a great professor! Super nice guy! The content is also really interesting. Definitely worth taking!
If you enjoy playing video games then I highly recommend his VG classes! He is very passionate and very friendly and loves to talk about games with you. Really nice and helpful professor
This class is easy. If you need a ULW credit, this is a great option.

Really nice professor. Workload is manageable and he is flexible with due dates. His writing criteria for each assignment are detailed and clear. If you follow it to a T you will get an A. Highly recommend this course for the upper-level writing requirement for CS majors.
Very chill but also clearly very knowledgeable. Some of the class does feel a little like busy work though. Not really on him as ULWs have to meet a page requirement.
One of the most caring and nice professor out there. It was a great class. Nothing bad to say

Prof Loporcaro is the best! I would highly recommend taking any class with him. He is genuinely one of the most caring and understanding professors I've ever had and he makes class fun in a way that it doesn't even feel like work. Absolutely take a class with him if you can!
I will give 10 stars if possible. Kindest professor in U of R ever. The world needs more Professors like Professor Loporcaro.
Great guy! Very chill and friendly. You don't see him as a professor, you see him as a neighborhood friend. Love him.
Reviewed for half an hour before taking the 1hr 20 min midterm and finished in 20 min. Straight A. Inarguably the easiest professor at UR. I took literally every course he taught.

Overall a very chill class. This class isn't related to my major and I just took it for fun. The class is very group project based and you are able to work at your own pace. He gives good feedback and is usually very accommodating when it comes to deadlines. Very recommended.

Joe is my favorite professor at UR. His lectures are interesting, and he's a really nice dude. Attendance and participation is mandatory, but it's not hard to get full credit on this end, just say something during class and you're good. As long as you do the work, you'll get an A.
Very chill teacher and class. I highly recommend his class.
Chill class; professors great at lecturing.

Very generous and caring regarding students. Adapted very well to the online format. Allows you to revise your essays for full credit if you email him. Basic CSC273W stuff, lots of boring essays, but easy A.
Loporcaro is the best. Take a class with him even if you don't need to. The nicest, most genuine professor I have had.

He's chill. Sometimes it can feel like a lot of work, especially if you're a CS major and don't write/read a lot, but he breaks the work down easily. If you follow his criteria, you'll get an A. He is also very accessible out of class and willing to help you.
rating_tags: Participation matters--SO MANY PAPERS--Clear grading criteria

comment: If you want you to take the most pointless class and learn nothing, take this class. If you want to be a walk across campus to sit and do other work and be on your phone, take this class. The choice is yours, where pointless test and assignments are graded like they are going to be the cure to cancer.

genuinely the most stretched out course and aimlessly and pointlessly tedious assignments and tests. Doesn't curve anything and intentionally gives bad grades, especially towards beginning of the year
Great Professor, if you put in effort you will easily finish with an A! amazing lectures and fun projects, Nescio is real and is a wonderful professor
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: A very kind person and knows a lot about the world of marketing outside the classroom. Does a great job bringing outside examples into class to help students understand the material.

she is not accessible outside of class, she takes everything so seriously, attendance is mandatory and if you miss you have to show a drs notes to have it excused, tests are mainly based on textbook readings and her lectures, she has some extra credit opps but i just can't stand her, she is rude to students and classroom management
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Nescio is one of the best professors that I have had at the U of R. She is very knowledgable, and organizes her class in a manner that enables her students to fully apprehend the subject. While the material is not inherently difficult, there is a lot of it. Thus, the homework and tests are very demanding and time-consuming.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: She's very direct, and is very clear that she treats us like adults, rightfully expecting us to behave accordingly. She can come off as strict, but in my experience it's usually deserved. Grading criteria can be a little fuzzy, but never felt unfair. Lectures are very well organized and engagingly delivered.

She is a good lecturer and really demonstrate her identity as a coach. Assignments are graded tough and tests are kinda hard too. Definitely not an easy A. Not really accessible outside of the classroom but I enjoy her class.

Great professor. Describes herself as a coach, and it's very accurate. Super helpful and incredibly knowledgable and confident. A lot of work, but the simulation at the end is fun, and the grading is not too bad if you put the work in. Overall a smart and caring person.

Professor Nescio is the best professor I have had, she is very smart and an amazing lecturer! At first I didn't like the class but then it really grew on me, I ended up really loving the course and the professors teaching style. If you put in the effort you will get an A
Shes tough, and abrasive. It is difficult to receive a high grade in her class. I would rather take the course with a different professor
final project is 30% of your overall grade. if anything wrong happened your grade is over.
Too much homework. If you miss one, you will fail the class.
Professor Nescio was the best Professor I've ever had! Her lectures are super clear, helpful, and she has a great grading system! I wish I could take her class again
One of the best professors I've ever had! Highly recommend her classes.

Too much work to be done in this class. The grading is very ambiguous so don't expect to get an A that you actually deserve. It is most likely that you will get an A- no matter how much harder you work than other people do. Better take this intro class with another professor.
She is a really good professor and she is easy to reach out to
super kind and always approachable
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: I took Prof. Wolkoff's class back in 2019, while I was at the UofR. I am currently a second-year medical student and his teachings stick with me to this day. He really teaches you ways of polishing your ways of thinking. Highly highly recommend taking this class!
Relatively interesting, insightful, and logical. He presented the material well and made it easy to take notes. Couldn't ask for a much better professor.
his class is the hardest i've taken in my life, made about 40 pages of notes for finals, and thats just one of many exams.
Very good professor. Shows interesting ideas and keeps that logical analytical approach that makes economics interesting. My favorite econ elective so far.
Fun guy and intelligent.  His tests are reasonable and so is he.  He knows what he's doing.
Awesome Teacher. Made a boring subject very interesting.
SMARTER THAN KANYE WEST.....good professor and very cool. not good sense of style.
A great professor who is responsive to students.  Made up for Phelp's noneconomics class.
A very dynamic and interesting professor.  I almost quit the subject after taking health economics.  But, this class turned me around.  Nice to take the subject from a true economist.

class avg was 63 on the first midterm...hard tests...and class can be boring, but he's a funny guy both when he tries to be and when he doesnt try...doesnt give you much to prepare for tests in terms of relevant old exams, but if you read the book and go to class you should be ok..he's a good teacher overall esp compared to other econ teachers
No Comments
No Comments
Wolkoff is a nice guy and a great lecturer, but he grades kinda hard.  I would recommend this class as one of your electives though.
No Comments
No Comments
Wolkoff made this the most boring class I have ever taken.  In addition to that he was not at all helpful.
No Comments
A hilarious guy and always gives useful feedback. Lots of critical thinking in class so be prepared. You will regret it if you don't take any of his classes during university.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: Amazing Prof!! Genuinely nice! Encourage student to reach out to him after class in a super gentle way! So supportive! The lectures are also intriguing!

He's an amazing teacher tbh his powerpoints do teach/clarify a lot. 1-3 readings for every class (many are long) but since discuss them in class could probably get by without doing some and still be well off for writing the essays (3 of them). If the readings don't make sense it's fine, he clarifies everything in class and discussion helps a lot.

Pretty engaging class, not bad. Many readings but he would always go over them and important takeaways in class so definitely can get by without reading. 3 section papers, 2 ethnographic assignments, and midterm/final (gave study guides for). Put in some effort, pay attention, take notes, and you'll do fine.

Highly recommend the course and the professor! The lectures were interesting and he really tried to engage the class with the material. There's a bit of reading but none of it is boring and for class you can just skim if you don't have time. When writing section papers though, you will need to put in the work - but if you do it won't be difficult.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: This class has a lot of readings, includes four books and many articles. We are also writing section papers, and they are graded very strictly. But overall, we can write our own ethnographic practices twice. It's fun and a good introduction into anthropology.
I really enjoyed this professor. His lectures were very interesting and I loved how the assignment instructions were clear. His class actually made me want to continue to major in anthropology.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: I found this class very interesting, and thought Professor Osburg was a fair and interesting professor. He definitely knows what he is talking about since he has spent lots of time doing fieldwork in China. Some of the readings are a bit heavy and boring, and he does do some reading "pop quizzes," but they are not really pop quizzes bc he warns you
He's pretty awesome. Easy A classes, teaches interesting subjects, keeps the class engaged.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He was a perfect teacher to take an intro course with, very good at getting the class excited about the material.
Osburg provided me a new perspective of China and I literally learned a lot in his class, despite I'm from China.
Highly recommend. He really knows his stuff and is very helpful and fair. Definitely take his classes if you can.

Osburg is a real quality professor.  He knows his stuff but is really good at teaching which makes the class so much better.  His lectures are really great, organized, easy to take notes to and very interesting.  The readings are really interesting, he is funny and approachable and really cares about his students.  I highly recommend him.
good teacher. very clear and funny.

ANT 201 was required for my major, I went in thinking it would be awful. Some of the material was dense, but Osburg was great at boiling it down and making it understandable. The material got better as the semester progressed. From what others say, he's the best for ANT 201 (Theory and Method)

I took his Chinese Society After Mao class, and coming in with absolutely no previous knowledge, he made it very interesting and easy to learn. Classes are all what you make of it, and on his end he made it wonderful. I'm looking forward to taking another one of his classes!

He made what would otherwise be an amazing class, studying Culture and Consumption, into a snore. I learned nothing in class, and the discussions are weak at best. The class is mostly a lecture with some questions thrown in. One can barely call it a seminar class. He's a nice guy, just boring. If only he made his class more interesting.

Prof. Audi is particularly hard to rate; he assigns two professional-level philosophy paper readings per week; this quickly becomes difficult to keep up with. However, the corresponding assignments for the reading are very easy and easily done if you read the article/use the Stanford Encyclopedia. He is very caring, passionate and fun to be around.

His lectures frequently devolved into complete nonsense and the TA was no help. Granted, the ideas in the readings are usually convoluted and require a lot of time to deeply understand. He was super chill when I had a health issue and had to miss some time though. Overall not much work but suprisingly draining.

Class not mandatory to do well, pretty lenient grader and a very nice guy. Lectures can sometimes be tough to sit through if you aren't interested in the topics but overall he is a very interesting lecturer.

Pro: Very easy-going, flexible deadlines. Really knows his stuff. Likes to make jokes in class. Gives few graded assignments, which can be both a pro and a con.
Con: Lectures all over the place, talks about whatever pops into his head, which takes some getting used to. And for some reason, his class is always super early in the morning.

Love the guy, but his lecture style isn't for everyone. He jumps from one topic to the next as comes to mind, which is really interesting if you already have the philosophy background to follow along. Grades based on short essays, so how well you can explain theories is as important as your understanding.

Professor Audi is a fantastic person and was always willing to provide feedback to students. However, he was an unfocused lecturer, which made learning impossible. In addition, the TA's were ridiculously harsh, which made it difficult for anyone to do well. If you need structure to succeed, do yourself a favor and do not take this class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: Audi is a great guy and always willing to discuss content or assignments. The material can be a bit scattered, but as long as you look at the slides and ask questions when you have them, it's not too hard to keep up with. I recommend sending in papers in advance for feedback. "Required" readings aren't that necessary.
Audi can be a bit disorganized but he really is well informed on the material and genuinely cares about his students.

Professor Audi is definitely knowledgable on philosophical issues and does a good job explaining a variety of perspectives. One of his strengths (which is unique among philosophers) is that Audi does very well exploring positions he disagrees with as well as those that are more familiar.

Seriously, this Professor is the worst Professor I have ever encountered in my college life. He has the worst lecture because he don't prepare anything before class. His worst part is his grading. All the grades come from exams and essays, they are graded very subjective by TA instead of him, if you ask about your work he will just let u talk toTA
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Professor Audi is actually a chill guy. I took a class with him during my first year in College. It was an incredible journey for me that began with a difficult start of the semester due to how philosohical and critical the class is. His office hours are helpful, and he even allowed students to redo their papers if they did not perform well.

Professor Audi is a true philosophy fanatic. His knowledge on the topics he's teaching is extensive and it shows. He also is extremely empathetic to his students and it allows him to better connect with the class as a whole. I would recommend to anyone to take his class. Lectures are hysterical as long as you do the reading.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: He's kiiiiiind of a mess - lectures are all over the place. But that's totally OK, given how much material the course needs to cover, there's time for it. I enjoyed going to class and participating, but a lot of students never went to lecture and still had no trouble getting As on the exams. There's a lot of extra credit anyway.

Audi cares a lot about his students. Classes can occasionally get a bit dry, but he has become one of my favorite professors I have ever had. Very intriguing concepts and he is absolutely hilarious. I had no interest in philosophy before this course, and I am now considering majoring in philosophy thanks to him. REALLY cares for all of his students

Had him for two classes: 101 & 110. He is actually a pretty good professor, but a lot of his lectures are disorganized. I'm personally pretty terrible at attending lectures, so I end up reading more by myself--and I got an A in both classes. Not hard to get an A if you take the time to learn the material. Also, he's hilarious and very approachable.
His lectures are so boring, he's even a worse lecturer than the TA. But the tests were super easy, just read the study guide before exams and don't go to class or read, you can get an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He is a bit of a scattered professor type. His thoughts seem disorganized and they are poorly conveyed to students. His lectures don't make sense a lot of the time. Graded by 2 papers, a midterm, and a final.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Audi is a super friendly and easy-going guy with a genuine interest in the material he teaches. If you enjoy philosophy then you will really enjoy his class, because no subject is off-limits.   The one down-side is he is so interested in the subject that he can get sidetracked easily, so sometimes lectures get a bit scattered.

He's kind of all over the place. Some of the worst grading system I've seen. Though, he teaches well and the class is structured in a way that if you do the right things you can get an A in this class. To those who will take this class: getting an A is NOT easy so you'd better put in the work. The grading leaves NO room for error.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Very passionate about the class and always happy to help you if you show you're trying.

Prof McGrath was fantastic. I personally dont care about mechanics but his lectures are really fantastic. He does a great job introducing concepts and explaining how to go about solving the problems youre expected to do in a very logical and concise way. Homework is unnecessarily difficult at times due to grading but the class teaches you a lot.

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful professor. Dr. McGrath really knows how to teach mechanics and he is very, very direct with what is expected with every test. Didn't go to this class for majority of the semester and it is one of my biggest regrets. Class isn't curved and it's also not that easy of a class, lots of work and high expectations.
Class isnt curved even when less than 20% of the class is in the A/A- range.

He has his personal labs and he is much more concerned with his labs than he is with the class. It took 3 weeks to schedule a meeting with him in regards to an exam and 2 days after that meeting was the next exam. Also he reuses his notes since 2003, when the class was started and he is starting to misinterpret those notes.
Learned a lot of great tricks for ways to think about and approach problems from him. Class is definitely not his first priority, but he is a brilliant man and I very much so enjoyed his class.

This professor is really clear and a great lecturer. He tries to be helpful, but doesn't necessarily give it to you so that it's too obvious. His homeworks are extremely time consuming, and problems sets don't really make sense... tests are worth about 65% while being ridiculous (mainly time shortage). Other than being demanding, he's good.
Good class but a lot of work. Not as hard as everyone makes it seem. Good prof but material can be somewhat boring
class is not his main priority
Tough class, lots of work, but the professor is great and cares about the students a lot!  Makes the class interesting, despite the mountains of work and hard tests.
This course covered a lot of material, but the prof was great at answer question and conveying the material in way that helped everyone understand.
homework each week takes about 8 hours and then is only worth 10% of your grade while hour exams are worth 20%... the graders are huge ****es too take off for random****
He can take a 2 semester course and cram it into one without losing people in the process.  Very enthusiastic and a really nice guy.  Wants to help students.
This professor reminds me a lot of Uncle Joey.  He was really dedicated, and even bought my b.s. about falling behind and being concerned yadda yadda.  Very willing to help students, nice person.

Very enthusiastic about the course and the students. It's a challenging, time consuming class, but well worth it, because you learn so much out of it. And a lot of that has to do with the focus he gives each student.
Not easy, but enthusiastic and puts in effort to stay in tune with what the class needs to learn the material.

Kostin cares a lot about the material, and is very accessible for help. Web dev is fake CS, so the material is all very easy. He focused more on front end/UX as opposed to more theory. MS not a PhD, but if you get a PhD in web dev you have bigger problems.

As a student with no knowledge of Cs, the professor makes this class worth a while. He is always available to respond to students in the class group chat whenever you text him-even if it is 1 am. This class has weekly lab work, and 3 projects. If you attend class and listen to all of the lectures you will be fine. In fact, he explained the labs.

I believe this was Kostin's first semester teaching this class so need to mostly rely on the textbook and self teaching. However, Kostin is willing to improvise and change things to make it easier on the students. He provides a lot of help outside of class and all assignment criteria is always very straight forward.

The WORST professor in DMS you can ever find. Academically, lame lectures, boring topics, and disrupting people ALL THE TIME. If there is ever going to be a discussion or, he will never let the students finish any sentence, for real! Personally, a man with NO MANNERs at all. Communicating with him is like arguing with a jerk on the street.

Professor Kostin is a chill guy. First day of class he said if you pay attention, it's an easy A, and I found that to be true. Even though I've never taken a computer science class before, his lectures and labs were straightforward and informative, so I was able to easily follow and learn the material.

By far the WORST professor I've had in my time here as a computer science student. Lectures are not mandatory to attend but he "takes attendance." Double jeopardy is HUGE on the labs, don't understand one concept but understand all the others? You won't get an A, or a B, or a C, because he will take off every lab you ever have from then on out.

This is the kind of guy who will, for the second day of class, assign a strictly time-limited three minute powerpoint presentation, including the setup time on a screen you've never used before, but then when you're too slow and the alarm goes off, it's "When the Bell Tolls" by Metallica because he thinks he's cool, funny, and relatable.

Professor Kostin is a fun guy. Although he doesn't really teach you what to do, everything is in the textbook. As long as you read the textbook you got an A. The group project is tough only when your members don't do anything (half of my team members pretty much did nothing). As long as you do your parts, you get your points.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: He's really good about explaining stuff during the lectures. As long as you do all your labs and projects, you'll get an A.
Good intro course--labs and project instructions are clear and easy to understand. Kostin is funny and understanding, which is a plus.

Though he is a nice and funny guy, he basically does the homework for you and tells you the answers on the exams. I don't mind, but I wish the homeworks and projects were a bit more ambitious so I could learn more and he spoonfed us how to do them less b/c I want to learn more web development!

Cool Guy. I personally never went to class and only saw him once and he made a bunch of jokes during the final exam. Class is an easy A. No due dates and redos for some assignments. This class is more of a Computer Science 101 for those that haven't taken computer science. If your looking to actually learn how to code I recommend you look elsewhere

Most of your help will be on the TAs, who are always willing to help in lab and through email. Labs are optional attendance, I only used them if I had trouble with the assignment/uploading. Grades are based on the weekly labs and projects (dont fall behind!). Easy A. Lab instructions are easy tutorials. Attend if you like to get a walkthrough.

Kostin just got more classes here at the u of r - but he doesn't really know what he's talking about. we essentially had to do the class , he just sat and gave feedback. don't take this class unless you need it ... everything i learned i got from the book.

Kostin has no experience in the field of design - he has said himself that he doesn't know why he's teaching the course. You'll get an A but you will not learn anything. The professor can have weird attitudes towards students.

Kostin is the bomb. Loved his "no due date" policy. Very friendly. He's an adjunct prof so he really knows his front-end web development. Don't bother buying the book we never used it, it'll be outdated in 6 months anyway. CONS: No mandatory attendance, but online daily quizzes which were password protected (the password was given in class)

Prof Kostin really knows his stuff and you learn a lot from his course, but he's such an easy teacher. You don't have to hand the labs in on time, and he literally gave us the answers to our final before we took it. Definitely take this class - it's fun and an easy A and you still learn a lot about web design.

The course materials should be interesting but they are not taught in a systematic way. He speaks fast and softly so video quality is bad. You have to watch the videos again if your notes are poor, Summarize and memorize every stuff at least a week before the exam so that you will get an A.

This semester was Jaenike's first time teaching Bio 113 in about 5 years. He is such a kind, caring person who is so passionate about what he does. He's the type of person who makes you want to do well in his class just because you want to see him happy. His lectures are easy to follow, the class material is very easy. Take his class if you can.
Prof. Jaenike is a great professor! He explains well and cares about his students. One of my favorite professors.
You have to go to class. I failed the first class but started going to class and got an A. He wites a lot info on the board. Very nice person though.
Jaenike loves what he does, and it is inspiring. However, I already knew most of the material covered in the class, which was boring.

Professor Jaenike is one of the few teachers that I can honestly say cares about his students' grades and makes an effort to help students. He is very fair and as long as you study for the exams you'll do fine in his class. I would suggest Jaenike's classes to anyone.

Jaenike is a super nice guy, and he really loves the stuff that he's teaching.  His exams are straightforward, but you need to memorize a good amount of material.  Lecture slides are mostly pictures, so you really need to go to class & take notes.  Sit up front if you can, he speaks softly.  Overall, not a stressful class.  Very fair.

Jaenike is probably the best professor I've had thus far. He explains things very well, and his exams reflect lectures and are fair. He is also nice outside class as well which is a huge bonus. He also loves what he does which reflects onto the class. He makes the material enjoyable and interesting, which can be difficult to do. A must take class.

Awesome! Really smart and, overall, just awesome at what he does. Very good at using math to help explain the subject and the models in the material. Extremely nice and respectful to students. A friend of mine left her coffee mug in office hours and he took the time to wash it and clean it for her before he returned it to her in class.

Lectures are vital. Tests are exactly from slides/notes - MEMORIZE all the slides, graphs, charts, etc. Exams very straightforward, just be sure to memorize everything. Professor is GREAT! Super nice and responds to e-mails very quickly if you have any questions. Make sure you go to class. If you don't like ecology, class may get boring at times.

I don't usually like Ecology. But Jaenike makes it much better. The exams are wonderfully straightforward - know the lecture material and you'll do great. The lectures aren't boring at all, even when he discusses population ecology. He's nice and approachable if you have questions.
Go to class! His lectures are boring but they are typically clear and easy to follow. Test are mostly memorization and aren't too bad if you study hard for them
Jaenike is awesome!!!
spectacular professor. maybe its because its after platt but i really enjoy his class and it makes getting up for a 9am class easier. theres no tricks to the test, its all from class.
No Comments

Really easy after Platt, just don't slack off. As long as you do the study guides and problems before the exams you will do fine. Very organised lectures, tells you what will be on the tests and what won't. No final!
No Comments

Frank is maybe the best lecturer I've had at U of R, very clear, entertaining and up-to-date. Funny guy. The curriculum isn't super set in stone as he can linger a bit long on certain topics, though that does make it easy to internalize info. The exams and hw are very reasonable and he grades fairly.

Dr. Frank is by far one of the best professors I've had. I wouldn't rate him any lower than a 5/5, despite MUSC116 being an exceptionally grueling class that I would not wish upon anybody. If you need to or want to take this course, I recommend waiting as long as you possibly can in hopes that it gets offered at a different time in the future.
very good professor

I took Prof. Frank for MUSC 112 and find him to be incredibly passionate about music and a very considerate professor. His homework is short and concise and his lectures are very informative for what you need to do on the homework.
Attendance is mandatory; he gave me a hard time when I missed a class due to illness. Good teacher but spends a lot more time than necessary on certain topics when we could just move on.

Professor Frank is incredibly easy to get help from outside of class hours, is a flexible grader with very obvious care for his students and he never tries to stress us out. He is also really understanding about granting extensions when needed. Overall, great class, would definitely take it again.

Dr. Frank is the most caring professor I've had at UR. He even takes the time to learn every students name on the first day. His class is pretty lecture heavy, but his homework and exams are very fair. If students are struggling, he slows down to make sure everyone understands the material.
AWESOME professor. Highly recommend.

Dr. Frank is a caring, knowledgeable professor! I love his lectueres and he makes music theory so easy to understand. He's the most caring professor I've ever had and genuinely willing to help his students succeed.
Dr. Frank is very nice!!! He makes music theory interesting and it is easy for me to focus on the course materials. He cares about his students and he is always happy to help.

Dr. Frank is the man. He gave me a new appreciation for music theory, and if you have any previous experience with playing/reading music in high school then his introductory theory classes will be a piece of cake. I have nothing but good things to say about this quirky music professor.

From day one, Professor Frank made a conscious effort of learning each and everyone's names. Every class, he calls on every single person to answer questions and provides hints and help when needed. He's hilarious as a person and teaches with clarity. 9AM classes wouldn't be bearable without him!
He's the man. His dad humor is what got me to campus at 9:40 MWF.
Great teacher! Really cares about the students and tries to help them learn the material. Class is interesting yet also acts as a good GPA booster. Would recommend taking a class from him.

Prof. Frank is great! He makes a point to learn everyone's names, and calls on you during class. Pay attention and participate, do all your homework, and you'll be golden. I get the feeling he doesn't like handing out bad grades, especially to people who participate in class. I don't think attendance is mandatory, but he does call roll.

Absolutely awesome teacher. I would encourage all prospective music majors (and anyone interested in music) to take every class possible with Dr. Frank. He makes it his goal to know each student personally and is an overall great guy. Amazing pianist as well..

Dr. Frank is an amazing professor. He doesn't require you to buy the textbook, he makes classes so much fun, and the homework is usually fairly easy. He's also extremely lenient; if you forget to do your homework, then he'll still let you get it in to him before he leaves that day. All in all, Dr. Frank is awesome and highly recommended.

Dr. Frank is incredible. He is a talented musician who cares deeply about his students. The material is difficult (and unusual; atonal music is very different!) but Dr. Frank makes it very accessible and actually extremely interesting. He knows how to keep students' attention, knows everyone's name, and is respectful and knowledgeable. Great guy!
NO ONE WILL DISLIKE HIS JOKES!!!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: If you're a physics major who's sometimes doubted your choice, this class could reignite the initial determination and enthusiasm that led you to choose physics in the first place.
Perfect balance in a physics professor of being extremely passionate about the subject to help inspire his students, while also understanding how to teach at a comprehensible level.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Marshall is hands down one of, if not the best professors I've ever had. His lectures are clear and concise and his homeworks and exams were relevant to important material to take out of the course. He is very down to earth and relatable, easy to approach, and he often went above and beyond any other professor to help us learn.

Marshall was an amazing professor. He tried so hard to help us succeed in 235 (Classical Mechanics). His lectures were clear and easy to follow and he often made us laugh. He was very accessible outside of class as he always held regular office hours. Even when he was sick, he made an amazing effort to help us prepare for the final.

Professor Marshall's passion for teaching really stands out from other professors in the department. Upper-level physics is hard, but Chris really puts in the effort to make it accessible (review sessions, being available, etc). Exams are an accurate representation of the homework and are fair considering the level of difficulty of the course.

One of the best professors I've ever had. Lectures are engaging and clear. Syllabus and class organization are clear. Homeworks and tests are difficult but fair and lead to better understanding of the material. He is also very accessible outside of class, even when sick and at home.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Marshall is definitely one of the best lecturers in the physics department. He cares about how students understand course material and REALLY knows how to teach. Very fair homework and exams and idealized grading rubric. Business casual never gets old.

One of the best lecturers I have ever had at university. His homework and exams were incredibly fair, and he always went out of his way, even when sick, to be available and helpful. Made upper-level physics very approachable and understandable. Genuinely a great human and professor.
He clearly knows the material and how to teach it. His exams are not easy, so do not be fooled, but if you do the practice papers, homework and workshops you have will get an A, guaranteed!

I would go out of my way to write a review for very few professors at this school, but Professor Marshall is one of them. Hands down one of the best professors I have had. Provides students with every opportunity to succeed and sincerely cares about their success.
Best professor at the school. His exams are exactly what you expect them to be and he is super organized. Takes students feedback into account and changes course based on what everyone wants.

Professor Marshall at office hour: "I wanted to make this semester being online less suckish for you guys." I usually don't rate my professors, but I highly disagree with the earlier negative reviews. You only get a great guy like Prof. Marshall as a Professor a few times in your college career. He was VERY accommodating.

As a first-year professor, Marshall puts a lot of time and effort into running his course. He is a genuine guy who actually cares about his students and asked for feedback (that he actually listened to and implemented) multiple times throughout the semester. Exams were not ridiculously hard, and it's physics, so nobody should expect a cake walk.
marshall's a good professor. people who complain about him usually complain because they aren't doing well in the class. this is more of a reflection on them than the actual prof.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Marshall seems like a stand-up guy, but he must enjoy his students failing. After literally the WHOLE class complained about the first midterm being too long and too difficult, he proceeded to make midterm 2 the same way. Everyone does so badly that a grade in the 60s is a B. I don't think he knows what the word "fair" means.

Chris is all over the place when teaching physics and skips steps. Makes really hard exams, and very long workshops. He teaches everything in terms of vectors and complicates concepts with derivations of formulas. This course is an intro level course for pre-meds however, definitely feels like a high level physics course. He is not accommodating.

Prof. Smith's class was my favorite this semester. Though ENGL 286 is largely structured around watching videos/documentaries in class, the material was interesting and Prof. Smith facilitated interesting discussions. As a student whose political beliefs largely oppose his, I can confirm that Prof. Smith does not show bias for or against anyone.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Respected--Accessible outside class

comment: As this is public speaking, you do have to show up. There are a lot of impromptu speeches, and there are four formal speeches, but they aren't bad. He grades based on how much you've improved from your first to last speech. Sometimes, he does get a bit politically, but as long as you make sense with what you say, he doesn't grade you down.
rating_tags: Respected--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Great professor who is insightful and encourages open debate.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: This class is video based and you learn nothing. The professor requires you to do two midterms and an essay. He doesn't tell you, but there is hidden criteria. If you disagree even slightly with his political views he will grade you harshly. He can be very ignorant sometimes and refuse to concede even the slightest thing that he disagrees with.
The class is video-based. Little to no teaching.

He's really funny in a cheesy, quirky way. at first I was really intimated and shy to speak in front of the class but by the end I was doing it like a pro. He is really helpful and makes you feel comfortable with speaking in public.

The Presidential Rhetoric class he teaches should not be a class. All he does is talk for 5 or ten minutes about his views on current politics and then shows a biographical movie about a president that has nothing to do with their speaking ability. The class is a waste of my tuition money.

Prof. Smith is really laid back, but he knows his stuff.  Excellent speaker, very passionate.  Limited bias.  He has an extreme appreciation for public speaking, so when he talks down about a particular president, it's generally about their ability to present themselves in public.  Fair grader.
Amazing teacher and good info, not hard.
Lots of video, real laid back guy

I had presidential rhetoric with him. he knows his stuff, and i actually didn't see a bias, not too tough to do well with him, he shows relevant videos and points out things i wouldn't have otherwise noticed about the presidents we studied.
all we do is watch videos.  funny how i learned a whole bunch in this class.
easy class if you dont fear public peaking..however must of us do. Repetitive, but he knows what he's doin. P.S. He's a Red Sox fan, keep that in mind

Bash Clinton, Democrats, liberal Republicans, or praise Reagan/conservative Republicans = automatic A.  Praise liberal democrats = automatic non-A.  Incredibly (almost humorously) biased, along the lines of "Democrats hate God" but easy to get a
Corny at times, but cool and knows his stuff. Looks like Robert Redford.
No Comments
Speechwriter for Bush (41)...KNOWS public speaking!
get over yourself.
rat **** climber. Doesn't care about students, only his own reputation
He never shuts up. He took a class with an interesting topic and made it so boring. He is so in love with his own thoughts that he is so pompous and arrogant.
His ego gets in the way of his teaching.  I hated having him as a teacher.  Luckily President Jackson was there too to mitigate Dean Green's awful presence.
No Comments
his ego is as big as his belt size
I love this man
he is an amazing professor and person in general as long as you dont suck
hate him
Sure he's brilliant, but he's not nice, nor is he considerate.  He occassionally argues like a 2 year old, meaning i guess it doesn't matter what you think, if you're not him that is!
bored/sleepy in class, thinks hes the center of all knowledge, and hard grader
Lazy Bum
Amazing teacher, but too smart for his own good
intimidating, but a great teacher
The damn prof. talks too damn much!
Dean green, mean and a spleen
He does not require workshop attendance! This was awesome for me! I suppose it would be a problem if you sucked at chemistry, though.
I liked his jokes during class.  It wasn't such a bad class.

He was my lab lecturer. I'm sure he's a very intelligent man but all he does is talk about mastermind as a fundamental for learning and logic. Also he sounds really insecure when he talks and I didn't get much out of going to his lectures. Ppts posted online for his lectures.
What the hell is everyone talking about. Turner is quite possibly one of the coolest chem    prof. His exams are easy but tricky. Come on people, he's not that bad.

AVOID THIS TEACHER...FARRAR IS A MILLION TIMES BETTER!!!!This "professor" is an unreasonable person who unnecessarily teaches everything based on biology. I had received a raw score above 870 out of 1000 possible points, a score 100 points higher than another student who also received an A- and 20 points less than a student who received an A...

Turner needs to stop teaching.  He makes you think that you know the material, then throws an impossible exam at you.  He misleads you on the material included on the exam, saying it is from the book when it really isn't.  He is ruining chemistry for me, and only made me laugh (uncontrollably) a total of one time. AVOID AT ALL COST!
Worst professor I've ever had.

Terrible at teaching. He knows what he's talking about, but couldn't explain it for his life. Tests are ridiculous, and memorizing formulas was stupid. Doesn't go over enough examples in class to help with the tests at all. Waves his hands funny, and bobs up and down.
He is a horrible teacher luckily i knew all the information from AP chem

one of the worst classes I have ever taken. so incredibly boring and he doesn't even know what he's talking about. the tests are ridiculously hard (harder than the other chm132 class), but he does put a significant curve on it. all he does is wave his hard around in class with a piece of chalk in it. he doesnt answer questions clearly either
This smug professor might be research prodigy for all I know, but he is a HORRIBLE teaching professor. Unapproachable, poor teaching style, an absolute bigot.
Not very approachable.  A lot of lecture topics were about his research rather than test material. Overall, the class was okay, average amount of work.
No Comments
Tests were ridiculous! This class actually convinced me to stop pursuing chemistry

Class was hard (tests) but definitely doable, may seem boring but shows you if you really like chemistry or not.  Turner's tests are absurd in the fact that he makes you memorize all of the formulas.  Other than that the class was fine.
I disliked this class a lot. The classes were very boring and seemed to have nothing to do with the tests.

Truly such an amazing professor! Lectures were interesting and engaging. Tests were hard, but doable. Make sure to watch your wording and include smaller details. Overall, highly recommend this class!

Dr. Raz's passion about the content she teaches is catching. The course begins very history-based but will ultimately lead to health care. Quizzes are specific while midterms are broad (questions may have multiple approaches, but she is looking for a certain one). Lecture participation can act as a grade buffer. Amazing content would recommend!

Her lectures were super interesting and engaging. She tends to be pretty specific on her exams when it comes to grading but she curves well and as long as you have shown improvement throughout the course you will be fine.
