Dr. Raz is nice and flexible according to student feedback (her first time teaching this). Seminar style -- a lot of reading and classes are discussion only. Some readings are heavier than others... some hard to grasp. Grades reasonably, put in effort, do readings, and participate (15% of your grade is active discussion!) and you'll be fine.

Hard exams, harsh grading on essays, 
Be prepared to have your essays roasted and the quizzes are really hard. She asks the most specific stuff.
Talks about Israel health system a lot which confuses student.
Many people I know did very badly in her class. Do not take this class unless you have to!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Raz was very passionate about her work and what she taught, it made the class more engaging and genuinely was thought provoking. It was kind of just her lecturing at you, but her excitement for the subject makes it bearable. Watch your wording on exams, points will be taken off if it's not exactly what they want to hear.

Dr. Raz is an amazing lecturer with well-structured lessons in which she is able to show that she definitely knows what she is doing. The only drawback is the lack of material that contributes to your final grade. This and the harsh grading (mostly on exams) made this class quite painful. However, the topics covered are genuinely very interesting.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: The best human to ever exist. I aspire to be her when I grow up. Great prof, learned a lot. Reading textbook helps.
Dr. Raz was the best!! She taught in seminar style and I loved it. Super interesting class, great professor

Dr. Raz is a wonderful, charasmatic professor and truly 100% what she's talking about. The only concern with this class is that you're graded on so little (2 exams, 2 quizzes and essays) so it's hard to get a great grade if you do poorly on something (Shes also a full time dr hence why though). Other than that challenge, truly a great class!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Raz is so smart and incredibly kind. She cares a lot about what she is talking about. That being said, very few points go into your grade... which is painful.

I am only in my second semester of my freshman year, but Raz is the best professor I've had thus far. I took her HIST373W class and it was a great experience. I think those pursuing a stem career should consider taking this class. I'll never forget the meaningful conversations that took place in this class.

Loved this course and Dr. Raz - she is incredibly passionate about the content and offers a great perspective on what you learn. Lectures can be a little quick but I appreciated that the workload isn't crazy and she is 100% willing to answer questions and clarify when needed. One of my favorite profs so far!

Multiple choice quizzes have specific questions each worth 1 percent of grade. The two midterms are broader, but questions are more open ended and grading can be strict (type fast). For essay question, try to be concise with a good beginning and a CLEAR STRUCTURE. To get an A, memorize all the slides because some will show up straight on midterms

No doubt the best course I've taken. Professor Raz is brilliant and inspired me (and many others!) to pursue public health. She is incredibly passionate and knowledgeable and it shows in her engaging lectures. She encourages critical thinking about the health system and its causes, instead of memorization. I would 100% recommend this course!

Professor Raz is a practicing doctor and professor, so this class was mostly discussion based, I assume because she is too busy to write lectures. But she is great! Very straightforward and not afraid to nicely call you out, but also fun and passionate about her field. I wish she lectured more, but the readings were helpful and grading was fair.

A good professor for Russian, you will most likely have her at one point or another. Russian is a hard language, but she teaches well enough and it's not too bad of a course if you put in the work. Upsides, generally small course, and lots of resources if you need it, and she's always happy to help.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Professor Givens is one of my favorite professors at this university. She makes learning fun and teaches russian in a way that is conducive for learning a language. She is very caring and is willing to talk to you outside of class if you need help or advice. Taking russian was probably the best decision I made in college.

Professor Givens is an amazing Russian professor. Her lectures are organized and straight forward. As a person, she is very kind and always willing to help or talk to you. I would definitely recommend her classes to anyone.
Genuinely caring, one of the best
I LOVED THIS PROFESSOR!!!

I was shocked to see the the things some people said about Laura on this site. She is easily one of the most caring people and professors I have ever met and she was the best professor Ive ever had at U of R. She really cares about her students and is very knowledgeable in Russian and can explain complex grammatical rules with ease. Helpful always

Laura Givens is an incredible Russian teacher. Her courses are well laid out, and assignments and class expectations are clear. Russian is not an easy language to learn, but Laura explains things simply and extremely effectively explains difficult grammar topics. I have enjoyed every class with her.

Professor Givens is amazing. Both Laura and John. She always gives help when you need it and responds to emails in a timely manner with grammar explanations, even if you're on summer vacation! Her class is friendly, and she encourages frequent use of Russian.
Helpful if you ask questions. Grades a little harsh.

People on this site give Laura a bad rap. She does have a dry personality, but she also has a good sense of humor and really does care about her students, after you get to know her (and assuming you put the effort in for her class)! She's tough, but she does care.
One of the best professors I have had at the University of Rochester. Easy to follow in class and is always willing to help her students.
Great professor! Very knowledgable.
She's really not as bad as a lot of people make her out to be. She's approachable, funny, and really helpful. I enjoyed class with her.

Not nearly as engaging as her husband(I LOVE HIM). She's a nice woman, kind and helpful if you come to her, but DRY DRY DRY and intimidating in class. Hard as hell grader, too. But, she knows her Russian. If you're there to learn grammar and not be entertained, she's good, but I don't think I'd take a class with her again unless I audited.

This professor does not smile, does not make you feel welcome, and keeps the class in constant fear. There is no way to improve if you have fallen behind. Class doesn't effectively help with Russian communication.
Not as good as her husband, she seems to not have as structured classes and is definitely not a warm person, i wish i had a professor who truly cared about her students.
Lots of reading, but super fun and caring guy. Took his Robin Hood seminar last year and came out of it feeling like I really learned a lot. Hope I get to take another class with him again :)

Absolutely amazing. Professor Hahn leads discussions really well, is always accessible and ready to help with anything. He does assign many papers, and there is substantial reading, but he is incredibly understanding and will basically always give extensions. The paper topics were interesting and definitely improved my writing and analytical skills

Great Professor! Drives along discussion well and gives each student the opportunity to participate in class discussions in their own way.  Gives excellent feedback on assignments and is very helpful when asked for clarification on anything.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: I love Professor Hahn, enough that I took two classes with him (Chaucer and Brit Lit 1) despite not needing any English classes for my major, minor, or cluster.  He has a fantastic mind, and peppers his lectures with useful terms allusions to literary theory.  He's funny and very kind, and writes one heck of a recommendation.  Great mustache, too.
although it was a survey course of Medieval Literature, we plunged right into texts and I had no idea what was going on at some points. Keep up with the reading.
This guy is great! I am about to start my third class with him. There is a ton of reading, so it isn't easy, but he is interesting and helpful.
good professor, very nice man and enthusiastic about his subject. the reading load is HEAVY, so make sure to stay on top of it

The level of material expected to be mastered was absurd.  Most English courses at the 200/300 level I've taken had a far lighter work load than this.  The required time for the assignments as well as the library of readings was inappropriate for a 100 level class.  I don't understand - was this an English "weed-out" course?  Don't take 112 w/ him.
No Comments
very knowledgable
go for it
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
he is HOT
No Comments

He is very knowledgeable and passionate about the subject, but he seems disconnected from students. His lectures were filled with demos to help demonstrate concepts, but you have to read the textbook.

Won't curve the grades when the average is above 60, but the average is around 64 which isn't that different at all, but you still need above 90 to get an A. Classes are boring, lots of labs and homework.

As other reviews say, he doesn't teach, he just reads slides and notes like a script. Very little elaboration about how concepts work and rushed through content. The only time I learned something meaningful from lectures was when a student interrupted him and made him walk through the examples. Better off taking the self-paced course instead.
okay? alright? he seems so lost and reads off his slides.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: The rudest professor I have ever met. He will ignore a line of students at the end of lecture even though more than 90% of the time, it's because he made a mistake with grading. He gives extreme attitude as well  and his accent certainly does not help in lecture. No one even understands what is happening in lecture.

Probably one of the worst public speakers I've ever seen. I remember lectures where he ONLY read the slides, including the long math equations. I don't think his accent gets in the way, but he definitely loses the attention of the class 5 minutes into the lecture due to his inability to speak without reading.
I would highly recommend avoiding to take any classes with this professor as he is the lowest rating physics department teacher for obvious reasons.
Very difficult to understand.

Very confusing, both in organization and accent. No one in my class got anything in out of lecture, and the 20% of people that DID show up, just did it out of principle. Tests were hard, and he provided little/no material to help you study. I resorted to reading the whole textbook front to back to learn the material before the final. Avoid.

Gao definitely means well, but he is impossible to understand.  His voice is almost a caricature of a chinese accent.  Nearly the whole class would either fall asleep during lecture or leave after the PRS questions, which he used to take attendance.  His final was unlike anything we had seen before.  avoid if possible
Very difficult to understand. Avoid if possible!

unclear. His accent was very thick and he couldn't address students questions clearly. I fell asleep in every class save 2. He did have some cool demonstrations at the end of class but as far as learning material, you might as well not go to class.
Very excited about the material, but *very* difficult to follow -- disorganized and distractible.  Didn't always understand questions to be able to answer them...  And a terrible textbook to match.

Not the best prof I ever had but he structures the class in such a way that if you do the work and put in the man hours, you will learn something.  He is not a good lecturer and the textbook is horrific so expect to work and work hard.

A simply ridiculous teacher.  I'm sure he meant well but he needs to lift his eyes from the power point once in a while.  More than half the class fell asleep every single day. Accent was often very difficult to understand.

Good demonstrations, but the class was hard. I think mechanics was designed to turn students off to physics... And Professor Gao? He's smiley and logical and has a great accent, but a little unclear sometimes. He did electronic polling (with PRS devices) of the class to keep us on our toes.
Professor Tresan is always willing to help during office hours and after lectures. The lectures were a bit boring but he explained materials thoroughly.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: There are 22+6+331 journal entries for three assigned books in this course, but you seem to receive full credits easily as long as you read and write carefully, and only materials in the first book (with 22 journal entries) are discussed in class and tested on exams (there are study guides and online revision sessions helping you to review).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: This is the worst organized college class I've ever taken. Unclear lectures and expectations, there are journal entries from different books that are due in class but other entries from other books due by email with no due dates just all due by a certain date and you can't submit more than one every 48 hours-yes it's as confusing as it sounds.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Terrible, boring lectures. The class is way too hard for what the class should be.
Hilarious is the descriptor that would best work for describing the man's talent at interrupting himself and other students from talking. He repeats and drones on with filler words "um" and "like".

He assigns a lot of reading, yet he never goes over the material in class. He would much rather discuss topics that aren't in the reading. Jon doesn't make himself available and left Rochester before he assigned an exam. This class has so much potential to be better than it presently is and the University should revisit the topic of keeping him.

Jon generally doesn't understand how to teach. He seems like a nice enough professor, however, he goes off on unwanted tangents and never explicitly addresses what he expects from you. It seem as though he doesn't even value his own thoughts on subjects, as his tests are open note and will mark your answers wrong for repeating concepts he taught.

He gives notes for almost every class and specific study guides before every exam. He always makes himself available after classes. Even if you are not in this class, he is happy to talk to you about some topics interesting. His feedback is clear and useful. And the grade is fair.

"Umm uhhh." -  Professor Tresan. He's a great guy and cares deeply for philosophy but his class is extremely unorganized. I really appreciate him as a professor and you can tell he's very good at viewing things from a different view. The tests are difficult but its possible to earn an A if you work for it. I'd take him once if you have the chance.
I wouldn't take a class with him again. Likes to hear himself talk, his study guides and reviews are just endless thoughts he writes down but never gets to the point.
Great guy- very helpful outside of class but lectures are extremely unorganized and hard to follow. Hard to keep up with the material if you do not attend class regularly.

He's undeniably a little eccentric (as many philosophy professors are) but he definitely grows on you when you get to know him better - I particularly recommend meeting with him one-on-one - he has a lot if interesting perspectives and insights.

He may not deliver his thoughts clear to every student and he could be hard to follow some times, but the lecture material he put in the study guide is logical, clear, and easy to understand. He is super helpful. Definitely talk to him about your thoughts or ideas. He will provide you a lot of related materials to enrich your view.
Do NOT do this to yourself. "Right, um, okay, yeah" and study guides the night before that are as unclear as he is. Terrible experience. Just. No.

Loves to hear himself talk - half of every lecture is nothing more than him walking back and forth, muttering "Right, hmmmmm..." over and over again. Makes you take a midterm the day after spring break ends and often times fails to reason properly. Pretentious, and obviously thinks he's brilliant, even though his doctorate is in a humanities.

He is all over the place, super unorganized, really laid back, is interesting though, kinda makes we want to keep attending just to see what he will do. I kinda like him, as a person but not so much as a professor.  Seems really smart though and is super nice.

Course was Post-Industrial America. Professor Westbrook is brilliant and clearly enjoys and cares about his students. I gained a ton of useful knowledge. Most of the reading was from two books. One was great, the other difficult to follow. We were always 1 or 2 lectures behind the reading. Discussions lasted too long, I learned more with lectures.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Have him for Golden Age Movies. He should stick to history. Takes points off papers for not liking a choice of words - btw there are only 3 short papers (6-8 pages) and one long final paper (8-10). Speaks SO slow to the point of wanting to sleep/mind wanders. Adequate film history course, I guess. Liked the movies well enough. He's not engaging tho

He's really passionate about what he teaches, and if your looking to take a hard history class and are really interested in it, then go ahead and take it. If your not a history minor and also not looking to take a moderately hard elective, this class is not for you. Its hard even when you try hard. He takes off points for not agreeing with you.

Nice guy, very smart. Very to his own idea. If you disagree with them or write about something that he disagrees with you get penalized for it. Also, very tough grader. Always come prepared to class because he does randomly call on people. Makes the situation extremely awkward if you aren't prepared. was not one of my favorite professors.
Westbrook is as friendly and helpful as he is brilliant. One of the best professors I've taken a class with.

Westbrook is an amazing professor. He really respects his students and challenges them to think about what they are reading. He is a hard grader, but definitely fair. The course consisted of a lot of discussion- not too much lecture. When he did lecture, he was generally pretty interesting.

The reading work (all primary sources) necessary for class discussion is extensive; be prepared. But the actual number of graded assignments is few (4?). However, his grading is difficult and adequate knowledge on the subject is required for a good grade.
Very good prof, clear lecturer, nice guy, fair work load/grading. Interesting class that I enjoyed very much, would definitely recommend any class with Westbrook.

he is absolutely brilliant. really nice guy, very likeable. classi s interesting if you have an interest in history. he assigns a lot of reading but you can get buy with just skimming the stuff. be prepared for class though, he randomly calls on people all the time. don't bother to go if you haven't prepared-- you will sit there dodging bullets.
Professor Westbrook is marginal.  I credit him with demonstrating the irremediable shortcomings of historical analysis, effectively truncating my interest in the profession.
Nicest guy ever, also brilliant.  my problem was that this should have been a philosophy class, not a history one.  and i hate philosophy.  so willing to help though and always in a great mood.
Great Prof. Brilliant man. Difficult grader, lots of reading. worth taking his class recent american thought

I loved this class.  The material was interesting in itself, but Dr. Westbrook helped bring it all together in a very organized and enlightening way.  His lectures were very informative and interesting, and he ran the class discussions very well.  He is one of the best history profs I've had.

He is a great teacher who really cares about his students.  I was in a huge lecture and he still knew who I was 3 years later.  He uses a lot of electronic reserves which hurt my eyes and/or my flex account.  He loves Bruce Springsteen and will find some way to incorporate his music into every class he teaches.

the worst professor/lecturer ive had at rochester in 3 years.  Reads straight from a piece of paper and does not engage the class at all.  Hard grader too, ive taken 300 level classes and gotten much better grades than i did in this piece of crap class.
Good professor.  Direct teaching style, very helpful and open to questions.  Impressive, nuanced knowledge of the material.

Reading isn't always mandatory and most of the things you need to know for the exams are covered in the lectures. He's a really funny guy and pretty easy to talk to. Definitely tries to make things interesting by adding interesting stories to his lectures. Would definitely take another one of his classes.

The easiest class in political science by far. Everything is directly from his notes that he posts so as long as you can memorize things, you'll be fine. There's two tests and a paper, and the paper is graded pretty leniently and it's short for the standards of the poli sci department. Fun content if you like law, otherwise just an easy class
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Fiandach always comes to class with an enthusiastic vibe. His expertise in the field makes him a good professor and the stories he tells are often exciting and funny. The downside to the class is that your grade is based only off of the midterm, paper, and final, so you have to do well on those to get a good grade.
Good teacher.  Sometimes says things that just aren't very smart though.
This is the best class I took at the University of Rochester. I absolutely loved this class and I will miss it a bunch
Amazing and I love his class! He uses great analogies to explain things and I learn a lot from him.
Funny. Class is very entertaining, and he is hot.
He is awesome! Likes to talk about his "stash of cocaine" to clarify concepts, but they actually help a lot, and give us a giggle or two. Definitely a fun class to take, and I learned a LOT.
Amazing!
No Comments
FANTASTIC.
No Comments
No Comments
Very fun professor, likes to tell stories about cases he's handled.

Awesome Class...Awesome Prof...hes an adjuct lawyer who teaches only in the spring, but his class is hands down one of the best here at the university...even if your not into poli sci/law, take it to learn your rights...he loves to talk about crack dealer

Fiandach is funny, sweet, and entertaining.  His charm and charisma keeps every class really interesting.  Taking his class will teach you a lot about being a lawyer, especially how to think as a lawyer.
She is an awesome professor!

I had Professor Li for Contemporary American Memoir.  She is a phenomenal teacher.  She lets the class take the lead discussion-wise.  She is tough but fair and very smart as well as passionate.  I highly recommend her.

by far the best professor I've ever had, and she is just a wonderful person on top of that. She is a tough grader but is entirely reasonable and acommodating. Talking about rewrites is great, because she is really supportive of growth; but do it in a timely fashion. Do the readings, even though there is a lot....it's very worth it.

Her lectures are great. For someone that didn't know a lot about American Authors, she opened my eyes up to a lot of good literature. The discussions are thought engaging. However, her grading needs work. She gives little positive feedback and interjects her opinions into her grading which often leads to low grades if she disagrees (happens often).

One of the University's best Professors yet! She actually cares about you learning as opposed to being obsessed with tests like some teachers are. The concepts you discuss make you rethink your own values and really allow you to get to know the literature and yourself more. It can be a tough class, but she's more than willing to help!

I had Professor Li for both American Lit and Toni Morrison. In the A.Lit class, she had a good selection of books and ran class similar to many other intro courses. My class with her on Toni Morrison was more group discussions than her lecturing. Overall, I think she is a wonderful teacher that is both knowledgeable and approachable.

She's really awesome... I wish she was ACTUALLY more of my teacher.  The class was split up into 2 sections and I got stuck with the lousy TA every Friday plus he grades all my assignments and papers.  That doesn't seem very fair at all.  Hes not that awful but I feel a little ripped off, know what I mean?  I want a good freaking teacher, not a TA

If attendance wasn't mandatory I wouldn't have gone too often--but I'm glad I did because she actually tests you on her lecture notes. Weekly quizzes made it feel like high school. Outside of class, however, she is extremely nice and accommodating. I thought the book selection was decent, too, but very lengthy.

She's a fairly tough grader but the challenge is worth it. Definitely go visit at office hours, she is very friendly one-on-one. Her lectures on Hemingway were super interesting. And she digs on Lauren like woah.
intelligent, pretty interesting, not my fav prof, but definitely a worthwhile and enjoyable class

Li definitely is knowledgeable in English, but has no clue how to handle a big class (aka 35 students). Assigned seating, power point presentations that go over just the surface of every book, reading quizzes almost daily? I was not personally a fan of her style of teaching, but she always was willing to talk about a book and hear your ideas.

She seems a little cold and subdued at first, but go and talk to her during office hours.  she warms up a lot and will like you after that.  also, she's really helpful one on one.  I thought the class was great.  Shes very knowledgable and really wants you to succeed.  She helped me learn how to write good research papers.
Really good teacher but lots of reading

She was really was not a good professor.  Her midterm was atrocious (one word questions to be answered? C'mon) and she was so strict on papers that she required a Works Cited for a 4 page paper on one book that everyone is reading in class.  She bumped you down a grade if you didn't have it!  Also, the discussions were not great, mostly opinions
A wonderful teacher, very knowledgable and inspiring. take this class if you're at all interested in american lit.
I had her for Am Lit and I really liked the class, good material, Prof Li is enthusistic and open to discussion - not an amazing teacher, but definately very good

Kose communicates the material well, mostly because he's following the textbook exactly, with lectures based on presentations of textbook screenshots, as such the lectures are a bit uninspired. The homework isn't bad if you don't do 3 weeks in one day, and is very useful. The final is hard and weird in the material covered but TAs grade it nicely.

He is a good guy. I love his accent. He is well prepared and always offer help to explain again if anyone raises any questions. Stops regularly to ask everyone if there are any questions. Overall, one of the best professors in Rochester. In addition to being a good teacher, he seems to be a great researcher. often gives examples from his research.

Kose is a good professor, better than any other ECE professor. He understands how difficult this class can be and makes sure each student learns during the lecture. He is very patient with some not-so-smart questions during his lecture. Highly recommend!!

Every ECE student needs to take his course. Luckily, he is a great guy and very approachable. While the content of the lectures are difficult, the homeworks are long, and exams, especially the final is quite long and difficult, Dr. Kose really makes sure each student has a good grasp of the material. Highly recommend!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Kose is a good professor. Highly recommend skimming the textbook chapter before each lecture, otherwise lectures might be a bit confusing. But he always answers questions, and tries to make sure most students understand before moving on. Recitations are optional but really really helpful. Don't procrastinate the homework!
Great instructor. He really cares!
No one understand what this guy is talking about

The class was difficult on its own but if he explained things by writing on the board instead of giving lecture from slides, it would have been more useful. If you try listening to his lectures carefully, I think it's possible to understand the material and succeed in this class. For my year, he gave extra credit to student who took the pop quizzes
rating_tags: Tough grader--EXTRA CREDIT--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: He's terrible at lecturing. Also he makes the final super hard. Average was a 50% on the final and no curve.
Dude is terrible at teaching
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Does not explain well. If you ask him questions he will clarify, however, his lectures are a drag. The best way to learn is by doing homework problems and asking TAs for help.

He teaches based on the textbook slides, and he isn't good at explaining concepts. The midterm is very easy but the final is very hard. Learn by doing homework. He said he will give extra credit if you attend every class, but I didn't know how he could memorize all the people since we never sign up.
Teaches through pictures of the textbook, moves fast, and isn't interesting. The topic itself is unintuitive but his uninspiring lectures and bad English make it difficult. Learn by doing homework.
Selcuk Kose is a brilliant professor that cares about his students success. He is always there to help. I found his office hours useful. If you want to get an A, don't miss the lectures.

Prof. Kose is one of my favorite professors. He is very helpful both in and out of the classroom. The course was challenging, however, Prof. Kose was always there to help. I would definitely recommend taking his course(s).

The professor himself is a great guy but he needs to redesign the course a little bit. He teaches off of a boring Powerpoint slide and in his lectures, it is very hard to stay awake. The first half of the course is do-able but the second half is where stuff gets crazy.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Dr. Kose's taught well but he was sometimes a bit rough around the edges. He really only cares that you get near the right answer, not how much work you put in. He's super willing to meet outside of class and really wants his students to attend every lecture. For my class at least, he gave extra points to people who came every lecture.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Amazing professor. Have heard many good things about him from others. Shame that most students wouldn't be able to fully appreciate his style of teaching. Makes you think and opens your eyes to not only classics, but the whole world and what it is made of.
This man was instrumental in my departure from the cave.
Simply amazing. I have learned more from discussing translations than all my other classes combined.
took 202 & 142. BEST TEACHER EVER. adorable...Zeus in human form.  he really just wants you to try to understand. discussion class. not much work.

Geier Is AWESOME! Really nice guy. I took his intro greek class as a potential for my cluster and his classes has definitely been some of my favorites. His classes are what you think college classes should be like...before you actually start college

The living reincarnation of Socrates minus the annoying factor. If you really want to learn the philosophy of the Ancients, you go to this man and avoid the philosophy dept. He might seem unclear, but the more you read Plato, the more you see Geier's quality in teaching. He is a living treasure and a fortune to those who connect with the readings.
The man is none other than Zeus himself

Very interesting professor- loves the material and makes you appreciate it because of that. He isn't your conventional teacher when it comes to grading- he wants you to learn. He also wants you to succeed, so he grades in your favor. Discussion based- speak up in class.
He seems like a space cadet, but he's a good thinker.  Do your homeworks during class.  You don't need to take notes to do well.  His grading is sketch, but there are no complaints about it from me.

Oh man, such a beautiful human being. If you're at all a student (in the ideal sense) and you're interested in the material, you should have no trouble at all. He's very discussion oritented, very intelligent, and occaisionally it goes above you, but if you act at all interested he will help you as much as he can.

He's all about class participation; his grading policy is one huge gray area, but in your favor.  He loves nothing more than when you show interest by asking to meet with him right before essays are due.  He's a very optimistic grader, looking for all your good points, more than criticizing the bad parts of your essays.  He's awesome.
greatest prof ever.
really interesting, just take notes and write your essays from them for ideas of the greeks, i really liked him
No Comments
Very nice guy. Great thinker. Interesting course for those that like philosophy or Greek Ideas.
Great philosphy/religion professor
Our first midterm was disastrous and little review was done. Average grade 48 and he said we should work harder...
He was a horrible teacher and had impossible exams and projects

I really enjoyed the material in this course but Koomen is a terrible teacher. The class was not well organized, we were given assignments on things to be lectured on the following week, and quizzes on things not covered in the course. Not too difficult (got an A-), but all in all the class was low quality. Would avoid if possible.

He enjoyed teaching the class but through not fault of his own the class was very disorganized. The robots themselves were complete messes but he tried hard to fix that. Wanted us to learn but tests were completely random with no structured review
You know you suck when 1/2 the class withdraws after the first project because they got under a 50 on it. LEARN HOW TO TEACH

This guy is more serious than Pawlicki, which can be good or can be bad.  He's an adjunct so he is not very "connected" to the campus, and doesn't really know how things work around here.  So he's a bit aloof.
Nice guy but puts trivial multiple choice questions on his exams. Teaches almost completely out of the textbook, including labs.
I liked him a lot.  He's an adjunct professor, so it can sometimes be difficult to contant him, but he's very clear. Many CS kids dislike him, but I'm a fan.

I don't know what the other people were complaining about... Professor Koomen is a _great_ professor.  He is demanding, but is willing to help you grasp the topics in any way possible.  If you aren't willing to work, possessed of any aptitude for CS or interested in learning, he's not the prof. for you.

His method of testing is God-awful.  He's very uninspired when it comes to helping with tests.  He doesn't provide practice tests, doesn't tell you what format it's in, and likes to surprise you with ridiculously specific questions.  When we asked him what to study for the test, he said "pages 1-400."  No topic overview, nothing.

Loooove his crazy voice.  Class is a cake walk for 7 weeks, then BOOM and Javascript tabling takes over your life.  I attended 4 classes.  What a strange guy, well organized, very specific.  Awkward most of the time

Koomen is a funny German dude.  The class is not that bad if you do all the work and study some.  If you fall behind or are a lazy you're f---.   It was funny watching him try to hit on the hot female Psychology teacher that taught the class before us.
Death on earth. If you don't already know java, do not plan to do well. If you know java, still don't plan to well. Its a split between easiness and reaaallly hardness.
No Comments
Class was fine.  His teaching inspired me to attend <1 time per month.
this class should be taken only by computers or nerds. the teacher is the devil, with his only saving grace being his entertaining voice cracks like a 13 year old boy.

Doesn't take class seriously and sometimes in lecture she brings new concepts as if we already know them. I needed to do a lot of studying outside of class just because her lectures were a waste of time
I think Knowles' lectures are a bit more helpful than Matson's. Both professors are very accessible outside of class. There are a bunch of opportunities for extra credit.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Everyone says her lectures are bad but they're fine. She's really nice if you talk to her. Class is on points system + has lots of extra credit even if you don't do super well on exams, but EC is graded super harshly. Get points for going to class but lectures are recorded. Only took 2/3 exams and still didn't need to take the final to get an A.

Lots of the reviews are a bit harsh. I'll give a real review. Knowles is an okay professor. Not the best, but not as and as some of the other reviews. Knowles is probably at her best at thermo and worst at quantum mechanics. Other than teaching, Knowles is very nice and is patient with teaching (since Knowles teaches the harder concepts).

Dr. Knowles was at least a bit more consistent than Dr. Matson. Her lectures however were boring and super dense, and often it seemed like she was skipping over or assuming students understand the material. I appreciated that she didn't talk down to students like Dr. Matson did, but I feel like the quality of teaching was no better.

Honestly, not the best professor I have had. Her lectures are confusing and exam grades are really low. Her and matson teaching does not work at all. It feels like they are on two different planets. The topics are hard and go to class. Recitations will help you so much so GO TO THEM.

Knowles is the second chemistry professor that made me appreciate Dr. H more. She is not the most accommodating person and tends to speedrun her lectures. Exam grades were low because she and Matson cannot teach well and fails to give out sufficient exam practice exams to her students.

Knowles is very caring of her students. She sometimes included problems students had trouble doing. She is not very good at teaching though. Her lectures are fast paced and some of her test questions felt like they weren't representative of the content learned. Overall, I think she needs time to become a better professor.

This professor looks like she tries, but simply can not teach. You can definitely tell she has very little experience teaching the course. Lectures feel like eternity and the slides are not fun to look at.

i think she genuinely does care about her students, but she just is not good at teaching. i do get that this was her first year teaching. she kept assuming we knew foundational information to understanding concepts when we didn't. whenever someone would ask where she got this information from, she would say that we should just know how to do it.

Unlike the other 132 prof, she's actually a nice person and cares about you. However, this doesn't erase the fact that she is a terrible teacher. She speeds through slides, makes test questions so hard and long that no one finishes the exam, and doesn't know how to use a mic. She doesn't know how to do her own problems, but expects us to. Pray.

Super sweet and accommodating professor. I understand it was her first year teaching, which shows. She goes through complex lectures quickly and really likes calculus for some reason. I believe she could be a great teacher once she gets more familiarity to students. Tests were tough, but with the amount of extra credit, 132 should be an easy A.

Personally, I think Professor Knowles was the better of the two professors. She paces her lectures much better and spends a lot of time on practice problems. She was kind and accommodating. My only issues with her are the cluttered slides and lack of energy. It's clear she is not used to lecturing to such a large class. Overall, she's decent.

This year was her first year to teach, and it could be seen. She was very nervous and unconfident. She essentially just read off of her slides, which she posted on blackboard. I liked her a lot better than the other professor, because she was nice and very approachable. I loved her modules as they were more interesting to me. She talks very fast.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: I left Dr. H's class thinking I'd have a better experience in CHEM 132. Let me tell you, that was a funny assumption... I was so wrong. The average for every exam was consistently below 50%, and that really shows how horrendous the class was. The only reason I survived this class was because of the extra credit. I don't recommend this class at all.

Someone needs to tell miss girl that flying through slideshows at 4523648768mph and assuming that your students just automatically understand everything isn't teaching. Though considering the overall poor quality of U of R's chem department, I guess the bar is pretty low.

If you are searching for this professor, I'm sure you came across Professor Robert Minckley before. One of his ratings was "I drove without a seatbelt and hoped I got into a crash on the way to campus." 
Compared to Professor Knowles, I Love professor Minckley. Knowles' lectures are so fast, It's almost like she assumes us to understand immediately

Take self paced if you care about your grade, class is hard. Howell does really want students to succeed but he is very busy outside of this class. Thinking about retaking physics in self paced. Tests for this class were the hardest I've ever experienced.

Not enough emphasis on examples, too many derivations. That's just not my learning style, I struggled with the class. Others talk about how workshops were so helpful, my TA didn't really facilitate a learning environment-everyone just sits there and does HW.  I'm not just bitter I didn't do well, I really actually did not learn well w his style.

Professor Howell really wants to help. He's well-prepared for the lecture and he tries his best to help students stay interested. Physics is not easy for most of people, but if you really study for it, go to his office hour as many as possible , you'll eventually ace it. I like pro. Howell and would like to take future classes with him if possible.

I love Prof. Howell! Teaching PHY 121 can be tricky, but Prof. Howell did a good job! He is hilarious and uses real-life examples to make bland subjects interesting. Grading and extra credit are very fair. I only wish that we can have more time in class for the clicker quizzes - I often don't have enough time to react before I answer. Good job!
Horrible teacher. You could tell he is a smart physicist but he just can NOT teach whatsoever. He also fails at putting together tests. I would avoid taking a class with him if I could.

Teaches the concepts quite well, especially entanglement which he knows a lot about.  Tests aren't too bad if you make sure you know the homeworks.  Extremely nice and positive guy too.  Overall a good course; I learned a lot.

I was very lucky to have him teaching PHY407 for the first semester of my PhD. He is a very nice and helpful guy. He is in general very considerate. And he would like to explain again and again if you have difficulty understanding the concept. His tests are the hardest thing in the universe. But he graded them nicely and he has a nice curve as well

My favourite subject so far. Very very good lecturer with very good presentation skills. Lectures well-paced. Used lots of examples from recent research to motivate ideas. Homework questions are hard and long but he is always willing to offer help although he appears to be busy(due to meetings/conferences). Highly recommended!

Howell, an experimentalist, presented a rigorous treatment of fundamental principles while pausing often to develop advanced topics such as coherent states, Peres separability criteria and continuously entangled states.  Additionally, he related many topics to experiments mostly done in his own lab to motivate ideas.  A first rate treatment!

Could tell he didn''t want to teach the class.  Once he changed his teaching style he taught a little better but midterms were unfair.  However he had a huge scale making it difficult not to get a B or higher.

Howell changed the way he ran the class in the middle of the semester, only adding to the confusion he created during lectures.  Take this class if you can study/learn  math/science concepts on your own.  Also, go to workshops, just make sure your TA is helpful (some are self-centered meanies!!!)
He is absolutely HORRIBLE! I wish I didn't take his class.  It was a waste of time and the unfair grading will hurt my GPA.  I learned nothing.  People who didn't go to class were better off.

Prof. Howell, for one reason or another (*cough*doesn't want to teach*cough*) believes that the textbook should teach you and that he should supplement it, not the other way around.  As a result, he lectures on things nobody has heard of, and this leads to mass confusion.  Overall, he's so terrible.
he doesnt like teaching and it reflects in the class...
Doesn't know the material, doesn't know how to teach, go back to grad school (newbie)!!
Worst Professor
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: THIS GUY IS NOT A PROFESSOR. HE IS AN ACTOR, will constantly talk about his time at MIT, and his friends at Berkley and IBM instead of teaching the course. Will fail the entire semester to remember your name. Pulls the race card every now and then. His mini exams are terrible and pointless. Just give me a real exam instead of these small ones.
classes went overtime, prof talked to long, work was hard, and tests were difficult
tough class
tough prof. i preferred the way he taught from examples rather than off a slide. hw, quizes and tests are though but they test everything you know, was pretty good overall definitely not easy
His class was difficult but fair. Do not expect an easy A and be prepared to work hard. He doesn't teach of the slides so you have to pay attention and  going to class really matters.
Very stressful classes since he lashes out at students so often, ridiculing them for asking questions or performing poorly. Almost every dropout in the department happened because of this guy.
Easily one of the worst and most unfair professors at this university. Someone needs to take his job away.
He explain example very vaguely and never really taught anything.
He rambles a lot in class when trying to explain something.  DO NOT CONTRADICT HIM.  He gets very hostile when this happens.
More of an actor than a teacher.  Tries to get you interested by being overly animated, which is annoying because as a result the material is never taught.

Spent too much time trying to learn our names and was overly verbose in describing concepts. Would habitually run over the alloted time by 10 min (which would not have been necessary if he didn't dance around the topics). The good thing is that he will call you out if you aren't paying attention and does seem to actually care about the students.
not good at all

He focus on showing off his knowledge, experiences and abilities on class through the stupid questions, but actually isn't a good researcher or teacher. You can totally understand the class via reading textbook. If you have to select this class, look out, keep being careful of your words and actions, he is splenetic, narrow-minded and humorsome.

Ridiculous class. Complete waste of time. this guys spends most of his time trying to appear calm and cool and easy going, but is totally opposite.Wont benefit much from this course. He ends up promising too much and delivering too little.

Dr. Nyibule was amazing. He was very understanding and if you have issues with ANYTHING he helps you out. I struggled in Physics but he was also very understanding with grading and lays it out very clearly what will be on each exam. Amazing curve and is always available to help

Good lectures, great guy. Has office hours every day - helps you with understanding material / do hw. Exams are not hard at all if you do the hw and weekly quizzes. Lectures are recorded. Clearly cares about his students doing well. Highly recommend taking classes with him - he is the nicest science professor here genuinely.
Good, can speak kind of quietly though
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Nyibule was one of the best professors I ever had. He is so incredibly caring for his students, having office hours every day of the week. He made a class I was scared of into a rewarding experience. His lectures are extremely clear because he posts lecture notes. He gives ample study material. He is such a caring person through and through.
Sheth is awesome! Super understanding. He assigns a lot of work but it helps with repetition. Material is hard but he is very approachable.

Def one of the best at UR! Sheth's truly a kind-hearted individual who wants you to succeed. He gives tons of extra credit, makes content understandable for those with no physics experience, and gives the fairest exams ever. He's very available for office hrs and actively encourages students who are struggling to talk to him. Highly recommend!

SHETH IS THE GOAT. As someone who almost bombed physics in high school, I think Sheth elegantly explains physics concepts well to the point where anyone can understand what he is teaching without needing extra help. He gives out a lot of extra credit opportunities too! As for the structure of the course, workshops are useless. Overall, a good prof!

PHYS 121 is not a well designed class, but Prof Nyibule makes it enjoyable and gives good lectures. The homework grading made no sense sometimes (the TAs grade homework) which is annoying. The test averages were not high, but he is willing to curve them if necessary. The class average was a B.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: A very good professor, who truly seems to care about his students. Office hours are a massive help and he explains everything very well. Lectures can get a bit monotonous at times, but in-class notes, slides, and homeworks are super helpful for test prep. Although the course was quite exam and assignment-heavy, they're pretty manageable!

I would 100 percent take this class again. I took this class in HS so I knew all the material, so class was not really mandatory for me. He is a good professor and explains everything in super detail. I would sit close to the front because he has a thick accent. He is very understanding as well.

He's pretty clear with explaining the topics and lectures are easy to follow. It's obvious that he cares about his students and enjoys teaching, but sometimes it can feel a bit fast and the test questions can be pretty different from lecture ones. Also, homeworks and workshops are so insanely hard that there's almost no point in doing them.
Very unpleasant class. Very difficult to understand concepts.

I had Professor Nyibule for PHYS 121. Lectures covered all the main points comprehensively in a manner easy to understand. The Professor is kind and accessible during office hours. Tests for the class were easy if you do the practice problems in lecture and the homework problems.
I took his class for a requirement even though it is not my strongest subject. He was very kind and helpful outside of class. The class was organized.

I am not good at physics but Dr. Nyibule was able to help me after class to pull off that A-. There are plenty of resources available to do well, but I will admit it is a pretty time intensive course, at least for me. Gives iClicker quizzes during class which count for your grade so make sure to show up.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: I took PHY 113 over the summer with Dr. Nyibule and had a great experience! He cares about students and wants to help them succeed. Very kind and a good lecturer.

I did not like the fact that he made us pay for a subscription for iClicker quizzes, but besides that I have no complaints. Definitely talk to hm after class about questions you have, it will be helpful. Go through all the textbook problems and do the previous exams and you should do ok. I had to work hard for my grade, but it's doable.

One of the worst professors at the UR. Very unprofessional and does not care for his students at all. Lectures are very monotone and boring. Does not reply to emails and is not accessible at all. Exams are doable only if you had exposure to physics. Lots of homework every week and workshops are very long. Avoid this professor and take self-paced.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Professor Nyibule is one of the nicest people ever, has clear lectures, and does a good job engaging the class with clicker quizzes to ensure understanding. Exams follow the notes but the homework strays off just a little (probably because it is just out of the textbook). Overall such a great guy and a super doable course.
The professor is personable and kind. While his course can be challenging to grasp, the exams are less difficult.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Most difficult class in undergrad by far. Sharma is great and knows the stuff, but the class is test heavy and he uses heavy math approaches in most of the lectures. This class is only worth taking if you want to sit down and get comfortable with critical fundamentals of signals processing, otherwise it will be miserable and you should not take it.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He gets a bad rap. Yes his course is very time consuming and difficult. This is not his fault, it is simply the nature of the material. A lot of homework because he chooses each problem methodically to illustrate a point. His grading scheme is also in favor of the student. He offers plenty of extra credit. He wants students to succeed.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: I think he is a very smart guy. However, the class is very intensive and to keep up with him is probably very difficult for most students. The homework is way too long for it to be a effective review of the materials.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: too much homework, and the review session does not help with the exam
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Too theoretical for an engineering class

He is a "math" professor, and therefore approaches the topic from a proof based course, which is a shame because you would be hard pressed to find a more useful and practical topic in math. hopefully in the future he will motivate it more from real world problems (he tests on them at least)

Prof. Sharma is tasked with teaching a great deal of material in a short time, and to his credit, he accomplishes that. While he assigns large amounts of homework (6-10 problems, with many parts, with subparts, which ask for multiple things), he shows an interest in students understanding the material, and runs the class recitation himself.

Very smart person, but not good professor. Course is very math-heavy and lectures focus on derivationsproofs of equations. Not always clear with what he is trying to provederive. Assigns huge amounts of homework, but reasonable with deadlines. Need to read textbook + other sources to fully understand course material. Also gives pop quizzes.

Prof. Sharma is an excellent professor tasked with teaching one of the harder ECE undergrad classes. He holds himself to high standards, & he holds his students to the same. He provides tons of extra help (in the form of TA office hours, recitations w himself, & special help sessions). He also puts a ton of effort into posting detailed solutions.
Probably the worst professor you can ever have.
He is a terrible professor.

Terrible professor. The material in class isn't helpful for completing the homework. The homework is unfair, unnessarily long, and I question how much of it he'd be able to do without the answer key. The tests focus on things never convered in class. When asked to do a test problem he spent 40 minutes and never came up with an answer.

Oh my god! This is the worst professor I have ever encountered. He is poor at getting the point across. He has no motivating force to make the material seem interesting. Plus he is a hard as hell grader. I wish I had followed suggested advice to avoid his classes. THIS IS HELL TIMES TWO!!!!!!!!!
Do not take any of his courses until he changes his teaching methods. Hard to understand, not just his accent.

Great person, mediocre professor. She covers a LOT of material per class so get ready to write until your hand falls off. Super personable and gives a ton of extra credit. Definitely one of the best professors at school.

I had Professor Cottrell for EESC 201 and 205, and for both she gave informative and engaging lectures. The Professor is upbeat and humorous, and is always willing to help students whenever they may be struggling. If you're considering going into geology, I highly recommend taking one of her classes. It will provide a good entry to the field.

Professor Cottrell is very informative and her lecture is a lot of fun. You can touch real fossils in her lab. Her assignment may not be that easy but they are definitely fun. Very patient and accessible if you get any questions. Understanding her lecture material is sufficient for her exams.
She's marvelous. Most understanding professor. She treats you like you're human, not a machine.

I took EES 201 for a cluster. I'm terrible at natural sciences, and Professor Cottrell was very understanding of my situation and gave me a lot of opportunities to get my grade up. Lectures can be a little hard to follow and labs can be tedious, but as long as you show up to labs and do all of the smaller assignments, you'll be fine.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: While the class is a bit of work (long labs!) The course generally has very easy grading. In fact, it's easy to get good grades just by sticking to the work and listening to lectures - Rory offers ample extra credit opportunities for attendance, at the end of tests, and I(while the book's use is low) offers links to the book's website.
great teacher - one of the best I have had at this school

Very accessible, interesting lecturer. Tests are easy if you take good notes and browse through the assigned readings. If you're not sure if you're interested in Geology, this class is a perfect introduction.

One of my favorite professors. Funny and enthusiastic. Corny jokes but keeps the class engaged. Very accommodating in terms of conflicts with exams/paper due dates. Review sessions are super helpful. All in all a great professor!

She's nice, kinda corny but helpful. Labs are worthless and elementary; time consuming.  Exams were on the deceptively tough side but not too bad, definitely have to study well even though she seems laid back about exams.

I really liked Rory. She's easily approachable and very flexible with exam schedules and deadlines. She cares about her students and is always willing to help if you ask. Very clear on what she wants yet very open to student's ideas. Tests are lecture/textbook based. Go to her review sessions, it's in your favor!!
Smart teacher who cares about the material.  Labs are somewhat irrelevant and boring but its not a big problem.  Overall pretty good
I didn't really learn much from Rory.  She's a very nice person, but she always seemed a little scatterbrained and was the most inaccessible prof I've had at the U of R.
Very easy to understand, a good lecturer and is willing to help if you ask. Seems a little corny/annoying at first but you realize that's just her way of being funny.
GREAT PROFF!!

Prof. Covach was a true rock n roller. Very knowledgeable of rock music and its history. Classes are very interesting if you like the Beatles. The quizzes do get a bit annoying (about 1 quiz every 2 weeks) and are mostly trivial stuff like identifying songs and memorizing facts; writing section was graded very generously. Still worth taking, tho!

Professor Covach is a wonderful professor, and his lectures are very interesting. However, his tests are ALL memorization and you will be spending HOURS brute-force memorizing useless information that you won't remember a week after. His test questions are often worded very vaguely and looking for overly-specific answers. Great lecturer awful tests
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Taken 125/130/131, all fairly easy. Exams are fill in the blanks, a listening portion (name the song/release date/album/band depending on the class) that's around 5 songs (out of ~30 supposed to know but fine if you don't as long as rest of exam good), and short essay questions. Pay attention, focus on slide content, big ideas, and connections.

His exams are easy, yes he talks a lot in class but because he's passionate about what he teaches so he gives a lot of background and details that are unnecessary for tests. Interesting to hear/learn about but if you don't care you could honestly zone out, the key: pay attention when he talks about things directly on or related to the slides.

Lectures are usually interesting, with stories, anecdotes, etc. Sometimes they get a tad boring but usually not. The tests are almost entirely memorization based, but everything you need to know is in the lecture slides. Professor Covach is a cool guy, very responsive to email and student concerns, and offers extra credit opportunities that help.

Professor Covach is a very enthusiastic and engaging lecturer and I thoroughly enjoyed his Beatles class. The quizzes are definitely memorization heavy, but are definitely fair and not to difficult if you pay attention in class and study.

Super kind and genuinely cares about all of his students. Takes time to make sure each student understands and very accommodating for extra help. He teaches using interesting examples to make the theory more engaging. Homework is graded just on participation, and as long as you go to class and study for the midterms, you will do great.
dont take this class

Instead of focusing on the main points gone over by the lectures, the quizzes went over trivial facts that do not impact music or the class in general (Beatles year of birth, month an album was released). The lectures barely focus on these facts and consist of tangents about specific songs. Less teaching and more showing off how much he knows.

Covach is a great storyteller who cares about his students. His tests and listening quizes require a fair bit of studying, but he gives lots of opportunities for extra credit. Papers are graded by the TA and are an easy A if you use the ppts. Tests are difficult and require trivia-level knowledge of minute details
great!! loved his lectures, learned a lot. very easy to understand.

Easiest class EVER, and fun! (Rock music in the 1970s)... definite GPA booster while listening to awesome music. Tests are trivial but questions come directly from lectures which are posted online, attendance is not necessary but you'll miss out on some great lectures.

I thought the class was a good general course to take, but it just talked about the major happenings and didn't really increase my knowledge...the tests are essentially trivia questions and aren't really reflective of the main topics of the lectures.
No Comments

Had Covach for Theory III and Beatles - absolutely AMAZING prof. Loved every class and learned a ton, fantastic lecturer, genius, grades a little tough but completely fair. A definite highlight of my college career!

she tends to go off on tangents about her boat and kids. shes very nice but is not scared to show her anger in front of everyone. she reads off of her slides and only sometimes does she add anything to them while lecturing, lectures are recorded. shes the only one that teaches 224/5 so youre stuck with her. talks pretty slow
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I loved this professor! Great Classes very caring and explains things really really well
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: She is the only professor that teaching intermediate acc 1 and 2 so you should get used to her, she goes off topic a lot, tells stories about her boat and kids, and laughs at her own jokes. she is very accessible outside of class, 3 homework assignments and you have to work in a group. first midterm is hard, second and final are okay.

I enjoyed being in Heidi's class just about as much as she enjoyed teaching it. Which is to say, Not at all. I second other comments about the fact that she plays favorites. You can clearly tell that she does not want to be teaching, and takes out her stress on students.
i went to her office hours to see my test and she was very mean to me
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Heidi is the BEST accounting professor I have ever had. She is incredibly smart and so nice. She is willing to help you out with WHATEVER you need. She has even helped me prepare for interviews before! I am better prepared for my job because Heidi has taught me so much. You do have to work hard for a good grade, but it's so worth it!

Great professor teaching a rather dry topic. Her exams are fair and the homework can be daunting, but she encourages you to solicit feedback from her and your assigned teammates. Do the work, get a good grade; it's as simple as that. Respectful of the fact that working adults are taking graduate classes. Highly recommended!

She is a great professor and provides all the material you need in lecture and online but it's very heavy.  She does not curve any tests or homework or offer any extra credit so your grade is your raw score.  Because of that there is no way to recover if you do poorly on a test or homework and many people have been known to take ACC201 twice.
Too much materials covered

She likes to play favorites, if you're on her good side you're good; if not, she will be rude to you. She screamed at me once during a midterm when I asked for clarification. Her lectures are okay, but filled with material. She assumes you can understand something in 1 second. Please take Prema Iyer instead, she's absolutely amazing!
Wonderful professor. She wants to teach anyone who wants to learn.
Great professor, is willing to help you if you put in the effort. Very funny and great person.
She makes the lectures fun.
She is tough but will give you all the help you need. As long as you do all of the work, the class isn't bad
She can't stop making unfunny stories. Her exams are really though, and she crams the class to the brim with material.

Extremely intelligent and respectful. She was able to answer any and all questions. The curriculum was very well organized and it was easy to keep up with the pace of the class. Definitely a worthwhile course to take - I feel like it has enhanced my critical thinking skills and the information we learned is so fascinating. Fantastic professor.

She's very good at explaining things for the most part, although she tends to use weird analogies that can be confusing sometimes. Overall, she is a good professor who seems to really care about the topic and tries to keep the class entertaining. She does check attendance so that's one thing you have to watch out for, but it is an enjoyable class.

Professor Ney is a great professor. I had her for PHL 101, and I really enjoyed the class. Let it be known: the class is easy. PHL 101 shouldn't be a hard class, though. She covers the material well, and if you're half-way intelligent, you shouldn't have trouble with her lectures--she's very clear; people tend to ask poor questions in class.

If you just get handouts and not come to the class you'll do fine. In fact, you might do better if you don't come because Ney's explanations are confusing at best. She over-books her office hours (expect to wait an extra 1.5 hours), and when I would see her and say hello to be nice she would just look me in the eyes and ignore me. Avoid this prof.

She really tries to drive her point across in this well designed introductory course. She makes a good effort to remember everyone's names. The required readings are really interesting. Professor Ney is also quite funny, but not everyone always catches onto the jokes. Also: so as long as you attempt homework, you get full credit. I'd recommend 101.
She's very knowledgeable and helpful if you're willing to ask for assistance

Quite easy for an intro class, she spoon-feeds you the curriculum with packets she's typed up.  She is very irritating in her articulation, however, she uses circular logic and never actually brings the point home.  It also seems that she is nervous in front of all the students.

You don't have to take notes because you spoon-feeds you information via handouts - I'm talking the kind of worksheets we had in 8th grade. She's bad at explaining things and answering questions. It won't be hard for you to do well but you'll want to gouge your eyes out from boredom and the way she says YEEEUH, YEEEUH when talking to someone.
The only thing worse than this professor's rote, pedantic teaching style was the oblivious, green-lantern t-shirt wearing TA, Greg Fowler.
Smart prof so uo need to know your SH**** but overall she's really helpful and nice. Great Prof A+++++
Good prof.

she's smart so you can't **** your way through this 101 class...so in a sense I feel like this class is pretty rough for a 101 class - not an easy A.  Um, but she's nice esp during office hours - wants to help....but yeah, she's smart so this class is pretty hard esp if you've never dealt with writing phl papers :P
she sucks
Pretty good. Covers everything in depth. Sometimes slows down the class for stupid people.
Boring, too practical

Kate Soules at first grades really really easy, but on the final paper her entire attitude completely changes. I went from getting 100 on all the papers to an 81 on the final paper. The way she grades is so unpredictable. The topics are so abstract and boring. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. If you like zombies and cyborgs then take it.

Kate Soules is the best writing professor ever. I cannot believe how kind and thoughtful she is. She really has our best interest at heart, and is willing to put in the time and effort to make us better writers. Even with so much going on in her personal life, she made sure to help us with our research papers. She is an extraordinary human being.

I love Professor Soules! Whenever I have a meeting with her, or just talk to her, she really works hard to understand our point of view and readers, writers, students and humans. She is extremely respectful and engaging and I would not have had such a great writing experience without her.
She was always kind and helpful and just wanted us to succeed.

Soules, based on what I hear from my friends, is one of the best Writing105 professors at UR. Her rubrics are clear and she will provide you with ample feedback on your rough drafts so you can write and A level final draft. The class was interesting and she is understanding when students do not do their readings. Great professor.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: I adored this class because of the instructor! She made an intimidating topic and course structure feel doable, and I am so grateful for her investing so much personal time in making us better writers.

She was engaging, interesting, informative, and most importantly fun. The activities/assignments she made us do felt like they actually mattered and wasn't just busy work. Every formal assignment I actually felt myself growing stronger as a writer.

She is very understanding of unforseen circumstances and was ALWAYS available and willing to help improve my writing or give suggestions. Every assignment given to the class helped me become a better reader/writer in its own unique way. Professor Soules is a gem and finding instructors like her are not easy to find in the world of academia.

Prof. Soules is so kind and caring. She is also very understanding. Although the class had a lot of thought reading assignments, she still discusses them in class and doesn't force you to participate. Very encouraging when it comes to your paper and gives good feedbacks. She is also pretty chill compared to other writing profs I heard from friends.

this class was a bit rough for a summer class. not an easy A. so much reading and participation is really important. that being said i liked the material and i think she made it a good environment even though we were doing hard things and talking about hard stuff like racism. a lot of your grade was the final paper.

Kind, considerate & supportive. Shows empathy towards students, provides in-depth, insightful feedback, & works extremely hard to make sure the course is interesting, varied and engaging. She is personally invested in your learning, & wants to make sure you succeed. Great sense of humor & easy to talk to; exciting and engaging classes.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: this class was the hardest thing iv'e done. she makes you write. go to office hours though. i got so much feedback i thought i would fail but she changed my life and i don't love writing but i got a really good grade and i'm waayyyyy mroe confident now.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Kate Soules is one of the most caring professors I've had so far at UR. She understands mental health and prioritizing that over everything. She gives really good feedback. Her class was also really fun which I didn't expect from a writing class. But it's so obvious she cares about the stuff she teaches and about her students. Loved this class.

LOVE soules. i took wrtg105, and she was so lovely to work w. was rly just trying to bang out my writing reqs but ended up enjoying class- its a lot of in depth reading and wrtg, but there were only 3 big essays over the course, which all included a lot of helpful peer and prof review during the assigned period. go to office hours, wonderful advice
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Gives good feedback

comment: I took this as a summer course. We crammed a whole semester into just a couple of weeks and the class meetings were 4 hours long which was h-a-r-d. She was kind and engaging and encouraging during class discussions. We covered some hard material but it was okay if we went off topic a bit. Loved the things we read like Angels in America and stuff.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: If you're into theoretical CS stuff, CSC 280 is the place for you. You'll be learning and solving many interesting problems from complexity theory. The small class size definitely helps with the in-class discussions and group activities. One of the best class formats I've seen in a course.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Genuine, caring, attentive, passionate, enthusiastic, loves to share stories (often over-shares random (but subjectively fun) stories), accessible, interesting course content and materials.

He is a nice person, and what he says in class makes sense, but I had to rewatch recordings to understand.  If you want to do well:  ALWAYS show up for attendance credit, and study the examples he does in class.  His exams are very fair.  If you understand the in-class examples you should be fine on the tests.  Work hard and you will do good, good.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Most people would complain about mandatory attendance when you can easily get 36% just based on attendance! Lane makes us do tons of practice that makes it impossible not to do well on the exams! He's caring, an expert in his field, and one of a kind! This is a theory class, so if you don't like proofs, DEAL with it and DON'T blame Lane for it!

Very smart man, cares deeply about his student's success. Lectures can be a little abstract if you aren't interested in the topic, but he delivers topics with great energy. Exams are very straightforward, he tells you exactly which topics will be covered. You should have no issue getting an A if you read and commit to understanding the proofs
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Ill just save you the trouble. do not attempt to take this class if you are going to have to miss school for any period of time. He isnt screwing around about missing class. I had to withdraw when I had a family emergency. I would have failed the class. In his 15+ page syllabus, it might as well say yea, good luck with that. No excuses
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: One of the worst professors in the department. Dismisses some questions by students in a condescending manner. Most of the people fall asleep in his class yet he thinks everyone is doing super great with the material. Also, talks way too fast without filtering.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Lane cares for his students (e.g. numerous email reminders) to the extent he babysits us. He even remembers most of the students' name, which is no ordinary feat considering there are at least 70 of us. However, he talks too fast with hardly and breaks. Going for workshops & watching YT videos is a must. You will notice how clear YT videos are.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Caring

comment: Great professor that is awesome about feedback and has amazing lectures
Both the quirkiest and smartest man I've ever met. Get to know him outside of class; it'll be worth your while.

VERY hard driving! Some weeks we had 3 6+hour homework sets. Still, he's very approachable and I've never had a problem trying to access him. His explanations do go quickly, so ask him to slow down (he says that on the first day). He also expects you to have a good grasp of the language of math, as well as of discrete math.
