Brush up beforehand!

FAST Talker. Unclear half the time, also cause the material is fast, but he expects us to understand it as easily as he does. Fair grader though, grades people individually rather than a class. If he sees you doing work and at least tryin, you won't fail.

Wonderful teacher, however completely nuts.  Moves very quickly through material with numerous tangents.  However, extremely knowledgable and if you are able to keep up with him, one of the best in the department.  Also, always willing to help and explain
Undoubtedly knowledgeable and well-intentioned, but a quirky mess. Assigns insanely excessive amounts of work and enjoys giving zeros to more than half the class for any given assignment.
Worst professor EVER~!!!  Rambles and talks too damn fast  :(

Maybe he is a good researcher, but not a good professor. He is a little bit disorganized. Every time you ask him a question, he wants to tell you everything he knows, but without key points. He taught just a little about the uncertainty part in the lab lecture, but the calculation of uncertainty is a huge part of the lab report.
Bad professor
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: This semester he taught hybrid and made it clear that none of us would fail. He really just wanted us to learn one thing. He was super kind, understanding, and was willing to give extensions to us. His classes are difficult, but he is willing to help you succeed.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Jim is a great guy. When taking his class it really is a you get what you put in type of thing. He will spend all day with you if you don't understand something but you have to ask him questions. His notes are sometimes not helpful. But he believes that learning is a process and curves.

I had Jimmy Z for a class a while ago, and I found that any affection he had for his students gets masked behind a layer of talking down. He is a nice guy, but the kind who is so much smarter than us that he is hard to relate to.
Jim's a great guy but a poor lecturer.  He gets off topic too easily and has trouble getting back to task.  His work on the blackboard could use practice as well.

Zavislan is a great guy & not boring, BUT his notes r not too helpful, he doesn't show many (helpful) examples, no previous hwks, his responses r vague & he ends up rambling about something completely different. his lectures r either way to over my head or not good. i'm struggling a lot in this class! while doing fine in the rest of my classes
he's a cool prof.
He knows everything about geometrical optics, and makes you work hard to learn it for yourself. When you succeed, you feel completely rewarded.

For some students the material comes easily and for many it doesn't. Either way, Zavislan is willing to spend a LOT of time making sure you understand.  It's just up to you to schedule an appointment.
Explains things in a coherent manner
Hahaha, yeah, Jim IS good at life
He doesnt write on the board so you have to pay attention in his lectures.  Its a very tough class if your used to learning off of notes.
Jim is good at life
No Comments
Very nice and caring. If you take this class seriously, you'll get a good grade.

As long as you pay attention to what she says in lecture and just use that material in your papers, you'll do well. She already has an idea of the writing/answers she wants. She gives extensions even if you don't have an excuse and is very kind. However, I would recommend another professor as her class/criteria is quite confusing.
There's no guidance or practical structure to the class. Consider taking another class for the writing req, not this one.

Prof. Zaman is a tough grader but will give you substantial feedback (which is tough at times I know). This feedback is really useful and will most likely enhance your writing abilities in the long run. However, this class is not easy even if the 105E label gives you that impression. Be ready to read a lot and revise a ton.

Extremely confusing deadlines and classwork. I was constantly confused on when assignments were due, what assignments were due etc. There were 3 of us in the course by the end of the year, and she would still talk extremely loudly in the tiny classroom. Whenever I asked her for her help it made me more stressed. Unbearable.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Very nice and critical but you learn a lot about writing from her. I can see why people might not like her because she has a very ambiguous grading scale and a lot of factors you have to assume on the fly but her teaching has made me a better writer. Would recommend
Pretty tough grader compared to other WRTG 105 teachers. Definitely much more confusing, however Nasheed will 100% make you a better reader and writer.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor was super helpful in answering concerns in papers and fast to respond to emails. She was patient even when students were blatantly lying about forgetting parts of assignments and overall very informative. If you listen in her class it is easy to know how to format the papers she asks for and there is a lot to takeaway from her class

she change the proposal of paper on every version. 
easy to get angry. 
tough grader, almost never give students a or a-.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: I did not enjoy this class and there was so much confusion over assignments and when I asked for assistance she was just more confusing. She never gives clear direction of what to do and no direction on homework assignments.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: She is willing to have discussions about any topic you're interested in after class and always encourage students to ask question. Paying attention to what she emphasises in class would definitely help writing a better paper.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Inspirational

comment: No real guidelines on how the assignments are graded are shown. This unclarity is detrimental to the structuring of many assignments. The professor gets passive-aggressive when you miss one class and will take points off final grades if she feels that you've missed enough classes, with the threshold of that being very low.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: She gives you detailed feedback, though you need to work really really hard to meet her criteria. There are also tons of reading during the first few weeks. Don't make her class your first choice unless you are so interested.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read

comment: Her class is super duper abstract; there's hella reading. I personally cannot relate to her logic, and most of the in-class discussions are just answering questions that are already an answer to the question itself. Do not take this class unless you are seriously interested or you just happen to love to read things that make no sense.

The professor does not have strict grading criteria making it hard for students that are following the guidelines to excel as she doesn't follow them to the dot. Therefore, she might not notice some students going over time or under page limit. I will not recommend this course to anyone. At times I feel that the professor is passive aggressive.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: I liked him, he can be a little difficult to get used to. He has a great understanding of the material and is always willing to answer questions and help.
rating_tags: GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Hard class, but he's very passionate about Physics and uses demonstrations to explain material. Very helpful in person as well. I see a lot of complaints about his accent but if you mind your professor's having accents, get over it! If you plan on going into research, you're going to be interacting with people from many countries, so get used to it

Bodek tends to mumble and has a slight accent but if you sit in the front, you should be fine. Physics is complicated in itself so it's irrational to expect a complete understanding of the material by just attending lecture. To really understand the material, go to workshop, do the homework, and read the textbook. Otherwise, he's a decent teacher
excellent teacher. I set in the front seats so that I could focus on the lectures.  I liked the demonstrations and the connections that he made to modern physics, e.g. quarks and black holes.
Amazing teacher.  Must have this guy teach physics!!!!  If not for him i dont know where i would be.

As a professor Bodek wasn't good. He is hard to understand and I don't like how he runs the class. If you do go see him in person, though, he is actually a nice guy. I  recommend going to him directly if you are having issues because I have had issues with the TAs and he is usually willing to help. He is just too smart to teach a basic course.

If you used to like physics, don't hang on to that notion for long. Absolutely awful, attendance is "mandatory" because of in-class quizzes that count for 1% of your final grade. The man developed the basis of the quark and should've shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1990, but he can't even get the powerpoint to work half the time.

Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.  Bodek may be a brilliant researcher, but all the dire stuff people have written here is true.  It is kind of hilarious that his demonstrations always fail, though.

He is really, really bad.  Sometimes very difficult to understand and follow due to bad handwriting and a strong accent.  Seems like a nice guy, perhaps, and is extremely intelligent, but just a horrible lecturer.  May god have mercy on your soul if you have him.

Bodek has to be one of the worst professors I have ever met!! Can't even understand him and he wears a microphone. All his in class experiments are a complete fail. He thinks he the Ish!! Don't go to class find someone to do your in-class quizzes. gkll;gslksl if you can understand this then you will do very well!!

I don't know where to begin with this professor. Currently taking this class has diminished my interest in physics. Bodek doesn't even speak a language; he mumbles and stutters for literally the whole class time. He's not accessible and has the worst handwriting. His mini experiments in lecture are always a fail and he's so bad with technology.

Pretty much the worst lecturer I've ever had the misfortune to have.  He's a smart man and he tries very hard, but his convoluted proofs and tangents (which are not and should not be tested) accomplish nothing.  On top of that, he has a nearly indecipherable accent and MUMBLES.  And lecture notes?  Forget it--they look like Rorshach blots.

Worst lecturer I've ever encountered. Mumbles, but the real problem is that he spent lecture time proving various equations (using calculus over many people's heads) and correcting his own algebra, rather than explaining concepts or showing how to do problems. Explained potential energy using subatomic particles and graphs...way to overcomplicate.

Avoid this guy. Can't understand a word he says... and he mumbles. Such a smart man, wants to help, but can't convey it to the students. I have learned everything from the book and my TA and not a single thing from him all semester. Probably the worst course I have taken at UR.
Totally Incomprehensible in class....more like disorganized. Worst online lecture notes ever, it looks like a five year old wrote them.

He was so amazing and funny which made the entire semester easy and enjoyable for his course. There is a lot of reading ( some with explicit photos ) so beware! But honestly it was a pretty simple and fun course and he gives plenty of opportunities for you to get extra credit. I wish he taught more courses :3.

Chill class and chill professor. Lectures were pretty interesting and this is by far one of the easiest classes at UofR so far, especially if you're STEM. Sit back, relax, and enjoy this class. Rogge tells pretty funny stories. Lots of extra credit (participation credits), didn't even need to do SONA.

I didn't expect so many readings before I took this class hhh but the contents are overall interesting. Well, I gotta say sometimes, there are pictures really make me feel uncomfortable, so be prepared. But interesting lectures, a lot of extra credit, so just enjoy it
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria

comment: I LOVE THIS MAN. SO FUNNY. and also genuinely wants everyone to do well in the class.

Hilarious, makes class fun. Quiz at beginning of lectures but they're easy if you do the readings. Fun participation questions in every class. Exam questions are from the participation/textbook questions so you'll do well as long as you're doing those other assignments. Lots of extra credit opportunities. Have to purchase the online textbook.
THIS MAN IS AMAZING
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Online Savvy

comment: Prof Rogge is probably one of the best professors I've ever had. The only issue I had was that the materials for the class were online and cost $200 but the prof was very conscious about students who struggled to purchase this and was accommodating to the best of his ability

This might be the easiest course at U of R.  40% of your grade is basically given to you for free if you just do the online quizzes correctly (he gives you the answers) and complete textbook questions (which are not graded on correctness).  The rest of the grade is based on 2 exams.  He gives review questions before exams which are very helpful.

This class was very interesting and was a nice break from hard classes I was taking. The majority of the grade is based on only 2 multiple choice exams but there are plenty of opportunities for extra credit. Professor Rogge is a super cool person who makes the class interactive which keeps everyone engaged.

He makes class super fun and entertaining; I actually look forward to going to class and even though there is a lot of content he wants his students to do well and succeed. His exams are all multiple choice and there are many ways of improving your grade through extra credit and extra projects etc. Super interactive class. totally recommend!!!

He is absolutely hilarious. Love his personal anecdotes - they show he cares and that he's passionate about the material. Everything is straight from the book but he gets the information across in a funny, understandable way.

Professor Rogge has a great sense of humor. His lectures are easy to understand and interesting to listen to. He gives you the questions that will be on the test the class period before so you don't have to memorize a bunch of information. You don't have to go to class or read, but you'll want to!
Best class ever. Best teacher. You will learn so much but it will be so easy.

Super funny and laid back.  He is enthusiastic and makes the class interesting while still teaching you the material. His tests are a breeze because of the review sessions and if you need help he is very accessible.

He's great! He's really funny and refreshingly real with his students. His explanations and really clear and he really puts in a lot of effort to make himself available to help his students. He even held a review session on a Sunday afternoon for 3 students who couldn't make it to the other one. Great professor!
bro is not valid i guess

The worst professor I've ever had. Didn't give a clear syllabus with the total number of projects, added on extra guidelines days before due dates. Wouldn't post answer keys to study guides, didn't teach TAs material, didn't teach how to properly submit projects on terminal until 2 projects in, and the worst lecturer known to man. my #1 enemy...

By far the worst professor I have had in several years of university. He simply doesn't want to do his job, so he just leaves us to learn everything by ourselves. There are no consequences to him for doing this because he's tenured. Incredibly rude and condescending to students for no good reason. Avoid at all costs.

Read that textbook like the Bible. Attending lectures became counterproductive partway through, so I stopped going. Power through the course while perceiving yourself on the constant brink of failing and power through to find a generous curve. 

No math prereq but linear algebra, multivariable calculus, & stats are helpful.

Awful lecturer -  reads straight from the slides and essentially just mumbles to himself. Doesn't attempt to explain anything. Project descriptions (at least the ones he wrote himself) are extremely convoluted as well, and the only way to study for midterms is to read straight from the textbook.

flesrouy kcuf og

read this backwards

Very unenthusiastic lecturer. Very disorganized, which is apparent through teaching, his website, and giving late updates on projects/exams. Better off reading the textbook thoroughly as opposed to going to lecture. Expect to be quizzed on obscure content from the textbook.

Very unenthusiastic lecturer. The first day of class I was sitting in the front row and couldn't hear him well. You're better off not going the lecture and just reading the text book. Gives us practice problems from the text book before the exam but does not share the solutions to them. He doesn't give the answers to the TAs either.

This professor does not care about his students, this is apparent in his lectures and how he does not respond to student emails. The homework's are relatively ok except that he uses an outdated system for submission. However the main problem are the tests of which the only way to study for is using the textbook, as he does not teach.

Worst professor I have ever had in my life. Really bad lectures and everyone I know taking this class with him either dropped or are struggling a LOT. No practice exams are given and a lot of self-learning -- even instructions on how to submit homework/projects were not clear and it took hours to figure out even by going to TA office hours

csc446 not 246
TAKE THIS CLASS! the best class ever had

PRML for textbook, and you should expect this a 90% math course, otherwise do not even touch ML
Homework:
He is literally the worst professor I ever have in my life. His teaching is so not organized and so random. He does not seem to care about how to make his teaching better at all

He is the best NLP research professor at Rochester, very proficient in machine translation. If you want to expand your experience in this field, please go to his class. Tough lecture content, but he has great teaching skills. If you want an easy semester, do not go to his course. The course needs a deep understanding of NLP and shapes a researcher.
One of the more difficult computer science classes you can take. Prof. Gildea is an expert in the field - although he can be a little quiet in lecture. Surpassed csc 200 as my favorite course.

An exciting topic right? Machine Learning. Not so in Gildea's hands. I am posting this 3rd week of class looking forward towards a dreary semester of unenthusiastic lectures. A new low for the worst professor I have ever had at Rochester.

Class was weighted well so if you got A- on every paper, you could still get an A in the class. I Took thinking about thinking, great material and was never overwhelmed or stressed. Gives enough time to do each paper and very helpful. So kind as well, great class and I would take again.

Suzanne was everything that I wanted when I was picking out a writing class. She was very caring and accommodating, especially with extensions that deal with your personal life. Attendance is mandatory, though, so just go. If you miss like seven classes or something you aren't allowed to keep attending class, which is scary but not her fault.
She's great! She does give good feedback, but has a bit difficult grading scheme IMO. She's very chill tho.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: It doesn't really matter which teacher you have for 273 because the course is so rigidly structured and graded. But Suzanne is kind so she's not a bad choice. She seems to understand that this is kind of a joke class.

Professor Woodring is an amazing instructor who provides helpful feedback on your work. I wish I stopped procrastinating when I wrote my drafts for the 2nd and 3rd formal assignments because I could've gotten more feedback from her. The class is easy if you are a decent writer, but I wish her criteria for the second formal assignment was clearer.

I have nothing but praise for her. Certainly, one of the best instructors I have had the pleasure to be taking Writing with, and honestly might just be one of the best ones I will ever take during my time in the University. Caring, flexible, understanding, knowledgeable, great feedback, great communications, clear guidelines. You name it. 10/10
Her class was good. I don't like writing tho
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: Very much enjoyed my time in this class. While it was frustrating having to take it in the first place, that's just the nature of a primary writing requirement, and would be the same for any PWR class offered. If you're willing to put in the work, the class is going to be very easy. If you're looking to learn, you'll learn. I definitely recommend.

Honestly one of the nicest, most accommodating profs I've ever had. Super supportive and structures the class with the best interest of the students in mind. Not too much work, and every assignment we did both in and out of class had a purpose.

She's amazing and the class is so much more flexible than all the other writing classes which help you balance better. She's also very understanding of deadlines and exams in other classes - and so she is extremely flexible that way. Always gives constructive feedback!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Take her class!!! She is really caring and easy to get along with. She always provides detailed feedback for our drafts for paper. She is more helpful when students have specific questions about their writings (in 1 vs 1 discussion) than in general class sessions.

Suzzane is a really nice professor. She usually provides very detailed, helpful feedback on each assignment and offers one-to-one meetings to help us with the final paper. I am not a talkative person, but on her class, I feel encouraged and comfortable in participating in group discussions.

Prof. Suzanne has done a great job being an effective and amazing writing instructor. She presented the opportunity to relate the course with something we had interest in as individuals. She is also extremely caring and very considerate with a constant smile on her face. You can easily get an A if you do the required work. Don't be lazy!

She never taught us how to write in class and she graded our paper so hard. She seemed to be a nice person but not for eaching teaching the course. She gave us exactly the same grade when we first  entered this course. I didn't see grade improvements after taking her class. Moreover, she told us there will be no curves in the grading. Worst prof!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Her class is the worst class I took during the freshman year.  If you improved things she mentioned in the first draft, she will  have more suggestions in the final draft. She does not grade according to the improvements between two drafts but according to her expectation of the paper. Be careful to take her class, worst prof.

He is very clearly a smart and capable philosopher. However when it came to lecturing, it felt like there was a weakness. More than half the students don't show up because of his attendance policy and there is NO discussion. I'm not saying to avoid him, because he is very good during office hours 1-on-1, but the learning style may not be for you.
I was never a Philosophy person before I met Prof. Povich. He is definitely the reason of why I study Philosophy.
Great professor! One of the best in U of R, and he's also my favorite. Would definitely take again. Recommend Prof. Povich every semester.
He is a very patient professor, and there is overlapping content between his non-logic courses. The exams are entirely based on the content covered in class.

Best professor ever. He's so nice and patient and would not like to "challenge" you on exams. If you enjoy discussion with professor and classmates, you will enjoy the course of course. However, discussion is not mandatory you can just stay silent and keep listening.
class is very easy if you listen to the lectures. he is very understanding and cares for his students a lot.

Professor Povich is an excellent lecturer and you can tell he cares about his students and the material. His office hours are amazing and he's great at answering questions mid-lecture. Be sure you can do the problems in the slides and you'll be fine - you need to do practice problems to succeed and you will certainly reap the benefits of your work.

My favorite professor so far, his content about all of the various fallacies was very intriguing. Very understanding if you cannot turn in the homework due to illness. Email replies were very quick, and the homework didn't take very long. Make sure you go to lecture the class before all of his exams, as he reviews everything in a detailed manor.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Phil is not my major but I really like this course. The knowledge of fundamental logic is very interesting and Mark  is a great professor, I would take his course again if I have chance in the future.

Professor Povich makes philosophy very accessible. Assignments are easy and grading is kept to a minimum so as to put understanding the actual subject material at the forefront. The Professor himself is kind, laid back, and obviously well rooted in his field. He can sometimes be a bit disorganized but I blame that more on classes being online.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Lecture is essentially him explaining the textbook. You need to practice the material to do well on the tests; go to workshop (40% of your grade) and do the textbook problems. Replies to emails on the two days he works at UofR, so do the math. A fantastic, compassionate human being. Mandatory class for PHIL majors.

Honestly, he is a really nice person but not a good lecturer. He never reply email. His class is boring since he was just reading his notes. His tests are not hard as long as you review the exercises in the book. His TA Jacob is such a nice person, but he studied different textbook, so he might teach some problems in totally different approaches.
pretty clear lecture, but he rarely replies emails..............

Prof. Povich is truly a great professor who cares about the material and teaches in a way that makes it interesting to learn. All readings are pdfs he post, and the HW is to answer some questions or think of your own. Go to class as his exams usually ask for class examples. He will explain as many times as you need in class but make use of OH too.

Provides PDF of text which makes reading and completing practice problems a breeze. All material comes from lectures. Workshops are graded on effort, show up and simply try. It makes the material easier if you're struggling. Also, go to office hours!

He gives you PDFs of the readings. You are graded on 3 tests, and homework but they are graded on effort. He is very nice and accessible outside of class. The class was mainly just him lecturing but if you ask a question, there will be a lot of fun and interesting tangents. The tests are 100% based on lectures, but not too hard, so take notes.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Super nice, he let me rewrite my final paper and even told me specifically what book to check out and use a source for my paper. Goes off on tangents about his experiences with certain cathedrals; can be boring if you're not reallllly interested in the subject. Lets class out early in the fall when it's hot (average of 20 minutes earlier).

Walsh reminds me of everyone's favorite grandfather. He occasionally rants and rambles about something vaguely related, but is extremely knowledgeable, and passionate about his classes. There are only 3 papers of average length and he's not the strictest grader, cares more for ideas presented than the manner of presentation. Amazing class.

An interesting course. Walsh makes it very easy to succeed. He is flexible with extensions and edits drafts. Entire grade is three 4-6 page papers. Get a seat at the front, take good notes and don't miss a class and you'll do fine. He seems like a very jolly old man. I plan to take more classes with him!

Prof Walsh is a very nice man, but I found his lectures rather boring, and since there were no exams (only three 5-page papers), attending class was unnecessary. The notes I took in class were not helpful to me. Despite my spotty class attendance, however, I got an A in the course - so either I'm an excellent writer or he's an easy grader!

Walsh is very nice, passionate and knowledgeable about his field, and really wants to help students succeed. He's very soft-spoken so try to grab a front seat. Sometimes his lectures are dry and boring, follow his train of though. Tangents a lot :) This class was graded on 3 short paper (4-6 pgs) - a GPA booster if writing is your strength.
Have taken multiple classes with Walsh all of them easy. You have to write 3 5page papers. Lectures are a little dry but tangents are good. He loves what he does and its evident

Reall nice guy, sometimes a little bit boring, but very passionate about the subject.  You can tell he really loves to teach it.  Just 3 papers which you have to put in good work on to get a good grade.  I learned a lot in the class and it wasn't too difficult.
He's an ok teacher, a little boring at times and a little weird but what can you expect from an AH teacher?

I personally never found a dull moment in this class.  Something amusing always seemed to happen.  My only complaint is that while Walsh was soft spoken and polite in class, I sometimes found him difficult to approach, though he was very accessible to students.

An enjoyable class if you sit up front and can hear him, maybe it was just the room, but you really had to strain to hear him talk, shows way too many art slides (ok i know he does art history) but this is just a history course. I went to every class took great notes, yet i still felt i didnt know much for the papers. Still expecting an A though.

Very knowledgable and the course is interesting. He welcomes questions and concerns from students and makes a point to make himself available. The work is some what demanding but quite rewarding. Walsh is an excellent professor and would suggest taking any of his other courses.
Professor Walsh is extremely knowledgeable, helpful, and entertaining.  I highly recommend any of his classes.
The most boring class of my life!

This class was painfully boring! It had such potential and he ruined it. It's entirely lecture, and he really knows his stuff but shows no enthusiasm. He's a nice guy, but I would rather be one of those artifacts buried in the dirt wasting away than to sit through another one of his classes.
Professor Walsh is extremely entertaining and definitely knows his materials.  His classes are always enjoyable.
Great lecturer. Getting an A is easy, but it's one of those classes where you should be aiming for more than just an . Guy knows a lot and loves to talk, so don't waste that!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Ruskin is awesome! He truly cares about his students' success in the course. His lectures are very interesting and he keeps the class engaged with visuals and cool stuff! His study guides are pretty clear for what to know for the tests. 3 midterms, weekly quizzes (which are straightforward), and two assignments. Overall great class!

Professor Ruskin is very passionate about BCS. His lectures are sometimes disorganized and hard to follow, but he is very accessible outside of class if you have questions. The weekly quizzes help you understand the content better and the tests follow the study guides well.
Dave is easily the one of the most helpful and engaging professors I've had.

Prof. Ruskin is the most caring professor in every way. His lectures are good, he gives ample review for tests, and is more than happy to answer questions whenever. This was a really great class, and I would definitely recommend taking it.

I took BCS 261 with Ruskin the first time he taught it. The content was enjoyable, and he let us dictate what we covered at the end of the class. The final was a pretty lengthy paper, but he gave great feedback through out the process and wasn't a hard grader at all. He is also an intelligent, genuine guy with compassion for his students
Wonderful lectures. Recitation sessions are good.
Great lecturer who keeps a large class engaged on the topic. He is also an understanding and kind man who will go out of his way to help a student who requires it. Would definitely recommend!

Prof. Ruskin is very passionate about the materials he teaches. Lectures are filled with interesting examples that really broaden your knowledge. (Although frequently, classes can get pretty disorganized).  The essays in the exams are hard, but are insightful at the same time.

I really enjoyed his class. He's a very quirky excited professor who is passionate about the material & also allowed the class to include their own interests as topics in the second half of the semester. Probably learned the most in this class of any class I've taken at the University. Highly recommend if interested in research. VERY reading heavy!

Super nice and makes the lectures actually interesting to go to by including good videos and pictures in them. No textbook, and the additional readings are pretty optional (he goes over them in class and emphasizes the main points). He's pretty clear on what he wants known for tests. He really knows his stuff and cares about his students.
Lectures are great and very interesting. Can be very understanding and kind. Office hours are great, cannot stress how accessible he is
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Weekly open internet quizzes are free points.  However, his lectures can drag on or get very off topic.  The readings are definitely not essential.  He seems like a great guy but in a lecture hall his style of sort of loose and fast info doesn't work the best.
Interesting, puts slides online, only negative is trickily worded online quizzes but there essentially free points
Dr. Ruskin was an awesome instructor... his lecturing style is awesome.

Tells good stories and seems like a nice guy. Lectures are useless but he provides good notes. So you mostly study out of the textbook and notes to learn the material.  Grades are based entirely on exams.
Class is not helpful, the professor isn't clear. However if you do the work, you will do well.

TAKE this class. Do the assignments and go to class. Very knowledgable professor. Will meet with students to clarify any questions. Makes the material very easy to understand. Test questions are based on the lecture slides.
DO NOT TAKE HIM
Worst Prof ever... Tried really hard to understand him, but still can't. Ended up reading textbook and self-learning.
Worst professor I've ever seen teach.
Nice teacher, tries to do everything. He has a heart to teach, but I just don't understand what he's trying to talk about in lectures. In the end, I end up self-studying from the textboks. = ="

Masters Level Accounting Course: Class was good, he taught it well. You had to do the homework in order to understand the material, as he stated every single day. Exams were very fair, but you have to spend time understanding the homework and reading the book. A typical class - you get out from it what you put in.
He is unclear, unhelpful, and gets distracted easily. He rambles about pointless stories and his exams are very tricky. Hard to be 100% prepared for his exams.

Gets very off topic but his stories are very interesting.  Definitely better than lecturing on accounting for an hour straight.  Tests are very easy, almost the same as homework problems except in multiple choice format.
An ok professor, but likes to ramble and really get off topic. Often hard to follow. Tests are all multiple choice, and tricky and all he bases grades on, so being well prepared is a must.
Great Professor, cares about students understanding the material.  Classes aren't hard if you do the work and go to class
Good professor, always has some funny story to tell.  Tests can be pretty challenging.
Monotonous, arbitrary, and repetitive to say the least.

Grades randomly. Many times he would leave feedback that clearly showed he did not read the entire paper and that he was unwilling to see things from a different perspective. Also, for an outdoor-based writing class, he brought up issues like class and race a lot. Cool guy, bad professor.

If you are an incoming freshman AVOID THIS PROFESSOR at all costs. He is the most unfair and illogical grader ever. He grades without a rubric, and deducts vast amounts of points for small errors in papers. I came into this class as an experienced writer writing for my high school newspaper for 3 years, with over 50 published articles.
best professor I have ever had.
He will tear your GPA apart for ambiguous reasons. No mercy!
I really liked him but he grades his papers hard. Class was discussions based and mandatory attendance. Daily assignments are light but the 3 papers hits hard.

Justin was an extremely helpful professor and always gave useful feedback. The lessons were interesting a discussion-based. The assignments were difficult, but he is helpful with them and is allows for an extension if it means it will improve your work!
Hes nice enough, but somehow he made an interesting course boring. Extremely tough grader, I got a D+ even though I took AP English in high school. Use the writing center, not him.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: Professor Coyne is patient to answer students' questions, and he gives specific and helpful suggestions to students' essays. He is always prepared for course so don't forget to read the reading materials before classes!

He managed to make a class on inequality boring. The professor doesnt know how to teach, doesnt know how to facilitate a discussion, and grades harshly based on a super niche criteria of his work. I managed to get an A-, but there was a lot of work, and only a few things actually mattered for my grade.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--So many papers

comment: He is an extremely friendly professor who wants you to become a better writer. He gives very specific and good feedback but you have to be willing to talk to him either outside of class or during. He helps you analyze all the texts we read (and there are a lot of them!) and really wants his students to understand the topics.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: - Three papers over the semester - Readings for every week - Mandatory attendance - Tough grader
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Seem like as long as you do spend your time and effort on the papers, you will get a decent grade. The workload is not heavy and the prof is really nice and willing to help anytime

He is a pretty nice guy, quite accessible outside of class. You do need to go to class. He gives good feedback sometimes. He seems to lack the motivation to fully read/understand what you write, almost like he skims. It seems that he reads but not fully like he should, for a wrt teacher. He picks uninteresting topics.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Pretty hard grader but gives good feedback so you're able to learn from your mistakes and improve over time. Attendance super important, but if there are extenuating circumstances he's pretty understanding. He's pretty much always open to talking about concerns or ideas outside of class, so just reach out if you want to talk about your work.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Yes, he is a tough grader. But he is super approachable and friendly in and out of class.

Very strict grader and will take off a significant amount participation points form your final grade even if you arrive a few minutes late to class or don't participate. Is ready to read and provide feedback for several drafts of your assignment given that they are sent at least a day prior to the deadline
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--Get ready to read

comment: Great teacher and really enjoys what he teaches. Make sure to go to class as lecture slides aren't given and exam study guides don't really help. Also, make sure to read the textbook. At least 20% of the exam comes only from textbook material.

Attendance is mandatory, as lectures aren't recorded and I wish Karl and Dan didn't skip/rush slides. I do appreciate that Karl and Dan give out extra credit and curve the exams. Liked how Dan discussed intellectual disorders such as autism. Suggestion: Go to lectures, read textbook, take notes, and do the assignments well; you should be good.

the professor is really sweet/. he is passionate about what he teaches. and he truly cares about his students. the class is content heavy. his lectures are not recorded. you will have to write down everything he says. you will also need to read the textbook.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dan is such a nice person with interesting teaching style.Graded based on three exams, one paper and five discussion questions. Works isn't that hard but some exam questions are a bit tricky. But he offers so many extra credits so it will not be hard to get an A

Boring lectures, but as long as you understand the material its an easy class. He doesn't post slides though, so you either need to go to class or get notes from someone. Exams sometimes pull directly from textbook chapters.

Professor Mruzek is a very sweet professor. However, he does not allow recording/pictures in his class and will not send out power points so attendance is very mandatory. He will also do random little extra credit "check-ins" to make sure people are attending lecures.

Dan is a very sweet professor and his lectures are silly and engaging. Lecture attendance isn't recorded however slides aren't posted so I recommend going. Textbook material that isn't covered in lectures is also on exams. As long as you go to class and read the textbook you'll do well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Amazing lectures

comment: Nice professor and pretty fun lectures, but tests were hard since he didn't go over all the content from the textbook in lecture. Lectures are non mandatory but still necessary to go to since he doesn't post the notes. 3 small essays but lots of extra credit opportunities

I have heard a lot of bad things about psychopathology due to an old professor that taught the course previously. I was pleasantly surprised. This professor was one of my favorites that I've had from my 4 years. Make sure you go to class because there are no slides provided and take good notes. His story telling makes the class so much more fun.

Mruzek is very kind. His teaching is structured and he often gives examples based on his practice, which was interesting to listen to. He also gives extra credit since the class is graded by few things. I recommend going to lectures and writing detailed notes. Reading the textbook may help with exam questions and general understanding.

I took 282 with him. If you want to hear lots of examples of his practice, you'll like him. He's an interesting storyteller. If lots of personal stories will upset you, take another class. Class is easy, but there are few grades. If too many people get a test question wrong, he drops it. The textbook is online, but I don't think it's necessary.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: He is probably the nicest professor I had in my 4 years, was very understanding when I had to miss an exam due to covid and was willing to help me catch up on my work. Very prompt with answering emails and always willing to expand on subject matter outside of class.

Great professor and generally very passionate and kind about the subject that he teaches. The class does require you to do your readings, but generally, as long as you understand the keywords and spend some time on position papers you should do well in his classes
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: I loved Dr Mruzek! I took BCSC 172 for my minor and it honestly was my favorite class of the semester. We didn't have many things that got grades (3 exams at 20% each, a research reflection paper on a topic of your choice at 20%, two discussion posts for the remaining 20%), but exam grading was lenient with lots of extra credit. He's hilarious too.

I love him so much. A lot of previous reviews claim that he talks too much about his life in a way that appears to be bragging but I disagree. He genuinely has a heart and passion for what he does and I personally think that bringing in real-life experience from the field is valuable information that can't be found elsewhere.
I love this man. He is a fountain of knowledge and I love his teaching style

Easiest class I've ever taken though I can't argue with the previous review. If you're looking for a class you want to learn from don't take this but if you're looking for an easy A with little to no work this is it! He's an incredibly nice guy too.

Just a horrible professor. He is the absolute nicest person which makes it hard to dislike him, but he simply should not be teaching any courses. It seems like this is just his way to brag about his fabulous career as a clinical psychologist working with children with autism (I'm not doubting that, but I'm here to learn dude!) rather than teach.

Literally the harshest grader and like others have said, if you don't share his viewpoint you don't get a good grade. The amount of papers and reading that was required for a 100 level class was ridiculous and the feedback he gave on the essays was not enough to make any improvements on the next one. Don't take a class with him, it's not worth it.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Professor Joseph is really good, and he knows the subject extremely well. He has been in this field for so long, and as such, he has written so many papers on the topics being taught. Unfortunately, he is a bad and tough grader. He grades you based upon what he thinks and what he wants you to write. He is the worst grader I have ever seen.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Someone please inform him that if we don't come to the same conclusion, it doesn't mean the viewpoint is wrong. He is set in his own worldview that he doesn't allow deviation from it. What is point of writing an essay if he expects the same conclusion and same points? What a joke, stop teaching, the world would be a be a better place.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Professor Inikori has a unique style of teaching. He made his syllabus easy and accessible for all students. Every class lecture has readings and questions to be discussed in class. This class is a seminar class, it doesnt come easy for anyone who is not ready to struggle in a class. Get prepare for huge readings, participation, and attendance.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Really knows what he's talking about. You will learn a lot in his class, but don't expect it to be easy. Really values in-class participation and it can be intimidating to try and give answers to the questions he poses. If you choose to take one of his classes, be prepared for the amount of reading required for it, and make sure to read it twice.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Was a seminar course but the rigid atmosphere made it feel better to not participate. The material was interesting, but failed to be rewarding when each essay was geared towards a specific point of view and conclusion that had already been selected as correct. You are almost being graded on how well you can repeat an argument someone else has made.

The most demoralizing teacher I have ever had (and I have changed schools due to a teacher in the past). Entire class revolves around summarizing his beliefs altho he is "open to disagreements" (in which often tells students they need to learn how to read! or take notes). The harsh grading seems like getting the last word. Frustrating. Do not take.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: He doesn't allow you to question his teaching, and only allows his worldview in the classroom. His lectures consist of reading off statistics from the readings. He continually accuses the class of not doing the readings when people attempt to get him to clarify a vague question. Would never take a class with him again.

Although he has an accent, it is understandable but you just have to focus in on his lecture. The entire class is lecture base. No need to read the textbooks, just write everything he says during lecture. Assignments, midterm, final are essays and easy if you listen and take notes during class.

The most boring class ever. Really bad teacher, really arrogant. He likes everyone to read his papers that he wrote, every single one of them. Material is interesting, would have been better if he wasnt teaching it. Essays are graded meticulously. DO NOT TAKE!!!!!!!!! NOT worth it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
So boring, worst teacher ever, only took the class because it fulfills economics and history elective. Don't do it if you don't have to.

Is the equivalent of a Wikipedia page with a strong accent that makes him hard to understand. He  lectures are just him reciting statistics. Very boring, unfocused, and his accent only makes things worse. On top of how boring he is the material is not that interesting. And essays are graded scrupulously. No reason to take this class.

I took Prof Inikori for an African American History class about 11 years ago.  He wasn't clear in what he expected.  He would lecture and assign reading on one thing but then have an exam on something completely different.  He advertised office hours and would never be available during them.  I felt like I wasted my time in this class.

So boring! The class only had about 30 kids but there was absolutely no discussion. Could not pay attention but had to go to class as he takes attendance. Assignments were okay but was bored out of my mind during class!

Dr Inikori is an expert in economic history. I learned about Latin America and World Economic History and how to write better. He was very articulate and had the grace to conceit to a different argument from his own if you could back it with evidence. An "old world", caring, thoughtful teacher.

Burges is the best professor I've had at U of R. He is warm and funny in class and most class periods were devoted purely to discussions, which were almost always effective and insightful. He was accessible and helpful outside of class. Midterm and final assignments were hefty, but he gives ample feedback for both. Would give 6 stars if I could.

Professor Burges was born to be a professor. He seems to truly care about what his students have to say. Discussion in his class can be lively and invigorating. On top of that, he is incredibly kind and accommodating. As long as you clearly communicate with him, he will ensure that the class will never be too much for you. He is great at his job.

Professor Burges is a great teacher who really cares about his students. The class is tough, be prepared to put in effort into writing papers but if you're interested in the material, you'll find it really engaging. Be warned - attendance is mandatory and they are strict on it. If you're someone who skips class, this is not for you.

Joel really likes his essays. I ended up with 5 for the rest of the semester which was really rough. He taught a class on television which was a flop because of his constant replanning of the course syllabus. He's a smart guy who can lecture well, but this class was not run well (which he is aware of).
Ridiculous amount of workload for a non-W course. Your grade largely depends on the group project, and he picks your groupmates for you. Allow two absences, takes attendance every class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--So many papers

comment: Took his class as a first-semester freshman. A three pages paper each week. But you can surely learn things and inspired by his class! One of the best teachers I had at UR

His lectures are very fun but solid. Every lecture was prepared and delivered well. Definitely an inspirational course to learn about all kinds of media and how to analyze them. Very heavy load of homework though. Lots of papers and readings to do. The good thing is that the topics and times are relatively flexible. Take attendance every time.

I love Professor Burges! Took me some time to adjust to his class because there was a lot of papers to write and a semester-long group project but he was very flexible and cared about his students. He took individual concerns seriously and was determined to let everyone learn. He's very intelligent and his lectures are amazing. I'll miss his laugh
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects--Amazing lectures

comment: The man clearly knows what he is talking about. For an intro class, the workload is very extensive, although sometimes he is understanding. The no technology policy is very helpful because some of the material can be dry, but one can still pay attention. Midterm focuses on specific details so be aware.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: It's as if the light of God is reflecting off his bald head. Great teacher, good guy, would definitely recommend. He's so pretty! And smart. The end.
He's absolutely brilliant, and Intro to Media Studies was one of the best classes I've taken so far.

Took me a while to get used to his type of teaching (no technology). He uses his extensive vocab and flaunts his aluma maters quite often however i learned a ton in his class, even though it was the hardest class i've taken at UR thus far.
Took me a while to warm up to him, but he's a brilliant professor. He knows his stuff. Classes can sometimes be boring, but that was more the subject matter than the professor.
Amazing.

Interesting material presented in a fresh and intriguing way. Burges is an incredibly passionate and intelligent professor but teaches at an elevated level. If you're not willing to do the reading and participate, this is not your class. I learned a great deal and felt positively challenged. Highly recommend.

I greatly enjoyed his lectures. He taught in a way that is natural. He seemed to perfectly embody the archetype of a researcher, and to be generally doing things right in life. 

However, later on, I got involved in research in the department. His actions were the "final nail in the coffin", of any aspiration I had towards being a neuroscientist.

His lectures are pretty fun to go to. However, if you miss a class then it will be hard to catch up since a lot of the information is directly explained by him. I also HIGHLY suggest going to recitations. Professor Tadin can sometimes be difficult to understand so it was good to hear the topic being explained by a TA.

Duje teaches the standard BCSC class- 4 exams, 1 dropped, silly bonus assignment, that's it. His lectures are really fun to go to, but if you skip, there is no way you will understand a word on his lecture slides. The exams are not hard, just don't forget the 'required' readings. He mentions them once and then never again till the exam questions.

Interesting and engaging lecturer, but his lectures are unorganized with little info on his presentations, leaving you to take notes mostly on what he says in his lectures. But unfortunately, he talks fast, moves through content quickly, and doesn't explain things thoroughly. Graded on 3 exams that are based on memorizing random info from lectures.

Do not take this class unless you are an extremely good problem solver and test taker. I studied for hours for these exams and still could not grasp the content. BCS 110 is a needed pre req for this course as well and they dont tell you that! I loved duje himself , very funny and nice guy but the content was so hard for me personally.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Dr.Tadin is super nice. He is patient and his classes are not hard to understand at all. He assign important readings, which is required due to exam purposes. He does not take attendance but personally I think it's important to listen to his classessincee he does not provide recordings unless you are sick and did not go to classes for rare times.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Hilarious

comment: The professor himself is funny and does a good job of getting the class involved in what he is teaching. He would bring 3d glasses to class to demonstrate his lectures which was entertaining. The class itself is very hard, he talks way too fast, the lectures aren't record so good luck with that. The tests are hard but the professor is a nice guy.

He is extremely nice and cares about his students, but the lectures are a bit disorganized. A lot of the material is not explained thoroughly. Leaves you with a lot of unanswered questions. Additionally, most of the class and exams are just memorizing random facts. The exams are difficult and require lots of studying. The classes TAs are helpful.

Great lectures and inspiring materials! The exams are not easy but if you put some effort into reviewing them you would get a good score with the curve. Attendance is not mandatory but there is no recording for the class. Super nice professor!

A phenomenal human being with an incredibly style of teaching. Accommodates students to the best of his abilities and is very committed to helping students achieve the best grade possible and learn as many of the concepts as one can.

Professor Tadin makes class really interesting and is really thorough at explaining the material. The supplemental readings are always short and relevant. Tests are straight forward but you need to take the time to study. Really liked him and would go out of my way to take more of his classes!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Tadin clearly knows a lot about the topics covered in this course and his enthusiasm makes learning enjoyable. Lectures are interesting and the class structure is straight-forward. I would take a class with him again.
Great guy. Really wants his students to excel and clearly puts effort into lectures, office hours, grading fairly, being funny/relatable in class, etc.
Tests were hard he does not have a good curve. His lectures are boring and he is boring.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: A great professor. Really makes his lectures interactive. Even when I was messing around on my laptop I would sometimes look up to see what was happening. Tests are straightforward, and the professor loves to learn about new things in perception as much as the students. Really great professor overall.
he's so slay. 10/10 would recommend.

Overall, this was a good course and Professor White was an excellent professor. His homework and exams/projects were clear but difficult enough that you needed to really understand the material to do well, which is expected. Not a harsh grader, and very accessibly outside of class time. In-class questions were answered well also. I would recommend
sucks
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Test heavy

comment: I took this class in Spring 2017 and to this day, this was the worst class I've taken and taught by the worst professor I've met at UR. Did not use an ounce of the material from this class at my internships and current full time job. To all ChemEs taking this class: push thru it, you'll never need it again or have to deal with such a rude professor
Professor White is great! His lectures are so useful, and he is also really funny!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: The contents of this course is useful. I wish this course was taught by a different professor.

Professor White always wants to teach as much content as possible in his courses. The syllabus updates constantly each year to match some state of the arts tools used in the computational field. But, if you don't have any programming background, you'll struggle in this course cause they are not taught during class.

Professor White is truly outstanding. He sets you up for success in his class. As the student, you have a full control over 60% of your course grade -- homework, project etc (he might/might not change this in the future). Exams are worth only 40% total. He even texted me while I was out of town to make sure that my question was answered.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Does not know how to interact well with students. If you ask a basic question to him, he appears frustrated and impatient. The school should just hire an actual compsci professor for this requirement, as this professor is disliked by the vast majority of ChE students for obvious reasons.

All the lecture notes are posted online and very organized, so it's easy to access them for the homework. There is a lot of homework, but it usually reinforces concepts well so that you can be prepared for the midterm and final. He could improve on how he explains concepts because he often repeats himself instead of explaining things in a new way.

Extremely rude professor and condescending. Not even the suck ups in the class like this professor or thinks he is actually funny. Does not respond to slack messages and needs to reevaluate some of the TAs for this course. Some of the TAs need a serious course in the basics of respect.
Worst class I have ever taken. A lot of material is stuffed into one semester and the class is not taught well and it in general is confusing. Final was absurd. Barely a curve at the end- good luck.

White puts all his lecture notes online so attendance isn't necessary. He basically just reads through the notes for class. He passes on a lot of questions he gets to TAs and has them teach and give most of the examples in recitation. Upside is the final is open everything so you can look through all the notes.

It was his first class as a new professor at UofR, and so some parts were rocky. He got much better at lecturing and connecting with the students throughout the semester. His homework sets are tough but the exams are easy if you've done all your assignments. He is totally reachable and cares about you learning how to program in Python.

This was the first class he ever taught. He improved greatly throughout the semester. Keys to succeed in this class: Go over the lecture notes until you understand them, do all the homeworks, go to office hours when confused. Class uses Python programming so experience with this helps.
I don't even know where to start? He is just terrible and shouldn't teach undergrads.
He was not a good lecturer, would talk in circles without fully explaining the topic.
By far the most boring class I've ever taken. Interesting subject matter, but horribly boring presentation. One time the TA taught the class, and the class applauded him after he was done.

I took BCS 112 and the lectures are really quite boring.  I made a meeting with him to go over an exam I took and he was very unhelpful and sort of hurried me away.  He seems smart and interested, but I'll probably never take bcs again.

excellent professor - brilliant man.  quirky personality but very down to earth and definitely approachable.  class might not be bells and whistles, but if you are interested in psycholinguistics, tanenhaus will get you thinking.

Mike is awesome, the dweeb chic thing really works for him and he's one of the nicest smartest guys out there.  His lectures can be a little monotone but you can tell he really cares about the students and tries really hard to make sure everybody understands.
Not the most exciting class in the world, but he is very informative and his tests are pretty easy.  He's a good teacher overall and also a nice guy.
Boring and a total dweeb.  I had a hard time not falling asleep everyday in class.  But an interesting topic
Classes bored me so much that I quit coming to class and just read the book. Still got an A on every test though so I guess that says something about how important his lecture are..
Very enthusiastic about the material.  He has funny jokes that nobody seems to think are funny but me.  And him I imagine.
good stuff
My god made psychology hard between non related powerpoints and the book written by himself. Crack couldn't keep me perked up in his class
Perhaps the only time in my life I've actually considered sticking the pencil in my eye for sheer entertainment
Good for insomniacs
While a little unorganized, he genuinely cares about how his students do in class and will put in the extra effort to help you succeed.

Scott treats his students like adults. He has high expectations from them, he treats them with compassion and respect, and he is always available for extra support. He is primarily concerned with empirical research, so don't expect a huge amount of theory. Show up, do the work, be honest, and ask for help if needed.

I loved this man's lectures. He was slightly unorganized at times, and had a habit of going on tangents unrelated to the class, but his lectures were still easy to understand, and that's how my brain works. He was very willing to help students outside of class times and very approachable.

He can be unorganized at times but the slides are posted and they're easy to comprehend.  Lectures are straightforward, though they can be boring, but overall it is a fun class due to the material.  This class is an easy A; he goes over the exact questions that will be on the final (take-home), so it's stress-free and you can just learn for fun.

Professor Abramson is fine. His lectures can be rather boring but they're fairly straightforward. The problem sets were confusing but the final wasn't bad. As long as you look at the slides (which he usually posts before lectures) and do the readings you'll do just fine.

A good professor. Disorganized at times, but very passionate for his subject matter, and a very fair grader. He is very kind, and if you go to his office hours, you will do well. He goes fast at times, but if you try hard, you will succeed. Problem sets were fairly challenging. Midterms were easy, but the final was hard.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Unorganized.
He is awful and unorganized. Hands down the worst professor I've had so far here.
Scott is very caring but he gives very boring lectures, and he's powerpoint is so unorganized, it is very hard to understand what he wants to say.
Unorganized, not good at explaining.
I really enjoy his lectures and I think I can learn a lot from him. Amazing professor!
He does not care about students' performance and always speak of dry jokes in class. An embarrassing and boring class with him.
Boring but clear lecturer, teaches based on a YouTube channel (I'm not kidding)

He is scatter-brained and does not care about the class. It is sad because the lecture material is interesting and I think that I would love the class with a different professor. Lectures have no correlation to homework, which is all math for a humanities class. He is inexperienced. He would not give us any hint on what to study for the exam.
The mandatory lectures were boring. The knowledge matter simulations made no sense and not easy to score. I learned nothing from this course.
Great introductory class to Marketing. Professor is very involved and cares a lot. Attendance and Participation is graded, but not hard to score as class discussions occur.

Class is about business buzz words and students learn nothing. Graded on simulations and multiple choice exams that give no instruction and barely relate to content. Instead of actually teaching he does mandatory virtual and asynchronous classes every week where everyone goes into awkward breakout rooms. Terrible class but usual for u of r business

The class is not hard. Attendance and participation are just really annoying as he tracks everything (yes, the number of times you answer questions in class). Lots of homework. Exams are pure memorization which is not so good too.
The content is quite boring and the exam requires a lot of memorization. But it is good to score.

All exams are multiple choice and based on lecture materials. Before the exams he will post a review session of the topic covered which is very useful in revising. Try to participate. Simulations as homework and final simulation is group project. They are manageable. The professor is very kind and wants to help students. Take him!
Best prof ever! Love him.
Good prof, good class, easy grade
Work hard and participate, then you will get the result that you wish.

Professor Schloff has a solid experience of the marketing industry. His lectures involved a lot of examples from his experience. He wants his students to participate in class and appreciates feedback from them. MKT 203 had a straight forward grading criteria and easy assignments.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: He is the most incredible business instructor I have met so far and the only person who gives me an A in my first semester in college. Amazing teaching skills and gives everyone opportunity to do great!
He is the best marketing teacher you can ever find at US colleges. Ditch expensive and overrated Wharton and come to Rochester for Schloff instead!
He's dope

I wouldn't go to class if participation didn't count 10% towards the grade. The Pr just reads off from the slides, which rephrase the book, and doesn't add any valuable insights. He has been teaching just for the past few years and lacks teaching experience. Tests require mere memorization of the concepts, no analysis involved.  A lot of group work
He is very passionate, funny, and knowledgeable. But he is also an extremely tough professor. Tons of readings and papers. Very tough grader on papers. Cares a lot about participation and attendance
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: He is a good guy and definitely cares about his students and their learning but his expectations are unreasonable. For a class full of non-english majors he expects a level of writing that is unattainable without providing instruction on how to do that. This is not a writing class but he grades as if it was.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: He really made me enjoy Spanish writing.  If you go in for office hours he will help you immensely with your compositions.  He improved my spanish proficiency ten fold, but also helped me with my english writing (critiques your thesis, organization of ideas, etc that translate over to English).  I plan on taking future classes with him.

Go to office hours if you're having issues - budget a good amount of time because it's difficult to stop him once he starts talking but he will tell you all you need to know to impress him. Overall he's funny and great and recently got tenured which is very deserving. Also, he hands out chocolate.

Charismatic about the material and quite a funny guy during class. This is a composition class, so be prepared to hand in almost a draft a week. However, he's very open to confer with during office hours and offers a lot of helpful advice. Definitely raised my Spanish proficiency and challenged me to improve my writing ability.
Extremely helpful during office hours. Helped with my writing in Spanish and in English.
VERY intelligent professor. Tough grader - certainly not an easy A. He really knows his stuff and he really wants his students to learn and to leave his class as smarter people.

Brilliant. Can be a little brutal if you debate him in class, but is very intelligent and a tough grader that whips your writing skills into shape. He's very funny. Class is fun and his commentary on texts make it less painful.

This professor is phenomenal. He made me think and helped me improve my writing in Spanish. He has high standards but we are paying 45k+ a year to learn after all. Students who complain about him are lazy and wanted a grade they most likely didn't earn. This prof knows his subject area and grades fairly. He made pre-18th century lit relevant

Professor Prendergast is one of the most helpful professors I have ever taken. Those students who complain about the work load simply feel they have some deserving right to coast through college. Professor Prendergast wants to maximize the learning experience for his students. Does that mean working harder at times? Of course. But it's worth it.

Grades essays really hard and a bit unfairly, takes points off for 'personal peeves' not necesarily for poor writing style.  Class discussion sometimes gets monopolized by him. Very unsympathetic to personal needs of his students.

Ryan is a pretentious ****.  Screams too much about stupid things.  Grades ridiculously hard.  Activities don't support class material.  I would have had a perfect semester gpa if not for this class. This was a complete waste of a class.
Very strange man, has a weird obsession with pop stars. Grades compositions REALLY hard.
An ok prof. He grades compositions pretty hard, and the curriculum of the class could use some work too.  Pretty fair. Not great but not bad.

He spends multiple weeks on the same material, and makes the same points over again.BORING. You have to read the book and pay attention in class or you'll be in for a rude surprise come exam time. The work load is very light and not challenging, but the class is astoundingly terrible. If you can stay awake the whole time, pat yourself on the back.

yeah, the class was kinda boring. but i thought the homework assignments were really fun! we got to pick ads out of magazines relating to what we were learning in class. tests were easy if you just studied a little.

Cool guy but the class is pretty complicated. No assignments except for one monster paper at the end. Attendance is not mandatory but will notice and not like you if you blow off the class. Grades basically on if he likes you or not.
Going to class is pointless.  Just read the book and you'll be totally fine.  He rambles on and on and doesn't say anything actually useful.
Rambles and explains things over and over again that are rather easy to understand. Read the book and take the mock quizes and you'll be more than fine.

He is way to old to be teaching. Runs out of breath all the time and says "um" a lot. Gives a lot of homework but spends the entire day when it is due going over it so you can do most of it in class. He rambles on and on about nothing important. Read the book and do the homework and you'll be fine for the tests.

Stay away if you can. Extremely boring and slow-paced, and often  doesn't know what's on his own slides and strangely for an advertising professor often doesn't understand very obvious ads. Books are boring, assignments are stupid and time-consuming, tests can be a little tricky.

I was really excited for this class at the beginning of the semester, but GAHHHHHH it's SOOOOO BORING!!!!!  A lot of what he teaches is so obvious that it makes you feel like you're wasting your time being there.  He also likes to ramble.
Made the advertising class a lot of fun!  and Easy!
meh. not impressed
boring, but very nice man.
Very easy class, but he's soooo boring
Greg is the funniest, nicest guy.  He knows his **** well and basically makes TV class a pleasure.
He sucked the life out of my Advertising class.
She is absent-minded and a terrible professor. She grades completely arbitrarily. Avoid her if possible

this professor is crazy in an engaging way. she is very helpful in assisting you to learn the language, especially grammatically. In class, there is always a conversation going (in spanish of course) and she makes it really easy to understand and follow. Note: knowing a decent amount of spanish makes this class ideal

Definitely an interesting professor. Try to get on her good side, participate whenever possible, and go to her office hours. Go see her after an exam to go over it, she'll even give back a few points if you do. She seems to give whatever grade she feels like at the end, but if you work hard and try to participate, you'll receive a decent grade.

Prof Kouroublakis puts a lot of effort into her teaching. she expects her students to participate in class discussion, but does not require them to speak well. she's big into helping students become more fluent and better gramatically in speech. Plus, some of those outfits really show off her curves...

She can be intimidating to some people.  She's a great person, but a demanding teacher.  She doesn't admit her mistakes and puts you on the spot, but her emphasis on speaking helps to immerse  you in the language in the beginning levels which is a great preparation for intermediate spanish.  I would recommend sticking it out, it's worth it.

Moods change randomly. Never answers questions clearly. Sometimes contradicts herself. Tests are fair and homework is easy, but papers are graded arbitrarily. Your paper could be perfect, but she'll give you a B if she would rather have had you write about something different. I'd recommend knowing some spanish before you take her class.
No Comments

The woman is nuts. Always shouting at us and getting angry for no reason. She often used vocab that we had not learned and which was not in the textbook on tests, almost never gave clear answers to students' questions , and never acknowledged or apologized for her many mistakes. I wanted to learn spanish but she made it not worth it.

She told me she thought I had a learning disability and should come in for extra help if I ever took a class with her again.  One day she started asking for vocab from a higher level Spanish and got angry at us for not knowing the answers.  When she realized her mistake she never apologized.  She got angry and yelled at our class every day.
Mostly speaks in class, involves no writing. Dialogue emphasized. Tests are fair and homework is not bad. I'd recommend people to know some spanish basics before taking her.
