A puzzling woman at times, subject to sudden changes of mood.  Some people find that intimidating.  Her expectations are not always clear but you get used to that.
do not take this

She is great at just immersing you with the language in this beginning class.  She tries not to speak in English too much.  She's very funny and energetic.  Her tests are repetitive, and she wants you to write a lot to show her how much you know.  Otherwise she will write all over your papers.
any language class will be difficult. She makes sure there's lots of class discussion, but thats tough too.  Her tests were difficult. She's quite animated though
condescending

Very nice person, cares for students, and gives LOTS of extra credit. I had over a 101% in the class before the final project. Final project is difficult, focus on something simple, but do it according to the process. He did seem very overwhelmed though and it hurt the class, since he was disorganized, probably cause he didn't have much time.
He defines awesomeness.

I loved the way Prof. Hoque was able to relate the materials to real-world scenarios. The guests lectures were very helpful to make the connection. Cranking up the prerequisite so that students with solid programming and research focus could only take this class will help. Otherwise, you are bound to see a bi-modal distribution in the feedback.
Prof. Hoque is a great teacher and genuinely cares for the students. Anyone who gives you him a bad review clearly did not enjoy being put on the spot in the class or was just hoping for an easy A.

HCI class has historically been a very easy class. A lot of students including myself took this class with that pretense and it backfired. On the bright side, I appreciated the way Prof. Hoque always responded to the anonymous feedback. He likes to  randomly check on people in the class; so you gotta always pay attention.

He is probably the worst professor I've ever had from the CS department. He is extremely condescending and has ridiculous expectations. He basically never taught anything in lecture-just talked about his research or brought in guests. The projects also took over my life, and I wasn't even rewarded for it.

Hoque was a new professor and he taught this course for the first time here. He pushed the TAs and the students to work really hard. He graded based on his personal preference on your projects, no matter how hard you worked. Plus, you need to warm up yourself with the skills to be used in the projects. Watch out!

The course was interesting at the first glance, but I quickly got bored after two weeks. Prof. Hoque taught superficial stuff in class, and simply by asking students a question and asking another to repeat what the previous one's answer was insufficient to draw the audience attention back from facebook, youtube, and games to the class.

This class ended up being lot more work than what I had anticipated. But the final project was a lot of fun, and Prof. Hoque is an entertaining lecturer. I personally loved the guest lecturers as our final project was inspired by one of them. If you know how to code/build, you would love this class.

The class topic wasn't HCI, most lectures were irrelevant "guest lectures," and you were basically graded on how good a project you could make with skills you were already expected to have, not taught. He told us on the first day no web programming skill was required, then told us 2 months in to drop the class if we didn't have extensive experience
I took his HCI class which is the first he's taught. Prof. Hoque is a great professor and will be great to have in the university. He really cares about his students
Prof. Hoque is new at the UofR, and very obsessed about his new class. I think he put a lot of effort in teaching HCI, CSC212.
The class was very unorganized and the processor is extremely condescending. I do not recommend taking courses with this Prof Hoque.

Honestly, Dr. Rich's lectures are not engaging at all, he just reads off of outdated slides I don't think he even made himself. Tests (only 2) are pretty easy if you just memorize info from the slides. Pop quizzes are graded on completion, so show up to lecture. Didn't really learn anything long-term, but if you just do your work it isn't a hard A.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: PHLT 103 was a snoozefest. Rich mainly reads off his slides or speaker notes. I felt as though I learned nothing of importance in epidemiology. Adding on, I wish the grading criteria were more lenient. If you lose 1 point on your homework, your overall grade goes down by 1%. My TA graded my homeworkers harshly, so be aware of the grading system!!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Boring lectures (made me hate epidemiology even tho it's my major). Lots of pop quizzes. HWs took really long and TAs grade so harshly. Tests are just the slides so just memorize those (if you can memorize 60 slides for every lecture lol). He barely shows up to class; the entirety of December was just guest lecturers/recorded lectures.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Rich was near impossible to reach outside of classroom hours. He would take days, if not weeks, to respond to my emails, and even then was very difficult to schedule with. To be honest, he made me disinterested in epidemiology.

Dr. Rich's lectures can be somewhat boring, but some of the guest lecturers are pretty interesting. Although there was a textbook, all the test material is from information from the slides so you don't really need the textbook. Know the definitions of different terms for the exams.

Dr. Rich is a good person, but his lectures were somewhat boring. I think this might just be because epidemiology as a whole isn't the most exciting. Try and memorize the slides he presents in lecture, since the exams mimic these slides. I purchased a textbook for this class but never used it and did fine, so I would recommend going without one.

If you do not have interest in epidemiology, you will find this class very boring. Dr. Rich just reads exactly what are on the lecture slides and adds nothing else. The guest lectures are interesting. One midterm and final which are multiple choice and are easy if you memorize the important concepts. Homework isn't hard, but tedious.

Professor Rich speaks in a monotone voice and his lectures are very boring. The course is difficult because we are given no study material except for the slides and pop quizzes. 60% of your grade is from two exams so you must do well. If you are good at memorizing and teaching yourself concepts, you'll be fine. Otherwise, this course will be hard.

Professor Rich does not care about his students and reads off the slides which is not helpful. He does not try to make the class easier and the exams are difficult. Every class consists of around 60 slides that need to be memorized for the exams. He holds his office hours off campus which is not useful for students.

I thought I was gonna like Public Health but I was wrong. This man is boring as hell, I don't pay 80k for a slide reader. His guest lecturers he hires while he is on vacation in Europe are somewhat better than him. There are only a midterm and final which determine your grade. If you are actually interested sure take this, otherwise don't bother.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Test heavy

comment: This class may be easy if you have an interest for epidemiology, however I would not recommend taking this class if it is your first time doing public health.Professor Rich constantly reads off his power point slides during classtime, and his voice is rather monotonous, which may make it hard to pay attention. He only gives one midterm, so do well!
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: good lecturer, not too boring that youd fall asleep in and stays on track. Always willing to help students and answer questions/emails. Class is pretty basic, not very hard content, but there is a lot to memorize. Textbook is nice but not necessary, 99% of the exam is covered in lecture slides. Stay on top of hw and pop quizzes, will be a breeze
Honestly the reason I am going to study Epidemiology. A really kind, down-to-Earth professor. Just go to lecture and take notes and you will be good to go!
Very nice and accessible professor who really knows his stuff. You do need to study for his class (he gives pop quizzes) and homework grades are somewhat dependent on your TA.
A really nice professor! She is willing to answer questions and offer additional help after class. She made me think about the Enlightenment period more critically.

Incredible thinker about the Enlightenment. Her class opened up new ways of seeing the period that I never even considered before. There was a good amount of writing, but it really forced me to think about the assignments. Overall a great course and instructor.

Excellent teacher. She really forces you to think about the assigned readings. Her feedback on papers could be a little more helpful, but I think this is just because of her bad handwriting. She is very helpful/insightful one on one. Again, excellent prof
No Comments
She is a riot, but the class I took was a bit like a tour of a museum of exploration.

Not that bad if you are ok with awkward silences. Heavier on the reading, and you need to do it. Fairly easy grader, and as a writing class I dont think one 10 page paper and another 20 page paper is unreasonable. They were double spaced. She knows her subject and is good on answering questions
The only redeeming factor of this "seminar" is that you don't have to attend to get an A.

Relatively easy professor, as long as you attend class everyday and do ALL the work (LONG reading assignments, 15pg single spaced papers, etc) Absolutely does not like people who skip class. Also expects students to do some outside research on reading assignments without being asked. Once you figure out what she wants, her course is fairly easy.

her class is ok, biggest peeve is her ridiculous assignments, like 14 pgers and 20 pgers single spaced.AND lots of reading. Otherwise though, she is a nice lady, although i've heard from other people she can be terribly sarcastic.
I get pretty much nothing out of this class, except what's in the readings.  The books she chooses are boring and fairly irrelevant, and the class discussion seems wandering.
Talk about needing to get out of the past
No Comments
Good professor, professional
Horrible teacher, needs to defleat her ego

I am not a fan of Dr. Fu. He absolutely hates being told he's wrong. He made an unfair policy about dropping an exam that was incredibly unfair to most of the students and even though multiple students talked to him he was extremely condescending and rude. He's probably one of the rudest professors I've ever had.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: I liked this class because I learned a lot, and the exams required high level thinking not just memorization. I actually learned a lot during the exams because it was open note. I definitely would read the textbook thoroughly if it is not open note.

Absolutely loved having Dr. Fu as a professor! He's good at explaining the content and seems to genuinely care about the students. Super organized and friendly. The content itself is not easy though, definitely need to study hard.

I liked his teaching style and he was a good lecturer. You will learn a lot about biochem from taking this course. In order to be in the A range, you need to be 1 full standard deviation above the mean for all exams. Meaning, only about a third of the class is getting an A- or higher. Your grade should not be determined by how others perform.
Hard class, but very fair. The professor is very likable and clearly cares a lot about the students and the class.

Bio 250: biochemistry is a famously tough yet mandatory course for students who will major in biological sciences. Dr. Fu's exams are very hard (except the first exam). He is expecting you to understand and memorize every single detail of every biochemical pathway (e.g. all the reactions and structures in TCA cycle). Yet he is a good lecturer.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: The class was very tough due to the sheer amount of material covered, but Dr. Fu is excellent at teaching and helping students to understand what hes talking about no matter how you learn best. Lots of examples and graphics. Powerpoints were super helpful.

Dr. Fu is very knowledgable and passionate about biochemistry. He does test a lot of stuff on the book, so keep up the reading may be a good idea. Also, his lecture is not very well organized, so your book is very helpful to really understand the material. Once you fully understand, the test doesn't seem so long anymore!

I really enjoyed Dr. Fu's teaching style -- he explained concepts at a nice pace and was easily understandable. I stayed away from his office hours because of these ratings, but I haven't personally heard that he was rude. From recorded office hours he seemed fine. Biochem is a tough subject regardless, but definitely manageable with Fu's style.

He is super stubborn. He will never admit when he makes mistakes in lectures or words his exam questions poorly, which happens often. He seems to care little about his students succeeding and is very condescending. There's a reason why everyone has painful memories from this class, and I don't think it is the content (although it is difficult).
Dude is scary when it comes to students asking questions Also his tests are obnoxiously worded

Dr. Fu is an excellent lecturer, but he is extremely rude when students ask him questions one-on-one. I don't recommend asking him questions, you're better off asking your TA or other students. The class is hard but doable if you put the time in.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: such a hard class. Not only is Fu a harsh grader, but his tests are next to impossible and he has little to no accessibility outside of class because he simply does not care for his students and their understanding of the material.

New professor. He's cool and I thought his lectures were clear. But the class is hard and you can lose a ton of points on the exams. Curved nicely though.  He tries to help. He provides study guides and highlights what you need to know. Textbook is highly important though!!!  A lot of people cried about him, but the topic is difficult not art 101.

wow, I thought I would be getting a great teacher with all the other posts, but she is very very arrogant and rude to students and really doesnt care much about you.  Your work will always be a B at best no matter how hard you try.  Arrogant, arrogant human being and I would suggest against her class.  I will not be taking any more classes with her
Best professor I had
Professor Parthe is prominent in her field and very helpful. Papers can be a bit tedious, but if you do them and participate in class you should do fine

Easy grader, allows rewrites of papers, and the essay prompts are straight from the readings/class discussions. She is fairly interesting and her discussions are fun.  I liked the class and I would love to take another class with her again.
Just go to class, easy grader, hand it in...get an A.  Not hard as long as you put in a tiny bit of effort.  She doesn't like people who pretend they read the book or don't show up.

I think most people like her because she's an easy grader. She's certainly a knowledgable person, but class time is usually not productive and you learn everything you'll ever need by reading the books.
Very intelligent, lenient about deadlines for papers, grades fairly easy, can be very funny, prominent in her field
She is so nice, and makes class fun. She is so helpful to all her students and knows what she is talking about.
Easy Prof...easy A

A lovely woman who would go to great lengths to help any of her students.  She gave me one of the greatest recommendations I've ever read, and I'm not well qualified!  She knows so much, and is really really passionate about her work.  Take her class
Amazing teacher. incredibly knowledgable and interested in what she teaches.
great teacher
she is so nice and has a wry sense of humor that makes class fun. she is very lenient too. the only teacher who i was willing to take two 3 hour classes with
Parthe is really smart and funny.  She makes Russian current events pretty interesting.

The class was standard, but my experience in Dr. Lalor's lab was intimidating. There was a noticeable bullying dynamic, and if you didn't fit in, you were excluded. Instructions were unclear, and core members were often unavailable or unfriendly, making tasks feel impossible. When I struggled, I was made to feel incompetent.
I like him so much, just simply did not do well in his class.

Lalor is a great professor. Very caring and understanding towards his students. Material is pretty tough especially if you're not into circuits. Make sure you don't fall behind as this class moves fast and it builds off of previous lectures. One of the best professors at UofR imo.
Professor is really nice and understanding. Make sure you don't fall behind bc the material piles up real quick.

lovely man. subject is tough if you don't like circuits and if you're a bad test taker. he is really willing to help students out and genuinely cares about students success -- great professor overall.
He explains material well and his class is really interesting. Hes my favorite professor here at U of R! Big recommend.

Very good class. BME 210 is great for biomedical engineers. The course is rock solid, prepare to learn a lot of things. Lalor is great at teaching and a very chill dude. Exams are tough, especially the final. If you study, you will do well. The course picks up a lot during the last month, so prepare.
Pretty chill professor and always available for help. DON'T SKIP CLASS. Before exams, do as many book questions as you can then do more.
Prof Lalor is great. A good communicator and very responsive to questions and requests for help. Cares a lot about the students.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: He literally doesn't know how to teach properly, just copying down the textbook. Just read the textbook and you will be fine.
This man is God.
I believe that thanks to him I have a stronger interest in the course material
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Prof Lalor 's lectures arent the best, the amount of math in this course is hard to demonstrate in real time so he just took slides from the book, BUT thats because the book is amazing. Read the book and pay moderate attention and you'll do good. He's great to talk to outside of class and clearly wants to help students any. Great listener.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: Lalor is the man. Class isn't that difficult, but the homework is long as well as the final.

I had Professor Clatterbuck at UW Madison and she was phenomenal. She gives amazing lectures and tries to involve students as much as possible. Even if you're new, she makes philosophy interesting and understandable. There is a reading due before each class. The essays can be tricky. There is a mid-term and a final, but they're not too rigorous.

She teaches at UW Madison now - but 4 papers, 2 exams, 20% participation - overall very manageable class with some pretty interesting concepts. Hayley is extremely funny and relatable, she's a great professor and this is a good humanities class I would recommend.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: She is very good at keeping the lecture interesting. Discussion in class is possible, but she is great at keeping it minimal if needed. If no one wants to answer/has an answer, the lecture still moves on at a great pace. She makes the topics interesting and is very knowledgeable. Oh and btw, she is a professor at UW Madison, so that needs changed.

Professor Clatterbuck is one of the best, if not the best professor I have ever had. Her lectures are fantastic, she engages the class well and mixes sociability with professionalism and learning. Make sure to know the residence time of a water molecule in Lake Mendota, as well as the average time it takes for an undergraduate to get their degree.

Even if you don't think Philosophy is your thing you'll enjoy it with Hayley. Super fun and interesting lectures and you can tell her and her TA Hadley care about you and your performance. I didn't do any of the readings because she covers all the material in lecture. 4 papers, 2 exams, and credit for participation and attendance. Must take.

I LOVE Prof. Clatterbuck. She is young and engaging and makes the material easier to understand. I didn't ANY of the readings, and I still did well in papers and exams. Just show up (she takes attendance) and pay attention and take notes. You'll be fine, and even if Philosophy isn't your thing, it's still pretty interesting.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: good

If you are a student at University of Rochester and you are, even remotely interested in Philosophy and you don't take at least one class with Hayley Clatterbuck; well, you have wasted your time! Lectures are great, readings are chosen very carefully, she gives clear and helpful feedback and there are plenty of class discussions.
Great professor all around
Amazing professor. Super good at explaining concepts.
Dr. clatterbuck leads good discussions and is very nice. Homeworks are problem sets and tests are short-answer

Dr. Clatterbuck is a rock star. Engages class in meaningful discussion, very respectful of opinions, and always available to discuss topics. Class consists of small writing assignments, two essays, and two exams. If you do the reading you will be fine.
Professor Clatterbuck is great and Philosophy of Mind is a really useful class. As a CS major with an interest in AI, I found this class particularly useful and interesting.
Professor Clatterbuck is very smart and an awesome professor. She is chill but also knows her stuff. The class is very manageable if you just attend lecture and do your work.

All around great professor. Really good at what he does, and his passion for biomedical engineering really rubs off on his students. He is the only professor that teachers BME101 so first-year BME students do not have a choice but to have him, but he is such an awesome teacher that I would not have it any other way.
He is a nice person, though the assignments are a lot and he really cares about the sig fig. Also, the criteria are vague so you won't get detailed feedback on your final grade.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Great Professor, take the time to do the homework and attend office hours. Go the extra mile to make sure all instructions are followed (i.e. pay attention to sig figs/boxing answers/etc.) ASK QUESTIONS IN CLASS!! Dr. Brown responds to emails so don't be afraid to reach out.

Dr. Brown is a great professor and a great person. I really enjoyed this class. If you want to succeed in this class, GO TO OFFICE HOURS! There is homework every week graded on accuracy. Its a tough class and you need to put in the work
love him but also hate him. You will never know your grade until the last moment

A lot of people struggle with BME101 and here's why: nobody expects that it will be hard so people go in thinking they can barely study and be fine. The average for the first exam was 35/78. The exam time is just 50 minutes, so don't expect to finish, it's okay. The average of the class is weighted to a B-, so just hope you are above the average.

Clearly passionate about the subject, but not great at explaining topics. Makes the course frustrating if you haven't taken physics courses before. He instructed the TAs to grade more harshly midway through the semester because he wanted a "wider spread of grades". Overall felt like a weeder course for BME students. Interesting material though.

Dr. Brown was very understanding and always willing to help his students. The class is tough but if you put in the work and use the TAs office hours, you will be ok. Put a lot of effort into the homeworks because they are worth a lot. Brown is a funny guy and his class is enjoyable too.

Not an easy A, probably because this is not an easy major. Professor Brown is so funny and gets the material across, but ultimately it is up to you to do well. The readings are helpful to do before class and a lot of material comes from them. I had fun though and would definitely take him again.

Focuses in class on the math parts of the class, but you need to read BOTH textbooks for the homeworks and labs. Homeworks are pretty hard and the TAs are useless, but the prof is great. Charismatic and you can tell he genuinely cares about what he's teaching. If you can, get on his good side and get a letter of recommendation from him.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: The tests in this class are brutal. Nothing like the practice ones that are posted. They are also in class so you have very little time to finish. He's a nice guy and an interesting lecturer, but this is a very hard class. There's a reason lots of BME students switch majors.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Dr. Brown's BME 101 is a very physics heavy course. Homework is heavy but managable with good planning. Put effort into the HW because it prepares you very well for the exams. THE EXAMS ARE TIME INTENSIVE, RUSH THROUGH THE QUESTIONS AS FAST AS POSSIBLE. You are not expected to finish every question, get as many points as fast as you possibly can.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Dr. Brown, who most BME students will take for BME 101, is an absolute gem of the university. I strongly recommend that you take his Biomedical Microscopy course, BME 270. He takes the class seriously, because it is his passion, and that passion bleeds through every lecture and activity he prepares for the class. Take this course.

Dr Brown is the most energetic teddy bear. He makes any topic fun and interesting because he is clearly so passionate. He is a bit all over the place so it is hard to know what to expect from homeworks and tests, but you will understand the concepts.
The course was hard but a lot of fun!

Great lectures and slides, tests are extremely difficult and make up a lot of the grade. Projects are also very challenging. I was a bit intimated by him at first, but he is quite nice in office hours. Project grading took a while but that is more so a TA thing.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment:
He does not know how to teach at all.

AND THE TWO GRADUATE TA SUCK. I doubt they understand any of the material and grade your exams just by mood.
Horribly irresponsible! He tries to pretend that he cares about the students but actually doesn't at all and don't expect him to reply to your emails :( This whole class does not even make any sense.
He encourages you to reach out to him if you have any questions. However, he did not reply any of my email throughout the semester.

The class materials are so beneficial and he is good at teaching I enjoyed the class a lot. But grading is horrible. Exams are super hard. Assignments are so so hard and you need to study on your own to do them the class materials do not help a lot with assignments. And yet he does not curve the class. I hate his grading criteria but good teacher.
Got above average grades on both my midterm and final and an A average on my projects but got a c+ in the class because he didnt curve the class at all.

Professor Zhu is easily my favorite professor in the CS department. His lecture style is very detailed and manageable, the projects (homework) are difficult but well-designed as they are from the textbook. Does a good job of making computer architecture very accessible. Start projects early, go to class and you'll do great. A really nice guy, too.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Great prof. Class is hard but it's a hard topic. Lectures are dense but good. If you can pay attention through lectures and start the projects early, you'll be alright. Really nice guy too.
Prof Zhu is great! His lectures are clear even though he covers a lot of material, and he's very nice if you reach out. Definitely a hard class though. Start the projects early.

The course is very difficult. You will have to work hard to keep up. However, Zhu's lectures are extremely comprehensive. He makes extremely complex concepts easier to follow. The projects are hard as hell, but if you utilize the TAs and start early, you will be fine. (Take CSC172 and MTH150 first!!)
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: Computer architecture is a difficult subject but the professor is really good at explaining the concepts both structurally and in details. Very organized lectures and if attending class consistently you dont even need to read the textbook

Trust me, the material covered in this course is very interesting but the problem is with the instructor. He doesn't care at all whether or not the students understand concepts and just rushes through the lecture. He is extremely bad at explaining and answering questions and makes extremely hard exams without providing enough practice material.

He is a horrible lecturer and is terrible at explaining concepts. You learn more by reading the book than attending the classes. In fact, attending the lectures would confuse you more. Also, he is extremely condescending and does not help a lot during office hours. Try to take this class with a different professor in the Fall.

Yuhao's lectures often lack some in depth explanation... students often have to ask questions to get the 'why?' behind most of the course material. But, nonetheless, Yuhao is a down to earth, pretty memey guy who I would certainly choose again.

Genuinely the worst professor I've had. Extremely hard to get in contact with bc she changes her office hours without warning and neglects her emails. Gives quizzes with little explanation of their contents. Instructions for project were unclear and she neglected to give us needed material. Takes weeks or months to enter grades for each assignment.

Straight up horrible. Gave us an extremely hard project with confusing instructions and no rubric. Criticized us in front of our entire lab about not having things in our project, yet she didn't tell us we needed that in our project. Took 2 months for her to grade our midterm #1 because her computer got "hacked". Would make students cry.

Overall, she's absolutely dreadful. Every email she sends gives me unnecessary anxiety because it's something new we were supposed to know but didn't, and it's sent way too late. Her assignments and quizzes are stupid hard and is too much for a 2-credit class. Disappointment.

She assigns projects that are worth 20% of our grade as if they came up to her in a dream. She plans as she goes, which stresses us out even more because she will email new pieces of information that are critical to finishing the project less than a week before it's due, and then will take her frustration out on us with her attitude.

She's as unavailable as my dad, but will pretend that she isn't and will turn it around on us when we struggle. Everyone emails her with questions. She probably deletes them to complain that she gets no emails to play the victim. She also will hold office hours, but the majority of the time is spent trying to figure out why her door is locked.

She is genuinely the most uninformative and last-minute professor on the planet. She attempts to teach, but the slides she posts, if she posts, are empty, and we all end up learning a grand total of nothing. With this knowledge of nothing she has bestowed upon us, she gives out quizzes that expect us to read her mind or think like MATLAB. (1)
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: bad professor, doesnt know how to teach and barely was able to give e us the stuffs
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: for BME 201P: impossible to pass any quiz or exam unless you can read her mind to tell what she's grading on. does not take feedback. doesn't release assignment grades until months later so you have no clue how you're doing in the class. doesn't respond to emails or show up to class.

Dr. Ganeshan was okay when it came to explaining concepts when they were first introduced, but if you forgot something a week later, she would look at and talk to you like you were stupid. She treated the material as if it was common knowledge for everyone after we had just learned it for the first time.

Horrible teacher with an insane amount of course load. Following the instructions on the lab report gets you a 70. Lab reports are long and irrelevant. She prepares you to join her life mission to stay in a lab and replicate smarter people's discoveries and basing your entire career on it. Be prepared to hate BME to the guts after this class.

Hands down one of my least favorite professors. Labs are a ridiculous amount of work for no reason but have little to no purpose. Barely teaches you anything, and often expects for you to know exactly what you are doing. Instructions for labs are often unclear, so you do not know whether or not you are doing the correct thing.

Veena was my instructor in the Signals class. She was very approachable when I needed her help with the writing part which is the difficult part of the course. She was good about giving clear feedback on reports. My first graded report was hard to accept but after the second one I saw how much I improved as a writer.

Veena Ganeshan is a professor for the super hard Circuits class. It is always hard to understand the lab since it is so much ahead of the class. Veena helped me on so many occasions when I was having trouble and guided me through each step. We had a full class but she still gave me the time I needed for each question.
She doesn't help students and if you ask her a question she will berate you instead of actually helping. She also doesn't respect social distancing and gets within 6 feet of you.
Unclear grading. Get marked down for things she never asked for to begin with and were never in the assignment. Posts things late and then expects you to get them done in the same amount of time.

Veena is the lab administrator for a few BME courses and is just plainly a bad teacher. She offers very, very unclear instructions and if the equipment is faulty during lab, instead of helping you fix it, blames you for not knowing what to do (even if she also does not know how to fix it). Just the worst teacher I've ever had, avoid if possible.
I took the BUS389 class. He is brilliant and gives me lots of useful advice for me about business research. For STR203, I admitted it is hard and heavy load.
Very good professor, definitely deserves higher scores than this
This professor is awful.

AVOID HIIM IF U CAN. He is the worst kind of professor who is very very imperious and careless. He doesnt care about how students really think of (ofc he would pretend he does) and then disagrees with you bc what he thinks is always right. His exam is horrible. DONT TAKE HIS CLASS MY FRIENDS

If you want to feel violated and offended, then this Professor is your go-to guy. He is rude, loves to put down other peoples opinions, and is extremely disorganized with communication. For a Professor of so many years, I was expecting professionalism and better organizational skills...

If youre a future student and youve stumbled across this Profs page, please just do yourself a giant favor and take this class with another Prof. If I could, I would rate him a 0. This guy has zero compassions for his students and is probably one of the most disrespectful Professors at this university.
He does not respect his students nor care about our learning. If you challenge his opinions, then you are wrong, so be prepared to be wrong. I do not recommend

He says your opinion is wrong even if you have a thought out argument supported by evidence. He disrespectfully cuts off students mid-sentence and attacks any opinions with which he disagrees. He grades exams harshly, gives no feedback, then assumes students with bad grades didn't try or care. He berated my writing skills for the 1st 5 min of class
Worst professor ever. He shows no respect for students' opinions. Super stubborn. Grading is unclear, you would never understand why you get a bad grade

This guy is straight up full of himself and keeps using ancient strategic principles at times which are not completely valid, and if you say that, he wont listen. Do not take his class. Go for Raiths class over his. I swear you will pay me if you find out my name and thank me that I made you avoid him.

Schmidt is the worst Prof. I have ever had. The Prof. is rude and full of himself. His opinion is the only thing that matters during discussions and tests. Challenge his ideas and you are wrong. His use of the Socratic method is flawed too. If you say something he disagrees with during discussions he cuts you off. Avoid him at all costs.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Struggled early on, but kept asking for help and explanations which Ron was happy to give. Be ready to work for your grade because he makes you earn it. Topics are a little dry, but he tries to use good examples to engage you and make it a little less boring. Don't avoid him because of things you've heard. You'll be happy you took the class later.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Simply awful course.  Teaching technique is absurd.
Very boring class.... loves to cold call and talk about stuff thats very irrelevant to the course.
I could have done a lot better. The class was not too difficult when you include how massive of a curve there was. He's a good lecturer.

The class is really hard with heavy class notes. Tests are 85% of the grades, and the class note is not assembled with the lecture slides he posts. Attendance is not required but if you miss one class is hard to catch up. His office hour is not helpful, but he has responsible TAs. If you think you are smart enough then you can take this class.
Dude's a genius, probably the best professor in the ECON department.
very prestigious and knowledgeable professor
You will realize how amazing and well-organized his lectures are when you go to a grad school. Excellent professor!
If you miss one lecture you will be lost for the rest of the semester.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Asen has method of lecturing that is very easy to follow, which is useful for a class that can get very dense at times. He will spend more time on certain topics of he sees that the class hasnt grasped the concepts. He makes his notes available, and they are clear and organized. Overall amazing professor.

Prof Kochov is a cool guy. His classes are interesting. This was a new class, and wow did he impress. His lecture notes are amazing, well organized and clear. No textbook, because there is no textbook for this subject of economics. He made his own course out of nothing and deserves serious credit. Innovative! Take him, accommodating and reasonable!
Very clear lecturer with a sense of humor
He's great!

Very passionate about the topic and an engaging lecturer. He posts his own notes online which are very helpful for doing homework problems and reviewing for exams. It's a very interesting topic, but I definitely had to work for my grade. However, it's been the most rewarding ECO class I've ever taken. Would definitely recommend.

The class is mind-blowing, but can be very hard, especially if you don't know multivariable calculus. (Not too hard to pick up if you know univariable calculus.) I thought this was just going to be applied psych; it's not, it's like advanced micro. A grad student suspects Asen will get picked up by Harvard; I can see why.
I like him, really interesting. Tests/homeworks fair enough.

He loves what he is teaching, but since he is new it is sometimes hard to follow but the hw's and tests are very fair and the material interesting, although not easy. This is not a blow off class. Would recommend!
He is the best professor I have ever had at the University of Rochester. He inspired me to major in philosophy.
Extremely approachable and I willing to help every student out to his best ability. It's been a great semester!!
He is the teacher you want for EVERY class. What a great guy and a great teacher! Extremely helpful and very approachable.

Jeff Glick is the man! I had him for ethics and introductory logic. His enthusiasm for teaching and willingness to help are outstanding. If you attend class (which I'd bet you'll actually want to attend his classes), you will not need to do much additional work to get an A. The textbooks are both cheap and are used a decent amount.

He's very engaging with the material and current day. Best philosophy professor i've encountered so far. In a semi large class, he still gives detailed feedback on every paper.  He's very dedicated to teaching students.

Glick is a really nice person and is always willing to help a student with things that aren't understood in class. There are a few intersting topics in this course. If you are really intersted in philosophy, he is a great professor to learn from.
Unbelievable. Amazing. Hands down best professor that I have had.
Great professor.  Makes class fun and interesting, good at explaining hard stuff.  If you work hard in this class you can do really good but if you don't its pretty hard.

Jeff Glick is the man. In my opinion he is the best professor in the philosophy department at UR so far. He knows his stuff and knows how to convey it to students in ways that he does not come off as "arrogant" or stuck up like many others. He is very kind and will go out of his way to help you understand the material. Take a class with him.

god bless this guy, he is so charismatic, he is even theatrical, but i wish he gave himself more respect, and acted like a professor, i mean i wish he were more cocky, cos he could be, i mean, this guy is great, bless his soul, he should also dress more like a professor, give more of a professor aura... i love him though
He is a great professor. He is very fun and makes it as interesting as he can. I would highly recommend taking a class of his.
Very helpful and easy to understand. Take his classes!

Jeff is a smart engaging guy, he knows a lot about the subject and is always willing to go back and do something over and over until everyone gets it.  The class moves slowly because of this, so if logic comes naturally to you you may find the class boring.

ECE 101 is not an introduction course even though it is presented as one. As a first time coder, this was not a good class to take and, although I learned some things, I would not recommend taking this course. It isn't required for the major, and it isn't a good class for beginners.

The guy on his own is a nice guy but GOD, his lectures are so boring. The course itself is pretty fast-paced and if you fall behind, it might be hard to get back on track. The programming portion of the course was horrendous, one had to learn the syntax and stuff all on his own. He wants you to succeed but his way of doing it gets you to do work.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: Professor himself gives decent lectures. Lot's of opportunities to participate and be engaged but you don't have to. Office hours are very helpful for specific problems or extra help. Actually listens to student feedback.
Just great professor.
You should see him at his office hours more, he really wants to make sure you get the idea and he helps you out a lot in those hours more.

ECE101 Fall '14. Huang is an extremely intelligent professor and truly wants you to learn. He encourages questions and doesnt rely on tests to evaluate you. He is more concerned that you understand the material. He is ALWAYS there to help. At times he isnt 100% clear in lecture, but makes up for it in office hours and by encouraging learning.
For the first time ECE101 was a course Huang was great at adapting to what the class was capable of. He's extremely smart and wants you to understand the material.
Absolutely the best professor I've had in ECE. Nicest guy and best class. Pay attention in lecture and your labs are easy. VERY ORGANIZED
mean as hell about late homework

Huang is very prepared for lecture and makes them as comprehensible as possible. If you don't understand something he spends the time to answer questions thoroughly. He's also very organized and accommodates to the pace of the class. ECE 114 itself was largely lab based. Grading was generous. Overall, one of my favorite professors.
No Comments

Huang is a great professor all around.  He puts a lot of work into his lectures and if you pay attention in class its easy to understand whats going on.  Extremely helpful and very easy to find/contact.  Make sure you keep up with the labs.  Huang is very lenient about late work but if you don't get labs in on time you fall behind VERY quickly.

This teacher truly knows his C++ and does a great job teaching it.  He understands that in an intro course in C++ he has to at least introduce data structures by the end. This by nature creates an intensive course. He makes up for this by having extrememly easy grading that anyone can get an A with. Lab intensive, most points are from labs. Niceman

The goat. Lectures are awesome and he gives great insight. Does a great job of making you think and keeping you engaged with the topic. Was always helpful with feedback on papers and wasn't heavy on the workload. Take his class.
Awesome guy, very helpful, very smart. Willing to take time out for students despite being busy. Kind of hard to do well, but if you work for it, it's doable.
A tough grader, grading can be somewhat arbitrary, doesn't give too much work, good guy.

Honestly this is probably the worst Philosophy class I have ever taken.  He basically teaches straight from his own book that is the worst sort of philosophy.  He fits the traditional old professor and thinks that because he says/writes things they HAVE to be true.  If you can smile at someone and pretend to agree with them then you will be ok.
awesome. so interesting. way better in small seminar class that in lecture classes. very smart, very helpful

The class is a joke.  He teaches from his own book, which is about the most petty kind of "philsophy." Be prepared to spend a semester trying not to laugh while he debates semantics at the most meaningless level.
Very good professor
Great professor. Teaches students to think rather than teaching a particular interpretation of a branch of philosophy.
He is easy when you work hard, but if you miss a class and don't understand lectures it's hard to catch up

Great Professor, Lovely person. very warm and helpful. Interesting class and topics. Yes, HIghly reccomended for people that like to think. Doesn't go into as much detail in the 100 level class though
No Comments
No Comments
Very fair, excellent skills and methods. Highly recommended

Grades harshly on papers. This class has group projects, so try to make sure the people you are working with know what they are responsible for. Participation really matters, but you can post on the discussion boards online if you don't talk in class. It's not a hard class. You just have to put the effort in. Lecture can be slow and boring though.
Very understanding
Be sure to participate.

Besides my final, I lost the most points for participation, so highly recommend reading/skimming the texts before coming to class and thinking of at least one thing to say. The TA this semester was a godsend, so talk to them. Public health ethics is especially relevant now, so the course content was really interesting.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This class at the face appeared like your typical public health class, but he and the grad TA graded so harshly with little to no feedback on the few assignments that contributed to our grade. Even then so, he never expanded on the moral theories or ethics we discussed but expected us to in presentations and papers.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Classes are philosophical arguments, invigorating if everyone's done the reading, but he's not great at facilitating when there's a lull. Dees is critical, but dedicates a lot of time to going over essays and making sure you understand. Discerning, reasonable, willing to admit he misunderstood. Expectations are transparent.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Professor Dees is quite knowledgeable when it comes to Philosophy, however when it comes to Medicine the man doesn't quite get it. He is a much harsher grader than anticipated, and is almost rude in some of his comments made when grading papers. He is non-approachable, and seems to have some non-constructive criticisms to his students knowledge.

(For Justice and Equality) A very understanding teacher. However the course was definitely not the best.  Readings and discussion didn't have clear conclusions about the main topics.  In addition, Richard is not the best at getting discussions going which made for very long silences.  Assignments: Q's for every reading and three 5ish page papers.
Knowledgeable but very unhelpful.
Picks favorites like whoa, and hates freshman guys for an unknown reason.  Also knows surprisingly little about medicine for a guy teaching Ethical Decisions in Medicine.
interesting subjects covered, terrible TAs.  grading is more harsh than I expected.
This class is really interesting and I think he is a good professor. Our TAs grade our papers and they weren't hard at all.

This class was interesting because it made you think.  I wasn't very fond of him as a professor though because I felt my papers were unfairly graded.  I almost felt he didn't even read it because alot of his comments didn't make sense or I did exactly what he suggested.  Also some of his comments contradicted each other. One point in the paper he would write something like "Great Ideas!" and then i'd get a 2/5 at the end for having unique thoughts or whatever he called it =/

This course keeps getting new professors, this time it's Dees. All he does is read from the powerpoint slides in class, so a lot of people stopped showing up.  But the real problem is that his papers are not only horribly difficult, but very harshly graded.  NOBODY in my section received an A or A-!
There's a lot of reading in his classes but I've taken 2 semesters and am still amazed at Lenoe's extensive knowledge. Lectures and discussions are interesting as are most readings. 10/10
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: One of the best history professors I have met. It was because of him I continued to pursue a history degree as a non-native speaker. His lectures are great and not boring at all. Will recommend!

Professor Lenoe's class was extremely informative, entertaining, and engaging. Lenoe himself is very knowledgeable, and has some great stories to tell. Would highly recommend taking one of his classes if you're at the University of Rochester
amazing lectures, very passionate about eastern front
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Lectures are not organized well and hard to follow. Doesn't show up to his own office hours and rarely responds to emails. I'm a history major and still hated this course.
Overall a great and very knowledgeable Professor.
Exams are wicked hard. You have to write a two page paper for EVERY class period. I never want to hear the word "russia" again.
Professor Lenoe is one of the best professors at the UR.
Awesome class. Easy to follow and entertaining too.
This is one of the most passionate teachers I have had yet.  I took his modern revolutions class and it rocked.  If you're ever thinking about taking a class with him- do it.
No Comments

Good guy, but grades papers weirdly(the things he picks out to dock you for can be odd) but fair all the same. He can be a little dry at times. I wouldn't hesitate to take a class with him though. All around pretty decent prof.
Definitely loved his class! He's a really fun guy and brings passion in to Soviet History. Very smart and interesting professor! I learned so much in that class! Strongly recommended!

Fall 2024 course-Charles Dickens (453). Failed to provide clear expectations for assignments, feeling confused about what was required for a good grade. Lectures were tangential and lacked focus, difficult to grasp key concepts. Feedback on written work was vague and unhelpful, leaving students feeling unsure how to improve their writing skills.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: As a transfer student I expected better quality professors but this one didn't meet expectations. She wasn't teaching the course as stated. She's hardly on campus or in her office. I had to seek others assistance in questions and clarifications I needed. I wouldn't recommend this class with this professor.

This class was very discussion heavy, but the discussions were really interesting, and Professor Rajan was always willing to answer questions. It was a lot of reading, but the grading was fair and the feedback was really helpful. The amount of writing was also reasonable. I would definitely recommend this class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: She's cares about and shows respect for student perspectives, and takes time to understand what they're saying, and does a good job balancing lecture with discussion. Only place for improvement would be that sometimes assignments are a bit delayed being posted on Blackboard, but I never found that to be detrimental to getting an assignment done.

Lots and lots of reading. A one-page paper is due every-other week, but I found them helpful for staying on track and tackling more difficult poetry. The tests were difficult for me, but all of it is quite doable if you keep up with the reading and pay attention in class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Rajan is a really sweet woman and a good professor. I found her lectures to be a bit dry, but it was obvious that she is passionate about English. Her grading was average. The class was decent overall, but probably my least favorite out of the bunch so far.

The amount of reading in both classes was excessive (even for an English class) and the response papers got incredibly boring week after week. That being said, the material she chose to read was interesting, and papers were graded fairly if a little harshly. If lectures had been shorter, it would have been easier to pay attention.

I love Professor Rajan.  She does a terrific job engaging students in discussion.  She is funny and bright and loves literature.  She is also very fair and gives students opportunities to rewrite papers.  Highly recommended!

Loved her so much! A very sweet lady, and extremely helpful - gave me suggestions of sources to use for my final paper unsolicited. Class discussions and lectures were very engaging. Highly recommend this professor.

One of the best professors I've ever had. Helpful, nice, engaging, and above all, passionate about what she was taeaching. I've taken two classes with her, and loved them both. She is eloquent and everything she says I want to write down. I would take another class with her in a heartbeat. She's a hard grader, but her classes are worth the work.

I found Professor Rajan to be extremely approachable and very helpful! I went to her office whenever I was confused about something or felt as though I was falling behind. Additionally, I found her lectures very enjoyable as well. She is passionate about her class and that translate well to her students. She may seem strict at first, but she's not!

I thought she was a very effective lecturer who tried and succeeded in pumping some life into Brit Lit II. I thoroughly enjoyed her class although I wish she did not assign response papers for the weekly recitations. These to me seemed like busy work. Other than that she was great.

Very rigid. Class involved a lot of busywork for a literature course - quizzes on minor details in the reading, weekly short essays, etc. Not very understanding in terms of extenuating circumstances - I missed a few quizzes for medical reasons and my grade suffered.

Pretty interesting lecturer.  Rigidly particular, doesn't cut anyone any slack.  Complained one day about latecomers without bothering to inquire why (she would have found out that the parking lot was jammed).  Came in late herself the next day.  That kind of thing.  Picky to the point of "anality" on paper grading.
Dummit is a great person, who provides detailed notes for the class and excellent lectures.
Such an inspirational, funny, and intelligent professor! He is very helpful, and you can tell that he wants his students to do well.

He is such a funny guy! I love that he gives an opportunity to make up for a bad midterm grade by doing well on the final. He is very helpful during his office hours. Just overall a great professor and the lectures were very enjoyable (he always gave out candy too! )
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Hilarious

comment: COME TO CLASS AND PASS

Professor Dummit is an amazing lecturer! He explains difficult concepts very clearly and often in a humorous way. He is also very willing to help us outside of class. I will definitely continue taking his class. Who does not like a professor who brings his students candies and brownies every class after all.

He is such a fun teacher! He gives out candy in most of his classes and is a hilarious dude. He is also such a good teacher and a genius! I wish he would stay next semester because he made calculus so fun! Don't hesitate to take a class with him.
A very fun and easygoing professor. He is always willing to help on both email and office hours.

I loved my multi-dimensional calculus course with Professor Dummit.  He is an excellent teacher with a knack for explaining and demonstrating mathematical concepts.  His lecture notes for the course were also outstanding; they can almost replace the textbook.
A laid back but very clear and concise professor, understands his students, and has a nice dry sense of humor!

Professor Dummit is the BEST!!! I took his Number Theory class. And although I signed up late to the class, he was very successful in preparing me through the process of learning the material. Also, HIS NOTES ARE AMAZING! My suggestion is dont buy any textbook or something, just refer to his notes if you need help. In conclusion, he is the BEST!

Clear and concise. Said on the first day of class that you wouldn't need the textbook as long as you paid attention in lecture and he was 100% right. Very intelligent, clearly knows his stuff. Prepares you well for tests, is respectful of student questions. Dry sense of humor is a bonus.

The best of the best for number theory lectures. Very honest and in touch with the learning process of upper level math students. Will publish lecture notes which are as good if not better than any textbook.

Fantastic professor. He's clear, helpful, and posts concise course notes online. Available for help if you need it. Responds to emails very quickly. Very intelligent. Textbook not necessary because of the TeX course notes he types.

Definitely the hardest class; a lot of it was just mathematical logic and thinking rather than calculation/memorizing which can be difficult for different people. Barelli was very approachable and available any time to help go over the material, always willing to answer any questions. Grading was really relaxed, but that might've just been the TA.

Game theory might be the hardest class I take in college, but also my favorite class so far. Barelli was fantastic. I enjoyed lecture, and he was super available outside of lecture whenever you wanted to see him.

He's genuinely interested in students' thoughts about the topic. But he uses very complex means to explain the most basic concepts (even he sometimes gets lost in it!). Class notes are similar- he often doesn't fully describe clearly how he is solving a problem but opts for long and redundant strings of undefined variables to explain his thinking.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Course material is hard and he is not good at articulating concepts. So you have to learn games by yourself. Sometimes he is condescending when student raises up a question. I agree with the comment that "Associate prof for a reason".

Professor Barelli is an incredible professor that teaches an incredibly difficult course. The material is very difficult, and a lack of understanding of arithmetic and calculus will really hurt you. I got a good grade in the class, but I really had to work for it. Barelli was very understanding and accessible, and he helped me a ton. Take w cautio
Very knowledge in Game Theory. However, cannot relate when a student does not understand the topic. Can be condescending if you ask questions. Goes through material quickly. Exams are challenging.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Lectures seem designed to conceal what he actually wants the class to learn then has the SHEER GALL to claim that 80% doing badly on his exams is OUR fault. I will say, thinking back with what I learned from my PS masters, he was teaching good information, but writing a good syllabus does not make you a good teacher. Associate Prof for a reason.
- Not good at explaining concepts. - Class gets too mathematical at times. - not enough emphasis on applications of the concepts.
Hard to follow, not good at articulating concepts.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: After each of the three midterms he spent at least an entire class going over how as a whole we were dumb and how easy he felt each exam should have been for us.  His lectures are exceptionally difficult to follow and he can definitely have major attitude problems when he feels something should be easy but the class is having trouble understanding.

Great professor, sometimes concepts were difficult to grasp, but spending time at his office hours clears that all up. Sometimes his homework/exam questions are a little unclear. Interesting class, ~5 hours of homework per week, exams were 1-2 questions in multiple parts and very fair.
Very efficient.
Lectures are hard to follow and have no bearing on the homework. Have fun re-deriving all of game theory yourself at home.
Avoid this man like the plague if you can. I'm so sorry for optics majors that have to suffer through his class.
Just avoid this class at all cost
Generally okay
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Accessible outside class

comment: Ohhhhhhhhh my goodness this man structured his class in the WORST way possible. He posted a million lecture videos each week and was in class to talk to us for 5 minutes. The TAs do all the work, but somehow never know what's going on either. He was so lazy this semester and everyone took the heat for that.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: He cares very much whether you're understanding the material but sometimes his Exam questions have confusing wording. Work with TA's, read the book and make sure you understand the homeworks. The more time you spend studying and doing problems, the better you will do on the Exams. This is a difficult topic, but he's not a bad professor.
It is incredibly hard, highly advise not taking this class
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Nice professor, very good course, very clear, Ez A.
He is a very good teacher. Lecture is hard, but you learnt a lot.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: He is one who prevent optics student studying optics
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: If, you are a optics major student, I feel sorry to inform you that you have to face Nick's education. And that experience would make you better because you cannot meet something tougher than this. If you are not Optics major and you have the option to take OPT 261, no matter what, just pick the alternative option.
A good reason why optics is one of the hardest major in U of R.
Content of class is really helpful, but the overall quality of this class gives students a hard time to follow the pace of instruction.
If you don't have take it then don't take it
homework have nothing to do with class

Had Dr. Chin for PHLT265 Global Health and she is amazing! Very interesting discussions in class, goes into a more anthro view of things. Also got my current research position from a recommendation, she really cares about your future and career! It's an ULW course but I wrote very little, aside from weekly discussion posts. Very easy course overall

Dr. Chin is a very good prof. She is empathetic and caring of her students. She is also very passionate about her field. The textbook largely covers the same points she does in lecture. However, attending lecture is crucial, as some points come from the in-class quizzes and the class itself is not curved and graded by few things.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes--So many papers

comment: Dr. Chin is perhaps the best professor I have had yet at U of R. She is very empathetic and the coursework is definitely interesting. One thing for sure is that the class is graded by a few things and it is pretty hard to secure an A. She definitely sparked my interest in public health and the guest lectures are also very interesting.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Amazing lectures --Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Prof. Chin is a respectable, kind, and knowledgeable professor. She really cares about student's mental health and values our needs. The guest speakers she brings in are actually really interesting and relevant to coursework.The short in class writing assignments and blog posts are rather simple-just make sure your points are clear.Learned a lot!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Chin is one of the few professors at the UofR that genuinely cares about their students well-being outside of class. She takes time every lecture to check in with how we're doing, and always makes herself available for help. Dr. Chin is the reason I decided to become a Public Health major, and has inspired me in so many other ways.

Dr. Chin is an incredible professor, and the material in this class is fascinating! The emphasis is placed on applying material to help be a more informed, conscientious, serve-minded, global citizen. The class itself is not very stressful which makes it a much better environment to truly learn and apply the material. I would recommend to anyone!

Dr. Chin was great. She takes the time to know each of her students and cares about them. There are only two tests for the semester, and a really awesome group project. Her class was very interesting and engaging. She loves to challenge her students to think in real world scenarios. If I could, I would take this class again!
One of my favorite professors at UR! Very nice person and a great lecturer. Got me interested in public health!

Nancy is an excellent professor-one of the best at UR.  Her passion for public health really shows-and inspires.  I can honestly say that I am a public health major because of her.  Take her class if you have the chance!

Very interesting class and a great introduction to the world of public health. Class was almost always discussion based. Do the readings - helps you understand material. One very easy exam and one very hard exam. Go to class - if you do, you won't have to study much outside of class. Lectures are helpful. Chin is VERY SMART! Great guest speakers!
She is great. Very easy to understand and really makes public health fun.

PH 101 is by far the best class that I have taken at the U of R.  Prof Chin is not only a professor but also a mentor for students in public health.  She is approachable and extremely helpful.  She is also probably my favorite professor also.  She makes public health exciting, fun, and unforgetable.  I would take seriously any class she taught.

Prof. Chin is the greatest professor I've ever had. She is thought-provoking and wise, and she pushes students to think 'outside the box.' Inspiring and wonderful, she has changed the way I look at health, behavior, and society in almost every way. Not to mention, she's a total badass. I would take twenty courses with Prof. Chin if I could.

Professor Stone required attendance at lectures (with a sign-in sheet), although the exams were almost 100% related to outside-class readings. Lectures were very in depth for an intro course, focusing on specific examples rather than teaching theory. Grading criteria for the essay-heavy exams was extremely unclear and subjective, and graded by TAs.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: I loved Professor Stone- he was always available for extra help and really knew what he was talking about. If you put in the work you will do well.

He is very smart and a brilliant and outstanding researcher. His class is very demanding. There is too much (and difficult) reading assignment and he asks you to do some unusual tasks (such as debate in class). He is also a tough grader and it is very hard to get an A.
You NEED an economics base to take this class. I never took econ, and struggled through all of the readings.
Boring. Unhelpful. Unlclear about expectations. I dont think he cares about teaching at all. He might be a good researcher.
He is incredibly interesting, I don't understand why everyone gave him such a poor rating. He has some great stories and is very enthusiastic about the subject!!!

Funny in a professory kind of way- dry wit.  Does an admirable job with ver complicated, difficult material, but could possibly be a little clearer in organizing the materials and linking everything together coherently.
nice guy but REALLY boring. hard to get a good grade in his class

He doesn't make them a prereq, but a good backround in macroeconomics and game theory would REALLY help.  He's a tough grader and some people say he's arrogant- he's a friendly guy but needs to explain things better, and not assume undergrads know grad stuff.
MUST take game theory before taking psc 272
Could he have been a bigger jerk?!
That class is too early...otherwise he is good. Game theory gets on your nerves after a while though. He needs to make more jokes about Bush.
He's too boring and monotone for a 9:40 class

Justin (he told us to call him that instead of Dr. Niziol because thats hit dad) was an excellent professor. I tend to get stuck very hard when I dont understand something and dont like to go to office hours. Justin encouraged me to come to office hours and after an hour I felt I was caught up. I recommend this class to anyone with time management
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: Prof Niziol fails entirely to work with his students. If I had to guess I would say hes the type to steal kills in Call of Duty and rush teams solo while screaming One Shot. If you plan to take this course, plan to be solo the entire time. NOT a team player

Prof. Niziol was not attentive to students who were struggling, and quite frankly downright rude. I reached out to him when a close family member died and his email response was cruel. The only reason I passed was because he curved the class at the end so it was impossible to fail - I'm guessing because if he didn't, most of the class would have.
I don't get why people are saying on here the he doesn't curve? He curved the class a ton at the end!!! He also drops your lowest exam score which really boosts your grade.

I was really scared after the horror stories of orgo but Niziol was really great. Lectures were easy to understand. Understanding workshop concepts are CRUCIAL to doing well on exams. I got an A but never looked at textbook questions, just did workshops over and over., and practiced synthesis. Also, if you get 90+ on final, that's an automatic A.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Dr. Niziol: nice person, good lecturer... AWFUL EXAMS! Exams are 100000x harder than lectures/learned content. He does NOT curve the class even when the average for all the exams were 40-60's. He thinks hes "making the class easy" BUT lack of curve caused several students to retake class. Grade consists of 3 uncurved midterms + final. THATS IT, NO!
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: I would say that he gives good lectures and clear explanations. He really wants students to understand the concepts and answer a lot of questions. However, his exams are tough and he doesn't curve the raw score even though the average is about 64. He only curves the grading standards(set 90 as A), which doesn't work very much.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: I'm not sure why there are such high ratings of this professor. Although he was very good during his lectures, his tests were unbelievably harder than the material learned in class and workshops. He does get credit for curving the grading scale but by not curving the exams he made it difficult to achieve an A (one would have to get a 90 on final)
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: He really explains the material in detail during his lectures and tries to simplify the concepts as much as possible. He was very accessible through his emails and was very helpful during office hours. I was initially scared for this class but ended up loving it. You can tell this professor wants his students to learn as much as possible.
A challenging class but very clear-cut! He drops your lowest exam and curved the grading at the end so getting a good grade was much easier than I thought.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Well, I do not know why so many students gave him so high rate...I just want to say, the average grades for midterm 2 and midterm 3 are 54 and 64. The A boundary is 93. Justin is truly a good professor, but his exams are toooooooo difficult!!!!!

I think I had Professor Niziol for the first time her was ever teaching Orgo and I was not expecting to like the subject as much as I did. He is always open for questions and does a great job explaining things in lecture. Understanding his workshops were the key to doing well on the exams so if you put in the work you'll be just fine
Amazing professor! Definitely would recommend him to any prospective orgo students!!
Attendance is mandatory because of pop quizzes. Exams aren't hard but you need to invest your time to prepare for them.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: Have to say that I was very interested in this subject and feel a loss of passion after taking his class. The topics and observation project are all fine and interesting, but he is a really harsh grader on small mistakes which sometimes make you think you are taking a Writing class. I learned more by myself instead of from him.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Test heavy

comment: You won't get good grades unless you watch his lectures at least two times and read the books carefully. Many exams, lots of materials covered, hard to remember. Very mean grader, and he deducts points on very small grammatical mistakes, and he also may not reply to your email because you got the wrong format. Not very respectful to students.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Test heavy

comment: The material and class itself are not difficult, but it's very difficult to do well on simple assignments because he grades so harshly (will fail a paper if you don't match his exact formatting requirements). Condescending and disrespectful towards students.
Dr. Werren is a brilliant man, but not the best teacher. Can be very nitpick-y at times.

STAY AWAY AT ALL COSTS. Horrible Profesor. Tests near impossible. TA's even hated him. Very textbook heavy. Random quizzes in class so attendance is necessary. He does not care about students whatsoever, either. 4 tests and a final. Random projects and reports.

I took his 260 Animal Behavior class as an elective and loved the material. Its incredibly interesting and easy to get into. He teaches with powerpoints that he refuses to post online no matter what  but adds in other important facts too. Hes scatterbrained and expects you to follow his guidelines to a T but overall I liked him and the class

Dr. Werren is one of the best profs I've had at UR.  His lectures are very organized, his explanations clear, and he's very willing to help.  You'll do well if you work hard (like you should). The questions on his exams are a bit ambiguous, but they really show whether the student understands or not. It's the nature of his discipline. Great course!

One of the best proffesors I had at UR.  His animal behavior class was incredibly interesting.  He was definitely tough but fair and he was always willing to help if you had questions.  He expects alot but if you do the work you shouldn't have any problems :) I also took my independent research course with him.  Like with 260, he tends to be quite strict with what he expects but it wasn't too much to handle and was well worth it for all that I learned :)

When you do an independent research project with him, you'll be able to see the depth of his uptightness.  He's very stiff all the time. Never cracks a joke.  I've never seen him smile.  His face has never even so much as twitched.
No Comments

Professor is very unhelpful.  His class, Animal Behavior, has material that is interesting, but I don't like the way he makes exam questions so ambiguous.  Don't take this class with this professor.  He's made people cry with his comments.
He is pretty cool in everything except he is very calculative and uptight
The best guy in the world.  Nice, funny, and so down-to-earth!  My favorite!!!

Prof Cadorette is awesome.  After attending the first lecture (by accident), I loved the way he explained Christianity in a very non-preachy way.
