His lectures were told more as stories and it made learning really easy.  He also encouraged me to do a study abroad in Italy and he even taught a section of one of my study abroad classes.  He's cool!
His quizzes are rather hard, but I LOVE him... he's so nice, incredibly easy to get a hold of, and just overall a really funny, awesome guy.

Prof Cadorette it one of the best professors I have this semester.  Sometimes his lectures are a bit slow, but overall they are interesting and he always cracks jokes.  He's also really helpful if you go to him.  Because of him I'm changing my minor to Religion.

Had him for 104 and 231, really great guy and very good prof. Lots of reading and short responses but light on assessments (no final in 231!). Learned a lot, even though his lectures don't tend to have strong organization, very interesting when he digresses into many cool experiences. Definitely recommend any of his classes.
He is very smart and extremely approachable and he encourages discussion. The readings are interesting, he requires weekly recaps, and there is no final. GREAT professor. Ask him about Peru.
I really like Prof Cadorette, he really got me interested in the subject and he is a very intelligent individual - definately take one of his classes if you have any interest in religion
great professor. really lets you pursue your interests.
Cadorette is one of my favorite professors I've had at UR so far and really got me interested in the Religion and Classics Department.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

Kuzmich is one of the nicest people I have ever met, and also one of the worst teachers I have ever had. She is not clear about anything in the language and you basically have to teach yourself because she only explains things in french. homework is all the time but she never puts it up until 9 pm at the earliest. tests are super hard too.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: The course itself requires you to do a lot of studying outside of class. There's no way to get around having to buy  the online code for the textbook. Kuzmich is a lenient grader, so even if you feel like you failed a paper or exam, she'll find points for you somewhere on your assignment.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Usually late.  The class has no structure.  She just randomly writes things that come to her.  She gives vocab quizzes but doesn't tell you which of the 200 or so vocab words at the end of each chapter she wants you to know.  Also, the textbook is awful.
Always late, not helpful/comprehensable.  Didn't learn anything, no feedback. Avoid if possible.

Terrible teacher. Always late, never prepared, 36 students in the class. Assigns busy work that's never graded. In the rare  occurance that she gives a written assignment, she will probably never correct or return it. Very unprofessional. and.. You will have her for THREE semesters if you want to learn German.

She is a good German professor, methinks, who is incredibly patient and helpful, and certainly knows her subject well. As for the other comments: her field isn't german culture (that's what the TAs are for), and so what she's always late? Oh, and the busy work is necessary in a language course.

A very caring professor, sometimes a little unclear in what she was saying or with assignments, otherwise a very good professor and person to know. Always willing to help you when you have any questions. Tries to make learning a hard language very fun :)

Took her class three semesters, really easy the first two semesters and I didn't learn much, definitely got a lot better third semester, made the class tougher and upped her expectations but taught a lot more.

She is teaching her second language in her third language.  But if that's not enough to deter you, she's always late, doesn't teach well at all, and knows NOTHING about German culture.  Her busy work is ridiculous too.

She doesn't teach. You would get more out of just trying to learn by yourself with the book. Tons and tons of busy work that she doesn't collect so there is no feedback on how well you understand the material.
Very very sweet, always available.  She enabled those of us who were serious about the class to find resources that helped greatly.
i thought she was very nice and always willing to help.  i really enjoyed her course.
No Comments

tested new concepts from a chapter never taught in class on the final exam. why?!?! you have to study a new chapter while taking the final exam, you either get it or fail the final and get a grade below B

He is easily the worst and most inconsiderate professor I have had at this college. I needed a make-up exam date due to athletics and he refused to give me one & said I wouldn't get credit for the class. He didn't hand back or post a single grade all semester so nobody knew where they were at. He would also ignore or pretend to not hear questions.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: He talks very quietly with an accent, boring lecturers, not helpful outside of classes.
Very good lecturer, makes complex statistical derivations very simple and elegant

The terrifying part of this class is not knowing how you're doing and having it all ride on the final, because your test grades don't say much. TAs are the best help for this class even though they don't always know what Rao is talking about, either. I encourage going to talk to Rao as well, he will change the curriculum based on students' needs.

His lectures are bad. His english is poor, he speaks quietly, and is not very clear in general. He refuses to use blackboard or provide any study materials. The lack of practice exams and his refusal to talk about upcoming exams make studying difficult.  He is not helpful during office hours or over email. On the bright side, his TAs are good.

His lectures consist of incoherent babbling. He is soft spoken and English is clearly his second language. You will rely on the textbook as your primary teaching utility. This would be fine except some of the material is quite difficult. I strongly advice getting in the habit of visiting the TA weekly because you will learn nothing during lecture.
sit in the front for his class or you can barely hear anything cuz of his accent. Skips steps and goes fast.  It's probably cuz he's taught it for so long he don't remember how hard it actually is
No Comments
Good prof but needs to get some TAs who speak English.
Professor Rao is fairly clear during office hours and in his writings.  He assigns a lot of material but the toughest homework questions generally are not on the exam.

His lectures consist of his mumbling voice and he never tells you what's going to be on his midterms.  He's not effective in his teaching and not one student is actually learning anything from his lectures.  You are screwed.
His accent is too heavy and he doesn't explain proofs and theories.

Such a chill dude. He will proofread your code and help you fix it if it doesn't work, just ask. My only gripe with this class is that two exams are worth 60% of the grade, and that doesn't make a lot of sense for a coding course which should be mostly project based in my opinion, but ah well.

Yates took over in the middle of the semester for Professor Lawton, I could tell he was very overwhelmed and did not have much lecture material planned. He did however know how to answer every question. He was super knowledgable and his tests are very short and concise, can sometimes be too vague though.
Very chill guy.  records lectures, pretty short hw's, and exams.

Overall best professor I had this semester. He is very lax and straightforward with what he expects of  you, and his test and homework questions are never meant to trick you. Recitation is very helpful (make sure you go!) and he provides supplemntal online lectures, which are a life saver for homeworks. Exams are also open note.
Really awesome teacher. Homework is great - low load and everything is applicable to the class (i.e. no busy work). Very fair exams. Great class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Yates is probably my favorite prof. I've had at UoR so far. He's super chill and I learned a lot.

He was filling in for another prof this semester, but so far he's been really great with making sure we know what we need to! Granted, this is a Python class for chemEs, so difficulty really depends on your ability to understand and reiterate.
He may be strict, but hes fair and he knows what hes talking about. If you do your work and put in effort, youll do well in this class.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: No Comments
final is very difficult.  hard grader in the end
Lectures are boring and monotone.
No Comments
No Comments

She is inspiring, clearheaded & has a straight-to-the-point attitude. If you review the syllabus, & plan accordingly, you will pass the class. Weekly readings are very quick to become tiresome, as she assigns two professional-level philosophy readings per week, and corresponding required responses; however, thoroughness is not required for these.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Inspirational

comment: PHIL223 was a challenging philosophy course but hugely rewarding. Marking is tough but entirely fair. Lots of readings as well. You'll learn a lot from doing all of it, however, and she is immensely knowledgeable, thoughtful and articulate. One of the best profs I've had in uni and one of the best classes I've taken.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: shes very nice, HOLY READINGS, new reading for every class and most were 10+ pages. classes are spent going over and conversing about the paper that was due before it. must annotate readings online and is graded. end of the year group presentations, you pick which topic you want but are randomly put into groups, would take again
Rosa is an incredible teacher! Very down to earth and approachable. The class itself was reading heavy, but easy to understand if you made an effort to attend class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Amazing lectures

comment:
disclaimer: for PSCI 293, not PHIL 226
Rosa is the kindest, most well-educated and empathetic human being; engaging and insightful professor who truly cares about her students. 11/10
LOTS of reading and in-depth class discussion about them, def go to class bc it helps a lot with the 3 take home essays (only 2 pages and thats the hardest part)

I had Professor Terlazzo for Phil 226 and she did a brilliant job. She never failed to make students feel welcome to share even if they were way off base with their response. She's a great professor, so much so that I took another one of her classes because she was teaching it (and for credit too, but she's a benefit of that course)
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Really great lectures and insightful connections of how the content she teaches connects to the real world. The readings are difficult and can take a bit of effort to understand. But the grading is fair and as long as you understand what's being discussed in class, you should do fine on the exams. Take the class!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: Rosa is amazing! I wish every class was structured like Philosophy of Law. She is genuinely caring about the students, provides so many opportunities to engage with the course content both in and outside of lectures, and she is very knowledgeable about her subject. Unlike most philosophy profs, Rosa always connects theory to reality.

Some of the texts are challenging, but the program she uses makes it easier to understand since you can access other students' comments on the reading. She's very accessible and easy to talk to, so I never felt bad asking for help. If you're curious, definitely sit in on a lecture or two.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Rosa was amazing at explaining all the concepts in the readings, and really broke everything down to make it super clear. She padded the grades a lot with easy completion grades for the reading and gave extra credit, and the papers weren't graded too harshly. Highly recommend!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Terlazzo is a good soul. She is so kind, non-judgmental, and asks thoughtful questions. Loves to make the students do the philosophy instead of lecturing at us. Make sure you show up, participate, and do the readings. Amazing course and professor - one of the best at UofR.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Such a horrible/difficult class to take. Nothing against Prof Terlazzo tho, she seems like a perfectly nice lady. But the class requires huge amounts of hours of reading and the TA who grades the exam is sooooo harsh. Make me wanna hang myself. Honestly, this is way too much work. Dont choose this class for ur own sake, unless you LOVE philosophy.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Rosa was very understanding and easy on students, especially during the pandemic. Did not demand a whole lot. Used a program that allowed us to discuss philosophical readings with other students, which helped me because some readings were hard for me to understand. Willing to add extensions, and is usually available for help.

If you draw a Venn diagram of someone who is smart and someone who is nice, there's really no much overlap. But Professor Terlazzo is definitely in the overlap. She was very supportive under this online circumstance--genuinely cared about students' mental well-being. She always came super prepared for class and respected students' opinions.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Dr. Hinds is a very straight-forward teacher. She sets clear expectations each week of what must be completed. She can be a little blunt and seem uncaring, but her ability to give fair and clear feedback is noticeable. The class is an easy A if work is put into it. Do NOT expect to sit around waiting for it.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: There is a lot of material to cover but this class really gives you an idea of all the interesting fields of study for BCS.  I really like Hinds as a teacher and I like that the tests are about applying material rather than just memorizing facts.  I would definitely recommend this class.

What a waste of time this class is. Don't skip lectures, but ignore the book. Recitations are a waste of time, and the tests are just a matter of being able to speak Hinds' language. You will be able to narrow each question down to 2 answers, but for a small sample of the test the 2 answers you're left with will be indistinguishable.

I wish Poujet still taught this. The tests aren't hard, they're just chalk full of terribly chosen and badly formulated questions. Hinds says this class is not about memorization, and she's right, it's about figuring out what the hell her questions are even asking. Lectures are unclear and I'm not convinced Hinds is knowledgeable on the topic.

The topics covered are interesting, but Hinds teaches directly off of the powerpoints.  Can you skip class because of this?  Perhaps, but it is always helpful to hear the material from her and take notes then in order to lower your study time.  Overall an easy class, but you should be able to apply the topics learned to different situations.

Nice woman but HORRIBLE teacher. Obviously knows her stuff but doesn't know a thing about how to teach. She teaches through Powerpoints - you can skip every class and get a decent grade. Many required readings but no textbook. Texts are somewhat easy but require lots of studying. Not the worst class ever but SO INCREDIBLY BORING.

The lectures are kind of boring and it feels like you don't actually get through much material because she spends half the class asking rhetorical questions. But her tests are really awesome. She is somewhat understanding. But she works here part time so it's really hard to meet with her if you need to talk to her.

The class covers many topics which is why is moves so fast. Overall, you can learn everything from her slides and do decent on the tests. Read the textbooks, because it will help you understand the concepts well enough to apply them on the tests.

Hinds is really intelligent but the lectures are drags. She tries to put an effort into teaching but it's as if she mostly does it for the purpose of being able to do research. The tests are difficult if you can't apply the material, which is really important if you want to pass. She posts slides online, so you can skip as long as you study hard.

admittedly her first course after receiving her doctorate -- hinds makes an entry level "organ grinder" class as engaging as possible.  A broad spectrum of topics over one semester -- would have liked more on clinical cases and abnormal psych, guess i'll have to take an upper division course for that.  very helpful during office hours as well.

She is the type of teacher that reads off of her powerpoint slides with very little commentary. You can tell that she knows a lot, but she seems to lack passion during her lectures which makes attending her class a dry experience. Her exams are fairly easy; you just have to put in decent study time and utilize the textbook for clarity of material.

Hinds is knowledgeable and seems very passionate. Lectures are dry because she talks "at" you rather than "to" you, but the quality improves over time, as the materials increasingly allow more interactivty in learning. Exams cover only lecture materials, but extra reading is recommended for clarification, as huge topics are rushed through in class.

Lectures are dry and not engaging. Attending class is not necessary as all the material explained with more clarity in the textbook. Her lectures move too fast and she touches on each topic too briefly, but she is somewhat helpful during office hours. Overall, her class is easy if you are willing to put in a lot of independent study time.

Demina is a great teacher, and a good professor. She excels at teaching and explaining material in a simple and intuitive way, and she engages the class well. However, she is not super accessible, and can be difficult to contact out of class. Overall, she is very good, and hilarious too. Tests were very straightforward. Would definitely recommend!

Demina is probably my favorite lecturer at UR. She delivers the material clearly and is especially clear about what she's going to cover in lecture on the day. It's a hard class with really hard material but if you go in expecting to work and do painful problem sets, you're good. The accent is Russian and so is the humor. She is Legend.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Her heavy Russian accent and ugly handwriting aside, her lecture can barely be followed. There is clearly no organization or logical structure in her lecture. You will find it more effective to study the subject on your own than from her. Also, the textbooks she used for my class is very dated. If possible, by all means, avoid taking her classes.
She's overall a pretty good professor. I mean she's got a thick Russian accent, but if she didn't have it, she definitely would be rated way higher. Her tests are seemingly easy... but very tricky.

Terrible professor. Demina's English is barely understandable,and she is rude and unhelpful at office hours. Her exams are very long and there is no grading curve. I got an A in the class,but that's because I taught myself everything from the book and got a 95% on the final exam. She ought to be fired.

Her physics is very good, her english not so good.  Nice power point slides, spends enough time on them and still takes time to work out problems on the board.  Always had a review class before tests.  She made it interesting.  She is defiantly recommended.

Very hard to understand russian accent, strange humor also. Her tests are way to long, not written or proctored by her either! Lectures drag on and don't cover more than whats already on the lectures. Good lecture but horrible tests that have lengty problems.

Demina has a very heavy russian accent that is difficult to understand. She goes through the powerpoints extremely fast and covers almost a chapter a lecture. The test questions come from the homework problems,so the exams are manageable but very long
No Comments
Does a thorough job of explaining material, boring lectures, straight forward tests and fair grading policy.
Really clarifies the information she's teaching, sometimes even too much. A great sense of humor and very straightforward tests.

Regina is cool, lecture gets boring but what hour and 20 minute lecture doesnt? be warned: her tests are only one hour long!  (wish i knew that before there were only 5 minutes left and i still had a whole page to go...)

She repeats everything at least 3 times, sometimes spending 40 minutes to explain a single PP slide. It's more than nessacery, and so really feels like she's wasting half the period when she could be covering a lot more material.

Ok so I can't say what class it is because it will just give away who I am but i sincerely wish I read all of these comments before. She is the reason why I've been so miserable this semester. Very unorganized, she gave no syllabus, every week was something new and not revelant to topic, and essays every week with no propt. Also shes miserable af.

she is a disaster. if you like being belittled, disrespected and confused as to what you should be doing every week then this is the class for you. if you are a fan of mumbling, tangents and eye rolling then again, this is the class for you. are you extremely self-loathing? like feeling bad about yourself? look no further than a class with fordham.

She is very knowledgeable but a bit nuts. I felt like the entire semester I was trying to guess what she wanted. She often mumbles and is hard to follow. She leads you to believe you have some freedom with your work but then once it's graded you realize you did everything wrong and she really wanted something completely different. She's torture.

Fordham is actually a leading anthropologist in her field. She has had a number of works published and her 'acting white' theory was even referenced by Barack Obama. Regardless, she is disorganized and unwilling to accept blame in anyway. She mumbles to herself, and goes in tangents. It is unfortunate that all her knowledge is lost in translation.
Don't.

Prof. Fordham was unorganized during class, but very knowledgeable about the material and passionate about teaching. Her most important goal was to make you THINK about the material and apply it. There was a lot of reading and she was critical at times, but it was to make you THINK about what you were doing. I am taking her again in the fall.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

If I were allowed as much profanity as I liked, 350 characters would not be enough for Fordham. I remember one student-teacher conference in which Fordham told me that I was a disappointment to my family in as many ways as she could think of. After a bit, I began crying, and she pondered aloud if perhaps she might have said something wrong.
Worst professor ever, and I'm not exaggerating at all. She's rude and so unprofessional. I recommend any class in the Anthropology department BUT hers.

she is the worst teacher i have had at UR. the amount of work she gives is insane, think 600+ pages of reading a week and writing something for every class.  she has absolutely no intrest in helping her students and if things dont go exactually her way she flips out.  i would recommend never taking a class with her. ps. im getting an A in the class
she keeps asking posibly can not think for herself
Great professor!

Dr. Jeannine Dingus is a great professor! She is HIGHLY intelligent and extremely helpful.  Most of my classmates were too immature to appreciate her because she is a no-nonsense type of person, but she is truly great.  She is the very best professor at the Warner School!
No Comments

Easy class, easy prof., but def. not open to others' opinions, and not a high quality prof. I just finished the UR's M.S. in Teach. prog. and I regret attending the U of R because of Profs. like Dingus, with little classroom teaching exp. She focuses on the negative and fails to prepare us for anything but teaching in urban schools.
No Comments

Assistant professor Dingus obviously thinks that she is a great assistant professor.  It is apparent in the way she teaches and speaks about herself.  However, it is also very telling.  Watch out my fellow students, assistant professor Dingus definately has some issues in the race department.  Buyer beware: her class is not free, but should be.

If you want a professor who is upfront and tells you how it is, Dr. Dingus is the one for you. She is an excellent professor who is fun and engaging. She is a critical professor, but who said that was a bad thing? She gets you to think outside of the box. If you want easy...go to MCC!
She isn't HARD, she is CRITICAL . . . welcome to grad school people. If you want easy, go somewhere else.
No Comments
Too hard, too much to read!
DO NOT TAKE A CLASS WITH DINGUS!!!  WORST TEACHER EVER, WHAT A WASTE OF MY TIME AND MY MONEY.  SHE SUCKS.  I HOPE SHE GETS FIRED!
No Comments

You can really tell Prof. Renninger cares about teaching. He explains the material so well, and he always gauges student comprehension in class. Go to class and workshop, and the homework and exams, while not being a walk in the park, should have no surprises. If you are considering graduate school in physics or optics, this class is so valuable.

Prof. Renninger is clearly an expert in the material and his homework and exams are very fair.  The course material is easy to follow, and closely follows the textbook, which is a good resource if you need additional explanation.  If you listen to his advice and go over material on your own you'll save yourself a lot of time and frustration.
Prof. Renninger teaches a hard class, but he is very well-organized and makes the content seem easy. Homework is well-written and useful, exams are extremely fair and easy. Great class overall.
He was a great professor, but really hard class. Super grateful he let me pass.
Midterm is easy, but the final, wow.

Professor Renninger is amazing. He is clear with his lecture content and you can tell he wants you to succeed. He is always open to answering questions you have about the course content. He will involve students in his lectures by asking questions. I highly recommend you take his class if you are pursuing physics.

His teaching style is easy to follow and you will learn a lot of helpful concepts that you will use outside of this class in other classes! Homework assignments can be difficult but office hours and workshops set up help a lot!

Know that I took this class in spring 2022. A lot of people who took this class last year rated it very low, but you can clearly tell he took feedback and seriously improved. His lectures are some of the best I have seen, and he clearly cares about students and is always willing to take quesitons. He has seriously improved.

Prof. Renninger is great. He is so passionate about his job, and you can tell he really cares about his students and wants them to do well. His lectures are clear and go hand in hand with the hw assignments. He is always willing to help and he actually listens to his students when we give him feedback about the course.

This was hands down the hardest math I've taken. Not because the material itself was extremely difficult, but because his handwriting is near impossible to decipher, and the things he teaches are only a light skimming of what he asks for on the 12-hour homework assignments. The TAs are going to be how you get through this class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: He was not helpful in learning what is likely some of the hardest math people will attempt to learn. He can be unforgiving and when asked to do explicit things by students he would often not do them. All the learning is done through the TA's and workshop so attend those and be prepared to take a graduate level course.

This man was such a lazy professor and all your learning is through the TAs. His handwriting is impossible to read and he never responds to emails. It is apparent he does not care for students and does not care about actually teaching us anything.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Taught the Undergraduate class as a Graduate class and was one of the most confusing math classes I have ever taken. The professor seldom cares about the students and doesn't really respond to emails. It's possible that it may be better taught in person, but this semester was especially difficult.

The only decent 150 prof, only because the rest are worse. Book is awful and effectively worthless, homework isn't the kind of questions he gives on the exam, and neither are the questions he goes over in review. The things people say are actually useful for CS are barely touched on and stuff like matrices appeared on no exam. Homework takes hours.
Not great at teaching, but the best of the 150 instructors. Exams are difficult, especially if you don't have prior experience of the class material.

Prof. Dannenberg makes sure to stop and verify you understand material and never hesitates to provide more examples or go over a part of lecture that wasn't clear. He makes frequent jokes and keeps lectures as light as one can when teaching discrete math. Homework assignments are difficult and lengthy but prepare you well for exams.

Lectures are like watching paint dry, does not give example problems while he teaches, homework and tests are loosely related at best to course content, grades very tough and feedback is minimal. Take the course with professor Almomani, much better teacher that actually walks the class through examples during lecture.

Above average. F2023 MATH150 instructor roster wasn't ideal, and compared to other instructors Danneberg was the best. Danneberg's class covered more materials than other professors including the Chinese Remainder Theorem and strong induction(was not tested). Sometimes Dannenberg makes minor algebraic errors during proofs but it is not a big deal.

I like his personality, very caring, happy guy. But his classes were difficult and his homework was long and hard. And the worst part was the HANDWRITING. Made it very difficult to understand what was written on the dusty small chalkboard. Otherwise fine guy, just a hard class.

MATH150 is very difficult, and I think a lot of the negative reviews stem from that. However, Dannenburg is very kind and accessible outside of class through office hours. Lectures are very fast with lots of content, so you need to attend all of them. If you need to take this class, this is probably the best professor to take.
He is a visiting assistant professor and he is not willing to help in the office hour.
Not patient at all.
His handwriting is awful and his lectures are incoherent. He stammers in class so frequently, and he is not willing to help explaining questions. He shows no patience in the office hour at all.

Sometimes his lectures were incoherent. His voice gets muffled because he wears a mask and gets nervous, so it can be hard to hear him sometimes. The homework was difficult and he is not the best at responding to emails. I would recommend taking the class with Prof Demihran, he really cares for the students. It is a difficult class.

Fantastic professor and fantastic lectures. He taught at a very good pace, was very engaging, and explained everything very clearly. He was always accessible in office hours for any questions and often stayed later than his scheduled office hours time to make sure he got to everyone.

Very kind and silly man but the class itself is pretty hard. Lectures are clear and helpful but textbook conveys the same material. Tests and gradescope homework are quite difficult but homework really helps with understanding the material.

Really great professor. Always makes sure he doesn't go too fast in lectures and is good at explaining things in simple terms. The tests can be pretty hard, but he's always helpful in office hours if you're struggling. Also a very caring guy.

Professor Dannenberg's lectures and office hours are very helpful. His lectures lessen or replace the need to read the (optional) textbook, and the office hours helped me to solve the hardest Gradescope problems. For a difficult math course like MATH150, Dannenberg is the kind of professor you need. I highly recommend him.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: I took Hist 186 with him. Extremely easy course. Take him if you want a free A. The grading was all based on three papers that are guaranteed A's. The lectures are not mandatory and he posts slides. You can write about whatever you want, it does not have to be related to lecture.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Easily the best professor and kindest professor you will ever have at this school. His papers can be longer at times, but they aren't hard to write and he will give you feedback to improve in future papers. For sure respect and suggest a Morris Pierce class.

Take this course if you are interested in military history. He is easygoing and friendly. He only restricts your essay topics to broad time periods so you can write about anything you find interesting in that time period. You will do well in the course if you know how to write at a college level (formatted, cited, and professional tone).

Never gives fair grades. He would only refer you to writing center which proved thousands of time useless. No grading materials and if you treat his paper as academic research you will get low grade. And if you use some new historiography you will get low grade.
Really nice Prof! He is super responsive and helpful, I passed his class with full marks on each paper and never went to class (reviewed PowerPoints in my own time). Honestly a gem!
5 papers in class... honestly I think it's just a completion grade. Didn't go to any of his lectures but still got an A. Very easy class, professor is kind and responsive.

If you have to take a history class Professor Pierce is your guy. Attendance isn't mandatory and the workload is minimal.  Showing up somewhat regularly and asking a few questions during class goes a long way. No textbooks either is a definite plus.
Interesting class and stories. Amazingly friendly professor who is easy to work with and provides students with plenty of academic freedom. Highly recommended.

Amazing class!!! You do not have any reading or exams. You do not need to attend class. The homework is just four essays which are easy to get high scores. You do not need to do anything and you can get an A.

Professor Pierce is low maintenance, easy going professor. You know exactly what he wants on tests and quizzes, and sometimes even says in lecture "you might want to remember this for the quiz" which he then hands out. Also he is a veteran of the Vietnam War and roomed with David Petraeus at West Point.
Go to class and pay attention.  This man has the most interesting stories.

This truly was the easiest class I've ever taken at UR.  He would plop in a video, turn the lights down, and then sit at the back of the class reading.  All assignments were papers and were generally easy to write if you paid attention to the movies and you read the assignments.  I think he spoke less than 100 words to our class the whole semester.
Easiest class I've taken here-no homework, really easy assignments, entertaining lectures.
Very helpful professor. He is very clear on getting the information across during lecture. Love his corny jokes too xD

Bailey is an awesome professor. He's hilarious and does a wonderful job explaining concepts in class. The homework is definitely highly suggested, his tests really are based off of them. Sad thing he's leaving next semester because he's a visiting professor but I'm definitely glad I took his class. Curves nicely.

Overall, he's a good teacher. Funny and personable. The exams are usually fine if you've done the recommended problems in the book and he curves so the average is a B. If you have to take multidimensional calc, take it with Bailey.
Hilarious, and a great treacher.
Good teacher, but another teacher makes math tests. He did not cover what other teacher wanted us to know for test well.
Easy class. Tests were a lot harder than you'd expect from the homework though, but the curve was sufficient. and homework was 50% of the grade.
Witty, funny, intelligent, a skilled conversationalist. Passionate about the subject and excellent at explaining.
Very nice and funny!!! Love him!!! Love his Curve on the final!!!!! mmmmm~

Very good professor. Grades with significant curve (makes average 80%). Tests are very reasonable, provides the ridiculous formulas. Only gripe was that he did not provide practice exams, only suggested homework which often comprised of 100-150 problems. Would recommend, however. Very difficult course but he made it possible

Professor Bailey is amazing.  He is an excellent teacher and does a great job at explaining difficult concepts in a clear way.  He makes himself very available for questions, and he is excellent at balancing scary material and yet making it relatable.  Very fair guy, excellent character.
Awesome professor!! Friendly, interesting, helpful, and makes things manageable!

Bailey is a really great professor.  He has a hilarious sense of nerdy humor and he's always ready to explain things.  He's very fair, and friendly, answers emails, and his catchphrase is 'I love cookies'.

Prof. Bocko is a very nice person, but sometimes it felt like he was over qualified to teach the introductory course. The class covered so much material that I found it difficult at times to understand it all. However, he got that the class was hard and all our exams were take home and our grades were mostly based on lab which helped. Easy A.
Really good professor who explains work on the board really well.
Best professor ever!

Bocko is one of the nicest professors I've ever had. He's an awesome guy and does a great job of making sure the entire class understands what he's talking about. The class I took was incredibly easy (he didn't give us a single test), but I still feel like I learned a lot from him.
Bocko is the best professor on the EE faculty.  Great all around guy, and his classes are well-taught and fair.  Make him your adviser immediately.  This guy rules.
This guy is the man!  Great guy, very clear, very enthusiastic.  Always helpful and makes class fun too.
Get this guy out of the Chair position and back teaching undergrad, the department desperately needs  it!

I loved Bocko.  He's an interesting guy and after I had done poorly in his class, he still offered me the use of a connection of his in order for me to get a great job.  He should get to fight UFC-style against Tom Jones
No Comments
Great professor, all around great guy.  Every engineering freshman deserves to have such an excellent professor.  Sometimes disorganized but generally had a really fun and educational class.
No Comments
Great guy. Excellent professor for freshman.  Make him your advisor instead of Tom Jones.

Ormsbee is such a caring and sweet professor! He gives great feedback and grades easily. 50% of your grade is just basically showing up to class and baseline participating so it is super easy to get an A. As for homework, it's just a small assignment on a class discussion board before every class, so again super easy. He is very chill and cute!

I'm suprised there are so many good reviews! Prof Ormsbee doesn't really give good feedback on your actual WRITING. He only really cares about grammar. Our classes felt really disjointed and there wasn't a good flow. I think maybe he's smart, but he's not a very good teaching. 0/10 would recommend for freshman writing.

One of the nicest professors you'll ever meet. He cares about students' mental health and is very understanding. Very easy to contact outside of class. His classes make you feel comfortable to participate in. As long as you do all the work, this class should be an easy A and it'll be fun too! I enjoyed all the papers I wrote in this class.

Prof Ormsbee is one of the best writing teachers I've ever had! He's so flexible, understanding, and gives great feedback on your stuff. He uses fun texts and examples like The Little Mermaid and Harry Potter. You get to choose a lot of what you write and work on, even if it's not fairy tale related. It was a joy and I highly recommend!

Michael is one of the best writing teachers I've ever had and I can't recommend him enough. He puts so much effort into teaching and he provides the most feedback of any teacher I have ever had. He is always willing to meet one on one to discuss a paper and is accommodating with deadlines because he really wants you to succeed as student.

Honestly, one of the most intelligent and passionate people I've ever encountered. I was so lucky to have had him my Freshman Fall. I would definitely say that he puts a lot of effort into making sure the needs of his students are met. He holds absolutely amazing discussions and it's clear that he enjoys what he teaches. Such a good professor!!!!!!

Michael Ormsbee was an amazing professor. He was extremely considerate with everything going on and never shied away from extending assignments and always took his student's mental health into account. He made my first year experiencing great, and I would definitely take him again if I could. Class discussions were lively and participation not requ

Mike was the best teacher I could have had for my first semester at U of R. He is super thorough in his feedback, and I always felt like he pointed out aspects of my paper which I missed. He is engaged in your learning and displays a genuine interest in both the class topics and your own topics. Amazing and super sweet guy!

For my first semester, Mike's class was an absolute gem. He works so hard to make sure that everyone is doing okay in the class and is pretty flexible. I'm so sad I won't have him again. Just know that if you're looking for a professor who cares about you, Mike's your guy.

Michael Ormsbee takes into account our workloads, and gives extensions if we are having difficulty completing an assignment. Class was very collaborative, and was always fun and interesting. There wasn't too much work, and he always let us know what we need to work on and gives us the opportunity to improve. 10/10 would recommend this class.

He is 100% one of the best teachers I have ever had. While our conditions this semester have been difficult because of the pandemic, he gives so much support. As a female student as well, I fell fully comfortable having 1-1 meetings with him and asking questions. On top of being a great person he is a fantastic teacher. He gives loads of help!

I believe he is the best teacher I have had for English. He cares so much about his students and their well-being, and it is truly reflected in how he teaches. He is very understandable about other workloads in various classes. As such, he is so kind towards shifting deadlines; the entire class learns more and has amazing discussions as a result.

Mike is kind, considerate & supportive. Shows empathy towards his students, provides in-depth, insightful feedback, & works extremely hard to make sure the course is interesting, varied and engaging. He is personally invested in your learning, & wants to make sure you succeed. Great sense of humor & easy to talk to; exciting and engaging classes.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Inspirational

comment: Love this class. The best professor ever in CAT training. We learned how to play with cats in the class, and it is a fantastic course at Univ Rochester.
I like the programming assignment in this course. The professor taught us to use AI to study cats' emotions. We studied many models and the result is perfect.
The in-class discussion is really interesting. I enjoy the time playing with cats in class.

His homework is to give you chance to communicate with your cat. I really like this type of homework. No exam, discussion-based. We sometimes bring our cats to the classroom and we together play with cats. Really nice.
Nice course, nice person. You will like him

He is really a nice person. I am taking this course for my Master's Dissertation. We learned to use the programming language python to mimic cat behavior. The course really makes me understand cats much more.
He is really good. For him, I changed my major to CAT, a small section of philsophy which the first doctor of this area is only him.
very nice professor, i would take this class again n again

He is talented in teaching. The one who gave this professor 1 is doing the same thing to other professors. That guy tries to break the whole philosophy department in Rochester. Do not listen to his advice!!!
Lectures are boring. Named every wall in my house just so I can apologize properly when I am hitting them. GET OUT WHEN YOU CAN
He really understands cats well.
He is great. I like his course. He teaches you how to understand a cat.

BEST PROF EVER. He is willing to listen to his students. Love the soft deadlines for assignments. He gives timely and constructive feedback. The class is very beginner-friendly, coming from me, an international student. His papers are intriguing but def not without challenges! Outside of class, he is very accessible, attentive and understanding.
Amazing professor! take his class!
I like him!!!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: Highly recommend everyone at UR to take Orisa's writing course! He is not strict with deadlines and cares about his students. As long as you do all the informal and formal assignments, you will be okay with this course.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: One of the best professors I've had at Rochester. Takes the time to listen to his students, gives great feedback and suggestions, and is accessible even at night on a weekend. Also a very lenient grader!!!

I personally found the class more boring than what I went in expecting. However, I don't regret taking it. I'm probably in the minority, but I did not enjoy the readings and didn't feel super interested in the material. However, I did enjoy the environment of the class. Santiago is very caring, understanding, and just an overall amazing human!
One of the best professors I've had here. Truly a gem in the Rochester community!

Amazing instructor and person - he cares for his students and frequently takes time to hear out (and apply) our opinions/suggestions in class. Course content is very engaging if you are interested in his writing course topic. The course schedule is structured so that all writing assignments are doable on time without unnecessary stress.

Professor Morrice is a very caring, thoughtful, and human professor. The readings he selects are very insightful and the discussions that follow are very well mediated and enjoyable to participate in. He also gives lots of freedom in his writing prompts which means that you can almost always find something fun you would enjoy writing about.

He is AMAZING! You will have the best reading discussion ever in his class! He also gives you fair grades, and they are usually pretty good as long as you follow his suggestions. Don't be afraid to catch him up after class and ask him anything you don't understand! He'll explain every comment he gave to your paper and help you to write better :)

What a legendary professor! He became a professor in the writing department of Rochester last year, but he has already become one of the highly recommended professors! His lectures are inspirational! Take him!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Inspirational

comment: Professor Morrice holds AMAZING discussions in classes. I really enjoyed attending his writing classes and he gives you both fair grades and constructive feedbacks.
terrible prof with bad attitude
Make sure you spend time after class and reproduce most models in Excel. Prepare hard work for the project. You should be fine. It is fairly practical for students who aim to finance industry.

He knows what he's talking about and is clearly passionate about his work, but he also keeps his personal life and careers very private and lacks that sort of connection with students. He is also an extremely hard grader and at this point, I don't think he curves grades
Incompetent professor with insufficient knowledge in accounting

The class material you learn for this class is great and sets up a lot of the foundations for equity research or Investment banking, however, he's just a extremely hard prof. He moves very quick on the material and doesn't explain whats on tests, average in the class ranges from 50 to 60's. He curves in the end, but be prepared for a hard class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Incredible Prof. Take him you will not regret it. Learn a lot!

WOW!! He is by far the best prof I have ever had. His class is difficult but insightful and useful. He uses excellent examples and his lecture notes are highly comprehensive. His teaching style is engaging and encourages participation. Take him you won't regret. The negative comments are those students who did not show up to class and did not work.
Best Prof ever had
Hard! But very good class!

Not sure why the comments are so positive.. he gives 80-100 pages of notes and does not tell you whats on the exam. He did not give a final exam review session and always rushes his material. Definitely take this class with another professor. Class averages were around 50%.
Amazing professor that i have decided to take all his courses.
Professor helpful, competent, and invested.  Course challenging and useful.

Professor Ho forces you to leave behind your bias and all the wrong American-centered history you were taught in high school (if you're American). My world is much wider than it was before I took HIS 143 & HIS 247 with him. He's absolutely hilarious. Warning: he'll take a month to grade the first paper and then you won't even get the others back.

The best professor I have ever had. Professor Ho is hilarious and clearly very passionate about what he is teaching. He can make any topic interesting, and is basically the definition of chaotic good. Just make sure to do all of your readings.
A very funny and interesting person who is keen on old-age music and eastern history. He likes to encourage students to go or extra-credit lectures. His jokes are great.
An amazing guy from Taiwan. Good teaching style. He loves to share classical music in class. He talks about Chinese history in a very neutral, objective way, which is great.
Amazing guy. Get ready to laugh. The only class I would go out of my way not to miss. So passionate and really has a way of dumbing things down so you understand them.

I haven't finished this class yet, but so far I love it. Professor Ho is a really funny guy and very passionate about what he is teaching. I can't speak much to the toughness of his grading, but the books he assigns are interesting and worth actually reading. When there are events on campus related to the class, you can get extra credit for going.
Easily the best history professor I've had in general. Clear lectures, boundless enthusiasm--he puts his whole heart into the course topics and knows how to make the class fun and easy.

Professor Ho is a great professor! He is one of the professors,  that I have come across, that really see when a student is trying their best! His lectures are fun, easy, and very entertaining! I am doing a INDEPENDENT STUDY with him, Tibet in Today's Society, this upcoming fall :)! Im looking forward to my senior year with Professor Ho!

Prof. Ho tries his best to maintain students focused by using all means. He teaches numerous asian history classes in both 100s and 200s levels. 200s does not mean more difficult course than 100s and vice versa (in most case, equally A-able so challenge yourself) reading may be little heavy but worth and generally easy to skim. attendance mandatory
Professor Ho is always energetic and fresh coming to the class. He distributes heavy reading to do, but it is very helpful.

Professor Ho definitely brings a modern element to history classes. He engages the students with many different films, documentaries, and fun props such as Chinese swords, Japanese swords, you name it. His class is relatively easy to be successful in; I thoroughly am enjoying his class this semester.

Professor Ho is the man. He is veyr energentic when it comes to his classes. He includes lots of relevant movies and documentaries, and brings in props; including swords and samurai helmets. The books he chooses are really interesting and the assignments are not overly difficult. He just wants you to show up, pay attention, and keep an open mind.

Bioorganic is much more relaxed than orgo so take prior reviews with a grain of salt. It's an exploratory course built for you to learn, not a weed-out.

Grading is lenient if you show understanding & effort. He's friendly, approachable, and goes on tons of tangential stories. A good background in orgo is vital and can carry you through the course.
The subject sucked, and his lectures were just like reading a textbook off a whiteboard. Hard class, but very passable with a curve.

Not a great lecturer as he assumed we knew most concepts that most students were actually unfamiliar with. However, gave lots of practice exams and was accessible outside of class for extra help. Might be easier to just read the textbook to understand some concepts.
Dr. Nilsson explains every concept clearly. He is passionate about orgo and he is more than willing to help people to understand orgo. Love him and respect!
His exam involved a lot about the problem sets and workshop related question, if you put enough effort on those things , it's easy to ace the course.

His teaching could be a bit unclear sometimes, he gets flustered and makes mistakes but usually is corrected by a student. If you go to workshop, do the practice problems, and go through examples, the tests are fair. There is not much partial credit, but there weren't as many questions that were super difficult as compared to CHM 203. Big curve!

Nilsson is extremely unclear in his teachings. He often makes mistakes. This class is hard, and made it clear that he thinks anyone who doesn't get the material is incompetent in his view. He grades very unfairly and inconsistently. I found him to be very rude and one of my least favorite professors.

Much like orgo 1 this class is really tough. Better prof than goodman (tho thats not saying much) but his TESTS ARE VERY HARD & partial credit is slim. Lectures are decent, sometimes mechanisms are unclear. REDO PRACTICE PROBLEM SETS & WORKSHOPS. Sapling online HW not that helpful. Must MEMORIZE BASIC RXNS & LEARN MECHANISM PATTERNS to do well.

Super friendly and very willing to meet with students who ask for help. Tests are difficult but not insane, though he doesn't give a lot of partial credit on mechanistic questions. Occasionally drops hilarious lines during class - he once said (describing hydronium) "it's just a dirty little proton getting shared around by all the water molecules."
Very good professor. Difficult tests, but fair. His workshops and optional problem sets are great preparation. Happy to meet with students and is helpful in office hours.
Very nice guy, but his tests were super hard. Get prepared to work hard.

A whole lot of fun and open to being helpful and improving himself (which is especially important when his H's and N's start looking the same on the board).  Tests were difficult but not generally out-of-left-field, with a fine curve when they were. I found it easiest to learn from lectures over the book, but many of my friends studied from it.

Prof. Soysal has profoundly impacted my understanding of philosophy. She is an amazing professor who has shown me the standard of what teaching looks like. Her greatest priority is ensuring her students' understanding of the material in the class.
Really wonderful professor! Always available during office hours, too!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Nice professor but very confusing class and TA's graded very harshly

Really great person overall. Stimulating but chill, nice course. Interested in what you have to say which is a fantastic quality in a lecturer, especially for philosophy. I also loved that the mathematical background sometimes showed as it is great for all the logic.

Super accommodating for students and she and her TAs are fairly (maybe even sometimes overly) generous when it comes to grading. Even though you can get by in 105 without having to go to office hours she's always available and can help you out a ton with comprehension. Good lecturer and she assigns a very reasonable workload too.
Good Professor easy and interesting class. 100% recommend.

Genuinely one of the kindest, most inspiring and intellectually stimulating Professors. Knows what she's teaching very well and does everything she can to help her students succeed in the class. The best Professor I've had at the UofR.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Inspirational

comment: The best professor I've had so far. Lectures are very clear and straightforward, workload is manageable, and Zeynep is always available to discuss and clarify. Participation and attendance aren't mandatory but the more you participate in class, the more you'll get out of it.
I have to say professor Soysal is really caring about students. Whatever problem u met, just email her and she will respond as soon as possible and be patient enough to help u solve the problem.

Intermediate Logic is definitely difficult, and a huge step up from PHL 110. However, Zeynep is very nice, good at explaining things, and generous with grading and giving her time outside of class. My biggest advice, however, is READ. Everything you need is in the text, you just have to read it over and over because it's REALLY dense.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: She is an amazing person on top of being a great professor. She cares about student success and is very responsive to emails. She's always available during office hours, even if it's just to have a casual conversation. She has clear grading criteria, and gives regular homework to make sure you are on top of the material. Everything comes together.

Zeynep is an amazing professor. She really cares about you as a person and is always ready to help. She was always available at office hours and was prompt to respond to emails even outside of her office hours. For my final project I went to her multiple times for advice and she always gave great feedback. Overall a great experience with her

Professor Beljanski is the most caring professor you will ever have at the U of R. She definitely does give a solid amount of HW, but none of it is too difficult. I would recommend her to anyone thinking about taking a German course. I have taken 3 different professors in the German department so far, and she is my favorite by far. Best professor.
She is an incredible teacher. She's very patient about mistakes made while learning and never makes you feel bad for making a mistake even while correcting it. She's approachable and understanding.

Tanja is an awesome teacher I love her so much. The class is fun and you learn enough for an introductory series. If you attended all lectures paid attention and studied for 30 minutes every week. it's super easy A for both 101 and 102. Tanja is so so so understanding I never asked her for extension and she refused. She is so caring and nice.

Tanja was a great teacher, she managed to have interesting lectures while still teaching effectively, and she's so sweet. Gives lots of extra credit, and she was very understanding about me missing class due to having to quarantine. Great professor!
TAKE THE CLASS!! She's one of the best professor's I've ever had. So caring and helpful, and the assignments take work but it's very manageable.

Tanja is such an amazing professor. So kind and caring for her students, and is more than accessible outside of class. Her feedback on any written assignments is detailed and thorough!! The only downside is her sometimes unorganized nature to class, but it is easily ignored for the rest of this lovely class!
Tanja is very approachable! Her lectures about teen representation in tv is engaging. Other than that, this class is pretty easy. Just do the informal and formal assignments on time.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: As a WRTG105 class, it was pretty good! We talked about Teen Television and literally came to class to talk about shows. There isn't much homework, but don't leave your papers (4 due by the end of the course in total) until the last minute. A lot of peer feedback to give to one another, but it helps. Participating in the lectures is expected!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Great professor! Love her German course. She is super helpful in my German learning.
I cannot say enough good things about Tanja, she is the best professor I have ever had.
Tanja is amazing and caring and it's clear she loves her students. She's also incredibly helpful and accessible. Everyone I know in my class loves her!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: She is a great teacher. Classes are fun and usually pretty easy. Participation is part of the grade and if you miss too many classes, you will fail, so be warned. Gives lots of extra credit questions on exams. Would recommend though.

Dr. Ghaemmaghami is literally the reason I became a biochem major, he's probably my favorite professor so far. Lectures are so well organized and content is explained thoroughly. Make sure you go over lecture slides often and you'll be absolutely fine. I recommend him to everyone.

Does a good job explaining things and has clear expectations. Intelligent, likable and funny. NOT an "introductory" course with hand holding or curve, so need to work and take initiative, including remembering information from pre-req courses like gen-chem and orgo. But if you put in the effort, it'll be fine. V. interesting content for pre-meds.

Sina is the man. Cool guy, pretty laid back. Doesn't curve so get ready to actually hunker down and study. Gives ample extra credit which is basically a curve, though. Ask questions often and early, attend lecture, go over practice questions & recitations (some questions are repeated verbatim on exams). He's willing to clarify pretty much anything.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: This class is a typical weed-out STEM course. Dr. G expects you to remember everything you learned from general/organic chemistry, and lectures are nowhere near in-depth enough to prepare you for the practice sets or exams. Averages on exams were all around a D and with no curve, however he did offer some extra credit for each test.

Best organized class I have had. His grading is fair and consistent and the extra credit helps a lot. This professor is passionate and about the subject and goes above and beyond for this class. He puts a ton of extra work into this class even though I am sure he is very busy with his research. Great professor and a great guy.

Class is structured so that everything flows nicely. The exams are very fair, and he has non-mandatory question sets to help you prepare. Class isn't curved, but he has extra credit which is very nice. Gives recorded lectures, which are very crisp, and easy to learn from. He is funny, knowledgable, and you'll leave liking biochemistry. Great guy.
One of the best

The class is moderately paced relative to the other biochemistry class but is structured nicely so that everything fits in with each other. The exams are fair and the extra credit that he gives helps out with making sure that you have a favorable grade. This class is effort heavy but pays heavily if you put in that time and effort. The best class.

Great professor. Gives detailed lectures, creates PowerPoint responses to student questions; he goes above and beyond in every category. He teaches an honors level class with no curve. You earn your curve with extra credit. Fair grader.

Very interesting class especially for those interested in medicine. Great professor who applies what he teaches to real life topics. This class is the reason why I am now a biochemistry major. It's definitely not easy and requires a lot of hard work but with the right amount of effort, you can do well. I definitely recommend taking this class.

LOVE this prof. Hard class. Not scaled. But very clear in his expectations and always accessible for help. Most caring professor. Loves his job and his students. Incredibly passionate about science! V interesting class and gives lots of fun extra credit opportunities.
Knowledgable and organized. Does a good job lecturing and answering questions.

Could hardly focus on the material, his abs were too distracting. lol. For real, take his class for his Greek God-like sculpted abs that he shows at the end of the semester to those who get a C+ and above.
His tests were tough, but he is easy on the eyes. He's so excited about his material that he is literally jumping and hopping around in class. 10/10 would recommend.

He is the dryest and the most boring professor I've had at the University. He does not get up from him chair and talks from behind his table. It is a 3 hours class on Monday evenings which makes it worse. He says his test will only cover material from the lecture, but he includes tidbits from the book that he has never spoken about in the class.
Pretty much just keep up with the work and you'll pass.
Very interesting class! Learned a lot but it could get boring since it was 3 hr once a week class but he is a solid professor.
Very easy class, exams are all subjective - Consumer Behavior
Great professor.
Real world look at business at a theory based school. Thank you for the experience.

A very nice professor. The class isn't the most interesting, but he does his best to keep you involved. Assigns a lot of reading for his exams, but they are still fairly manageable, as long as you don't wait until 3 hours before the exam to begin preparing. If you have any interest in marketing whatsoever, I recommend taking this class.
best prof. ever, maybe a little dull, but his niceness makes up for it. 2 thumbs way up!!
No Comments

GREAT teacher in an interesting class..very straightforward with what will be on the tests...case studies aren't hard...no hw...do the reading and take good notes and its a guaranteed good grade...loves marketing and loves to teach...very nice guy too

One of the best lecturers I've encountered. He shows genuine interest in his teaching and is highly engaging. Don't buy the textbook; all info is in his lectures which are all posted online. There's a lot of material, but if you memorize the lectures, you will do well. He doesn't curve, but there are opportunities for extra credit. Great class!
He did not videotape lectures for our class and he's pretty boring. Tests are ok, but he asks some pretty random questions. Also be prepared to study really hard and not do well.

Holtzman acts like he cares but he's such an ****. He'll be rude in class if he doesn't like your question, he'll lower your grade after the test, his tests cover material that is irrelevant, and his class is generally painfully boring. I'm a good student but found it hard to do well in his class and definitely do NOT recommend him

Not only are his lectures extremely comprehensive, they are VIDEOTAPED and put online so you NEVER have to show up! (and he makes the lectures as interesting as possible if you do want to show up). Memorize the lectures the night before the test, guranteed A.  So much better than the previous professor from what I've heard

Crystal clear lectures. Very, very organized. 3 test - all count, not curve, no extra credit. Memorize everything in lecture and will do fine. (BTW - when Nordeen teaches this class - it absolutely blows, or so I've heard).
Holtzman is a fabulous professor who is very helpful and knows how to keep students engaged! once he brought a boa constrictor into class :)

Good professor, knows his stuff and had some good stories to share.  His tests were manageable.  I found myself studying alot and all I got were B's.  I thought he should've given some extra credit of some sort since our whole grade was based on exams.
studied constantly and ended up with 60's every time...
Great lecturer, exams were a bit tough and he does not like to curve, so that is not cool, but he is one of the best lecturers I have had.

So much material; the most notes I've ever taken.  But the information was fascinating particularly when augmented by Holtzmann's outstanding (and for the most part very interesting) lectures.  Fair tests-only hard because of the amount of material they cover.  Doesn't really curve.

Holtzman definitely gives out some tough exams.  The good thing is that he has very interesting lectures and does a great job guiding you through the material.  He also puts all the power points onlin, so if you miss a class no big deal.  Just make sure you study your butt off.  He's pretty funny and approachable to
exams are hard

Dr. Holz is awesome. Physiology is definitely a challenging course with a lot of material, but he breaks it down pretty well and assignments/workshops are well targeted. Lectures can be a little convoluted, so rewriting/organizing notes might be helpful.

One of the best professors at U of R. So caring and makes lecture content enjoyable. Accessible to students and very responsive when issues or questions arise. 10/10 recommend taking physiology with him, it was an awesome class

Great professor. Exams can be hard, but if you study you'll do fine. He is receptive to questions and feedback and genuinely wants students to succeed. Attendance is only required at workshops as lectures are recorded.

Hilarious professor and a great human being. Makes you want to participate and times jokes that fit in and make class more enjoyable. As far as content wise, material is very dense and covered over a quick time. 100% recommended to rewatch and take hand notes as exams can have material you never expected. Bump offered for every exam based on avg.

Dr. Holz is a straight-up collegiate-level professor. His class requires significant time and dedication to excel in. Unfortunately, the course leaves little margin for error and one or two mediocre performances on exams will tank your average; however, I realized that this course opens your eyes to the high degree of competency required in life...
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Holz is one of the best professors I've had here at UR. He encourages class participation, is receptive to feedback, and the lecture style keeps you on your toes. Exams are quite tough, however there's a so called 'bump' that accounts for the difficulty. He'll definitely make you work for your grade but by no means is it impossible.

Dr. Holz is very enthusiastic and tries to engage students and make class interesting. However, there's an overwhelming amount of material covered on each exam and he doesn't refrain from testing on trivial details. Most exams are curved heavily as a result, but if you try to memorize EVERYTHING on the slides you'll do fine.

The class is a typical upper-level biology class. A lot of content- if you memorize lectures you will do well on exams. As for Dr. Holz, he is unapproachable, lazy, and lacks sympathy for students. For one writing assignment, my peer and I received the same exact feedback, down to the typo. Unprofessional and rude-- the worst I've had at UR.

Has a ton of material to cover in each lecture, but tells you exactly what you need to know on exams, and also throws in well-timed jokes. He also listened to the class when we wanted to switch to live lectures. But damn is there a lot of content on his exams. Made me work for it.
Kind of lazy but definitely a fun guy You have to work in this class

My favorite bio prof at UR. Why can't all professors just be like him. He speaks clearly, uses powerpoint, and his tests are fair. The class isn't easy by any means, but your effort is usually rewarded.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: I took BIO 204 with Dr. Holz during the Fall 2019 semester and LOVED it! Definitely my favorite professor ever! He talks fast in lectures (and tells jokes that are actually funny), but they're recorded so you can go back and fill in gaps in your notes. Super nice and genuinely wants students to succeed and enjoy the material.

Dr. Holtz can help you believe that you can succeed in the natural sciences. Dr. Holtz does his best to be entertaining and informative, even while juggling insane amounts of responsibility. IDK why but he sometimes bugs me; I guess it´s a me thing. If you get him as a professor, then cherish the experience.

Dr. Phillips was a great professor for WRTG 105. She encouraged participation and even rounded my grade up at the end of the semester due to my abundance of participation throughout the semester. Very nice and understanding! Great prof.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Phillips did a great job of allowing her students to use this class to learn how to write in a discipline relevant to their major. Additionally, she offers tons of support to her students and is a relatively light grader if you participate in everything you should get an A!

Phillips is one of the most caring professors I've met. Although there is a fair amount of reading/writing for homework, the more you apply yourself the more you get out of her class. She gives an incredible amount of freedom, which is a breath of fresh air and allows you to use your time to delve into a topic relevant to you/your future career.

Kate really cares about helping her students learn! There is a fair amount of work, but it is engaging. Kate has great respect for students. I have taken several classes with her, and she is one of my favorite professors!

Kate really cares and was quite understanding when I struggled with certain assignments. I took WRTG105 Uncertainty, and while it was interesting, it was a vague topic and towards the end of the course we barely talked about uncertainty at all. I don't really think my writing improved at all, and I did not get a ton of feedback, but over all fine.

Kate is such a caring professor. She really takes the time to read all your assignments and give plenty of feedback. She's also very big on your paper, being your paper and sometimes that means not using all the suggestions. I definitely want to talk another class with her and would recommend her courses to anyone looking for a great WRTG 105 class
May sound like an interesting class, but I learned nothing about human happiness. Wouldn't waste my time with this class.

Kate is an excellent professor, really takes the time to figure out how to teach her students the way they want to be taught. The syllabus was a bit intense in terms of reading and writing, but she offers ample time to make up for any missed assignments. As long as you're willing to do the work, you'll be fine. She's great, kind, and wicked smart.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: interesting class, breath of fresh air from other more rigorous courses

I'm a STEM major who needed the writing credit and Kate was the best choice I could have made (yes we were allowed to call her Kate). She was open to any idea, opinion, or discussion imaginable and was super flexible with due dates. Don't get me wrong though, we still had very serious and respected assignments, but overall a great class!

Ms. Phillips is the epitome of the high school english teacher who grades essays based on how much they like the student (in this case, being liked depends on being a feminist, liking Ariana Grande. and raising your hand for every question in class). Also, fair warning, human happiness is NOT what this class is about.

Professor Phillips is a great person. She is very charismatic and passionate. However, the contents of the course have very little to do with the title. Although it is a required writing class, we have really only discussed making an argument and research, which is not the only kind of writing there is. Ultimately, I wish I chose something else.

After I saw the title of this class, Human Happiness, I thought that maybe I could attribute this to my own life for once. Personally, I am very unhappy. And after taking this class, I am still very unhappy. We used Vox articles as "credible" sources, and the formal assignments are graded by luck. Also, she really needs to get a new haircut

As mentioned by others, Reichman is a very curious guy and will inquire about your background if mentioned--especially if it relates to his research or the topic of discussion (especially if the former). This reasonably can make some uncomfortable while others may appreciate the candid interest--regardless, keep in mind if taking the class.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Whatever you get out of Reichman's class is proportional to the amount of work you put into his class. Lectures cover engaging material, there are weekly group discussions if that's more of your thing + there's room for extra credit even if the exams and paper are very fairly graded. Also super insightful to talk to in office hours. He's great.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Class was pretty easy, not draining or that demanding. Only assignments were ethnographic assignments which were fun to do and not that hard to write about. Class is mostly discussion, of the assignments or whatever other topic based on light readings. Also had Q&A's with other Anthro professors who talked about their careers/research, was cool.
Im a Chinese student, and I dislike how he would call me out in class. He would assume things about my culture that was not true. Kind of intimidating

Heavy reading-- but do the work, show up, and have opinion/ideas and you'll do fine. Grading is fair and feedback is always helpful and insightful. Course reading is fascinating and he gives you his own ethnography as reading, so you get to talk to the expert on his work, which is an amazing opportunity.
