Professor Tucker has an amazing ability to keep everyone in his classes involved and interested. He has a genuine ability to make students feel as though they and their opinion truly matter.
One of my favorite professors.  Genuinely interested in his students and cultivating their intellectual pursuits.

GREAT professor.  Taught a very intresting class and attempted to get to know everyone in a large class.  Assigns a fair amount of work and you will do well in the class if you keep up.  Plus, he gave NO tests!!

Jeff Tucker is a kind, patient, helpful, reliable teacher with a genuine concern for education and a strong desire to foster intellectual interests in his students.  I couldn't possibly say enough nice things about him.
Anyone you can make Poe boring is a terrible professor.  Staying awake during his class was the only challenge I faced.
He's awesome, really helpful and a professional sweetheart --make sense?e

I found Rubin's course to be delightful. I took her for a History seminar which was mostly discussion based. She led good discussions and seemed genuinely interested in the lives of each of her students.

She is an easy prof. Attendance is mandatory since all her tests and everything is based on her notes. She gives 3 tests and a 5min project to do. She has a passion for art and thats what made me stay awake. Dont buy the book because its useless, just be in class and youll have all the notes you need for the tests.

Appears to look down on people who she deems below her social class. That's made clear if  she has her suspicions about you. Does not seem at all interested in the students, in general, actually. Rather insincere. It's not that she asks you do do anything difficult. In fact, she treats most students as though they lack intelligence. AVOID!

Terrible at leading discussions and organizing classes. Bland and self-absorbed. Thinks very highly of herself. Learned nothing from the course and her reading selections were all irrelevant. Stay away if you can. Gives no constructive feedback. Every student in the class felt let down. Crimminal that the U of R can take money for her courses.

She is a great professor. And contrary to a prior post, she does not hate men, she just probably despised that student because he seems close-minded. I was a male student in her class, and she was always helpful. If you didn't understand something in class or wanted to debate further, you could always  go to her office hours and talk on end.

nice lady, means well...but she's very unclear in her lectures. she is often scattered and the notes you take don't make much sense later. Part of this is because she is not very engaging. I love American History, but this was soooo boring. I also felt that her essay grading wasn't too fair.

Prof. Rubin got me excited about American cultural history -- I never expected that to happen! But she made history come to life. She asks good questions and really gets the class to think seriously about American cultural life. She is one of the most helpful, kind, and compassionate professors I have encountered at Rochester.
Hates men and makes it very clear. Rude and   Unless you are very liberal stay away
No Comments
Rubin is sweet, intelligent, and I enjoyed her lectures.
No Comments

Aside from not posting a syllabus (he announces everything each lecture). He is a very straightforward professor and incredible lecturer. He not only introduces basic quantum, but prepares students with more advanced topics such as Entanglement and Dirac notation. Contacting him takes time, so don't be afraid to talk him about meetings after class.

He has short lectures and while they do have examples they can be a little too much theory. He can be hard to reach outside of class and tended to post homework late and not actually do the weekly quizzes
Easy to get an A in his class and he is a good researcher, yet he is really bad at teaching.

Did not attend more than 5 lectures for the entire semester. Prof Bigelow is a very nice guy and cares a lot but his lectures are not useful at all. He presents the slides and then reads and explains them. There is no working through long problems in class. Workshops are a complete waste of 3 hours. Class material is not bad if u r in engineering.
His grading is very inconsistent, as he says he will have quizzes every week but at the end of the semester we've only had 2
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Learned a little, but mostly was frustrated by group assignments and professors style. He definitely likes the sound of his own voice and has a large ego. This class is required.

I think of all the stem professors I've taken in this school, Professor Bigelow ranks in the top 5. His physics 113 was not graded on a curve but he didn't need to. His expectations were clear on what to do to ace the class in terms of number of points needed to earn for certain grades and was available outside class for help!
Possibly the nicest human ever. I had to take Physics and I am terrible at it. He was super helpful, caring, and patient. If you have a class with him, you are lucky!
Incredibly knowledgeable, helpful, and all-around friendly nice guy.  Take a class with him if you possibly can.
No Comments
A difficult course (but then quantum always is), but an EXCELLENT teacher and a great all-around guy.  Very busy, though, so be sure to *schedule* office-hours & other appointments.

Caring professor, super nice and approachable (open to all questions), and very knowledgable in his field of study!
The homeworks can be a little tough/time-consuming, but they're really interesting and you get a lot out of them. It's easy to get full points too, as long as you make sure to thoroughly answer the questions!
Would recommend
Steve is a hilarious person and great lecturer! His class is pretty hard, but engaging lectures more than make up for it
Caring and kind professor! Clear lectures as well. The assignment-based format of the class (no midterms/finals) made it easy for me to emphasize learning over grades.

It appears that all of the people who found Prof Piantadosis class difficult go to U of Rochester, which isnt exactly known for its rigor to be blunt. Steve is a truly great prof. His lectures are informative and his attitude is caring and fair. While the class was disorganized, it was easy to look past that all else considered
Boring
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Lectures were easy-ish to understand, but I was really unsure about in what way the materials are going to be tested. No sample questions or whatsoever to help.

I did not find this class to be anything but disappointing. He should really stick to research. He seems to find making the class difficult fun. His lectures were sometime difficult to follow. The exams were hard and he was not the most helpful, nor was he willing to explain things in a clearer way. Do not take this class.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Tough grader. hard class. Weekly assignment with tough grading and you dont even get feedback on your assignment. Concentrate a lot on research which is confusing during lecture. lecture was helpless but had to go because attendance is mandatory. Hard exams ! And final is worth 30% of your grade!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: He is not a lecturing professor and needs to just stick to research
Really enjoy this class! The assignments are really inspirational! Love him!

Professor Piantadosi is highly knowledgable, and it comes across in his lectures. The material is tough, but totally fascinating. Tests are tricky multiple choice, but there are also weekly writing assignments to boost your grade. Attendance is not taken, but there's a large amount of content so, functionally, you won't pass if you skip lectures.

Professor Braun was the best professor I ever had. He explained philosophy in a way that was very clear and allowed me to evaluate old questions in new ways. He is very inspirational. I am 38 now but took the class almost 20 years ago.

Prof. Braun is a great guy.  Knows his material very well.  Funny, nice, and smart.  Has a quirky way of getting some of his examples across, but it keeps interest going.  I will be taking him again next semester.
Adequate.  Don't expect any inspiration or anything, though.
Has a very absurd and sick sense of humor.  Knows his material very well and encourages thoughtful discussion.  Excellent lecturer.  Most enjoyable professor I've had from this school.
Knows logic in and out. Practically wrote the book. Good explanations, makes sure you know what you're doing. Kind, considerate, learns your name. Great professor.
take notes exactly as written on the board, don't miss class, don't read the text, don't bother with the T.A. Prof. Braun is a smart man, learned my name, and the class was interesting.
Rote memorization, mathematical proofs applied incorrectly and irrelevantly to philosophical concepts, but mainly incorrectly. There is no clear use of logic to derive philosophical conclusions.
ehh,its just rote memorization on exams, dont read the text, but take notes (exactly as written) for the tests
No Comments
All you have to do in the exams is write what he gave you in the notes verbatim.
Seems like a brilliant man, learned my name, but doesn't make himself accessable to students. the T.A. is a shmuck.

Professor Masny is the most understanding and kind professor you will ever have. She will notice you are stressed even without you telling her and will make accommodations for such. She deserves to be a tenured professor. The exams contain material discussed in class or lecture and are completely fair. I am glad I took her course.

Her exams are easy as long as you plan ahead and start studying early, because the exams are mostly memorization. She also does weekly online quizzes and you HAVE to be in class because a code is usually required. Her labs are alright, but sometimes difficult to understand with the way she words things. She's a nice person, overall.

Julia reads off slides most of the time but can easily answer questions and expand. It's a difficult class if you don't do well with solid lectures; I had to go home and teach myself everything simply because it's not a style that works for me. GO TO CLASS! She will give extra credit for attendance, especially if attendance is generally low.

Professor Masny is a nice person, but she clearly doesn't know how to teach in an engaging or educational manner. She almost entirely reads from slides for her lectures, making attending class practically pointless. The labs are kind of fun and she's very helpful with questions, but overall don't expect to learn a ton.

I really enjoyed Prof. Masny, she is really kind and more than willing to help. The tests were pretty easy and there was not much homework. At times the lectures can be a bit slow, but all the important information is on the slides. You only need the lab manual even though another text book is recommended you do not need it.
Loved her slides, very informative

Really nice during lectures and labs, a few extra credit assignments as well as bonus questions on tests to help boost your grades. Easy to talk to if you had any questions. Only need the textbook for lab but you could just share with your partner.

Very chill about missing class when youre sick/traveling, just wants you to get your work done tbh. Ask questions and attend lecture, lab is basically just another assignment. Masny knows her stuff and is very invested in the subject.

The class is extremely easy as long as you show up to lectures and labs. It feels like an easy high school course. She makes sure everyone knows what's going on in lectures and labs, even though the labs can be a bit confusing. There's practically no homework and as long as you go to lecture the tests will be easy. She's also a great lecturer.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: Professor Masny is very nice and caring, and she answers all the questions you have in lab and homework. Sometimes her tests and labs might be difficult and frustrating, but she's very likely to help if you ask. You won't regret taking this course!!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Took her for intro to earth sciences. The class isn't too hard compared to a lot of other classes, but sometimes the lab/test questions can be worded weirdly, especially if you do it online and not in person. Overall, she is very nice and understanding! There isn't much HW which is very nice.

The class itself isn't very hard. She's just super disorganized and has no structure to anything. Her grading also makes no sense. I got almost perfect scores on my bibliography and prospectus but then got a low grade on my final paper for which there was not much explanation, and with no feedback until I asked for it. Avoid her at all costs.

She is a bit scatterbrained with assignments to the point that it might hurt your grade sometimes. That being said, she's incredibly smart and I did enjoy her lectures and came back to take another class with her later. She also gave great feedback/advice. Not everybody's cup of tea but if your interested in the subject, definitely take her class.
She is unorganized. Does a terrible job at clarifying course material. Your grade will mostly likely suffer after taking her class.

Terribly unorganized.  I saw far too many peoples' grade suffer due to her vague assignments, unclear directions, or general lack of any semblance of structure. I don't think she even knew what she was trying to teach the class.  She may be nice, but don't let your grade or your interest in linguistics take a hit by taking one of her classes.
You will learn so much from her.  She is just fantastic.  Love her love her love her.  Enough said.

Joyce is a really great professor and lecturer.  Yes, she's scatterbrained--you just have to get on her with questions.  She might not always be clear in answering them, but if you pester her enough you'll get your answer.  Any class she teaches is definitely worth taking.
Extremely vague about assignments.  Frequently makes mistakes.
Joyce does a decent job of explaining basics, and although she's flighty she has her own special sort of organization.  She's very helpful and generous, if nothing else.

She's very engaging, and really makes me into it (although lots of ppl fall asleep). Her problem is that she sometimes doesn't define concepts, so she'll say "this is when.." and give an example as the definition.
Very sweet lady, sometimes the topic can be slow or dull, but she's very good about explaining it.  Not much homework either, compared to sciences.  Tests aren't too bad.
Ah Joyce

She is a great professor, all you have to do is show up on class and hand in assignments on time and you will be fine, and even with that kind of stuff she is incredibly understanding. She is clearly passionate about the subject as long as you listen you will learn a lot.

Never be late. Never miss class. Hand things in on time. You'll be fine if you do those three things. I definitely see why people don't like her but in class, she can be very funny and charismatic. Just don't get on her bad side.

One of the WORST professors I've ever had. Not compassionate at all, yells at her students, and gets easily frustrated. She acts like her students are a burden and continuously emphasizes how much she doesn't want to be there. If you have to take SPAN 151 or 152, take it with Komocki instead, he's the exact opposite and so incredibly nice!

Never had a problem with her. Then again Im well-behaved and do my work on time. There are a lot of tests but theyre very casual. Because of her fun nature people assume that the class doesnt require as much effort, but youll still need to study and work if you want a good grade. Though she teases a lot, shes very patient and lets many things slide
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: Horrible. Consistent attitude & don't be shocked if she blames it on her health condition. Makes a lot of racial comments, constantly insisting the Korean student in our class eats japchae & listens to k-pop. Will yell at you and Godforbid you sniffle in her class, she will make it seem like you have cancer and you are highly contagious.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Within the first 5 minutes of our first class, she asked a non-white student what his "real name" was, shoved a student out of the classroom, and said we had to keep our hands visible to prevent phone use. She gives multiple due dates for each assignment, and treats you with near 0 respect. I am almost certain that she wrote the other reviews here.

She's an amazing teacher, but the class feels harder than it needs to be. Lecture's are great, she's really caring and funny, but expect to participate a decent amount. I'd say the only downside is she doesn't really know how to make tests since they always take way too long to finish. It's not a very hard class if you do the hw and study for tests
Truly cares about her students and will make time outside of class to help you
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: Profesora R-R is awesome. She's very clear and funny but her class isn't the easiest - you have to do the work. She cares about the wellbeing of her students as well as their academic performance. She calls herself Mother Theresa, she's SO right.

I can say with confidence that professor Rojas is by far the best professor I've had yet. She is amusing, funny, understanding, and very helpful - which isn't to say she's a pushover! You will learn a LOT from her!

Professor Rojas is extremely fun and interesting, my favorite so far at the University. She is engaged and makes a huge effort to help her students and get to know them. The class isn't ridiculously easy, but it is fantastically rewarding and you'll learn a great deal. She is a native speaker and generally only speaks Spanish in class.
He's an awesome lecturer and cares his student a lot. Even though the freshman organic chemistry is much harder than the sophomore one, it worth it.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: This professor has a wonderful teaching style and know very well what he is teaching.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Freshman organic chemistry is very hard. However, Professor Weix provides you with everything you need to make it through. If you put in the effort, attend all the lectures and workshops, you can make it through. After every test he gives the class a pep talk (avg. is usually around 60%; big curve as a result). Gifted lecturer
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Good lectures make the class interesting and if you keep up with the reading you shouldn't have any issues
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Dr. Weix is a great lecturer who genuinely cares about his students. He's accessible and understands the student's perspective, so it's nice to talk to him during office hours if lectures don't already make sense. Tests are totally fair for the material (for Chm 171) and lab is exactly as challenging as it should be (Chm 210).

Beware, this guy plays favorites. He might not try to, but in this class he definitely reached out to the freshmen way more than the sophomores. The grading scheme is confusing, so it can be hard to do well if you haven't ever written reports for him before. In spite of it all, if you get on his good side the class will go well for you.

He is a great lecturer and cares so much about the course and the students. We definitely had a great understanding of what to do in lab before we got in there and why. The lab was a ton of work both in lab and for lab reports, but it makes everyone a way better chemist. Only gripe is that the grading system is not straight forward, so it stressful
Same grader as the previous rating. I made a mistake th class is CHM 171 not CHM 173 my bad.

The class is a lot of work to keep up with the material and the exams are definitely challenging but his curve is nice and he's very well-liked by the students. He's funny and ties the stuff from lecture into real-life chemistry lab work. His lectures are definitely the most important, especially later in the course. I'm very glad I took the class.
It's clear cut- he really cares. The textbook sucked though- get orgo as a second language.

Pretty nice guy who is rather knowledgeable in the area of organic chemistry.  He is very willing to help you out if you have questions.  The lab reports are rather grueling, however, and the class really should be at least 4 credits instead of 2.  But that isn't his fault.

AMAZING professor. Lectures are engaging and he's hilarious. Exams are killer, but if you do the review sheets (most answers are in the txtbk) and memorize hard, you'll be fine. Reached out to me when I wasn't doing well and took time to meet and go over material to help raise grade. Continued checking up on me afterwards, never had a prof so nice!
Awesome teacher but the class isn't easy. Study for his tests, attend class and you'll be fine. He's also extremely friendly and personable.

One of the best psych classes I've taken.  This professor is one of a kind (in a good way, could not believe he has a phd when first saw him).  In class exercises and demonstrations were very helpful.  Provides nice review sheets before tests.  However the tests are still difficult.  Over all though, professor and class are both highly recommended.

Probably the most interesting lecture class I've ever taken. Shows lots of videos and examples and has a good sense of humor. I would go to this class just for fun. EXAMS are killer though, more information than you could ever remember and he asks a lot of detail. A lot of work, difficult to do well, but incredibly interesting.
no tests!!! Assignments were easy as long as some effort was put in. Professor was knowledgeable about the field and ecouraged discussion and questions. VERY approachable

I really liked the way he set up his lectures and his classes are really entertaining.  His review sheets are killer, but if you actually do them, you'll ace his exams.  He isn't tricky in any sense on his exams.  He does do in class exercises, so if you don't go to class that might hurt you.
I thought the class was really interesting.  He made the material easy to relate to by always showing videos and giving good examples.
frustrating class. poor lecturer. his voice killed me too.
He was entertaining...his voice killed me!
Hated him.
No Comments
Yea Burns rocks-IN RECITATION. In recitation he explains everything perfectly while making everyone fall on the floor laughing. Lectures are ok but not as good.

The lectures can be boring but that's due to the subject, and Burns tries to keep it engaging with his jokes. I think he's a really nice guy, and generally a good professor, but he does occasionally make mistake in his example problems that can be confusing. Taking the class with him was just fine, and he easily accommodates for any issues.

Professor Burns do sometime makes the lecture sounds difficult. However he is super reachable after lectures, and he's very willing to explain any confusion you may meet. Spend more time into this class and it shall be a easy pass. (i admit it's not that easy to get an A rank)

I took solids (226) and materials (280) with him and I think he's great... His lectures are hard to follow but his tests are similar to the homework and workshop problems and if you can do the practice exam type problems, you'll do fine. Burns is really understanding and just a great guy. Enjoy!
Very friendly and enjoyable to talk to. Very helpful one on one, a bit confusing with the organization of lecture notes. Good jokes.

Never expect to take coherent notes. Disheveled, and unorganized. Nevertheless a pretty understanding guy. (In our class he pushed back the homeworks almost everytime we asked). Goes off on tangents a lot.
Shouldn't be the chair.  Very unorganized.  Tests were a surprise not related to course material.  Reviews don't help.
I love him.

Seems jovial, but really is stubborn, not too interested in the students, and is often unclear. About 20 minutes before the end of almost every lecture, he would go off on some calculations/problem and leave almost all the students scratching their heads.
Very unorganized.
He is very boring and inconsistent.

The intro to neuro class is a good introduction to neuroscience at UR. His class is fair, but hard, and the tests are easy if you study hard enough and listen to lectures. Bring a recorder, his slides are only pictures.
He is very nice, but his class is very hard
He leaves no holes in his explanations, he is my favorite neuroscience professor at the University of Rochester
good lecturer, knows the subject really well

He's an exceptional lecturer: while he's not funny nor animated, he is very clear, organized, and genuinely interesting. Be sure to bring a recorder, as the slides only have pictures. The class is challenging, but the practice exams help a lot. If you're interested in neuro, you'll probably enjoy his lectures. NSC249 is much better than NSC201 IMO

Nordeen (the man...he also has a wife who teaches) is a very organized lecturer and clear on the material. He is, however, kind of boring. Slides are useless unless you have the lectures recorded (the ppt's are only pictures, no words).
slides fairly useless for studying but pretty good lectures

I thought he did an alright job.  He is always there to meet with you in office hours if you need it.  The tests are not hard if you do the back ones.  He is kind of boring and not excited about the material.  But overall not bad

Instead of worrying about fluffing up his vocabulary in lectures, he should turn his attention how he treats students.  The intro neiro class is used by him to pick out the brightest students to work in his lab.  He told me getting my masters in Neuroscience would be a waste of my time.  The favortism is sickening.
No Comments

Prof. Nordeen didn't care the least bit about the fact that I couldn't write a paper because my mother was sick with cancer and eventually died later that year.  There is another student I know who had a similar situation and he didn't care there either.
She can be a bit confusing, but is a greater help when you see her during office hours. The class was good prep for Lin 110 and she's a nice lady.

She sucks. I was interested in linguistics before taking her class and now I never wanna hear the word "linguistics" ever again. She cannot explain herself and hands out tons of useless instructions that simply confuse you further.

I became disinterested in her classes because I didn't feel like I was learning anything.  A lot of class is interactive, which should be interesting, but instead feels like a painful beating of a dead horse.  She is a nice woman, and it's an easy class.  I would like to see her teaching a tougher Linguistics course.  The 101 level was just boring.

ok so she's a little scattered and last minute about things, but for the most part the class is easy so this is not too much of an issue. she is a genuinely nice lady who cares about her students. she was always very considerate and helpful!
Ridiculous essay prompts, excessive homework, last-minute emails, and difficult to understand.

The course has little unifying theme- very scattered.  The workload is minimal, though she relies on TA's to do all of the grading.  There were two TA's for my section, and grades varied significantly between the two- basically all grades were left up to luck.  Never used the book...

Really nice lady, but she's a little loony.  Sometimes she's a little condescending, but I don't think it's intentional.  Her assignments and directions are usually pretty unclear, but she's willing to help.  She sends a ton of e-mails, so prepare to be pestered.  Also, she's very nitpicky with essays (critical of the little things), but not a difficult grader.

Ok, so I didn't have her for linguistics, which is her natural calling. But for CAS, she's horrendous. She doesn't know what she's doing, she can't make her assignments clear, she constantly contradicts herself, repeats herself, confuses everyone, and is just generally bad. She does give good feedback on essays, though.

I actually really liked prof webb. I though she  is very devoted to her teaching. She is an easy grader, the material is easy, not alot of hw or reading. I thought she was really nice, though sometimes a bit scatterbrained. Every once in a while it would get boring, but i mean how many people can make the evolution of the tract interesting??

She sucks. She might say the same thing at least 10 times in the same class. She will more than likely repeat the same thing 10 more times each class after that. If I hear anyone say "home sign system" again, Ill kill myself

Good class.  Excellent teacher.  She really knows her stuff.  She does seem to spend a little bit too much time on gestural communication, since it's her specialty, but all in all, the class was an excellent review of linguistics, and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

FMS 131 was the worst college course I've taken. Big lecture-style class but attendance was mandatory and for some reason they tried to make it discussion-based? The "lecture" part was mainly powerpoints with quotes from that day's reading (aka lazy&pointless). Oh. And the convoluted prompts for "response papers" (graded by TA's--very inconsistent)
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: I took Intro to Media Studies with Professor Haidu last semester and I liked the class, even though it was for Humanities Cluster. There is a ton of readings (some are pretty difficult) for class but she explains it pretty well. The class is graded on midterms, weekly journals, and participation. She grades pretty hard in general, but is nice.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This class was terrible for me. The professor is alright. She's a lot nicer and more helpful at her office hours. The topic of this class is just dry and uninteresting to me, just required for my major. Tons of reading about useless things. Go to class, do the homeworks, ask questions, go to office hours, study and you will get an A+
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: She made this class super interesting (sparking my interest as an AH minor) and helped a lot outside of the classroom. Studying for the tests were lots of work and the readings were dense and difficult, but very well explained in class and super interesting (the responses helped me grow as a writer too). Definitely recommend.

I had Haidu for Hist of Photo, and she made the class very interesting. The exams were a little tricky as you had to remember lots of photo ID's and there is alot of emphasis on participation in class but she knows her stuff and her lectures are very interesting :) I recommend taking her classes
Engaging lecturer.  A very fair, but tough grader.  The readings are difficult.  Helpful outside of class.
She's amazing!
Man, I wish I were in her league

The course was interesting on its own, which helps things along.. She's not the most interesting lecturer (class was 1.25 hrs and i would start checking my watch around a 1/2 hr to 45 min through), so when the stuff we discussed got less exciting the second half of the semester, I had a lot more trouble paying attention.
No Comments
Some problems with course, readings too hard/boring/much.  Overall not a harsh grader and fair.

Not really about VLSI. Mainly covers the metallization. Not very update professor. He still talks about inductance, while modern technologies do not give a damn. I was impressed by his large number of citations, and later figured most of the citations are self-citation. Not a bad course for getting an easy A.
His knowledge is outdated.

Awful professor. Doesn't lecture well and seems like he doesn't know what he's talking about. He also has a weird thing against Chinese people. He called out the Chinese students in our class on the first day, even though they didn't do anything wrong. He spent a whole lecture complaining about China's semiconductor industry instead of teaching us.

While the VLSI is all about technologies, giving some obsolete lectures is the only thing he does. Nothing to learn from his lectures. IMPOSSIBLE to access him out of the classroom. Sending email to him is forbidden. Weird as hell.
REALLY hard.  REALLY good experience.
Excellent professor.  Drives you to work very hard.  Doesn't like lazy students.  You'll learn a ton.  Very time consuming... wouldn't advise mixing this class with a job.  Grade A class.
He is the best I've ever met
Very tough professor, but very good class. Professor has extreme network of industry connections.
Hard as hell.  Come out clean.
Very hard, but you'll learn more in this class than in the rest of your university career.

Professor Friedman is an interesting guy.  He has tons of industry experience, and he talks about it all the time.  This class is the most difficult, but also the best course in terms of material that I have had at the University of Rochester.

Incredible lectures, really looked forward to going and hearing what he had to say about each topic. Even when it was supposed to be more "seminar" like, he still talked a lot which was good. He's really passionate about making sure you understand. Tests have both general ideas and specifics about the history of things, not so much hard bio info.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. Orr is great. interesting lectures, the science is easy if you have experience in bio, just make sure you know your history- he's passionate about you knowing how we found discovered things/lines of evidence, not just barebones facts. This is really the only undergrad course he's teaching right now, so don't miss your opportunity to take him!

Professor Orr is a great teacher! He explains concepts simply for non-science students, and he is willing to go over any questions in class. The content was interesting, and the workload wasn't too heavy. Just make sure to go to lecture and take good notes, because the tests are all short answer responses, so you need to know the information.
Great professor, great lectures.
Dr Orr was my favorite Bio prof @ UR. He's really smart & a bit of a renaissance man. Google his book reviews, he's a superb writer. Very interesting lecturer, Evolution was a great course.

Very interesting and knowledgeable professor.  Lectures were easy to pay attention to and very clear.  Be warned though, very short test with true/false questions.  Also be sure to know who (what scientist) did what or why they are important.  Over all, class and professor both recommended.
awesomest guy ever.

He's awesome.  If you attend classes and recitations you should have no problem getting an easy A in the class.  He's very good at his explanations and very helpful to anyone who has questions.  By far my favorite professor at UR :)

While one of the best classes i've taken at the UofR, I don't know how much credit I can give the guy who was the biological consultant for the movie EVOLUTION. If you haven't seen the movie then you're lucky... it was horrible.
HOT!!!
Awesome professor and an all around nice guy. Clearly presented, interesting material and he's always helpful. Tests can be tricky.
She's actually really helpful and makes an effort to explain confusing information to her students.
She was nice but rather boring. Her Tests/Lectures were straight from the book.
As long as I actually paid attention and went to class, I did well. Really enjoyed the class and would recommend it. Textbook not assigned but helps a lot while studying.

She isn't that bad. I didn't like that she read straight from the slides and didn't seem to know much of anything. She couldn't answer student's questions but she did convey the material clearly. I wouldn't suggest taking it if you're looking for an insightful, knowledgeable prof.

MSA was the worst teaching experience that I've ever had in my life. She was reading straight from the textbook, unenthused and only really cared about her kids. The only reason anyone ever attended class was to hear her random pieces of information that were used for extra credit ex) what her youngest son was for Halloween. DO NOT TAKE HER COURSE

She is not as bad as everyone says she is... I found her very accomodating, organized, and patient with us.  She teaches from the book, but she gave us all the tools we needed to do well- provided the student study.  I personally learned a lot and and enjoyed the lectures.

by far the worst professor i have yet had. as someone else said, she seems to know the material less than her students.  she is about as knowledgable and good at lecturing as a high school substitute teacher. i stopped going to class after the first exam.
she is a totally incompetent teacher. probably knows the material less then the students do.
Willing to accomodate to the students and helpful, lecture is straight from the book and painful at times to sit through
Totally is a horrible Lecturer!!!  DOESNT KNOW WHAT SHE IS TALKING ABOUT

The concepts he goes over in class are really something you can't learn anywhere else, making it hard to study if you didn't quite understand things in class. His lectures can be pretty dry if linguistics is not super interesting to you. He gives opportunities for extra credit, but his tests are extremely difficult.
rating_tags: Participation matters--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Incredibly helpful, especially to students getting involved with research. He's intense, but definitely accessible.
Hard, Hard, hard!

People who care about getting a pretty good grade with low effort love this class. People who come wanting to really learn about language research... prepare for disappointment. The professor is nice, but spends a lot of time talking about himself and, when on topic, he often makes no sense. As an eager learner... I resented the time I lost here.
Interesting class, but professor is a bit full of himself and refers to his own work excessively... and he's not very clear a lot of the time, but is so sure of himself, he will likely never notice.

Great Professor. His idea about the discussion forum is great since it answers a lot of questions quickly! Gives a superset of exam questions which makes studying super easy!Also he is adorable and super hot with German accent ;)
Excellent teacher! Florian is the MAN!  He gave out a superset of test questions before each test.  It made studying a breeze!  Class was still challenging though.

He moves a little slow at times (spends way too much time explaining things), but he is so kind and willing to help.  He really cares about his students.  And the class is interesting (lots of interesting guest lecturers) and not hard.
really nice guy, good lecturer, he also gives you the test questions before the test so that definitely helps.  you don't always have to go to class either which is kinda nice.

Florian is very helpful and routinely sends out e-mails to remind us about the homework or explain something from class. Tests questions are always provided in advance so you are aware of what will be on the exam. Also, he's really hot (especially with his German accent) :)
Can't teach, sexist, and not a good person. Other than that he was great!
Generally a terrible person. Should probably be fired just for being such a jerk. Has it out for women and undergrads in his classes.
Knows the material he is teaching but does not know how to teach. He reads of slides that are just taken from the book. The hardest midterm i have ever written in my life.

He's a nice person, and knows the content of the course. However, his tests and assignments are way too hard based on what he teaches in class. As well, his lectures are very boring and is mostly just copied from the textbook. The first midterm was the hardest test I have ever taken.

His lectures are a slideshow of screenshots he took FROM THE TEXTBOOK. He NEVER solves problems during class. The online assignments are difficult and impossible to complete without Chegg. His midterm was extremely difficult and did not reflect the lecture or homework. He takes off marks for asking previously answered questions.

Truly an awful professor, the worst I've ever had. To start, if you ask a question that he deems "irrelevant", he literally takes marks from your final grade on the spot. His first midterm was the hardest test I've ever written, and the class unanimously agrees that the material on it was FAR beyond what was covered in the lectures or homework.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Does not do enough examples and hates answering questions. I wish he could teach the material he put on the mid term.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: The midterm was the most difficult test I have ever seen. He has lots of office hours and isnt that bad of a teacher but the homework and midterm were death level.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: You should feel privileged, you are about to be taught by the worlds worst professor (in history). Actually, taught is the wrong word in his context. He will not be teaching you. His lectures are deadly boring. His tests are irrelevant to the homework and lectures. You cannot ask him questions without getting penalized academically, not kidding.

Classes tend to be very boring and drag along forever. He doesn't get involved enough in his examples and the class often turns into simply watching him do calculations instead of learning. He is pretty clear with his explanations and will answer any questions you have. His demonstrations are actually pretty helpful usually.
Professor Berger is one of the only professors to teach at a conceptual level first and foremost. I don't think any class has helped me understand the concepts as well as his has. Highly recommend.

Haven't had him much for 223 yet; however, he's a great professor who takes his time to explain concepts thoroughly. He does tend to drift around the same material a tad too long, though he ultimately succeeds in getting his students to understand all the topics fully. I hope that this pacing does not rush the end of the class, but so far so good!

This Professor has a horrible set up he has all of the lectures recorded and the uses in class time to talk about useless an inane things. He gives students a huge amount of meaningless busy work. I would recommend avoiding this class if at all possible. He is a terrible professor and an annoying person

-Master of literature, but not suitable for teaching physics stuff. Really good at making metaphors, comparisons, piling up decorous sentences to explain simple things. -Like to waste time making students poll in class and have fun seeing their puzzled faces, never clarify the answer, and make students poll many times until the majority got right
Very willing to help and make sure you understand the material. Sometimes his methods are complicated. Make sure you know your matrix math. Would highly recommend his other class - Biomedical Optics.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Great professor!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Awesome teacher- I highly recommend taking his classes. He's really organized and all the hw relates to material and notes.  It's a tough class, but you learn a lot.
He tries to make the class fun
No Comments
Deserves the best award there is for a teacher. Class material wasn't that difficult but w/o a good professor, it can be horrible. He made it great

DONT take this class if you dont need it. Prof. speed runs PowerPoints of 50+ slides, each slide containing enough for 10 mins of content. Often wouldn't finish slides and tell us to go over it on our own. VERY DISORGANIZED. Exams are ridiculously difficult considering the amount of information you need to take in. Only 3 tests = overall grade.

If you don't have to take this class, then don't. Her accent is pretty hard to understand. Her grammar and sentence structure is even worse. lectures are disorganized. her exams focus on like 4 concepts. In other words, knowing 8 slides well can get you an A. But the exam covered literally 380 slides. Worst bio class i've taken besides physiology.
Very kind and helpful! She gives a lot of information in lecture, but really works with the students to help them understand the material. One of the biology classes I've learned the most in.

Really sweet lady but a pretty lousy professor. Her lectures are incredibly disorganized and difficult to follow. You have to put in a lot of work outside class to make sense of what's going on. Her tests are tough and there are only 3 of them. No textbook, it's all based on papers (you can skim them - no heavy reading).

Pros: extremely intelligent, kind, knowledgeable, helpful  professor. Cons: I personally had a lot of trouble following her lectures. Her accent is not difficult at all to understand, it is the lack of a flow in her sentence structure and in her lectures. The figures in her slides are equally fragmented and esoteric. Her exams are very detailed.
I liked the class, but I saw her once during office hours and she was really rude and unhelpful to me for no reason...it was such a bad experience it ruined the class for me :(

Dr. Benyajati is difficult to adjust to because of her accent and communication skills, but when you get past that she is absolutely one of the best professors here. She really wants all of her students to do well and will be as helpful and supportive as she can. The class was interesting too, a lot of writing, but Tip made it manageable. Love her
Miserably difficult class. I wish she'd have made better slides or at least labeled the figures. But she's really nice and helpful.
Really smart professor, goes very fast in lecutre which can be annoying, but good staying after to help you.  The textbook is really good for clarification.

Dr. Benyajati is one of the most knowledgable professors.  She does have an asian accent, but once you get past that anybody should realize how great of a professor she is.  She has always been there to help me, and she is willing to help those that ask.  Don't expect a platter with your name on it.
He was the only teacher who I could engage intellectually. We had good debates back and forth. Overall a very charming scholastic bourgeoisie.

He can make the most difficult philosophy texts clear, fun, and understandable, which is just incredible. Every lecture is mind-blowing and highly packed, but if you concentrate they are easy to get immersed in. A lot of readings are needed for good grades (the quizzes are pretty hard to get higher than B+). But the lectures are pure pleasure.
One of those guys who wants his students to like him. Don't get on his bad side. Better yet: avoid him.

A superb professor who is passionate about what he's teaching and about his students' learning. Effectively explains difficult, dense material in engaging lectures and is super knowledgeable. I sometimes struggled in his class but he was extremely helpful to me!
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Doran is one of the best professors I've had at UR. He's charismatic, understanding, and absolutely loves what he teaches. The readings he assigned were pretty dense, but I really enjoyed how he presented them. My writing also improved a lot in his class.

Robert Doran is one of my favorite professors, presenting the material in a clear and engaging manner. He's also a nice guy who genuinely wants to help his students gain a better understanding of the material and do well in his class

He is extremely outgoing. He makes learning fun, which is a rarity in college. His passion translates into his teaching, and yet is he never so passionate as to deride a student when he or she tries arguing against him. Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. TAKE THIS CLASS - YOU WILL LEARN SO MUCH AND YOU WILL LOVE THIS MAN.
Great teacher who gives his students every possible opportunity to succeed. Extremely approachable and knowledgeable.
REALLY GOOD professor!! The class really helps you learn French. I'd definitely recommend it!
Great guy, some of the grammar is a little confusing and he's really tough on papers but tests are easy for the most part.

Upon entering her class, I was genuinely excited about ancient history. I soon realized she was excessively strict, teaching in a dull, textbook manner. Her grading lacked flexibility, resembling that of a robot. Honestly, she ranks among the worst professors I've had so far. If given the chance, I would definitely avoid taking her class again.

I adore Professor Colantoni - she has a very traditional teaching and exam style, but it's not a bad way of learning at all. She's very passionate and it's contagious. Her lectures also aren't boring. If she doesn't know the answer to a question she will research it and get back to your next class

Professor Colantoni is easily my favorite professor at U of R. She gives very traditional-style lectures, but she keeps them interesting. The reading is just enough to give you a thorough understanding of the topic and is very manageable. Show up and pay attention and an A is easily achievable in her classes. She's also just a great person!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Colantoni is great! She gives a lot of relatively traditional lectures, but she's good at it so it isn't really an issue. Expect 2-3 textbooks, which you will actually use. As long as you show up, pay attention, and do the reading an A is easily doable.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof Colantoni is great. She's super knowledgeable about her material, and presents it in a style that makes it easy to remember and repeat on the test.  If I had to complain about something it's the fact that she talks really fast and it's hard to get everything she says written down, and she's overly picky about grammar and style on papers.

There is simply nothing wrong with Professor Colantoni, as a person and as a professor. She's possibly the most knowledgeable professor I've had in any subject, and very clear with her thoughts and teaching methods. Her tests you have to study for, absolutely, but they're extremely fair. Take her classes!!!

There is not a single bad thing I can say about this professor, and I would say she is one of the single best teachers I've ever had. Extremely helpful, extremely knowledgeable about her subject, and a very fair test giver, I would recommend to take anything she teaches!
Very engaging; clearly knowledgeable of the subject matter. A lot of reading but definitely enlivens the material taught in class.

She's awesome! Definitely have to do your work and come to class, but she's extremely helpful and knowledgeable of the subject. Even if it's not part of her major, take one of her courses for fun! Note that it usually is a bit more reading and work than other classes you're used to.

Great professsor! She's very approachable and very helpful outside of class. Lectures consisted of her talking to the class with a powerpoint in the background to supplement what she had to say. Tests were very straightforward and you knew what to expect.

As someone who has no interest in philosophy, she made PHIL 101 pretty palatable. Her lectures were relatively interesting and the readings were mostly engaging. She is very understanding and flexible, but basically all of the grading is done by the TAs. There is really not a lot of work for this class, 4 easy assignments and 2 essays.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: We need to read a lot and the material is hard. Participation grade is an important portion of this class, or the most important. However, I would prefer if we are asked to write essays about different philosophers instead of only one. Feel like that would benefit my understanding.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof. Peterman is amazing! At first, I wasn't excited to take this class, but she makes modern philosophy way more interesting than I thought was possible. The assignments are pretty easy and she tries to make them more fun/creative than most philosophy profs. She's very accessible outside of class and eager to chat with students. No final exam.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Peterman knows her stuff. She talks a lot in class but it is all interesting, and she leaves time for questions and discussion. The project is cool.
Not responsive to students' questions. Not very respectful to students either. The project seems to be fun but she is not very helpful since you can't reach her after class.
Really great!

A lot of the lectures are very heavy on reiterating what was read, but when this lapses into long discussions that's where the learning really happens. The 2 papers were a great chance to apply what we'd been learning. Before exams she gives a list of 20ish questions and 5ish of them will be on the exam.

History of Modern Philosophy is not the most interesting philosophy course, but Peterman presents the material in a clear way, and assigns a doable amount of readings. Requirements and grading are also fair.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read

comment: A very nice, down to earth professor, which is rare in the field of philosophy. Her classes are very fair as well.
It's a class all about metaphysics.  Really vague and boring material. She's nice though.

He is not a good lecturer.  His notes are posted online, and somehow more interesting and helpful than attending lecture.  He doesn't help you understand conceptually what we learn and why.  Not a good professor.

Michaels is one of the most approachable and respected teachers I've come across. He is always willing to help students, especially by answering questions in lecture. He also gives out his notes that are exactly what he goes over in lecture - you could never go to class and still get an A with these (but go to class because Michaels is great).

Prof. Michaels is probably one of the nicest people I've ever met. No matter how silly you may think your questions are, he will always answer them. His lectures are a little dry and long, but he posts notes for each unit which are incredibly helpful. The exams and problem sets are very difficult, and require a great deal of studying to do well.
Very clear and helpful. Super "intellectual" and interested in what he is teaching. Very happy with my experience in 209.

209 itself is hard but Michael makes it harder. However, he is very nice person and he is very willing to help students. He provides his version of notes which is really helpful. Homework is extremely hard, as our TA said they can't even solve a problem without answer key.  The exam is hard but there is a curve. The average is about 50 but I got 95

209 is a very difficult class and Michaels' tests expound on that. The average for the first midterm was a little below 50. There's a huge curve. Do the readings, go to class. As the class progresses, keep up to date with the notes. Know the intuition behind the models WELL. He's a very nice guy, and is very helpful if you talk to him personally.

I'm taking macro this semester and Michaels has got to be one of the worst professors. He goes through long mathematical derivations and doesn't explain them clearly. Homework is hard, and grades are fairly low. Avoid Michaels at all costs! I wonder how the first exam will be....

(This is with regard to his 209 course in fall 2011) Intermediate macro is all about abstract models and algebra, so it is hard to expect a professor to make it a lot of fun. I don't blame Michaels for that. He might not be the most engaging, but he prepares good lecture notes and is very willing to help. That's good enough.
Macro itself is hard but he makes harder. He is a smart guy but not good at teaching. The class ave is really low but there's a huge curve.
209 itself is hard but he makes harder.... Averages are really low in this class but there's huge curve. But still HARD.

Dr. Slone is a very structured, punctual professor. Class content is difficult, but understandably, as it is Calc II. Dr. Slone solves many example problems in class (but almost to the extent of quantity over quality). I'd suggest visiting office hours and especially math grad student office hours frequently. She also has weekly lecture notes.

Homework grading was very difficult and unclear. Even she sometimes didn't understand grades on homework, but communication with the grader should be better. If you showed up to lecture, she would give hints and answer questions. The material was easy, but the way it was graded definitely made the class more difficult than it needed to be.
The math is easy- the instructor makes it incredibly difficult. Her grading standards are enigmatic at best and unknown to you before you submit the homework. She is absolutely terrible.
RUNN!!!

I mean the grade for homework is kinda harsh but still manageable, in my opinion. Easy class, such a relief in a stressful semester. Didn't understand the last chapter very well tho. She gave a lot of reading days. The material is easy and kinda fun. I liked this class.

Grading is completely arbitrary. Problem 4 on the homework says do xyz? Nope, Carissa Slone wanted you to do abc. Goodbye homework grade. She never communicated that to you btw, you just have to guess. No rubric or anything. My weekly homework was always obscenely long, because every agonizing detail was knitpicked over. Incredibly frustrating.

Terribly unfair. This professor will judge your answers to a criteria that is completely impossible to follow. They will FIND REASONS to remove points from you. Never take this class. The math is super easy, but you will be graded to such a degree you won't be able to succeed.

Math is hard but Slone makes her lectures very clear and her lecture notes are fantastic and comprehensive. Very kind person. Had her for a math 162 sub for a week and understood the material far better than the entirety  of the semester previously, not even in her section but I use her notes to study and if I miss a class. 100% would recommend
Her lectures are very helpful and she's great at explaining the material. If you follow along and take good notes at lecture, you'll be well prepared for the tests.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Amazing notes and lectures are easy to follow
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: I love Heather so much. If you can, TAKE A CLASS WITH HER!!!! She cares so much about you outside of class and takes the time to get to know you, your interests, and your well-being. I wish I can take every class with her.

Heather Layton is one of the best professors in this entire school, she teaches painting in a way that gives you so much freedom, it was your vision not hers and she loved seeing everyone we came up with. She really enjoyed out of the box thinking, but no matter what was supportive of every students piece.

Professor Layton was one of my favorite professors I have ever taken. She is so incredibly kind and so beyond understanding. I was having a really difficult time in my life, and she would constantly take time out of her day to talk with me and support me. She is so inspirational and really amazing at dealing with all levels of skill. 11/10 Amazing!

What a great teacher. Very involved when you want her to be, very hands-off when you just want to work on your own. Also, incredibly smart and well experienced whether that has to do with art, science, or travel. Rated a 3 difficulty because once she sees what your capable of, there's no slacking.
She is really a great professor, even a great friend of student!
One of the best classes I've ever taken. Heather helps you grow as a person and as an artist in her class.
She's awesome.
So BRIGHT in every way. You will learn something about yourself in a class with Heather, guaranteed.
Heather doesn't trust anyone.

heather is a very inspiring teacher!  Down to earth, always enthusiastic, extremely helpful and fun spirited!  She is incredibly understanding and she brings out the very best in her students!  This class was a blast and I learned a ton about painting!  Love her to pieces!!!

As my first college-level language class, it was very fast paced and took a lot of effort to keep up. She is respectful and helful during her lectures even if she expects a lot out of her students. There is a lot of homework, so try to do around an hour of it per day to keep up with the content.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: She is very caring and willing to answer all questions you ask. She always encourages me when I feel nervous about the test or my progress. There is a lot of homework, but they are very helpful for understanding the texts and mastering new knowledge. Tests aren't hard if you put effort into it, and she gave us chance to get extra credit.

Professor Papaionnou's class is very stress free. She promotes an environment where you are allowed to make mistakes, which is imperative for a language course. She is very strict about attendance, which is the only issue I have during the pandemic (of 2020). Nonetheless, If you want to learn french, she is a solid choice.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Participation matters

comment: She's very disorganized and it's sometimes incredibly difficult to find out what's going on in the class. I feel like every time that I show up to class it's a complete gamble on what we're talking about that day. She doesn't really inspire or encourage discussion of topics and the homework is difficult and the workload is heavy.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor Papaioannou was a fantastic professor. She's clearly very knowledgeable about the material and values students who make an attempt to care about it like she does. 200 would be a very, very difficult class if you aren't coming in with a good amount of experience, but if that's the case, just start out lower down.

Prof. Papaioannou is a very good professor. It's easy to tell how passionate she is about the course she is teaching. The only thing that is difficult to get over is the grading. Man, she is such a tough grader that I've found myself honestly questioning the fairness of it, something I've never done before.
She is very passionate about the class and the topics at hand, but she can be a bit intense when it comes to perfecting grammar.
She is a caring person and teaches good lectures. If you attend lectures and do some review after class, you will be well-prepared for the exams. There is quite some homework though.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Her class is a challenge, but it's worth it. I've learned more from her than I have in any other French class.  Participation can be a little intimidating when you're first starting her class, but I at least got used to it. She seems to really love what she's teaching and she makes quite a few jokes, so she's made the challenging class fun.

She's a pretty harsh grader and she makes asking questions intimidating in class. You'll see people visibly confused but afraid to ask questions because of the demeaning way she tends to answer them. Overall, she's a nice lady, but she made me want to stop taking French. Also, the textbook doesn't have ANY guides for pronunciation, just listening.

She is wonderful. She's a fun person, and really wants to be there, which shows. She makes everything very interactive, which is fantastic in a language class. She grades fairly and tries to give you as many points as possible. She is really sweet, and very helpful. I've only been to her office hours once so far, but can't wait to go back.
great professor
Good professor

Honestly, I've taken statistics and economics honors before, so I'm not sure what went wrong in 230. But what I do know is that she really underestimates the level of exam difficulty -- they're far harder than the textbook problems, and the single practice exam per midterm she gives is not the best predictor of the exam difficulty. Avoid her.
She is a great professor with sophisticated understanding about econometric in financial world
Unhelpful lectures and does not prepare you well for the exams.

One of the worst professor I've ever met. Except for hw answer copied online, there's nothing else to review out of class. Everything needs to be done by reading the textbook by myself. She just can't prepare u well for the exam and even the answer for the past exam is really unclear and lack of working steps. NEVER TAKE HER CLASS!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: She is very kind and willing to help. The tests are very fair given the difficulty of the material, I always felt well prepared. The content is tricky but useful in applied data analytics.
Poor professor. with a thick Asian accent. Class is a waste of time, as she just teaches right out of the textbook. Notes all over the place, unorganized

Few hw assignments, and they are pretty short compared to what they could be, and the book is pretty helpful for them. Just pay attention in class to get the stata code and have a vague understanding and the class isn't too bad, it ended up being one of my favorite econ electives bc of material. One easy writing assignment for W requirement.

Not approachable. While the material and homeworks themselves aren't too hard to grasp, but she doesn't prepare you well for the exams. She misunderstands students' questions and basically teaches out of the textbook and it's examples. Class lectures are a waste of time. The only plus are her organized lectures. Heavy Chinese accent as well.
She is too foreign to understand and speaks too monotone. it usually put me to sleep in the class. it did not help that nobody showed up.

Objectively speaking BCSC 111 should be an easy course. However, this professor is literally the worst. Most of her TAs never took her class before, and her exams are hard (to the point of confusing some of her TAs!) If you try to give her advice or complain about the grade of the course, sorry, you will be rejected. The grading is kind of insane.

She is nice person and always reply to email but I truly don't like her lecture that much. Although she tried to make the classes engaged, it is still overall boring. I'm also not a huge fan to her speaking style. This class is overall very easy but grading is poorly designed. You need > 94 to get an A based on three 50 mcqs tests worth 30% each.

Poletti was a great BCS professor, and I really enjoyed her class. She tries to engage the class and involve us in the lecture which I loved. You do need >94% to get an A, but that is pretty doable as long as you go to class and pay attention.I would definitely take again if I could.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: BCS 111 is much easier than BCS 110, but her lectures are so boring and I definitely learned so much less. Her wording on exams is oftentimes very confusing, and she does not give points back. You need over a 94 to get an A, so while this class is very easy, getting an A is not that easy since you can only get 2 questions wrong on each exam.

Very good teacher, clear material, tests were straightforward, gave freedom of choice for the big end of year assignment which meant we could pick anything we were interested in as long as we could relate it to the general prompt
Ridiculously easy everyone should take it
Extremely easy compared to BCS111 and a nice professor! Not the most interesting class but her tests were fair/easy.

Absolutely nothing like BCSC 110 with Davis. Very relaxed and easy-going lectures. The exams aren't bad either, as long as you take notes and pay attention you'll be all good. She's pretty chill and a solid professor. Definitely would take this class again, easy to understand and learn. Took during COVID over Zoom.
The absolute sweetest, a true gem. Anyway yeah she's super nice and the tests are very straightforward. Just attend the lectures and pay attention and you should be good.
The lectures are basically watching youtube videos or documentaries. The 1 project was fun, but lectures are extremely boring and it's mainly focused on classical music.

yea grading is harsh. and the course should be called: experience Dr. Harman's music. You either get A or B(with just a single mistake you make on the exam) make you go to concert and unclear what he wants you to know.
If you are in his orchestra, you are more likely to get a good grade in this course.

Dr. Harman is a really amazing conductor.  He tells jokes, gets everyone involved and expects you to give your best everyday.  Because of his high expectations, he may seem arrogant, but he really just realizes everyone's true potential and strives to bring that out every day.

I don't agree with the previous posts. I took Harman's Symphony and the Conductor class and I loved it. Harman is just very enthusiastic and knowledgeable about music so he may seem arrogant, but he's really only passionate about what he does.   For MUR 121 he teaches with more of a discussion-based style rather than a lecture which was great!
he's not the usual conductor, but he knows his stuff and he's enthusiastic
i agree with the people who have called him arrogant. his grade scheme is such that 1 point off on any assignment is 1% off your semester grade. the assignments are also unclear and pointless.
agreed with previous post (4/28)
One of the most arrogant jerks I've ever met.  Fails to realize he's not at Eastman.

Harman is arrogant and not helpful. He makes you go to the concerts he conducts so he can brag about it the next week in class. The only bright spot was the TA, David Plylar, who was very helpful and nice.

He'll go over something truly difficult that the class has issues with and be like "Got that? Good" and move on, with all of us confused, then he'll proceed to explain how to factor a polynomial. If you ask him a question, he'll get very defensive about it. If he makes a mistake, he'll play it off like he's still teaching, and you made the mistake.

I was only in this class for a day; he scared me off with his messy handwriting and thick accent. There were only 10 people in my class so I switched out of Q for a larger class/slightly better prof. Prof makes the class, I think. He's very nice though, wants to be your friend and very eager to help. Plus points for that.
Great professor - one of my favorites in the math dept. Always willing to help and very approachable.
extremely willing to give help if you ask for it. cool guy with quirks you'd expect from a math professor. very approachable if you need help.

He tends to talk directly at the whiteboard which makes it hard to hear/understand if you're not in the first 2 rows of the class. However, the exam questions are almost identical to the practice tests, so getting a good grade is easy. He's a little monotonous, but is willing to go through practice tests to prepare for the final.
He's okay. The material isn't that challenging. He gets defensive when you ask questions, though. Ask anyway.
A terrible teacher.  He talks very quietly, mumbles, and has heavy accent.  Unable to answer questions or explain the material.  Luckily, he pretty much follows the book
No Comments
nice guy, tries hard to explain clearly
SHE IS AMAZING! I would recommend!
This professor is a very nice, hardworking professor. As one of her students, I recommend Afrah for your professor.

Shes honestly the best professor Ive ever had ever since I joined this university. Most professors dont care but shes so considerate and caring that I was shocked because of how rare it was in this university. I recommend taking a class with her! Her classes are easy, as long as you have a general idea of the language youll get an A easily.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: She is one of the nicest professor in the university. She is really empathetic and genuinely cares about her students. The classes are extremely easy if you go to classes and listen to her. The exams are basically what she teaches in class which prompts you to not miss a class. A very easy A if you go to all the classes

She's a really nice and caring person who'll go out of her way to help you. The tests are easy and it is easy to do good in this class. She's good for all Arabic levels - 101, 102, and 103. She requires that one participates in the class though.

This professor is very caring. Besides the Arabic language being challenging, she makes it fun and interesting. Very understanding and accessible outside class. There are also conversation hours which are very helpful.
She is extremely nice and a very reasonable person. She cares for her students and tries her best to make learning easier. Would definitely want to take more classes with her.

This course is a bit harder than ARA 101. Knowing all the stuff from ARA 101 would be beneficial. The readings in this course get much longer and some writing is introduced. One also has to pay attention to grammar. The tests are easy though and if one studies, it's not hard to get an A.

She's a great professor for Arabic. 101 was easy and the tests are very easy as well. The class involves some participation so don't expect yourself to just come, sit, and then leave. The course involves some reading and learning of a new script (obv) so if one is completely unbeknownst to that, one has to put in some effort the first few weeks.

I really enjoyed taking ARA 101 with her. She has a humble nature and always facilitates her students in the best possible way. She tries her best to make learning Arabic easy for her students and her tests are easy if you pay attention in class and do the homework.

Very fast-paced. Doesn't even give you time to open up the lecture slides , jumps straight into incredibly dense content.Uses too much jargon without explaining step-by-step what it means. Requires a lot of out-the-lecture work - the lectures are basically useless. It's better use of time to not attend , learn at your own pace and read the textbook
Good professor, but is fast paced and expects you to learn quickly. Very Dense class.
BAD
Very tough class. Does not explain material well.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Very hard class, does not teach the material well.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Smartest finance professor I've had!

Seems to be too smart for his own good. Glosses over fundamentals and goes into theory and proofs without really covering/practicing the basics so it's easy to get lost. Exams are torturous. Lectures go a mile a minute. Grad-level but expects a lot to be covered in undergrad when it often isn't. Way too much to cover/review in so little time.
he is really smart. i like him
He's pretty good at what he does.

This class is not easy and you shouldn't go in to it expecting it to be. However it is a really worthwhile course if you take it very seriously. He teaches you and provides you with the skills to really understand the financial investment techniques being developed and being used today. He is really good but tough.
This could have been such an interesting class and he absolutely killed it. His lectures are so dry and unengaging. There are no exams, only papers, and if you read the book you'll be fine.

He's a really nice guy but his lectures are somewhat inconsistant and repetitive. Most of the content comes from readings, which are a lot. You can miss a bunch of class (like me), do readings, and do well in the class. The exams/paper are reasonable but still difficult. No final, just a 10 page final paper. Consider the W, it's not much more work.

He is at least 90 years old. Half the time, I can't hear him because his normal voice is a whisper, and when I can hear him, he makes zero sense. If you do all the reading (it's  a lot) you'll do fine on the exams, but I really wish he was a better lecturer for such an interesting topic.
I didn't like him as a professor or a person.
He was OK.

He's very smart and I learned a ton about Social Security but he's a jerk and the worst professor I've had.  His grading is incredibly unfair and he only likes conservatives.  You have to agree with his views to do well and critical thinking is discouraged.
There are few professors who can engage me at 8:30 in the morning, especially on a topic like Social Security.  This one can, I recommend him highly.
No Comments
didn't return mid-terms until class before the second mid-term, can't get straight answer out of him, and hard to follow.
For an 8:30 am class, Jacobs does an amazing job at presenting material in a straightforward manner without relying too much on the intense reading required for the course.
Very interesting class, take Humanistic Psych if you have a chance!
No Comments
the class was not very interesting & the exams were tough.
Really considerate and excited to teach
Very boring lecturer, smart, full of himself...
Interesting class  to take

Learning the theory first hand is an opportunity that must be taken advantage of. The lectures are on the boring side but with some effort can be very stimulating. If possible, take Humanistic Psy (fills very quickly)a course that is unlike any other that you will ever take
No Comments
hard, boring, but very smart
An interesting an articulate lecturer!  We actually learned about his theory from him and read from the text that he wrote!  What an amazing opportunity!

Mihai is one of the most enthusiatic math professors i've ever had. He absolutely loves what he does and expresses that during class. The only problem with him is he writes way to fast leaving most of the class in the dust and skips over some steps during a problem that he expects us to know, which some of us dont. Go to his office after hours.

I took Mihai's math 210 1.5 years ago and now I'm taking his math250. He is hot, nice, and funny but honostly he doesn't know what he is teaching at least for math 250... and for math 210, he doesn't explain things clearly but rather gives out how to use formulas. and I saw him several times in gym. Hot and friendly but not that helpful honestly.
Explained the math in class very clearly; Very helpful in office hours; Exams are reasonable.
