If you don't understand something, say you don't know/ask questions and she will be more than happy to help! Her lectures are always very interesting and funny. As long as you do the daily homework/quizzes, you'll do great!
Good lecturer, and the recitation is always the most funny class. Lesson tests and exams are totally acceptable if you participate in every class and not playing smartphones.
One of the best professors I've ever had, very caring with a lot of ways for you to boost your grade, and the course illustrates basic chemical engineering principles very well.
I had the honor to TA for Professor Porosoff, he is such a kind person and genuinely cares about his students. He is a very generous grader and wants students to engage with the material.

Professor Porosoff gives really good lectures that are clear and easy to follow. He makes it clear what will be on each exam/quiz and gives comprehensive study guides/practice problems. He is very helpful and genuinely wants every student to succeed. He's probably the best professor the school could have chosen to teach an engineering intro class.

Professor Porosoff does a great job at easing the freshmen that take CHE 150 into chemical engineering and university life in general. He reassures students whenever they happen to not do good on an assignment and has rather engaging lectures with bits of humor sprinkled in. The textbook is not required. Everything is covered in lecture.
Great teacher, really passionate about his subject and finds a way to make his lectures personal and not stuffy. Willing to meet outside of class and wants everyone to succeed.
Professor Porossof is such a great professor you can clearly tell he's passionate about his work and he genuinely cares about his students.

Professor Porosoff was very good at teaching and had very clear expectations. His lectures were easy to follow along and he made sure the whole class understood. Not the most accessible out of class, but if you email him, he will make time.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Franco was amazing. Messaged me after every test to tell me how I did. One time I missed 2 lectures in a class of 80+ people and he emailed me to make sure I was okay. Would definitely recommend. Teaches with passion and understands the material very well. He will always ask for feedback on his course and methods. Chem 137
For CHEM137. Very great professor. Extremely talented and shows a lot of passion and enthusiasm towards students. Best college professor I have had.

(For Chem 137 but it wouldn't let me pick that as an option)
Actually cares about students and explains things well, but it's a hard class. Definitely have to read the textbook, but I know people who never read it and did fine. Homework is helpful, but he has quizzes every Thursday (50% participation grade though). Overall, good professor.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: Fairly challenging course but Prof. Franco was literally the best professor anyone could've gotten. Very caring, very responsive and always open to suggestions. As long as you put in the work then the course will be a great experience. 8/8 valence electrons.
Very great professor. Always open to answer questions. And his lectures are very interesting and concepts are carefully established steps by steps.

The best professor I have had in college by a longshot, and Ive had some great teachers. Whether its lecture, office hours, or email, he is able to quickly and deftly explain even the most complicated topics.
Previously on CHEM251! Beautiful! Exactly! Questions! More question! See you Friday!

251 for me was the hardest subject matter of all the Chem classes- but you will never find a better teacher for quantum chem. Do all the hws and understand the workshops- the tests are hard but there's extra credit, and a lot of homework to supplement your grade- so you can still get a good grade. Would take any class with Ignacio again.
Professor Franco is one of the most wonderful professors I have ever had the pleasure of learning from. He really wants all of his students to learn a topic he finds so interesting and exciting.

Professor Franco is very kind and caring, and extremely passionate about the material. He tries very hard to make class a dialogue and encourages people to ask questions and ask for clarification. His exams are fair and his lectures are engaging.

Joan Saab is one of the reasons why I love humanities at the U of R. She is so knowledgeable and has a teaching style that most people respond best to. She genuinely cares about her students and wants her classes to be enjoyable and you can tell. She is everything you want in a professor, enthusiastic but chill, and just so understanding.
Nice and caring professor!!
One of the best. Approachable, encouraging and supportive. I loved this class! She will give you an A as long as you participate (as long as you try).
Professor Saab is one of the best professors around! She is super caring and is available outside of class. She always responds to emails and is a very clear grader.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: No Comments
Extremely smart and passionate about the subjects. She uses variety in her teaching style. She can be a bit intimidating when attempting to approach her however.

She's really nice and always in a great mood.  Very passionate about the subject.  I learned A LOT about American architecture, she is usually very interesting.  one midterm and a couple of large papers but you have a lot of flexibility on the paper topics.  Saab is a great teacher.
Great professor at Swarthmore coming over from Rochester.  Accessible, clear teaching, and interesting classes.  A true "teacher" who cares about her students.

I loved her. She teaches very concisely. She comes very prepared to every lecture. Her handwriting is very legible. She's also extremely helpful in her office hours. Mavinga is easily approachable, and she's willing to help you out. I would recommend sitting in the front row, though. You'll be able to hear her better.
Poor planning. Rushing through materials that needed more time...
Not good. I'm pretty sure this class made me forget the calculus I already knew. She is very confusing.
One of the worst professors I've ever had
She is very difficult to understand but more helpful if you ask her a direct question after class. She writes and talks quickly. She's not very good at explaining things and talks quietly.
She is useless! She just teaches right out of the textbook and her accent is to thick. She seems nice but really has no personality at all. Class is impossible to get through awake.
AVOID TAKING HIS CLASS. YOU WILL FAIL OR DESTROY YOUR GPA. Take it over the summer elsewhere please!!!!!!

Though reputedly easier when teaching thermo, avoid taking fluids with Thomas at all costs. He is infamous for failing students and trashing the GPAs of survivors. Friendly guy, but extremely difficult prof. Problem is compounded by his tendency to assume that poor performance is result of student laziness. Take fluids elsewhere over the summer.

Tough teacher. Only understand his way of thinking.. which is different from the book at times which get confusing when you ask him about it. Erases constantly so take fast notes. A lot of people end up having to retake it or barely passing. The final is impossible.

He sent this to our class TO: Students in ME 225 I have just submitted final grades for ME 225, and here I want to comment on the results of the final exam. The performance overall was very poor, and very disappointing to me. I am a bit shocked by the poor performance, especially after the third hourly exam on which the class did quite well o

very easy exams until you miss a minus sign, when he mercilessly tries to fail you. asks same questions on all exams, except for final, where we got major curveballs. i asked him to help me prepare for the first exam but he was unwilling to do so outside of his obligated office hours. unreasonable atendance policy. overall great experience though.

Excellent teacher.  Really knows his stuff, barely looks at his notes.  Very passionate about thermo, and helpful in office hours and workshops.  He demands excellence, and is tough with partial credit.  He wants you to do well though, so talk to him.  Factors in improvement a lot when it comes to grades.
his love of math is inspiring and sparked a deeper interest in mathematics. Very thoughtful professor, we need more professors like this.
I have been hate math in high school, but this lecture is inspiring and I think I have found some of my confidence in math now.

Pretty good at teaching, obviously really passionate about math. His notes were a little bit messy and he's kind of awkward, but if you asked him for help, he helps you. He wants the student to succeed. Just take practice exams to do well on the tests.
Enthusiastic and approachable. His passion for math is inspiring.
his love of math is infectious. genuinely wants students to succeed. explains anything you ask

His lectures were frustrating. He wrote on the board the whole time while teaching. I couldn't learn this way- where the professor doesn't teach but describes out loud what he's doing. I honestly think I could have skipped his lectures. Recitation was sometimes useful. If you learn just by lecture notes or by just listening what he does, he's fine.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Tests are tough

comment: He is a very good professor who explains the material well. He goes over a lot of examples in class which helped me understand the material. The problem is that the tests for this course are too long for the time given. You really have to rush to get it done in time.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Professor Muir is one of the best professors at the U of R. He dedicates countless hours to perfecting his notes and projects he assigns as well as making himself available for all of his students outside of class. He is a mentor and a great resource for personal projects outside of class, and very passionate about the material he teaches.

You can tell that his heart is in the right place but this guy really isnt the best Prof. The class is only two credits yet you meet for over 2 hours every week and were given 2 weekly homework assignments. Lectures were ineffective at explaining course material and the notes gave away most of the answers. Office hours were also not helpful.

Muir is very passionate about the students, and makes himself available to answer any questions despite the fact that he is very busy. He is a very funny and sarcastic person which makes a boring topic much more exciting. The class does come with a lot of work, but this also helps grades be more true. Definitely keep up with the lectures.

It was very intimidating to ask questions in class and he likes to call people out. Very bad prof. the textbook was much more helpful. Going to class actually is less beneficial because you should use that time to read the book instead. Decent with 1 on 1 help but not very accessible.
Great instructor.  Clear, communicates very well with students, and knows quite a bit about his subject. Very pleased with the outcome of the class.

One of the worst professor at explaining his materials. He often neglects and ignores topics which he does not know and will still put them in homework and tests. The absolute worst professor at explaining and teaching his materials, almost like he barely knows more than the students.

Prof. Nelson was one of the nicest professors at the uni. Super approachable and replies to emails fast. Mkt 212 was basically a stats class, though, and lectures tend to get more complicated than it has to be. About 1 assignment/week on average. Allows cheat sheet on exams which was life-saving. Gives EC generously!
Really bad hand-writing on the board and slides
Professor Nelson is really approachable and is always available to give feedback on whatever question you have. Plus super great lectures
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Great Professor, wish I had him for all of my classes
Good teacher! Sometimes glosses over complicated material. VERY HELPFUL one on one!

Best professor of the MBA, I learned a lot he is an amazing human being who cares about you learning the reality of the Canadian market, he even helped to improve my resume, I would 1000%. HRMT has bad reputation but he made it so easy that I would totally repeat again.

Too bad he's currently full time at RIT, it's really our loss. F I guess this page has no use anymore. Bobby if you're reading this, come home!! Your lectures were the golden days. 1/2 the class was restarting the Apache server and all nighters but I think that was my fault. You always called out front row dorks for their pointless questions.
Amazing teacher. Great lectures. Chill dude.
He was an amazing professor. Loved his lecture, tons of examples. He did make the class harder than it had been in previous years but we were prepared for it.

Great lecturer, clear grading criteria and awesome powerpoints. The projects he gave us were a little bit challenging but I had so much fun working on them. You can really learn a lot from him. Strongly recommend!!!
Had him for the one semester he taught this class and it was awesome. Really nice guy that gives good lectures.

Awesome prof! Majorly discussion based class, but he makes a comfortable environment to share your views on the material, so discussion feels natural. I enrolled later into the semester and he made sure I knew exactly what to catch up on and the major themes. Overall cool guy who really seems to be passionate about what he teaches.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: lectures were very interesting!! he is a very insightful man and made milton way more interesting than i ever thought it could be. it was fascinating just to hear him speak about milton and blake- his passion really shines through. super caring and accessible and supportive- helped me through a tough point in my life
great prof

Took what could have been a polarizing topic and taught it in a way that was both fair & respectful all while looking at aspects of Christianity through a lens of literature. A truly excellent Professor!
Great Professor who uses his broad knowledge of Literature, Philosophy and Culture to create a wonderful learning and discussion based environment.

An engaging professor who seems to truly care for his students. Encourages dialogue & discussion between classmates and actively helps students formulate their own interpretations of the readings. Would highly recommend!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: I took the first non honors/grad class he taught. You could tell he's used to teaching higher level courses, so sometimes things got a little tricky. It's clear he cares about his students, when everyone bombed the 2nd test though he adjusted the grading scheme and the final's difficulty. He is super passionate about the subject.

great lecturer but the lectures were too fast. reading the textbook is more beneficial. he loves that textbook. the exams are hard with little time to complete. the content was interesting. he was sweet.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: BenZvi is an amazing lecturer and also cares deeply about his students. He has high expectations for his students, but he makes these very clear. If you are willing to put in the work, you'll succeed in his class. We are fortunate to have someone like him teaching honors E&M

Almost unreasonably difficult for an intro physics class, but he pushes you to the limit. I don't think I would have learned as much if it wasn't for Professor BenZvi. You'll need to commit a significant amount of time for the class. One issue: if you ask him a question, he doesn't listen until the end and ends up answering a different question.

His lectures were good and very informative and he was very accessible out of class. However, he consistently wrote test problems that a majority of the class couldn't solve, and the class average on one of the tests was below a 50. Great teacher, but the tests are very difficult and punishing.

Lectures are a little fast paced. It was difficult to take notes and learn at the same time, but you get the hang of it eventually. Also, if you ever have questions about material please just ask him, I am convinced it's impossible to make Segev angry.
Quite Busy; Hilarious-but it may take some time to get his joke.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Weber is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about the topic at hand. The class can get boring at times, but overall I had a fulfilling time; Professor Weber was always accessible outside of class and always gave a lot of time to finish the work assigned. All in all, it was an enjoyable class, but be prepared to read!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: I loved Professor Weber. Passionate about the book we read, super knowledgeable, always open to other perspectives and additions, plus her assignments were fun and interesting. She was so careful not to give us too much work and really considerate about personal circumstances. A really fun and engaging professor
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Simply the best professor I've had. Class discussions were incredibly engaging with great dialogue, as Prof. Weber really facilitated a classroom community that made it enjoyable to speak. Feedback on papers was helpful and specific, and more than anything, the readings we did were fascinating. Great course, even better professor.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Weber is awesome. She usually has a lot of energy, and is very eager to answer any question that you might have. She's also very flexible as long as you talk to her. The course is structured around lessons and for each lesson, there are 2 quizzes and 1 test. As long as you put in a bit of effort and do your work, you'll be fine.

Grading was random and based on arbitrary participating measures, you can get As in all the assignments and get a B in the class at the professors whim. Course material was interesting but you could just read the books and wouldnt miss much.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Really enjoyed this class! The content was super interesting and Professor Weber is very approachable.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr. Kennedy is very organized, but can be picky about small things (you won't get any credit for the problem set if you don't assign pages in gradescope). Reading the textbook isn't required and there is a lot of extra credit.
Almost no way to receive high points on assignments. Always picky about some minor irrelevant stuff to have points off. Boring lectures that are not helpful at all for the homework.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Picky about wording. If you got one word wrong, even though you were right, you won't get full points
Very clear and organized lectures, and readily available outside of class. Exams are difficult, but points system makes it possible to get a good grade. Problem sets and exams are well written.

Very nice and organized. A good teacher but exams are really tough. Almost everything is graded on correctness. Points system makes it possible to do well in the class even if you don't do well on exams. Her notes are clear so there's no need to read the textbook. The course is what's difficult but she's a great professor.

I Preferred Kennedy over Dino (orgo 1 vs orgo 2) due to the point system that Kennedy has and the more in-depth lectures. It's definitely not an easy class but Kennedy very clearly shows that she cares and has very fair exams and assessments.
Dr. Kennedy definitely cares about all of her students and has engaging lectures. By far one of the most organized professors I have had so far.

Dr. Kennedy is sweet, caring, and good at clarifying confusing topics. She encouraged group work and questions during class and office hours, and she made classes feel less competitive because she was willing to reexplain topics to those who didn't get them right away. The tests used the same concepts as the lectures, but scaling was still needed.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr Kennedy was very organized, competent, and handled the switch to online format very well. Her notes were comprehensive and informative, but some of her explanations could have been made easier to understand. The tests were very difficult with a 50-60 class average but there ways to improve the grade with homework and extra credit prompts.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Horrible lecturer, simply just read his slides. Somewhat responsive to his emails, but doesn't work efficiently. Unclear about what he wants in homework/projects/exams. Your codes could execute all the things he asked in question but still would deduct points because you didn't do it the way "he expected".
Professor Schwarz is a good professor with passion; I would definitely work with him again if I have a chance to become a TA.

This course is honestly the most speechless course I took as a BME student. He assumes everyone has a good foundation in coding and starts giving extremely hard midterms. We don't even know what exactly are his expectations for a good presentation. Also, the final is like a pain in the ass. He just likes to see his student suffer from tons of tasks
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Ok, the course itself, fine, the labs especially were helpful. Lectures on the other hand, not very helpful. I went to most of them until the end and honestly I did better on my own versus going to lecture. The project at the end was a nice topic but good luck trying to get a group to work well together. At least he responds to emails?
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: Let me preface this by saying that this course is NOT beginner friendly. Do NOT go to lecture. He says the same things on the slides (better off on your own). Comments are very important in your code so don't skimp on it. His attitude in class is very monotone and not engaging. He will give you pretty much no help on the project at the end. GL!

The professor only reads off what is on his slides word for word and does not explain much after that. The textbook is optional and you need to do practice outside of class for the midterms. He does demonstrations, but most of the hand-on coding will come from the labs and the TAs.
This class is a really good intro to the different systems that affect law and policy in the US, through the lens of food policy. The content was interesting and Prof. Alexander is great!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: In Intro to American Politics I found some of the readings interesting especially the book Stamped from the beginning - which you read throughout the semester. However I found Professor Alexanders lectures to be boring and slow. The essays you have to write tend to have creative prompts but I would not take another class with him.

Alexander is a great professor! He is always open to discussing material and grades during office hours while being friendly yet respectful. However, I found the class graded very harshly for an intro-level course. He is open to regrade requests and discussing improvement areas, but this can still be frustrating. Overall, he was great!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: While Professor Alexander cares about the material he teaches, his lecturing is super boring and slow and his midterm was unnecessarily difficult for an intro-level political science course. He said that the exams were meant to be easy for those who attend lectures, however, that was certainly not the case since he graded them super strictly.
Prof Alexander is great!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Dan cares about the material he teaches - he really wants students core concepts and leave the class with a better understanding of American politics. Lectures can get stale at times, but the papers are really fun to research and write for. If you attend lecture and go to office hours, you should find the course relatively comfortable.

Very good and clear professor who has thoroughly prepared the class ahead of time. You'll need some comfort with regards to mathematics to do very well in the class, but it's not very hard, just rigorous, and you need to be consistent. It's essentially problem-solving. Very good slides that I could follow even if I ever missed class and good TAs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: He knows what he is doing. Kind of condescending if you do not understand the material right away. His slides are almost impossible to understand unless you have full understanding of what is going on and keys never give the process.
Great Professor! The material is quite tough. But the teaching assistants (especially Sergio Ascencio) is extremely helpful! Definitely go to histheirs office hours for help! (if you need any)

He is a nice professor, clear, and will go out of his way to help you, but the material is brutal if you fall behind.  Not too many tricks, just a lot of work.  Make sure you ask your questions in class because the T.A.'s could be useless.

Solid teacher, doesn't run the most interesting class, but engaging and very approachable. Surprisingly responsive to feedback and even constructive criticism. Also very good in a one to one setting when he has the opportunity to explain in greater detail than in class.
Prepares lectures throughly, cares, very sharp guy.

Prof. Nasra moves quickly and assigns a lot of homework, but her lecturing style is focused and easy to understand, and if you take the work seriously (which I didn't always, hence the B), it's exactly what you need to absorb all the material and score well on tests. She genuinely cares about her students, and I really recommend taking this class.

She's a really good professor and she actually cares about her students. While she does give a lot of homework, and the class can be hard, French is hard in general. It's a college-level class and lessons do go by fast which is why there is a lot of homework so you don't forget. She's one of my favorite.
DONT TRUST THE REVIEW THEY ARE FAKE. THE PROFESSOR ACTIVELY REPORTS NEGATIVE REVIEWS AND GET THEM TAKEN DOWN AND INTIMIDATE STUDENTS. WTH

While this class did involve lots of homework I found it to be useful and helped me prepare for tests and really learn the language. She is really caring and wants you to succeed and is willing to help in any way she can
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Participation matters

comment: She is a great teacher and will go out of her way to help you understand the material. You can tell that she really loves teaching and cares about her students. There is quite a bit of homework and class participation is expected but I felt that I learned so much from her.

You'll def have to put in effort to do well in this class. Not an insane amount, but at least a couple hours of review per week. Prof. Nasra is a good teacher, but if you're not on top of stuff outside of class, good luck Charlie. She is very sweet but doesn't have time for bs.

I think that Nasra was a great intro professor. Although she has a tendency to come off as harsh and strict, as long as you put in effort both in the class as well as getting to know her, you'll become friendly in class. The work load was very manageable, so if you're willing to put in effort, you'll be fine.

Had him for Planetary Science. Extremely interesting class, which he pretty much let the  TA run. He gave lectures on articles which otherwise would have been really hard to digest, though. He's a bit distant, and I know some of the other geology profs. don't really like him, but he's very smart and I can tell he really loves the subject.

Intimidating at first. I actually thought he hated me on the field trip...turns out I was wrong. He's a nice guy. Probably one of the most smartest professors I have ever met. Always be prepared for his lectures, he doesn't like it when people are not prepared for class.
Really great class. He's a good teacher just very intimidating. Expects a lot but isn't unreasonable. Hard to tell whether he is making a sarcastic joke or hates you sometimes.
Fun class, cool field trip.
No Comments
No Comments
Explains things very well, funny, will clarify if you ask, gives good examples, gives webwork extensions when needed, expects students to do well. Cares if students understand material.

Great professor. Takes you through each problem you will most likely face on WeBWorK. A very clear teacher though he does have an accent. He really cares about his students and is willing to answer any questions during or after class.
Very intelligent man - a little difficult to understand at times due to his accent but it wasn't a big issue.  If you took calc in high school and did well, then this class should be a breeze.
Annoying accent. Explains poorly.

Easy course, but his thick accent that sounds like Borat can make learning a little difficult. Funny guy, won't recognize you outside of class - (classes are too big). Grades harshly on exams, but is lenient with homework. If you don't show up to class and want a good grade, you need to keep up with the book.

Great professor.  Gives many examples every lecture.  Exams are alright since all sections were given the same exam at the same time.  Book is not really used so much, but I would recommend doing the homework and reading before each class.  HW is sometimes harder than exam questions so if you can get through those you can get through the exam.

Kinsler's econ of education class was awesome. The material is very relevant and very interesting, so except for the beginning, which is almost all econometrics, it's very easy to pay attention. There are 2 papers, 3 tests- standard fare for a 4000 level class. Go to class, take good notes, and it's not a difficult class at all. You'll learn a lot.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: His exams are ridiculously hard and he goes very quickly through lecture. If you fall asleep for even five minutes, then you're sure to miss probably the most important part of his lecture. He also loves going over class time by a couple minutes, so get ready to be late to your next class.
You need to go to class. His exams are hard, and require you really understand the material. That being said, he really will help you and if you do the hw properly you can succeed in the class.

Spends 5 minutes of lecture on a difficult proof that will show up on your hw/test, then 30 minutes on calculating the slope of a line that you've been able to do since 10th grade. Lectures are tedious, but you need to attend (and stay awake -- challenging!) so you don't miss the 30 seconds of vital info.
One of the best teachers I've ever had.  He's absolutely crystal clear, I don't think anyone could teach econometrics better.

Class is a waste of time, as he posts all powerpoint presentations online. He is a horrible professor and the class is one of the most boring classes I have ever taken. There is a large curve in the class since he makes the tests (especially the final) extremely difficult. The TA's were extremely useful and helpful, however.
Dosent provide good feedback or resources for students. Grades subjectivity. Doesnt seem caring at all.
Unclear grading criteria. No tests, so all grading is subjective. You will need the textbook for the assignments.
Very poor instruction, guidance or interest in student's education. Do not waste time with this instructor. Do not be misled by her authorship of textbook.

It is doubtful the text written for the class is used anyplace else, it reads like a high school science book, and is very lite on science.  Tests are poorly written, and do not relate to the material covered in class.  Overall a bad instructor in a bad program.

Amy Karch's class is extremely poor quality.  Concepts are overly simplified in the textbook she has written.  As A graduate of a Top 10 university, Graduate classes taught by Karch are worthless.  Tests are not based on facts from an easy textbook, but on abstract NCLEX style questions, that do not correspond to the material covered in Lecture.

Brilliant teacher. Very knowledgeable. Breaks down complex information and makes it entertaining and easy to learn. Uses case scenarios as writing assignments, which forces students to use critical thinking skills to connect ideas.
Little bit wacky sense of humor, long labs, and overall lecture vocabulary based exams. Penny is great
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Dr. Higgins is awesome! Her love of Geology is infectious, and she is lively and funny lecturer, although at times she would drag on with jokes when she should have been lecturing. If you pay attention in class and take notes, you'll do fine on the tests. Overall she's a really nice and accommodating woman. I highly recommend her!
Penny is awesome. Her classes are never too hard, but always pretty fun. She's friendly and helpful, and also good at making animal noises. Like, really good.
Great, funny professor! Very organized and clear. Easy to contact with even after class. Exam is not hard and totally follow her lectures. I like her!
Good.

Penny gives enough information to understand the topic in class, yet still gives you room to think about a scenario that could arise. Her exams are very straight forward and offer extra credit. Used twitter for the first time and answered almost every tweet within an hour of it being sent out. Take this class if you can!! Worth it!!

Jeff is a great guy and runs his class very well. 220 has little homework except for short weekly quizzes and no textbook. Some might find the subject matter a little dry, but for the most part its a very informative, low-stress class. Most information i given in lecture, so try to go.

Runner is a brilliant professor. He ran the class on an entirely discussion-based model, with no textbook use and very little homework. The material is very interesting, if slightly dry in the beginning, but it picks up quite a bit as the class goes on. He is energetic and passionate and very willing to help students. Great professor.
Great guy, great class. It was very easy and interesting. The topics get a bit risque, which is always a lot of fun. Minimal stress and you get points for showing up!
Amazing. Ran the class without a textbook, simply using discussion and homework to move through material. It was incredibly effective. He is energetic, entertaining, and a pleasure to learn from.

There is no need to go to class all the time... go to show your face and then study for other classes on blackboard or just go on facebook or something.  The class is interesting, but very repetitive.  Try hard on exams, make sure to do the REs early.  He's very nice and knows what he's talking about.  People get opinionated in this class.
Easy class. Hard to pay attention in. Somewhat disappointing, but he's a nice guy.
Maria is sooooooo awesome!!! I learned sooooo much Spanish from her! I would not want to have any other teacher for Spanish!!!<3's to Maria :)

Overall, a good class. We watched movies and had cultural discussions. Lots of papers to write. Only complaint is that grammar is expected to be learned by students OUTSIDE of class. She believes class is just a review of material. She is a native speaker and is quite funny. Volunteer to read in the class. She pays attention to who pays attention.

I don't understand all the negative comments! I thought she was a great teacher. She's very nice, helpful, and fun. Plus she's from Spain, so she has a first hand perspective on the culture. She's definitely one of my favorite teachers.

She moves VERY fast, so you HAVE to keep up with learning all the new words from each day. I suggest making flash cards and committing to some serious study time for this course if you want to do well. She's very fun, and wants to be helpful if you go to her, but the language barrier does make it difficult for her to actually help.
This professor was terrible.  Does not understand how to teach a language 101 course.  Avoid having this teacher.
She is terrible.  If you miss an accent mark, the entire question is wrong, and this is an INTRODUCTORY language course.  Definitely the worst professor I have ever had at U of R.
The nicest professor ever ! Arabic 101 was such a success ! I learned a lot.

I enjoyed taking ARA101 with Adham, he's serious about his job and very eager to have us learn Arabic, the amount of work in his classes is a lot but that's good for students to learn, I feel that I learned a lot from his class and will be taking more classes with him. I liked that he has great TA's who helped us going through all of our questions.

I took Arabic 101 with Adham Hamid and he was such an amazing professor! the policy was strict about attending the class and how that would affect the students' final grade (which most students hate) but that helped us learning, I can say that I learned more than what I expected either from Adham or hie TA's.
He's an very unhelpful. And has the worst policies
I enjoyed taking Arabic 101 with this professor, he's been working really hard with his students to make sure everyone is learning and just slacking.
Great professors, recommend students at UoR to take Arabic classes with him.

Fair & balanced. The Guyton Hall Textbook is used by med students with a pre-med curriculum, which nurses do not have. This book assumes this fund of knowledge, but he does not want other sources used, which you must use. Everything is run through safe-assign, which creates a nightmare, but he tells you to ignore the number & focus on quality.
You have to put in a lot of work but its worth it. Andrew is very knowledgeable and more than help to help students in his free time understand difficult concepts.
Very good course
Excellent professor if you really want to learn. But don't expect it to be easy just because it's online.

Advanced pathophysiology is a very challenging course. Andrew did not dumb it down, but was able to explain complex concepts in a way that I could understand and learn. If you really want to learn pathophysiology, he's the professor for you.
Described complex concepts VERY clearly; had fun and creative assignments that were relevant to practice.
Good professor, cares a lot about the material, and makes it challenging but fair. If you really commit to this class, you'll learn a lot. You get out of it what you put in.

Professor Oakes is a bad professor. He simply derives equations in class, and then quickly and poorly goes over examples. He does not explain concepts well, nor does he really teach understanding. Like said by others, his tests are not similar to the hw. The only reason I got an A is because I took AP Physics. Do NOT take his class, take self-paced
Do not take this professor' class!!! You will learn nothing because you could not understand anything.

All he does in class is derive equations. His exams are nothing like the homework or workshops, which he claims to base them off of. Overall, not a good professor, but is very knowledgeable as a researcher.  He curves this intro class to a C. Those who do well seem to have taken the course before. Good luck to you if you have this professor.

He is a great teacher! He has a presentation for each lecture. The way his test work is that he makes it really hard so that the average is around a 55% however he curves the median to a 75 so usually curves are +20 points. He is understanding when it comes to mistakes on a test. Great professor. Dont trust the last review.
Tough for people who aren't familiar with his teaching style.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: wish he focused more on concepts and connecting things, rather than rote memorization. felt like there were no clear objectives and what he wanted us to take away from lecture. would recommend using anki. do the homework questions, they help

You don't need to go to class. Slides just have all the information on them and he just reads off of them. Did well on exams because genetics is just memorizing (true for any genetics class) feels like I didn't gain anything from the class, just doesn't compare to Dr. Clark or Dr. Stein. Obviously his first time teaching, wish Stein still taught it

His lectures are incredibly dense and quick. It takes some serious effort to keep up. But he makes himself available outside class and is genuinely respectful of his students. Make sure you do the homework and go to his office hours, and you will be fine.

I can't say enough good things about Dr. Longan. He is the best professor I've had so far, in terms of caring for students and teaching ability. He is super helpful in office hours, lectures are very organized, and he goes above and beyond to re-record things if needed. Answer the homework questions and you will do very well on exams.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: As a student taking this class along with 2 other STEM classes, this class became overwhelming very quickly. I really wish he focused more on understanding content and having less content in each lecture rather than rote memorization. Even with the homework questions, it's still a lot of memorizing and studying to do.
Longan is great and you can tell he really wants students to succeed and does everything in his power to make sure students understand the material!

Take him for 111 next sem! He restored my faith in biology after last year. He is so organized and re-records lectures if the recording had issues. he would meet with you if you can't make it to office hours. his slides were literally all i studied, exams were easy for me. he also gave 20-30 questions as extra material per lecture(not graded).

Dr. Longan's class requires a lot of memorization, both of material and of specific things he says in class. It's possible to do well if you aren't good at memorizing, but I think it's more difficult than it should be. However, his exams are relatively straightforward to study for (homework questions
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Longan is like rediscovering Dr. Clark all over again. His lectures are super interesting and you can tell he has a great interest in teaching genetics! His exams are also very straight forward and their designed to feel completely fair, sometimes generously to where not every little detail needs to be known. Study his HW problems! 10/10!!

Dr. Longan is a chill guy who likes what he teaches. His slides are very detailed and contain all the information you will be tested on so the book is optional and supplementary. The class is memorization-heavy but the professor generously gives you homework questions that are essentially the exam questions. Great professor

Dr. Longan is such a breath of fresh air after Minckley. He is and his lectures are organized, he teaches the content extremely well. By no means is the content easy, it requires a ton of studying but it is very clear what he requires of us. Still in the process of 198 but I have been very pleased by the way Longan runs the class. Do the HW!!!

Requires memorization of topics not taught in class. If you cannot rotate molecules in your head, DO NOT take this class - you are not allowed to use a model kit like in orgo. It is definitely tough, but Dr. Neidig is fun and is a great lecturer so it makes the course more bearable.

Neidig knows what he's talking about - the dude is smart, no doubt about it. But doesn't know how to teach. Tests were too long, felt extremely unprepared despite lots of studying. He was very condescending and rude. Never felt comfortable talking to him one-on-one. Liked the content, hated the course & prof.
Love Professor Neidig - very fair grading and he definitely knows what he's talking about Don't be intimidated by the beginning of this course
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr. Neidig explains concepts well, and his TA's are incredible at clarifying them. The exams are fair and representative of the homework. I took this class when it was hybrid, and found both the in-person and virtual lectures easy to follow. He maintains some professional distance, but he's approachable. Go to office hours and ask to see his dogs!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Amazing lectures

comment: Clearly a very smart guy, also is nice. Has office hours, don't be scared to approach him. Do all his problem sets and workshops and you'll be set for his exams- his averages didn't dip below 75%, so they're pretty fair and representative of the hw/workshops assigned.
This is a very interesting class if you enjoyed organic chemistry. Challenging but definitely doable. Tests are representative of lecture notes.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Tests are tough--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Hard Grader
Hard grader.

Professor Kocherlakota is a great lecturer who does a great job at connecting the course material to current events. As the former President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, he adds to his lectures his own insights gleaned from his experience, a real plus considering his class is all about monetary policy.
He is super smart and inspiring but he makes his classes super boring. Also he's not that accessible outside of class.

He was the former President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, so he lends a lot of personal experience and insight to his lectures. He presents info from the readings in a really digestible way, so going to lecture is a must. However, he'll still ask questions on material not brought up in class, so do the readings as well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: One of my favourite econ professor! Inspiring lectures.

Love Myounghee! She is such a caring and nice professor. However, this class is way beyond any other language class I have ever taken in the amount of work I had to do for it. I was genuinely overwhelmed everyday of the week trying to keep up with this class on top of my other coursework.

RECOMMENDED!!!This prof is very nice, you will have some projects in class, but you can do a lots topics whatever you like in this course. If you are a kpop fan, ofc that you can share or introduce your favorite idol or groups in your project. The most important  things are you need to spend some times on vocabs and grammars, but prof will help u!

One of the best professors I have taken in the U of R. She cares about everyone's performance in the class and encourages you to participate. Although there is a lot of homework, it is manageable and doable. Exams are very fair and she is willing to help you on anything you struggle in. Great language professor.

I love this professor so much! While attendance is mandatory, she is extremely sweet and will answer any questions you have at any time. She replies to emails fast, gives out grades often the day of quizzes or tests, is always a joy to talk to, and is an excellent professor.
You have homework every day, but it's honestly not long or hard. Take her!

Only take her courses if you are actually going to show up to class. She is understanding of missed attendance but there is homework every day (very easy) and a lot of material to get through. You can't use your phone in class but you genuinely won't need to because the class is so engaging. Super fun course, shouldn't get a bad grade if you attend

Her lectures are great and interactive. She goes at a very good pace and will give a lot of help outside class. She is also extremely caring and considerate. If you ever miss hws, or even forget about a test, she is very understanding about it. You will get opportunities to improve your grade through EC. There is hw almost every day tho (short)
Amazing! He explains very good, his notes are so organized and easy to read. A lot of homework but very useful for learning.

Very intelligent and interesting. He's not the most relaxed and informal professor, but he knows his stuff and does a good job conveying that information. Taught the class on a slightly higher level than was anticipated but it was nonetheless enjoyable.
Well organized lectures.  Notes and solutions published regularly on the internet.  Very approachable and helpful.

I think that the others are wrong!  He's a great prof.  His sense of humor isn't ever-present, but he's very knowlegeable and well organized in his lectures, and incredibly helpful outside of class.  His classes are hard, but that's the material's fault, not his.  He does a very good job, I think!
This guy belongs in a lab with no one around.  Not a good teacher for teaching's sake.
Knows a lot about classical mechanics and probably makes a good researcher, but doesn't know anything about teaching a class of students.

Professor DeAngelis runs an interesting course with a reasonable workload. The exams are mostly multiple-choice and readings (outside of those for discussions) are not needed to do well. Though not always the most engaging, he incorporates fun examples of the phenomena he is explaining and does a good job of breaking down more complex concepts.
Learned a lot from this course.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Very smart, good lectures. Take home exams can sometimes be very  hard but doable
Great, loved him!

he is very smart, but the exams are really hard. I do great on the take home exams (trust me, be prepared to spend about 50 hours on them) but one thing I hate is sometimes he is very unclear what he wants on an answer. Many times, the entire class missed a question, not because they don't know the answer, but because he was very unclear.

He's a great guy. Incredibly intelligent and definitely knows his material. He delivers an interesting way to look at neuroscience. His exams are half take home and in class. The in-class is pretty much straight up memorization of the lectures. The take-home, however, are much more difficult and require thought and knowledge of the material.
worst professor I have ever met. apparently he knows his stuff but is unable to pass it on to students.

Literally the worst professor I have EVER had. Can't stand going to his class or dealing with him. He is unclear about absolutely everything. He gives you a choice for a term paper but then shoots down everything. Monotonous voice. The majority of the class falls asleep if they even go. Never take his classes. Also, disgustingly hairy ears...

I know few professors who get as mixed responses as Dave Pollack. Personally, I think the man is a great lecturer who always comes to class with something new and exciting. He's very helpful in his office, incredibly knowledgable about his area, and a pretty fair grader. The assignments are sometimes irritatingly vague, though. Overall, great guy.

He is very knowledgeable about Japanese culture but I'm not sure that makes him competent in teaching art history. I'm an art history major and found the lectures to be irritatingly simplistic + one-sided. he did not give us enough social/historical background but just rambled on about the most random details of 1 print for 45 min. The class was OK

Worst class I've ever taken. Apparently spending two classes on a topic doesn't necessarily mean it's related to the course. You have to pick the topic for the large paper (anything related to the class), however it's completely hit or miss if he'll approve it. Save yourself and don't take this class.

This class puts me to sleep. He gives the most boring lectures and the take home midterm is vague, and overly long for the time alotted. Its a 6-12page paper to be written in under 48 hours. If you like yourself at all don't take this class.

This class is literally stupid. She just reads off powerpoint and she teaches like a preschooler teacher. I also took her ULW session which was even more stupid. The TA was confused and the rubrics are very confusing. No room for negotiation even when the problem was the rubric that they made. DO NOT RECOMMEND.

Easy A, I just forgot to do some quizzes. She has interesting lectures and all exams are open-book with bi-weekly quizzes based on the lectures (also open-book and can repeat multiple times). It's an easy class, I barely attended and still passed.

I would greatly recommend not taking this course with this professor. Her teaching style was the bare minimum. Heavily relied on pre-recorded lectures. Course was very test and reading heavy. She does not try to reach out to her students or help them when they are struggling to understand topics and papers in the course; not understanding at all!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Excellent professor, offers extra credit if you need it

Honestly, the professor is good but it wouldn't take a lot to be. The class is mostly common sense and there are three exams which are mostly multiple choice and like 20 quizzes that you can keep retaking until you get a 100. She seems like she would be a nice person if you needed to see her in O.H.

Professor Elenbaas is a fine lecturer, but honestly I mostly used the textbook. I attended every lecture because she occasionally she showed cute videos or scenarios that helped visualize the material, but I'm sure I could have passed the class with just the book. Grades are based on 3 big exams, and then 20 easy A quizzes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: She may be good for history, but not language. Expected us to be fluent in Latin, and this is the 3rd semester most are taking it. Very high pressure & condesending. Tests based off in class translations; test 1 was to translate 5 paragraphs randomly selected from 20 pages of latin, & they're cumulative.I do not reccomend her, take P. Gresens class

She's brilliant! I've never had a professor that is so knowledgable and passionate about their field of study. Sometimes her lectures are all over the place, but she's very animated so they are interesting. Lots of reading plus mandatory attendance and quizzes every class. 4 online tests (really need to have notes organized). Final paper (4-6 pgs).

I took her course on Roman Poetry -- rocked my world. She's the bomb. Never in my life have I seen such an awesome visiting prof who knows so much on her subject and beyond. I only wish she was a fulltime prof here. She is extremely helpful, intelligent, and down to earth.
She's the best teacher I've had so far.  Makes lectures interesting
Lovely woman, fun to listen to even when she's not talking about the subject. Tests are reasonable and she is just...cool

She's nerdy and pretty cool, often going off on tangents about a cool book she found or Futurama. Her lectures tend to be interesting and the essays are pretty easy if you know the material: no surprise questions or curve balls. She's really big into helping students with their problems and is really flexible. Only downside is she lives in Buffalo.

Professor Chang is very intelligent and kind. He says hi to you outside of the classroom. He know a lot of things. His lectures are amazing. However, his exams are brutal and the curve is harsh. I mean, can he just be easy on students who already choose honors class?
The best professor ever!
a very good liberal economist. The homework may be tough and time-consuming, but it really helps to understand macro well.
Yongsung Chang is a true scholar, outstandingly intelligent, and far ahead of his contemporaries in terms of pedagogical insight and understanding of economics.
Chang is really awesome
Brilliant all around.

AMAZING professor, I really like his style of teaching and he is super helpful. Would definitely take him again and can tell he is passionate about teaching so glad I was able to have him as a professor.

He is a really nice guy and a great professor. He is a bit quirky and uses some funny real-life examples to emphasize his points. Definitely go to class and recitation to do well in this course. Also, watch out for pop quizzes in recitation.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Funkenbusch is the coolest dude ever. Not sure why he avoids eye contact all the time, but besides that he's awesome. ME 222 is pretty easy and really interesting. I highly recommend it!
Very good lecturer. Quirky and entertaining. Definitely recommend any class he teaches.
He's a great professor. Go to his office hours!
Overall easy class but helpful materials. Naive experiments but instructive to understand concepts. overall useful class, should teach more frequently.

The Prof is very engaging in lectures and enthusiastic about the content. I've taken multiple courses with her, and every class was fun and had a comfortable environment. The courses can be a bit content (reading&film) heavy at times, but Prof Rosenow is very understanding and open to extensions as long as she has a forewarning.

James cares about her students. Sometimes expects students to do lots of reading and watch several movies in a week for her comics class particularly. She's very loose with projects/presentations/papers which are easy to do well in. Participation is a large part of the final grade. She's very knowledgable and passionate about the field.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Group projects

comment: One of the few college courses where the professor genuinely treats you like an equal and not only respects, but actively encourages joining into a discussion and sharing your perspective on things. You can clearly tell that she knows so much about what she's talking about and her enthusiasm is fantastic!
James Rosenow is god-tier. I love her. Best lecturer at UR.

Professor was nice and accessible for the most part, clearly knew what she was talking about but the class was incredibly disorganized. I have little to no complaints about the professor herself, but the way she organized the class was one of the worst things I've seen at my time at UofR.

I've greatly enjoyed both classes I took with Professor Rosenow. While young, she's clearly very experienced and knowledgeable about film. She wants all of her students to share in her passion and conveys so through her lectures. My only gripes would be ambiguity around assignments though she's far from a tough grader so it doesn't matter much.

There are so many negative reviews about prof. enck but i thought he was a great professor. he really knew what he was talking about. he was also more than willing to help his students to work around deadlines if they missed class. the feedback he gave on work was always constructive and he graded based on effort/improvement.

Being in this class made me dislike drawing. Enck is harsh, unreasonable, and doesn't understand that students have things to do outside of his class. He openly disrespects students in class, grades extremely harshly, doesn't give any extensions, and doesn't even teach. This class made me constantly anxious and felt like a waste of time and effort.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: This professor is the worst professor I have ever met in UR!!!!!!!!! Disrespect for the efforts, harsh in grading. This man ruins my day!!

Prof Enck grades everything very harshly and expects a lot out of students for an intro drawing class. Your art projects will not be graded on effort, but quality, which is why he rarely gives out As. He's extremely petty and takes note of who's late to lecture and takes off points from your grade bc of this. This man honestly made me hate drawing.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Good person, bad teacher. He doesn't understand that "Art is Subjective". He grades and critiques everything based on his opinion. As an abstract sculptor himself, he teaches drawing surprisingly and wants you to follow every rule and rubric. Class is boring. It's more like a math class instead of an art class.

He might be a good architect, but definitely NOT a good teacher!!! He actually does not "teach" us knowledge, but just let us study by ourselves. He always grade the homework based on his own opinion, ignoring the progress we made through all the semester!!!!

This professor made me like math again. He's fun, nice and genuinely cares about his students. The course material was definitely very complicated, but he did a great job breaking it down. I would only take this class if you're genuinely interested in math, however, because it takes a lot from a lot of different courses to understand it.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Math 215 (Which is his chaotic dynamics class) was by far my favorite math class in all of undergrad. The lectures were fantastic. The grading was a little chaotic, but if you spoke up in class, went to office hours, and wrote out your thought process on test questions he would often give you the benefit of the doubt.

Professor Juan Rivera Letelier is a terrible teacher. On top of that his grading for midterms is completely ridiculous as he gives no partial credit for attempting the problems. He gave a majority of students 0/18 on a midterm question and had to be overridden by the other 3 professors in order for students to get exam credit. Terrible class.
Just don't take his class. He will write a lot of proofs and suddenly realize that he skip a lot of concepts that we need to use for the proof.

Apathetic towards teaching. Makes many mistakes. Appears that he does not have proper knowledge of the subject. Teaches trivial things in class but gives super hard homework without explaining. Please don't take him.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Worst professor ever. Does not know the subject properly. Not sure why he is teaching. Just don't take if you want to live.  Combine all bad properties of all teachers and you get Juan
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Chill guy but basically doesn't answer any email even when he sees it. Gives extension when asked. Just make sure you do the assignments and follow the requirement can receive good grade.

I have mixed feelings on Kirby. He is obviously really talented and passionate about photography but I don't think he really enjoys teaching this class. Lectures are generally quite useless and consist of looking through the works of well-known and critically acclaimed artists.

The material discussed in lecture is totally irrelevant to assignment. He shows us artwork by virtuosos, but never mention how should we do with the software for assignments. He even just left us a pdf file to let us learn how to operate!! So, I learned these knowledge from YouTube. What is the purpose for the existence of professor?
Very knowledgeable and genuine teacher. Takes interest and value in what the students create. Make sure you put in effort.

Took intro to photography with him. He's very knowledgable and willing to dive deeper into whatever you have questions about. He is flexible and understanding but also doesn't take bs so just show that you care. I missed two critiques because the class is in the am, but I made up for it, bless him. Great guy.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Kirby is really understanding if you express that you're having difficulty with an assignment as long as you show that you're putting in effort.
this is the worst class I have taken in my four years as a mechanical engineering student
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy

comment: Prof. Borrelli's lectures are really in depth and a bit technical, but this is not always the information that we are expected to know. It takes a bit to figure out what you are expected to take away from each class. But it's a super interesting class that crosses over a lot of disciplines!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Lecture heavy

comment: Not very suitable for non-environmental majors. I didn't feel like learning anything from this class, and the test was graded very harshly. Although Professor Borrelli is really nice, the materials are heavy to study. I received all As in other courses but received a B+ in this 100-level class. You have to get 95 to earn an A so it's tough.

Professor Borelli is knowledgeable but very unapproachable. She does have lots of extra credit opportunities but the class material is too heavy for an intro class or anybody looking to take an elective. The TA in charge has an attitude and the exams are fair but it is a lot of material to memorize. Would not waste the time in this.

Didn't really care for her class. Borrelli was very dry and just reads off her slides for lectures, making it very difficult to pay attention. She has extra credit which is nice, but there is no curve. Tests are kinda hard, but if you study you'll be fine. She grades strict on homework and tests. Class is hit and miss.

Professor Borelli is a real sweetheart. Even though this was her first time teaching over zoom she made sure to be well-prepared for classes and made a lot of effort to make sure we all knew what was happening. She also provided a lot of optional extra credit to studnts and even allowed assignments to be attempted again after initial submission.

Actually mind boggling that people like this professor. Mediocre lectures, unreasonable. Once used r as a constant without saying it was a constant for a test question IN OUR UNIT ON POLAR COORDINATES. Bald and deserved to be bald.

Love Professor Wolf! He explains things in a detailed manner which is easy to understand. He starts with the very basics to make sure the higher level concepts have a good foundation to them. His notes are very easy to follow and his office hours are extremely helpful as well. If he taught higher level math class, I would take those as well.

I hated Calculus, but I would go to office hours often, and Wolf does a great job of working through the problem and making sure that you fully understand the concepts. He also made sure to do extended office hours the days before the midterms and final if you needed any help. Definitely utilize CETL and recitations if you need help.

He explained things simply and efficiently. He's a solid choice for an intro math class and a friendly guy. Webwork (homework) is unlike the lecture examples and exams. When studying for exams, review notes/lectures and then work on old exams.

prof wolf seemed like nice little man until we got into the material. he rlly did try his best to teach us, was v accessible outside of class for help, but is one of those insanely smart guys that simply cannot impart knowledge. class was mostly just doing an example prob and then expecting us to pick up on concepts and letting us loose on the hw.

Nice guy! He is patient and gives us time to write and makes sure we dont have any questions. Theres just the weekly webwork homework, but I reccommend going to study group for help, much harder than examples in lectures. Dont do what I did and bs the homework. Spend time everyday on them. I failed most midterms because I wasnt serious about study
Great, engaging professor. Highly recommend Physiology if you are willing to put in the work!

He is a caring person, but his lectures are not well-organized. Tests are hard but curved. This course is content-heavy; the amount of content you need to memorize is crazy a lot, which is presented in a not-so-clear way. You need to do extra work to reorganize them. I don't really like this class, reminding me of BIOL 111, by Minckey, but harder.

If you don't test well this class is not for you!! TOUGH grader. curve is based on errors in grading. Lectures move very fast and often doesn't go into as much detail as he expects you to know for the exams. Past exams given for practice are very different than the actual exams. Nice guy but exams are unrealistic for the average student to do well.

Genuinely a caring person, I failed 2 exams and he reached out to check up on me. When we met he apologized to ME because he usually tries to check in if everything is alright after the first exam (if bad). The class is fair, weekly open note BB quiz, exams based on lecture content, probably fine as long as you study (I didn't, S/F, changed minor)

This is my second course with Dr. Holz. He is absolutely great as a professor, but is sometimes a little bit disorganized. Anatomy definitely isn't an easy course, and requires a lot of memorization. I really recommend going to lecture, because tests are only on lecture content. Over all, Dr. Holz is entertaining and cares a lot!

Dr. Holz was very entertaining in his lectures, and he showed he really cared for students. BIO204's difficulty lies in the large amount of content he is trying to cover in a short time, but he is available for questions and office hours. Tests are tough but curved - would recommend rewatching lectures over reading the textbook!!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Hilarious

comment: The content of the class was easy but he graded us as if we were all psci majors (when most everyone was taking this class for a cluster). At the end of the semester he didn't give us our grades for the paper, presentation, or final exam he just gave a letter grade. Basically everyone got a B+. Wouldn't take again.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: He is the best professor I have had. His lectures are so interesting and he cares so much about the subject he teaches I can't wait to get him again next year. He is great.

An especially engaging lecturer. Passionate on the subject, funny, full of energy, knows a ton. The reading is intensive, but as long as you go to class and skim the key articles, you'll do fine. Exams are in essay format, some in class and some take home. Very accessible for people with no PSC background or for environmentalist types.
Best professor I've had so far. Really interesting and cares about the subject. Easy as long as you take good notes.
No Comments
He's approachable and genuinely interested in teaching students. You definitely need to go to class but his lectures were occasionally a bit dry.

The best lecturer for this course, she is very knowledgeable, has the relevant experiences, and honestly will teach you a lot in this course. I certainly enjoyed all aspects of the course, but perhaps assignments are a little bit frustrating because you really need to know all deadlines for hw, projects and essays and print them out to class.

Professor Kyker is an interesting person with a lot of relevant experience, but she is so snide and unaccommodating. She makes assignments as hard as possible by making printing mandatory (refuses to learn Blackboard) and omitting necessary information about said assignments. The class is deeply enriching but it is frustrating to work with her.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Admittedly, there is a lot of work for this class, but she handles it so well. Her structuring of the class is brilliant as she spreads out the paper so well during the time. Homework is also graded critically but not too harsh, and it is not difficult to get full credit on it. She is so knowledgeable and makes class so much fun.

You have to work for your grade since she gives a lot of homework but the lectures are worth it and super enjoyable. The material itself isn't hard and she brings in interesting people for her workshops. Would do again 10/10!

Professor Kyker is the epitome of the UofR's liberal agenda. I enrolled in her World Music in Context class to experience different kinds of music but half of the class was just focusing on protest movements in America. The material was blatantly anti-right, and so was the large amounts of reading we had to do. Workshops were enjoyable, though.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: I went through 4 years of engineering courses, and only for a few of them did I need to spend as much time on assignments as I did for this course.  Be prepared to spend 2-3+ hours on doing the reading and hw for each class. The attendance is mandatory b/c of quizzes and in class participation (which the prof has 10% control of grade).
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: I took the intro ethics class. Easiest A you'll find at Roch.He gave us sheets with the notes on them.   Study for tests and know what's on the guide lines. I know a few people who took it WAY too lightly and got Cs on the first test. Do the reading (it's SO short and interesting), show up once in a while, and study for half an hour; you'll get an

Philosophy of Language is not the most enthralling course but he tries to make it interesting.  He's definitely a nice guy and a pretty good teacher.  Lots of assignments but he's pretty cool about giving you enough time to complete them.  Biggest issue: he doesn't give any comments on assignments, just the grades.
He is very nice and he gives out worksheets that help us.

He asked the class what our favorite disease was.  I want to give him a hug because i feel bad for him, leave because it's terrible to stay in a classroom with him, and then have a beer with him later b/c he's prolly a good guy.
he gives you the notes, i didn't have to open a book...but sooooo boring its ridiculous.  easy class though

He hands you typed copies of the notes but his explanations can be boring and very hard to understand.  Especially when he starts writing on the board.  It is usually illegible and he writes over things without erasing them making it worse.

Timur is  bellow average as far as teachers go here.  He structured the class so that the students are working together to solve problems and barely takes the time in explaining the material.   Lectures are evidently not prepared often ahead of class and, if you can at all avoid taking a class with him, I would recommend it.

He explained things pretty well in class, even using real items to show integration (traditional Nesting Dolls and potato slices with a mandolin). Attendance was mandatory, material taught was exactly on the midterms and final. No curve balls really, if you did your webwork you should have passed with a B/B-. Liked the class to participate

He is  helpful and nice. He held a review session before the final and was available during the office hours. However, sometimes I had a hard time following his lectures and had to do self-study. I wish he could slow down a little bit and give more examples. The math 162 tests and the homework were hard.
Teaches fast, lectures are secondary material compared to the book. He tries to be helpful, but he isn't.

I could not understand what he was saying half of the time (like most professors at the university of rochester). He did little to no in class examples and the TA's had little to no idea what was going on. Hard class expect to teach yourself most of the material.

He is the best professor in UR math department. I've never seen any professor as responsible as him. He holds review sessions and makes review sheets. His lectures are very clear. Although his jokes are weird funny, he is a humorous and nice person. He is just awesome.

As long as you do the readings and come to class, you'll do fine. It's not my favorite class in the whole world, but it's not the worst either. She's a super cool and fun lady and even though the subject isn't something that I am personally interested in, the class was still okay in my book.

One of the only professors I took at UR that was willing to meet with me outside of class, and answer emails. She cares about helping students succeed, and prepares interesting reading and class sessions.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Although Professor Mannheimer can be a tough grader, if you go to her for help, she is more than willing to give you feedback and help you improve your performance in the class. As long as you are willing to put forth effort and genuine interest , taking a class with her would be very beneficial. She was very helpful with papers.
She's okay, sometimes class tended to be boring, not much preparation for the midterm or final.  She's really cute though.
I took her class on Jane Austen. Very knowledgeable and enthusiastic. The class was not demanding, just two essays and two midterms. Also, cute as hell.
Mannheimer has to be one of the most enthusiastic and bubbly professors I've ever met. She's great.

I had an A for the entire term until the final. When we had the final, it was poorly written and on topics we did not learn. I got a 35%, the class average was a 50% and the high was a low C. Upon asking him to consider a retake option he said no adamantly and I, the person who had an A all term, ended up with a C.

Absolutely hated this class. The professor seems to only care about finishing the class on time. Even if most of the students were confused he didn't address them and would just say to talk to him after class. Studied alone and did better than attending class.

He is just reading the slides during lectures and you can learn nothing from his lecture. His tests are 20 multiple choice questions, but most of questions require tons of calculation and he wants you to finish in 65 minutes. You cannot finish those even you understand everything on class.

I've learned nothing from his class. He just talks to himself and not care if his students are understanding. Your grade is only determined by 3 tests and maybe because his lectures are confusing and not helpful the tests were challenging to me. I learned more by studying the textbook by myself.
Very clear expectations, tests based on material learned in class. Going to class and reading the textbook are both optional, all information is in the powerpoints.

He wasn't a good professor at all. He always read his powerpoint slides in class and sometimes skiped reading a few slides. When you ask him a question in class, he will always answer just go back and read the slides. If he wants you to read the slides then what's the point of having a lecture? He never cares about students, he cares about paper.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Interesting class, interesting man. Lots of reading, lots of analyzing.
