Professor Glade is an amazing teacher. I lover her making constant analogies to explain difficult subjects with daily life examples.

Professor Glade superbly integrates soft matter physics and fluid mechanics into explaining Earth processes. She derives all the necessary mathematics in a clear, concise way and offers demonstrations of certain concepts in lab experiments and numerical models. You get to devise a lab of your own for the final project too! Very kind and smart.

Professor Glade is easily the best professor I've ever had. Her lectures are incredibly engaging due to her humor and enthusiasm. She's very skilled at describing the physics underlying processes that occur on Earth's surface. She's also incredibly kind, caring, and charismatic and even hosts a hiking trip at the end of the semester for class.

Oberly was a great professor and very caring! The class itself was very difficult, especially the second half. Oberly was very helpful during office hours though. I also recommend going to study group and tutoring through the learning center if you need help with webwork problems.
Awful course, but a great professor. If you have to take Math 162, take Oberly.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Tough course but he is always available to answer questions and enthusiastic

Challenging class consider if you have ap calc ab and jump straight into college level calc 2, a lot of students I know have bc or equivalent IB background. I recommend watching corresponding lessons from professor V on youtube before coming to class.

Big difficulty spike in the second part of class with series. I recommend going to office hours, the 162 study groups, and finding a (free) tutor through the learning center. Oberly is a caring and available professor even if his lectures sometimes drag on, and if you do the webwork consistently then you should be on track for a good grade.

I thought he did a great job with teaching this class and his lectures were genuinely helpful. I must say that a common struggle that many had was the wording of this semesters exams which really confused me because of how unclear some sections were. Otherwise, he is an approachable professor and I highly recommend asking questions!

Oberly is a kind professor who takes time to answer your questions and teaches in a good manner. Sometimes he skips a few steps or goes a bit too quickly but overall, he is pretty good. Out of all the math 162 teachers, I recommend him because when talking to my peers, he seems to be the best. But math 162 as a class is hard and tests are unfair.

Peter is super accesible outside of class, passionate about teaching, and welcoming! This class is definitely pretty hard, especially since the final makes up such a large part of the grade, yet lectures and recitations are helpful. Lectures can feel a little dense and overwhelming, but overall a great class!

Super knowledgable and cares for his students a lot! His lectures are quite content heavy but that's expected for any math course. Not necessary to read the textbook but it makes the lectures easier to understand if you skim beforehand.
Awesome professor and really kind. Made microbio 220 lectures interesting. Always super helpful in the MBI221 lab too. Made us stand by our projects and took a picture of us like a grandpa haha
Professor that really cares about student's inquiries into their own projects. Is approachable and extremely knowledgeable. Understanding and kind. Highly recommend.

Is very fair and approachable. He will tell you exactly what is and is not on the test. He keeps lectures interesting, though if you want to do well you will want to read the textbook. He does not solely us it though.

He was the worst teacher I've ever had. Late to class 90% of the time and then keeps the class late. He has the class buy the newest version of the book but uses old slides. He cannot answer questions and frequently gives misinformation.

I found this class tough because I had no previous bg on movable do and relative pitch, but I enjoyed this class. Most of the grade is attendance and prof Meeker is very flexible so that you can receive credit for attending. Overall very chill and caring prof. I you do well on half of the exams (2/4) and do extra credit, you'll get an A.
He cares so much. You can tell how much he loves music, and how much he loves what he is teaching. It makes you want to care as much as he does.

Meeker is an amazing teacher! He's excellent at making sure all of his students are following the material and are participating. A large portion of your grade is based on participation, so by just coming to class and consistently following along will boost your grade. No outside work required, just coming to class is enough to do well on exams.

Meeker is awesome! He gives very reasonable homework, and to some extent you can choose how much time you spend on it. He is also a very likable guy who really wants to get to know his students. The exams are a breeze as long as you've been coming to class and doing  the homework. All in all, Meeker comes highly recommended.
Very helpful professor.
Heidi is so nice and a very sweet person. She is extremely helpful..made my CAS class seem so simple...and passed with a good grade :)
No Comments
Wonderful professor at Empire State - REALLY knows his course. I would be happy to take his course again.
Prof. really considerate and understanding... helps people with their writing a lot.
No Comments

Definitely recommend taking her classes! She is such a caring and kind person. Her classes are fun and relaxing. Have taken 2 of her classes and still going to take more! If you do the work you're suppose to, you will definitely get an A!
Huang Laoshi is an amazing professor, I highly recommend anyone studying Chinese to take her courses. She is extremely kind and helpful.
Language classes always involve a lot of participation and assignments, but Ms. Huang is always open to questions and feedback on the course structure.

Prof. Garzione is one of the best geology profs at the UofR. Her lectures are clear and concise and she's a very nice person. If you have any interest in geology at the UofR, take EES 101. Now just because it's a 101 course, don't underestimate EES 101 as an easy class, the material is challenging for those not used to geology.

Carmie is a wonderful professor, very knowledgeable, very friendly and approachable, EES 203 is called sedimentology and stratigraphy, which is in Carmie's field of expertise, tests are harder (more technical material) than the ones she gives in EES 101, but if you study hard, you'll get the good grades.

So far, I think she's been a really great teacher. I like her teaching method- she writes notes on the board of the important information and has additional slides with lots of pictures and animations. Her tests are really easy if you just study your notes from lecture.
I am a Spanish major and she is the best professor I have ever had. Extremely helpful and encouraging. Wants to see her student succeed

She's a great teacher, really good for someone who just started teaching.  I enjoyed the class a lot.  Thought her grading on tests was wicked (like ridiculously!) unfair but I don't agree with the previous comment that she lashes out at students.  I thought she was always very polite and she never criticized anyone for participating.

A good teacher, if you manage to stay on her good side. Showing up late, not participating enough (or too much!), or asking a question she deems unnecessary will instantly land you on her bad side, and you won't be able to get back. Tends to be moody, lashes out at students sometimes, plays favorites. Helpful and nice if she likes you, though.
very helpful
Clear and concise.
best TA ever

Kristen Lennarz is an very carrying professor. She tries to make herself accessible during times that work for the student and understands that students are humans too. She is very enthusiastic about teaching and goes out of her way to help her students. If you have any troubles or concerns, she is a very approachable professor.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects

comment: Kristin's professional experience and high level of intelligence make her an awesome prof. She impressed me by adjusting to different learning styles. The textbook she chose was solid and she gave us spreadsheet of awesome digital tools. Plus she connected me with professionals during my job search after class ended. 10/10 would take class with KL.

So unorganized! Most of the class had a hard time understanding the requirements of her assignments and even the lectures. She always includes a lot of redundant information in her lectures and makes them so confusing.

He appears nice and caring on the surface, but shows misogynistic and racist tendencies in class. Shows favoritism to female students. Think of Majorie from Fat Fighters treating the class attendees, very true esp to overseas students/foreigners. Pretentious personality and awful person

'HE WAS NEVER A SUCCESSFUL ENTREPRENEUR. HE FAILS HIS BUSINESS FROM DAY 1'. Ask him if you don't believe. Will you let some useless and loser one teach you in the class that will make you from felling to lose money? Try to teach people how to pitch when you never raise any money. Even a little student could beat you man.

Professor Estad is very caring about students feelings during the lecture. The pitching class is small scale and its a good chance to make friends and practice your presentation skills. In order to get an A you should arrange a rehearsal with professor and make changes according to his comments.
Excellent professor

Professor Kuo is the best. She knows biomaterials is different from our other classes, and spends extra time reviewing basic concepts both in class and in office hours. If you go to lecture (she gives amazing lectures), actually read the book, and follow her study tips, you'll ace the class. She is really fair, and also gives lots of extra credit!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof Kuo was absent for at least three weeks of the class. She rarely gives actual answers to the questions she asks and does not explain the concepts on the homework. The class isnt very difficult if you just read the textbook and repeat exactly what it says. She claims that orgo isnt necessary but if you dont know it youre at a disadvantage.
Nice person.

Lectures somewhat boring but it's calc. Somewhat helpful in office hours and will remember your name if you go to office hours. Exams were much more difficult than expected. Class is mediocre at best.

Great guy, knows his stuff and is pretty good at communicating to his students. Was nervous at first but as the semester went on he got more confident. Also very willing to help students out outside of class
He tries to teach students, but he fails most of the time. Lectures are not that good, so be prepared to study this class by yourself, otherwise, you won't pass.

Caring professor. Wants to make sure students understand the material. Believes understanding the material is more important than memorizing equations. First test super easy, second test impossible, final was fair. First time teaching the class so it took a while to figure out how to make good exams. Will probably be better in future semesters.
Difficult exams!! Professor basically teaches out of the textbook. Written homework is impossible, webwork usually easy. Prof is decent, beware of exams, they are HARD
rating_tags: Tough Grader--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: I loved this course. The professor is super engaging and fun. The content is also very interesting. I will warn you that the exams are tough due to the scientific wording. If you are inexperienced in BCS, you might struggle. You will also have a lot of easy assignments, but they take time. If you are struggling, the TA and professor are helpful.

He is really a good and expert professor. He explains concepts and reading materials well. The tests are not that hard if you pay attention to the lectures and go over the slides. The homework is also interesting as a Twitter-like comment is required for each journal article. I really like him.

Professor Dodell-Feder does a great job of teaching the material. His lectures are interesting and interactive, which makes the class enjoyable. He cares about his students and has a good sense of humor. Overall a great professor and a great guy.
Vague comments on your essays and vague requirements. Very strict graders and get ready to read a lot. the materials are not hard, but the way he grades is very weird.
Very strict grader and is not very helpful when you ask for help. His comments on essays are very vague.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: I had class during his office hours and still met with him before each paper because he was willing to be flexible and work with scheduling. He gives detailed, helpful feedback on all of our work, which was especially helpful in a writing course. Grading criteria is not always the most clear, but if you follow his feedback you will do well.
do not take her course
I love how she designs the class projects. I love the LD discussion, which brings everyone together and closer. Same as WRTG 102

Her class helps people in class became friends cause the class vibe is really good. As a freshman, I gained a sense of belonging from her class and classmates. Attendance is really important (cause she grades you on it). If you follow the class and complete every homework, you most likely will get an A-. Most of the students in our class got A-.

I enjoyed taking CSC212: HCI with Prof. Yan. He was a good lecturer and the guest lectures at the end of the semester were quite fun with lots of Q&A interactions. My only caveats are the course structure - sometimes materials and grading were messy; but that's understandable, given that it was his first time instructing the course.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment:
Interesting lectures and fun assignments/projects to work on.

There will be pop quizzes that count on your grade.
rating_tags: Group projects--Amazing lectures --Beware of pop quizzes

comment: He give you one week to do an assignment that cannot be don't properly given the time frame. His lectures are not clear and have no structure.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--So many papers

comment: Avoid her at all costs. You won't learn anything. Her class is just common sense.
Omg, she's so bad. Fake class with random guest speakers.
She thinks she smart and pretends to know a lot.  But she doesn't know anything.  Worst class ever.  Don't take it if you don't have to.  You won't learn anything useful.

He took over for professor Slane halfway through the semester. Fortunately moved slower through lectures so it was more easily understood. He also occasionally dropped a few homework assignments late in the semester which was clutch.

He is a super understanding and caring professor. He makes learning fun and stress free. He test questions were always from homework or workshop and he was very transparent which the test information. He organization skills lacked sometimes as he would take forever to grade homework but over all he made dynamics very easy.

lectures were a little slow but he explained it well. he has amazing notes he posts. homework was kinda time consuming. exams were much easier than any practice problem we did. overall super sweet and caring

He did his job, man. He explained MATLAB things well even though he started teaching the class in the 2nd half of the semester (which meant two classes with him back-to-back if you also took Dynamics)
Really good explanations, was very kind with exam content and grading criteria. Show effort.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Really clear in explaining complex problems and step by step walkthroughs. He also gives lots of resources and help outside of class if you need it, 10/10 would recommend
He is sarcastic and rather mean to his students. I learned everything from the book and from my TA.

Super nice guy and very easy going. He tries to keep class interesting with random jokes as well as random stories. He teaches the material fairly well and always encourages students to attend office hours to learn, not memorize the material.

Olsen is a nice and often funny guy but he unfortunately does not possess the skills to connect with this students. He lacks the ability to conduct a course, he stumbled through class often having trouble with the very problems that he formulated...going to his office hours were helpful....but only because other professors were present
Guy is basically a genius, but gives his best every class.  Always willing to encourage other views

Very bright, though a bit abstract at times. Sufficient rigor but fair in assessment of student work. Not ideological. Encourages students to express different ideas. Flexible regarding deadlines and understands that adult students often must prioritize professional and/or family issues over their studies.

Excellent professor; a lot of reading but it all ties in together and is very helpful.  Makes class interesting and does not sit up in front and lecture all the time.  If you do the reading and work hard you'll have no problems.  Very engaging and knowledgable and willing to help students.

Easy class in terms of workload.  Very little actual work, more just reading of the material.  Elliot does a great job explaining material so it is important to go to class.  Tests are difficult if you do not take decent notes in class.  All the readings are online so no reason to buy a textbook.

Dr. Elliott is great at teaching things clearly. He emphasizes what's important and is great at answering any questions that come up in class. The assigned readings aren't necessary to do well in the class, but they augment understanding and most of them are very interesting. His tests are also very fair because he gives good study guides.

He's the man! Made me want to take more philosophy classes. You have to go to lecture and take good notes if you want to do well - he breaks down all the readings so they make more sense, and spoon feeds you arguments. Midterm, final, and one paper (not a lot of work). Also really helpful in office hours and very interested in what his students.
LOVVVVED her class. It's super easy and interesting as long as you actually show up!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Amazing lectures

comment: She graded papers a bit harsher than the requirements she had posted, but otherwise Jess did a decent job at teaching about writing.

She was a good professor. It wasn't boring and I feel like she went easier on us than the other writing professors did. She offered help whenever you needed. As long as you put in a good effort, you can get a good grade. But she does grade papers extremely hard.
this professor didn't have empathy.  i feel badly to give this review but hope that it helps students considering this course.

I'd say he is a good professor overall, but he can be a bit too laid-back. He shows up late to class so often that near the end of the semester, I left my dorm when class should've started and I'd still make it before him. He gives pretty good feedback on essays, but it's really hard to get an A in this class because of the way the class is graded.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He creates a laid back atmosphere and he encourages students to express their opinion and urges them to think outside the box. He gives really useful feedback on papers and overall it was the class I looked forward to most
Good teacher. Really cares about students
A sweet and kindhearted woman. She will always brighten up your day in her glasses, guaranteed.
Jackie is the best yoga instructor you will ever encounter. Must take this class before graduating!
She's super understanding and lenient. Jacki is great!
Excellent professor and advisor! Definitely expects students to work hard and master material but you will always walk away better off! :)
Great professor; esp. great advisor!
Everything she says in class pretty much is tangential to your understanding of the material.

Best English Professor I've ever seen. Very easy to approach. The workloads are very manageable. The paper in the class didn't weigh too much on your final grade. So don't worry if you are not a good writer.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: The best professor. Very fair and class was excellent.
She's a great person overall. Her lectures are good and not boring. The class is designed to be discussion based so you'll end up talking to your classmates a lot more than the professor herself.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--So many papers

comment: If you actually want to learn about HR, don't take this class.
One of the better prof's at Simon.
unhelpful, arrogant, tests poorly written, lectures boring and vague.

Prof Korn is an excellent professor. He would always make sure that his students are learning the Italian language and that they practice their writing and conversational skills. As a matter of grading, he can be a tough grader sometimes but he would always give good feedback. Because of COVID we did not have quizzes, instead, we had papers.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Amazing lectures

comment: Although he was not bad last semester in IT101 he has made a 180 in his teaching and his grading. He is a strict professor and does not listen well to student feedback, as he finds ways to justify his harshness. You need to go to class, but even if you participate don't expect 100%. Exams- he will take points off even if your answer is right.

Andrew is passionate about Italian language and culture and has vast experience inside and outside the classroom.  I was afraid to start learning a new language and he gave me the confidence to not only try but persist, which is critical in language acquisition.  When Andrew tells me, bravissima!, it is worth all the work.

Professor Abtahian is a really fun professor. The class is hard, and she can sometimes be a bit scattered, but she is really nice and workable if you need deadline extensions. Her exams are quite hard, but she offers retakes which really do help so take them if offered. I would definitely take a class with her again.

This is a lecture-heavy class, but she's a strong lecturer. Sometimes it feels like she's so familiar with the material that it's hard for her to remember what it's like for us to be learning it the first time, but she adjusts accordingly when students are struggling to understand the material. She's great at engaging with students personally too.
Maya is great
He is unfriendly and mean to students. Wouldn't take his course again.
Professor Haviv is a great instructor. If I have chance, I am perfectly willing to take his another programming courses.

Haviv isn't a good professor. He doesn't distribute grades until it's almost too late. He will ask you questions in lecture and then yell at you for answering. It doesn't surprise me that he doesn't teach undergraduates, because he's unfriendly and unwilling to help. He redistributes points such that there aren't too many outliers. He's awful.

This class was pretty easy. A basic understanding of math is needed. Dr Smith herself is obviously passionate about the material but isn't the best lecturer. She is also not the most consistent with posting assignments on time, something that became prevalent in AME 141 (the next class in the 140's series). Labs are pretty good, and TA's are great.
TOO EASY LMAO

This class was really easy for me, Sarah Smith is very very nice and made the lectures really clear with her pre-class notes. Explained everything from the basic math and physics principles for people who haven't had much experience with it, and overall very helpful in both the lectures and labs (when she comes).

Best professor I've had here. His dedication to teaching is second to none, and teaching is his side gig. Class can be quick but he'd take time to make sure everyone was on the same page if needed, would stay 30+ min extra if anyone had questions & would encourage us to email about anything. Gave clear grading criteria & good lectures. Excellent :)
Professor Moon is very Nice and Helpful. Always there for students.

Professor Moon is one of the most talented and humble professor I have seen in ECE department. He is super helpful and willing to spend hours with you to explain something over and over again untill you really understand. The course itself is hard but please, reach the professor out, he is going to solve all your problems ! Don't procrastinate!
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Starr is one of the worst professors I have had so far. She is very disorganized and is a professor that just comes in because it is her job. I never felt she actually cared whether her students understood the material or not. Her class is very dependent on the exams so good luck.
Professor Starr is a very nice and caring professor but she looks like she dreads her job. She walks in and already looks bored. Her class is pretty easy.

The professor is nice but she can be clumsy or unprepared for class often. The class isn't really a lot of new information, mainly everything is read off the powerpoint. I wish there were more assignments in the class or opportunities for discussion. The class is alright, not too hard if you study. Sometimes the professor seems like shes rushing
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: Course is full of fluff until the end where he tried to pack content in. He answers questions with questions.  He creates trick questions that do not test your knowledge. He wastes a lot of lecture time with personal stories. He is a poor lecturer and speaks really fast. Exams are punitive and require you to install software that tracks your eyes.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: Terrible decision to use paper exam for a coding class. As with any professor that do exams for coding, does not understand that coding is a language and how to teach coding effectively.

He taught introductory programming extremely well. His lectures were very clear and organized, and had lots of examples. He made class super fun and easy. I still program a lot today and he set a very strong foundation.

Not a bad professor, but the class is harder than expected. The first two exams have very dry material with a lot of jargon and math, making it boring and challenging to study for. He's clearly very smart, but the material is too challenging for it to be an easy A.

Loved Dr. Presgraves -- very clear lecturer and answers questions well. The exams are a little difficult because they're multiple choice so it's all or nothing. That being said, they shouldn't be too bad if you take careful notes and attend the discussions. They are helpful because you can get a sense of what he thinks is important in that unit.

Went into molecular evolution relatively uninterested in the subject and was put off by the heavy reliance on algebra for the first exam. Make no mistake though, the remainder of the material is extremely interesting and Presgraves is a very clear and thorough lecturer.
Prof Sbriglia is a great guy and always willing to help.

Took an American Studies class with him at St. John Fisher college and absolutely loved it. Great teacher, gave help whenever needed, and pushed me to find new pieces of literature to help better understand concepts in American history.

Prof. Sbriglia is the best guy on the face of the planet. As a chemistry major, I never was very good at English, but Prof. Sbriglia made it very easy to do well in his class. Extraordinarily entertaining, nicest guy at this school. Lectures were interesting because he made them fun and informative. I would take any of his classes in a heartbeat!

Excellent professor that facilitates a great learning environment with thoroughly explained concepts and insightful info on research. Lectures are dense with info, and the exams are tough but open notes and she gives you a superset of exam questions that she'll choose from. Answer those questions ahead of time and take good notes and you'll do well

Prof. Kurumada made me wish that I was a BCS major. While the exams were difficult, if you prepared good notes (exams are open-note), you could absolutely do well on them. Fascinating material, and the course design facilitated a greater understanding of and appreciation for it, which made the experience much more enjoyable. 11/10
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Caring

comment: Had her as my PI for a research class. She's incredibly helpful.

If you look for a prof. with no teaching skills at all then you are right here. She doesn't give you new insights, only reads her overloaded slides & isn't able to create a warm learning atmosphere with interesting in-class discussions. Plus she can't handle any kind of electronic device on her own. She's clearly self-opinionated & rude. Avoid her!
awful. seriously.

If you're willing to sit for 2 hours and 40 mins listening to her drone on in a thick polish accent about the plots of movies, and are not looking to do any thinking whatsoever, then you'll have a ball.  Plus, she can never remember how to use the dvd player, even though someone shows her how to every week.  She has no original insight of her own.
Really really nice and helpful. The first few weeks are hard and it seems to make no sense but it gets a lot easier. She's really understanding and always willing to help... even at the last minute.

One of the best engineering professor I have had to date.  She really knows the material and makes sure that you do as well.  Very helpful in office hours and recitations.  One of the fairest exam graders you will find.  Lectures can be very dry, but you do learn a lot.

despite some people's impressions, prof grac. actually has a sense of humor, and is possibly the nicest professor i've had at the ur yet.  unclear during class on occasion but willing to explain over and over again till you understand (and always available to do so).

For being in grad school and teaching, she is doing very well. She was always more than willing to help at her office hours, and she would answer questions at midnight sometimes. Very knowledgeable for being so young. I wish the course had less math.. that was one thing I think the course could do without. Great person!
seems smart in topic, yet has difficulty conveying information to other people

Absolutely terrible professor. She is extremely boring and hard to follow along with. She also is very unclear and doesnt explain things even when asked for clarification. She will just ask students to explain it, not herself. She doesnt know what she is talking about and will try explaining something for awhile before realizing that she is wrong.
good professor, but if you need a good grade, don't take his class. you will kill yourself since he is very harsh grader.

Shukla is a very knowledgable man, especially in the subject matter of this class. His passion and enthusiasm are evident, making for engaging classes that seem to warp the ordinary perception of time.  The workload is not too heavy and he is very accepting of students' situations in terms of grading. Certainly a course that I would take again.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: Very smart, explains all the readings very thoroughly. If you ask him for extensions on writing assignments, he usually gives them if you have at least a decent reason for an extension.

Teaching was striaght-forward, concise, and never too wordy or to drawn-out on needless topics or derivations.  Taught the project, while still making us do the research and come up with unique solutions.  Very approachable and knowledgeable.
Among the best.

Ahmet is cool to talk to, and he has a sweet job where he's clearly well-respected. However, he skips tons of "obvious" steps in his lectures, leaving most of the class confused. His handwriting is lousy and he erases things before you can write them down. He taught nothing that helped with the project that constituted the majority of the class.

Lectures were Powerpoint-driven, which he always posted online after class. Always answered questions and made sure students really understood the material. Lots of word problems on the exams. The last class before an exam was always a review session, which is very rare but super helpful. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
Lovely person and great professor. I genuinely enjoyed this class and am so glad I took it in lieu of 111.

Rabeling is such a great professor. His exams are very representative of the lectures and he is very fair. He wants to see everyone do great in his class. I personally know a couple student in the Bio 111 or Bio 113 courses who wish that they took this professor. You won't regret taking him.
Very clear and detailed lectures. Very approachable and easy to meet with for help outside class.
His lecture is amazing and everyone who listens carefully can get a good scores.

Professor Doyle's lectures were always clear and well laid out. Although it seems counter-intuitive, actually read the textbook. Very few students read the text and only complete the problems, but it is worthwhile to read the book. Doyle was very approachable and office hours were productive and helpful.

Really nice, puts a lot of time into giving feedback, if you go to office hours you will do better. Doesn't give the most clear instructions... so just ask for clarification. You're an adult communicate its not all on the teacher. Once you ask everything will become clear usually, if you TRY you will probably get at least a B in this class.

Great professor! The learning objectives are clear: students learn to analyze research papers. By the end of the course, you will probably become fluent in determining objectives, methods, and interpreting results. And with this comes the necessary workload. Be advised: if you are not interested in research, maybe this is not the professor for you.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: This professor is AWFUL. Her lecture are pedantic, and the writing exercises are tedious busy-work that will be very harshly assessed. Only take this if you are taking no other classes besides this because this is how she treats the course. She has absolutely no respect for her students.

Nicole is arguably the best and sweetest professor/person I have met in my life. She's very approachable and offer the best advice for your writings. If you planning on taking WRT 105 and is here to figure out which professor you should take it with, take it with Nicole!

I feel like sometimes she treats us like we're in fifth grade and I thought the class would be more interesting. She's not very engaging and we are covering material we have already covered (eg. MLA) I think the class I have learned the most from consisted of a student discussing the history of bananas from a book he read. Discussions  great.

Nicole is one of the nicest people you'll ever meet. She is helpful in and outside of class, and genuinely cares about you as a student. Amazing things she did: canceled class the day before Thanksgiving break so we could go home early, gave multiple pages of amazingly helpful feedback on papers, and let us write about topics we enjoyed. Loved her!

Searle is a gem of the University of Rochester anthropology department. As a class discussion heavy class, doing the readings helps you get the most out of this class. She is thoughtful, engaging, funny, and really cares about how material is presented and student engage with it. I found class periods to be really engaging!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: I have come away from each of her courses with the feeling that not a second of my time was wasted and that the experience was truly valuable. She is always available outside of class, super helpful, and really fun to talk to! Her classes do require serious participation (and a good amount of reading), but doing so is incredibly rewarding :)

Llerena Searle is a phenomenal professor. She is one of the most intelligent and well spoken individuals I have ever encountered. She genuinely cares for her students. She is a tough grader but in a fair way, if you put effort into the class you will be fine. She is the reason I want to major in Anthropology.

Maddox is my favorite professor at the UofR. The class material is hard, but he really tries to make sure the class is understanding things. He genuinely cares about students and tries to explain the material in several ways so that everyone understands what's going on. Homework is hard and time-consuming, but that's typical BME.

I loved Prof Maddox: incredibly nice guy and amazing lecturer. Homeworks were a lot to handle sometimes and the course content is difficult due to the nature of the material, but Maddox made learning about the material fun and engaging. The lab reports were terrible and unhelpful, but that is not his fault since he does not run the labs.

Maddox was one of the best teachers in the department. His class was definitely hard, the homeworks almost unbearable at times, but that is pretty standard in the BME department. His lectures were always pretty clear and he always made himself available for questions, and adjusted the course for students as needed.

Amazing professor. Would 100% recommend this class to anyone looking to explore great authors from all over the world. Truly changed the way I view literature, his class was the highlight of my freshman year!!

He's such an amazing professor who actually genuinely cares about his students and what they're going through. He assigns really good reading material - I also took his Black Speculative Fiction course, and to this day, it's one of my favorite courses. His class discussions are so insightful and engaging; he really tries to pull his students in
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Omelsky does a great job facilitating class discussion and helping students become passionate about the material. The workload for my class was fairly light, and he was always very willing to help students outside of class.

Dr. Larracuente is one of the best instructors I ever met. She goes out of her way to help students with the group project. I went to my first class with zero genomics knowledge as my major was not comp bio or genomics and came out of the last class with lots of knowledge.
You need to know things already if you want to like this course.

She is a lovely and considerate professor, who cares a lot about students and their success. Amanda was willing to be flexible and pushed us, while also having realistic time and workload expectations.

Was very excited to take the Music and the Mind class but sadly, it ended up being quite disappointing. Piazza is one of the kindest and nicest professors I've had, but the lectures are quite slide-heavy and dull. A real shame because the material is very interesting.

Dr. Piazza is awesome. Her class is pretty heavy on the slides, so it's not super engaging. But she provides so many examples of the musical/psychological phenomena we talk about, and these are extremely helpful for understanding the concepts and having fun too :)
The grading is pretty slow, but other than that the class is good!
Dr Piazza is great. Interesting material in lectures and overall very kind. All the midterms are open note and fairly easy. Would definitely recommend!

Mind-numbingly boring lecturer that spends much more time than needed on very basic concepts. Assigns weekly homeworks, mandatory workshops, and discussion posts. Pop quizzes scattered throughout the sem, which I'm convinced is the only reason anybody actually attends the lectures. Nice person, gets the curriculum across, but just so boring.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: The professor is nice but boring. The only thing that kept me interested was the content. For an intro class, I would say it takes a lot of effort to learn this new information. Lots of my peers said they struggled. There is also a mandatory recitation that is extremely helpful. Take advantage of that. The exams are simple if you study.

As an introduction class, there was little introduction material. Topics were discussed without proper understanding from students. The class was entirely lecture-based with little to no group discussion. Homeworks weren't discussed in class and did not come from class discussions. Exams and quizzes are correlated with homework not lectures.
I liked the class. Good to have some math background
I really liked his class. Not easy though

Unfortunately, Professor Moretti does not know how to teach. The professor reads off PPTs and flies through units, finishing all the content two weeks before the midterm. Although the teacher is very intelligent, sometimes intelligence doesn't translate to being a good teacher.

homework and tests much harder than what is taught in the lecture. She explains things well if you ask her. This course is not friendly to anyone who have not learned coding before, feels like it expects you to know about python already. She is a good professor but the homework and tests are too hard for a python starter.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: I really enjoyed Lopatkin, for a lot of CHE students this might be the first experience of coding, but she is extremely nice, this was her first semester teaching this course (spring 2024) and she listened to a lot of our feedback on her class and testing policies. Exams are hard, but her lecture slides are amazing and really help with studying.

Not incredibly engaging lectures and homeworks tend to be way more difficult than what is taught in class. You're basically forced to look a ton of things up. Exams are also pretty hard and theres a pretty big advantage for people who already have coding experience. But overall not terrible since it gets curved in the end.

I am taking Professor Slaughter's "Thoreau's Nature" class. It's my favorite class by far! Professor Slaughter steps back and lets us speak, but he makes sure to steer us in the right direction if needed. It's hard (but not impossible!) to get an A on a homework assignment or paper for his class, but he offers good criticism.

Take professor Slaughters Just and Unjust War class, it is literally the best. This class examines the history of wars but you get to pick which war you want to research. He's so helpful and encouraging and I'm so glad I took this class!
Best Prof at Rochester
Very nice teacher, very helpful.

Best math teacher I have ever had. Hands down. He is so clear and helpful! A great teacher and was one of the reasons I was able to do well in the class. he is also funny and jokes around a bit, which makes the class enjoyable.
One of the best professors for calculus 142. A friend with another professor went to Haessig's lectures because he taught better. Hes also witty if you're quick enough to catch his humor.

Lectures can be very boring because she doesn't use any outside visual aides and is content to just talk for the entire class period.  That being said, her dry humor keeps the lectures tolerable.  Grading isn't too harsh, but don't be fooled into thinking that this class will be an easy 'A'.
Story time with Grandma. Not the most interesting a little rough on the grading
Despite her age (or perhaps because of it) Young is a mediocre professor.  She is surprisingly funny, but occasionally her monologoues are intolerably boring.

Professor Welte's passion for science and teaching really made this an enjoyable class. I really appreciated that he took the time to get to know his students, and offer help. The assignments were challenging, but very applicable to a career in biology research. I thought this was the best course I've taken at UR.

It's obvious that he is excited about his art and wants you to share his passion as well. I guess the best way to make a person swim is to throw him in the water. This is exactly what Prof. Welte does. He would make you read loads of papers and come up with project proposals and give presentations and actively participae in class discussions.

What an EXCELLENT professor!  He answers any questions you have and encourages discussions toward which he contributes very clear and concise information.  He has a passion for the material, and his German accent is awesome.  Oh, and I think he's gay which would explain his apparent fabulous-ness :D
Great dedicated professor, and extremely knowledgable about everything brain. I found her energy inspirational.

Her lectures aren't bad, but she's very difficult to work with and not accommodating to her students. Adamantly refuses to curve tests, and if you want to challenge an unfair or miscalculated grade she'll fight you to her last breath.
I know a lot of people had trouble with this class.  She talks really fast, but she teaches right from the book and if you study the powerpoints she gives you its really hard to go wrong.

Good lecturer. No textbook, and most of the information is on the slides, but I'd definitely recommend going to the lectures because he gives context to the information and studies on the slides that you wouldn't be able to get from just looking at the slides. If you go to class and study the slides well, the tests are very fair.

Really enthusiastic about the material and the exams were fair. The 4 non-cumulative tests are the only things you're graded on, but as long as you go to class and study his lectures in detail, you'll do well.

Great class, great professor. Explains things very clearly, and tests are extremely fair (not easy, but your grade will be proportional to your effort). Probably my favorite class so far, and I'm excited to have him for BCS 246. Highly recommend him.

She is a very nice lady, is the best way I can explain it. She's truly excited about Hebrew and teaching it. The only issue I had was that she appears to attack you if you do something wrong, spending 10 minutes on fixing something that you may have accidentally mis-pronounced. The textbook she uses is not the best.

She spoke in Hebrew more than last semester, but when she did she spoke super fast and then often translated what she said right back into English.  She went away from the book more than last semester though.  And it made for a much better class.

She's an incredibly nice lady,and it's evident how much she cares about her students.  She didn't speak in Hebrew as much as I would've liked (so the learning curve was slow), but she made the class pretty fun.  She has such a passion for the language that it's infectious.

Really kinda pervy and off putting. His lectures and tests were all about statistics and irrelevant information, rather than about concepts or ideas. It was an easy A class, but really uncomfortable to attend and I highly doubt anyone willingly attended his office hours because of his off putting demeanor.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--EXTRA CREDIT--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: So much memorization of statistics that aren't relevant. Really awkward lectures that just leave you feeling uncomfortable, and I realize that the material itself is capable of that, but he made it 100x worse by over-sharing. The participation questions made me want to skip class so that I wouldn't have to answer them. Would not recommend at all!

Near 0% of the material covered actually has anything to do with psychology; it's mostly just biology and statistics. Gives quizzes at the beginning of each lecture, and he openly disregards the many people who aren't able to access the site for various reasons. He tests a lot on statistics. Also heteronormative. Do not take this class if with him.
One of the worst professors that I ever had.

She gets paid and the class does all of the work.  Over the 14 weeks she might have taught 2 hours.  Unapproachable, talks about other students, and cares only about herself.  If you need to meet with her it is around her schedule only.  If you work, good luck.  She wants 110% of your time.  Expect 200+ pages of reading a week and 2 writings.

Julia's classes are very challenging, but in a good way.  She knows so much about inclusive education and is so passionate that you can't help but share her passion!  She is always available to answer questions and chat, and truly wants all of her students to succeed.
Very helpful class. Great Professor.
This prof is organized. He gives out copies of his notes, which is very helpful. They should make him teach more graduate courses!
knows what he is talking about, is very organized, requires a lot of work but you learn a lot too. best professor in ECE.

I loved taking Human Sexuality with Dr. de Jong. He makes sure that lecture are interesting and is always trying to get the entire class engaged as much as possible. I highly recommend taking PSY 331, not only is it probably the most entertaining psychology electives but you learn important aspects about relationships and your own sexuality.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: Good class, just don't get behind

If you need to take intro stats,  I would take this class. David is really good at explaining concepts and going over examples in class, so even if it takes you a while to understand statistics, it's possible to eventually get a  decent understanding of it. There is a good amount of homework but it is very helpful for exams.
Lectures can drag on but Professor Duro is extremely nice and helpful. He encourages discussion and the class is interesting

If you enjoy art history, this class will be enjoyable. However, if you aren't so passionate about art (as a cluster class in my case), lectures can get a bit boring. The class is graded on 4 essays spread through the semester and a participation grade. Professor Duro is very kind and he gives a lot of good feedback on the essays!

Definitely a class to take! The lectures can feel a bit long at times and seem to drag on but the material is very intetestinf, especially if you're into art history yet never had the time to delve into the theory on your own. The readings should read carefully when they apply to the essays, otherwise you can skim and be ready for class

He's actually really helpful and responsive. He's nice and understanding. He's a good choice for a writing professor but the way he designs his class is very demotivating. The sheer amount of essays and other assignments is very overwhelming5. I felt like it was my most tiring class this semester.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: TOUGH GRADER but he is really passionate and kind. He tries to be understanding, responds to emails fast, also enjoyed conferencing with him. He gives really great feedback. If you are not a great writer though, you won't do too well.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Just please don't punish yourself by taking this guy's course.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: the classes are not recorded and he does not give out his notes. he goes through the content very quickly, you will barely have any time to write it down. you will have to read the textbook as he does not cover everything in class. content heavy, way too much info. I would avoid this class if possible.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Not the worse professor, not the best either. Attendance is mandatory, as lectures aren't recorded and it doesn't help that he rushes over slides. I do appreciate that he gives out extra credit and curves the exams. Wish he didn't make some of the exam questions so convoluted. Go to lecture, read textbook, do assignments; you should be good.

Lectures are very content heavy and he goes too fast. Doesn't post any lecture material either so get ready to spend the entire class taking pictures of the slides. Exams are ridiculous for the content- entirely trick questions and obscure content. Genuinely the worst psych class I have taken at this school take 181 + 161 instead. Love Mruzek tho!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Pretty Tough

Nice professor, but tests were hard. You gotta go to lecture because he doesn't post the notes and a lot of info that wasn't in lecture are still on the tests because they're in the textbook. 3 mini essays, but lots of extra credit opportunities. He goes super fast in lecture so be prepared to take pics of the slides to take notes
Hes a beast in chemical engineering.  Very caring guy.

Professor Tenhaeff is a great lecturer and has very clear notes. He is very accessible outside of class and willing to help students understand the material. Although helpful, homework was a bit long and always had lots of coding. Exams are difficult but it's easy to get partial credit on problems. Would definitely recommend!

Prof. Tenhaeff is very professional.  He knows exactly how to teach and is very clear, organized, and caring.  The ONLY downside is his homework is just too long, really, it's way too long sometimes.  His homework almost always had coding involved which also really sucked.  But everything else about the class was awesome.  We love you Tenhaeff ;)
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Textor is a great professor and a very kind person as well. The class is pretty easy and the topic is enjoyable and there's not a lot of homework. Overall a good experience.

I took Professor Textor's WRTG105 and I would recommend that everybody takes this class. She is by far the most caring Professor I have ever come across. She is always available to help during or after class. If you complete all your your work and come to class you should be able to end with an A no problem.
Good professor overall and easy to get an A
great teacher but tough grader
yes she is kinda harsh on grading but that totally makes sense and you can learn a lot from her regardless of what final grades she gave you

Anne is a very nice lady, however, she's  a harsh grader. For a 2 credit intro to ballet course she takes her grading way too seriously. I had to study more for this class than for my 4 credit courses I'm taking. I've also received lower grades from her than from my other professors whose assignments were harder.  Wish she'd adjust her expectations
This class was incredibly easy as long as you did the work.  Prof. Manni is so sweet and funny in class and she genuinely wants her students to do well.

Professor Manni is really sweet and definitely cares about her students.  She is a very easy grader but makes you want to do well.  She does expect you to already know a lot and sometimes doesn't understand what you're confused about since she's a native speaker but will always try to help. She made herself very available and was overall wonderful.

She does blow off some grammar structures that she thinks you already know but if you ask her questions in lecture she will definitely answer them and go over something again or in a different way. She certainly cares about her students learning and tends to be flexible with deadlines.

Boring and confusing lecturer.  Unorganized and frantic, always talking about her cats. The theories were hard to understand and her explanations could have been better.  Understanding the material is difficult but getting an A in the class is easy as she gives you exactly what will be on the exams.  Also seems to be quite lenient in grading

She was always all over the place and relied on the TA's to do things for her. She was very full of herself and never was prepared. She would show up late to class and got mad at the students when they didnt show up. Tests were somewhat easy and she often went over what would be on them. just very unorganized and kind of spacey.
Often unprepared for lectures. I had hoped to learn more in this class.
Lectures are critical. Do not miss any if you want to stay on track. His door is almost always open if you need help with material, and he is brilliant.
Great lecturer- be prepared to write a lot!  His exams are fair.
This class is tough, but you learn a lot. Jones is brilliant.
Very difficult. Bordering on impossible. He teaches undergrad class like it's a masters class. He is ridiculously intelligent; too smart to be teaching 200 classes.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: This is a very difficult class but he is a great professor. You must attend class, if you don't expect to fail. He is extremely intelligent man, and can answer just about any question off of the top of his head.
He is a great teacher and always Knows his material.  He might skip steps because he assumes you know it.  Go to class and you will learn a lot.
Really fun, chill class. Katrina is a sweetheart.
very interesting and relaxable
Great class, great teacher. Would take more if she taught them but looks like there's just the two

Super caring, really wants everyone to ask questions, will wait until people actually understand what's happening. Make sure you go to lectures!! I personally didn't use the textbook, but a lot of people did. I had this class during corona, and he was super understanding and accepted feedback on his teaching. Great guy!
He's definitely smart but has trouble making things clear in lectures so I ended up skipping a lot and just relying on the textbook and online resources

Honestly, if you get him as your teacher, don't bother going to class. Just Google the concepts. Although he might have been the smartest teacher I've ever had, he doesn't understand how to communicate his ideas to the students, so even the most basic stuff doesn't make sense.

One of the best singing experiences ever. Made me change the way I listen. Very picky  especially when it comes to vowels and rhythm. Cared a lot about the reputation of the group. Loves the Renaissance.

Terrible choral director, spends too much time on minute issues, while failing to teach the lyrics of a song. Class is a waste of time. She doesn't spend any time on technique, and doesn't accept comments from students during class.
Great class!

Heyworth is incredibly intelligent and is more than happy to share his knowledge at all times. In class, he's always focusing on how students think and look into nuance. He has high standards but is committed to helping his students reach those standards, ultimately for the better. He cares a lot about his students and has a high degree of respect!

It's obvious that Heyworth knows his stuff, but sometimes during our lectures, he would focus on small points and we would end up losing class time because of it. He's very passionate, but it would've been nice to have a more structured class and paper set up. He grades fine but he really nitpicks sometimes on things that aren't that important.

Professor Heyworth is very smart, but it tends to show in his lectures that he makes a good amount of the stuff on the spot, although it sounds good. This makes his classes sometimes feel like it's all over the place. He also occasionally concerns himself with little lines that sometimes cause a drag to the class. Not bad, but he is a tough grader.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He is currently a terrible teacher, but in a few years he won't be. He will be slightly better than terrible.

Honestly, he is a terrible teacher. He does not know how to teach at all and his homework assignments are weekly. In general, you will most likely use outside sources to understand the material. Which, isn't difficult in the first place.

He's a new professor, so he doesn't seem too confident or loud when he's lecturing.  It's actually pretty hard to hear him, even when sitting towards the front.  He is knowledgeable on the subject and a compassionate and understanding professor, but he could be a much better lecturer.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: really boring professor.... horrible lectures.... overall horrible experience. do not go to rochester for finance.
A great finance professor, very structured syllabus. The curve for the class was good.
He is a good professor. However, the exams are extremely tough.

Yufeng is a very nice professor, his class is friendly to those without programming experience. R programming is difficult and knid of boring, but his class is not. I build a solid foundation in R after taking his classes.

I give a 4 for the level difficulty cuz I am new to the R programming language. I have to say Prof. Huang makes R so easy for me to understand and I really happy to learn it though it's an early morning class. He guided us to do programming step-by-step with a clear structure and a programming mindset. That's what an R starter just wants.

Prof. Huang is the best professor I've ever met in my life! He's amazing! Thanks to his early class on Monday, I was motivated to get up every Monday. He has a good sense of humor, his teaching content is very clear and easy to understand, and he is very patient to answer any questions raised by students. He made me fall in love with programming!
Textbook needed, extremely hard tests, the mini assignments boost your grade barely so it's just extra work for you. Hard to enjoy a class you know will be tested excessively.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Test heavy

comment: Showed interest in class with lectures, and had fairly easy homework assignments that helped with grade.

Dr. Duprey was one of my favorite psych professors I've had. I am not a very good test taker, so having assignments in addition to the exams was very nice to have versus some of the other psych courses I've taken. She liked to ask us about our opinions on topics since the course was about adolescent development, so I definitely appreciated that.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment:
Marcie was awesome! Very down to earth, lenient when it comes to deadlines. Her course does an amazing job of actually teaching you how to write, feedback is also great.

Classes are generally small, and reading passages / discussions are generally really interesting. 

However, compared to other 105 classes, this class is not guaranteed an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: While Professor Woehl was a good professor, this class was definitely graded harshly and it was hard to do well.
rating_tags: Tough grader--So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Woehl is an outstanding professor. I always look forward to her classes. Her engaging personality and care for her students creates a fun and interactive learning environment. While Professor Woehl is a tough grader, it's because she's deeply invested in our learning. Every assignment becomes a journey of self-development in writing.
amazing professor
think ppl think he's cool and other ppl have a crush on him, doesnt qualify him to be a professor lol
brings a lot of sports examples to class, not too hard at all. Chill and probably closer to his students age than other profs

Young professor who sometimes will go to slow to make sure every single person understands (what office hours are for lol), causes him to sometimes speed through other material. Other than that cares a lot about his students and that they understand the class. Great lecturer, makes a lot of boring material fun just by the way he talks about it.

He is fun and his lectures are fine. Does not write good test or homework questions, and has students use ancient and unhelpful programs to complete homework assignments. Textbook was almost useless. Lab portion was unorganized and unhelpful.

He is super funny and nice! The only thing that was annoying were on exams, there would be way too many questions with high complexity for the allotted time, and it was very difficult for many people to even finish.

Rich is kinda awesome. His lectures are really engaging and he has a great sense of humor. I have to admit, I didn't care a whole lot about phylogenetic but I really got into it by the end. Wasn't great at it, but at least I was interested. He's a super cool guy and I highly recommend him and Tree of Life. Keep it up, Rich!
Doug is very accessible outside of class for help.  He cared about the success of his students as well.  The class material was very dull IMO.

I had Kelley for 246 (Junior Lab) and 255 (Senior Design), and I can honestly say he is one of the best professors currently in the department as of Spring 2018. While I feel he unfairly misinterpreted my junior lab report, he is extremely knowledgeable and caring and was able to help every senior design group regardless of their topic.

Visit him outside class for help- his office hours have 5-6 students at a time before an exam. He'll really try to help. The class is quite difficult, the curves are dramatic, he's soft-spoken so it's hard to hear in the middle and back rows. He has a really laid-back attitude though so I didn't feel intimidated at all.

The professor is nice, but beware his class is not well organized. The first half of 448 will be your easiest class. But in the second half you will be thrown into tons of difficult coding assignments. The notes are half pictures so studying for paper exams is impossible.

There is no exam, no homework, only (six) projects that will make you put your hands on and get to learn parallel programming using some initial samples from lectures' codes. The TAs and the professor do answer your questions but it is your code so don't expect them to find your errors, they will tell you maybe what to look for.

He is great at teaching programming and you will learn a lot from him. BUT the quizzes were quite tricky. The exams and projects were fair game except the TA's made mistakes in grading them VERY OFTEN.
very clear in class. provided good material for taking the exams.
He's pretty good.  Doesn't have patience with people wasting his time.
Funniest professor ever. He's so helpful during and outside the class.

He definitely challenges you , as he teaches at a fast pace so you do need to study outside of class. He is very helpful though and emails you back within a day regarding any questions. He's a smart guy and tries his best to make sure everyone understands economic issues. I would recommend him for this grad class.
He rocks. Great teacher. You can get an A. Not super duper easy, but not hard. He will always be very helpful and constantly clarifies things.
Best professor everrrrrrrrrrr!
Smartest lady I've  met in a long time. Extremely passionate about education.
Not clear or helpful
We did work out of a textbook for another class. The name of the class is The Meaning of Life, if I wanted to take Logic and Inquiry I would've signed up for it.

Took this class over the summer. Easygoing, laid back guy. Definitely knew what he was talking about. No powerpoints, only lectures, so be sure to take notes because what he says shows up verbatim on tests. Read your book for HW assignments and so you won't be lost in class next day.

If you go to class and read the book, the answers are fairly clear. The tests are not easy and if you believe you can get by through not going to class and just reading the book, or vice versa, you are very wrong. If you have questions, she is happy to talk to you and will answer emails, but you should try the TA's first.

The exams are horrible! Multiple choices have very similar answers, I'm not talking about just words choices, I'm talking about how the questions could be read multiple ways! Don't go to class and read the book

He's inherited the department's bizarre sense of humor, but he seems to understand the content and how to teach it (although he needs to tone down the meme content). The course begins very easily but gets significantly harder as it goes on.

I had him for Web Programming and he makes class very interesting and never boring. Notes are online but attendance is required for random quizzes (approximtely weekly). It's not particularly difficult but you'll learn a lot of programming languages by the end.

Professor Glenn was passionate in what she taught and brought that positive attitude to class. Her lectures were very straight forward and the tests were what you should expect. She can be a serious professor, but she commands respect and often times would subtly crack jokes and make the class laugh.

Professor Glenn is an amazing professor. Her lectures are interesting and clear. She takes time to answer peoples questions and she knows the material well and almost always has an answer. Not only does she understand the material that is current, but also thinks about where psychology may go in the future. Overall a wonderful professor.

Really fantastic class taught by an even better professor. Prof. Singer cares deeply about his students and the subject matter, and shares that passion and enthusiasm with his students. Lectures are engaging and interesting and he does a great job engaging the class in discussion while maintaining a lecture environment. Highly recommended!

Not a bad professor. Still pretty young, and hasn't had a ton of teaching experience, but definitely intelligent when it comes to the great philosophers such as Hobbes, Locke, Mill, Rawls, and others. The class goes through about one book every week, so be ready to read a ton (although he recaps most stuff in class).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Lauren made chemistry so much understandable! She is the best!

This was my first course ever at University of Rochester and Lauren made it great! She really cares about her students and would do awesome demos that made an otherwise dull subject pretty fun. Quizzes were tough, but study the homework and you'll be just fine.
Rebecca is an amazing writing teacher. I feel so much more confident in graduate school after taking her class!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: This instructor is nitpicky. She looks for spaces, periods missing or inadvertently present in the APA format, claims that citations are missing when they are there, gives written directions that change when grading. Weekly APA quizzes, assigned reading from an APA MANUAL. A five page paper with at least 3 revisions, all for a ONE CREDIT COURSE.

Nice enough person. No examples in class. Just reads formulas & derivations. Tests are easy but some material isn't covered or is skipped. Taught one section from his own notes instead of from textbook ok from understanding theory perspective but useless for application on homework and exams. Get help from TAs to learn how to solve problems

He is a really nice guy and gave our class many opportunities to improve our grades. However, his teaching style consists of reading slides off of PowerPoint and not doing many in-class examples. If you have the motivation to read the slides and textbook outside of class, just do that, but if you do not, definitely go to class and office hours.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: He's the man! His nickname is Carcara, which in Portuguese means "hawk." This should give you a good idea of his personality. His course is certainly not for the faint-hearted, though any level of fitness will do fine with enough motivation. Grade is an easy A, just show up and participate.

I could not walk the day after my first class. Watch out when you are rounding corners with this one. Very unorthodox, real style of teaching--do not take if you are weak of heart. Always full, many drop out within the first week. He is not the standard university professor so be prepared to think outside the box. Please wear deodorant.

Professor Tawil recently passed away. He was lovely and kind. He taught me everything in American literature, and pushed us to think and refelct deeply. Usually 3 papers, open topic, or based on prompts. May he rest in peace always.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: He's funny and really cool. He will ask if the students are enjoying the readings and if they don't, he'll ask for suggestions and maybe make a few changes in the syllabus. Very pro-student. You learn a lot, too
Still have trauma even after taking his course for half a year. Take care.

Wow, worst professor I think I've ever heard. The entire class is just him writing down theorems and proofs then when it comes time for homework you have no idea how to solve a problem because he's never even worked out one in front of you. Avoid at all costs

Neimic teaches a lot of major lectures at the University of Rochester and because of this records a lot of his material for student to use as asynchronously. He seems to care and you will come away from this class knowing the material but he definitely is a character - is a little polarizing. Overall I think he cares.
LITERALLY SO RUDE.

This guy is a GOAT. He is extremely helpful to those students who strive to stay on top of the class. As long as you read your articles, attend lectures, and ask questions, I guarantee your time will be spent wisely. For those interested in journalism, I highly recommend this course! 

Be warned that there are pop quizzes and long articles.

Professor Liu is an excellent teacher. He would give ample examples on techniques he wanted us to learn and have us try it out in class, and he is great with constructive criticism. He kept the class engaged and interactive by having us read really interesting journal articles and by having us work with each other on in-class work.

Took this class on a whim and loved it. Your grade is composed of participation, 2 essays and 1 final project. She is teaching her research so it really laid-back. You watch 1 film a week. Discussions in class are more about the historical climates and director's influences, not the technical cinematic choices. Take if looking for an easy class.

Rita Safariants is one of the newer faculty members in the MLC department and one of the best professors I have taken. Insightful, respectful, and wants you to learn while exploring your interests even if they don't perfectly align with the course. Mostly seminar based in my experience, a manageable level of work, and easily reachable if need be.

Impossible to get ahold of outside of class. I struggled with the class and often reached out but never got a response. The class was entirely exam based, just a heads up. He wasn't there to proctor his exams, and the final in particular had so many spelling and grammar mistakes that it was impossible to figure out what the questions were asking

The entire course was based on tests, which were incredibly similar to the practice questions he released. He goes over basic topics which is on the tests, but then he goes into harder/more advanced concepts which are fun to learn. He has a tough accent but it's manageable. I would recommend taking with the other professor, usually Kalandrakis
I would not take linear algebra generally. He is a good professor, it was just the exams were all too hard for me.

Tough homeworks and exams but it's discrete. Not an engaging lecturer. Simply project him writing notes on his iPad. Write note extremely slow, which makes me fall asleep. You can attend any discrete professor's lecture, and I much preferred Danneburg.

EXTREMELY DISORGANIZED! Will not grade anything the whole year. Trust me it is not worth doing the assigned readings for they don't have much to do with actual content. I feel like I wasted my money on this class.

he goes by Brady fletcher, check that for more reviews. he does not teach at all, he reads off of long slideshows. he is also extremely unorganized, he tends to forget what he put on the syllabus. not once did he ever explain how to do projects/group assignments. he doesn't even introduce debate, all just trying to get you to join the debate team.

Prof. Renz is a sweet professor and really cares about student input. He could have taught the class a little better than just reading off slides, but other than that it was alright. He gives a good amount of material to help students learn and prep for exams as well. The exams were kind of hard, but he also curves at the end of the class.
gary was a sweet man, albeit not the greatest professor all time but his class is hella doable and pretty easy once you figure out his testing style

Professor Chitrakar gave great feedback for each paper and it was clear he cared for his students. He was very easy to reach outside of class and would respond quickly. There were few homework assignments during the semester. Overall it was a manageable course and I without a doubt became a stronger writer.
a lot of work but great professor
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: I really love him! He is super knowledgeable and easy to reach! Always reply emails in few hours and happy to discuss anything related to course works. He makes me wanna do a minor in East Asians Studies and I really wish I can take his class again.

I tried to reach out by email but he do not respond emails.
He do not grade any assignments but he post awful grades at the end of semester.(no agreement with the students for the grade)
This might be the first time writing complaint form to the university.
Before saying about the class, he cannot grade and never perform his duties as a professor.

AWFUL AWFUL AWFUL!!! What he says in class is like not useful at all, his tests are ridiculously hard. He wastes half of the lecture yelling at us about how we need to be better students and then he only has enough time to get through 5 slides which the information on those slides won't be on the test. AVOID BY ALL MEANS POSSIBLE
Worst professor ever. TAs were also awful. He doesn't write the tests just relies on the TAs. Very hard!

Professor Caie is undoubtedly brilliant. He completed his Doctorate in 2011, and already has 2 papers published in the Philosophical Review. Many of the best tenured philosophers have only achieved just 1 publication in the Review throughout their careers. However, he has struggles as a lecturer in presenting ideas clearly and stimulating a class.

Michael Caie is a professor that means well, but ultimately fails at teaching. He is a nice enough person, but isn't the sort of person you want teaching you. This becomes particularly important when his specialties are logic and philosophy of language--two areas that are easy to become confused in. Ultimately, I would have to say to pass on Caie.
Very challenging class, but she makes it easier to understand the concepts. Still a lot of work and be prepare to spend a lot of time reading the material.
